Rapp (1949) illustrated the effect of shifting sand in an Indiana dune on \i{}E. arvense\i0{} s.l. where it produced forms \i{}alpestre\i0{} Wahlenb., \i{}diffusum\i0{} A.A. Eaton ex Gilbert, and \i{}decumbens\i0{} Meyer, all on the same rhizome. Schaffner (1928) showed variation on a single plant with respect to branch number. Kato (1964) presented a graph showing that, at least in Japan, the lowermost nodes of a plant bore mostly 4-angled branches, the uppermost, mostly 3-angled. It was suggested that the difference in the number of angles is related to whether the plant is growing in sun or shade. Hauke (1963) suggested that this apparent correlation breaks down when one gets into the Arctic and the shade form disappears, but does it? The image library has a picture of a plant that was growing between rocks at 81°N and was possibly quite shaded. \par{}One obvious feature of \i{}E. arvense\i0{} is the dimorphism between its vegetative and fertile stems. All conditions exist, from fertile stems producing a few branches (var. \i{}irriguum\i0{}) to fertile stems resembling the sterile stems. The latter forms are frequent northward, where they are often depauperate (\i{}E. calderi\i0{} B. Boivin). \par{}Hauke (1966) concluded that \i{}E. arvense\i0{} is a noteworthy plant in the many different growth forms it can assume, but evidently these are only superficial modifications and none deserves taxonomic recognition. The reliable characters that characterise this species are as follows: rhizomes (including the internodes) felted, branches 3-4 angled, with the first branch internode longer than the subadjacent teeth, stem sheaths slightly longer than they are wide, slightly involute or appressed to the stem, and branch teeth with subulate tips. These characters, plus some internal anatomy characters, differentiate this species from all other taxa and remain essentially constant in spite of various gross plant modifications. \par{}The physiology of fruiting is not understood. Whatever it is, there is a control mechanism that can be upset. Depending upon when and how it is disrupted, a fertile stem may develop branches, which is not surprising, since dormant branch apices are present. Conversely, a vegetative stem may develop a cone, which is less easily explained, since the shoot apical cell must change its pattern of activity. Occasionally, an apex begins to produce a cone then reverts to vegetative activity, and a proliferated cone is produced (illustrated in Hauke 1963). \par{}Elven et al. (2005) state that "there have been many doubts about whether there is a separate arctic-alpine race or only a group of arctic modifications. A race was reluctantly accepted by Øllgaard in Jonsell (2000). Both Tzvelev and Elven tend to accept it as a subspecies, but Elven commented that its reported distribution in European Russia and Siberia seems very large compared with its strict restriction to northern high alpine and clearly arctic areas in northwestern Europe and North America. Schönswetter et al. (2001) argued for acceptance as a separate race, based on several morphological criteria." Hauke (1993, \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment, p. 81) states, \ldblquote{}Among the many infraspecific taxa that have been named in this species [\i{}E. arvense\i0{} \i{}s.l.\i0{}], \i{}E. arvense\i0{} var. \i{}boreale\i0{} (Bong.) Á. Löve, has been most generally accepted and has been applied to plants with tall, erect stems with 3-ridged branches. Because both 3-ridged and 4-ridged branches may occur on a single stem, the variety \i{}boreale\i0{} is not recognised here as distinct.\rdblquote{} Schönswetter et al. (2001) convincingly argued that the name \i{}'borealis'\i0{}, more or less uniformly applied for this arctic-alpine race, has been misapplied. It is based on plants from Sitka in southeastern Alaska that differ from the arctic and high alpine plants in most morphological features. The next available name is Wahlenberg's var. \i{}alpestre\i0{}.\par{}Much of the material in the Flora region aligns with \i{}E. arvense\i0{} var. \i{}alpestre\i0{}, but further study is required on the North American specimens. Therefore, following Hauke (1993), here we treat this taxon as a species in the broad sense.\par{}Field horsetail is well known to be a poisonous plant. Hay containing this weed is apparently more dangerous than the plants are when they are growing in pastures. The deaths of many horses, particularly young horses, have been reported to veterinarians, but there is reason to believe that many more losses are unreported (Frankton and Mulligan 1987).>

<Porsild (1957) suggested that this species is probably always sterile in the Canadian Arctic Islands, but fertile specimens have been collected on Southampton, Coats, and Baffin Islands. Cones may mature in summer or they may overwinter and shed spores in the spring. \par{}A diagnostic difference distinguishing this species from \i{}E. variegatum\i0{} is that the base of the plant is strongly papillose (and dull), whereas it is almost smooth and shiny in \i{}E. variegatum\i0{}. Very often the stems of \i{}E. scirpoides\i0{} are papillose along the ridges, but this may also be observed in \i{}E. variegatum\i0{}. The young or undamaged "teeth" have attenuated tips that are sometimes sufficiently long to twist, especially at the uppermost node of a stem branch. The stems are perennial and firm in \i{}E. scirpoides\i0{}, whereas they are annual and soft in \i{}E. arvense.\i0{}>

<The subspecies that occurs in the Arctic Archipelago is subsp. \i{}variegatum\i0{}. Subspecies \i{}alaskanum\i0{} occurs on continental North America and is distinguished from subsp. \i{}variegatum\i0{} as follows: sheath teeth, erect, with prominent white margins, subsp. \i{}variegatum\i0{}; sheath teeth incurved, with obscure margins or all black, subsp. \i{}alaskanum\i0{}. \par{}Arctic floras with Porsild as an author have indicated that this species has 6-8 sheath teeth at each node, which distinguishes it from \i{}E. scirpoides\i0{}, which has 3-4 sheath teeth. Hauke (1993, \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment) indicates that \i{}E. variegatum\i0{} may have 3-12 teeth per sheath, in fact overlapping with the values of \i{}E. scirpoides\i0{}. According to Hauke (1993) these taxa are distinguished because in \i{}E. variegatum\i0{} there are as many ridges to the sheaths as there are teeth, while in \i{}E. scirpoides\i0{} there are twice as many ridges as teeth. (The number of ridges can be determined by cutting cross sections of the stem.) \par{}Some authors claim that Schleicher's name of 1797 is a nomen nudum and that it was first validated by Weber and Mohr, Deut. Crypt. Gewächse 60: 447. 1807.\par{}>

<Wagner (1992) reported on the difficulties of determining chromosome numbers in the Lycopodiaceae, which include the fact that the spore mother cells, in general, have very thick walls and they may be full of cytoplasmic granules and oil droplets that take up stain and may be mistaken for chromosomes. Also, the chromosomes, unlike those of most ferns, are commonly of different sizes. She stated that \i{}H. selago\i0{} had once been categorised by Manton (1950) as the worst cytological object she had ever encountered. Wagner (1992) published a photomicrograph of \i{}H. selago\i0{} at diakineses for the count of 2\i{}n\i0{} = 134. \par{}The Panarctic Flora project (Elven et al. 2003) has found that there are two current models for explaining the variation in the \i{}H. selago\i0{} species group and that the two approaches are mutually exclusive. European-Russian treatments are based on a hypothesis of gradual divergence of races of which three were proposed as species by Tzvelev in Elven et al. (2003): \i{}H. selago\i0{}, \i{}H. arctica\i0{}, and \i{}H. appressa\i0{}. Northwestern European authors recognise two species (\i{}H. selago\i0{}, \i{}H. arctica)\i0{} and tend to regard \i{}H\i0{}. \i{}appressa\i0{} as intermediate between \i{}selago\i0{} and \i{}arctica\i0{} without its own rank. When this is done \i{}appressa\i0{} is included with \i{}arctica\i0{}; see, for example, Kukkonen (in Jonsell 2000, Fl. Nord. 1). \par{}Wagner and Beitel (1993) hypothesise that the variation in the genus \i{}Huperzia\i0{} is caused by different combinations of original (diploid) genomes that are present in the different ploidy entities. In their 1992 paper on the generic classification of modern North American Lycopodiaceae they provided a generic classification based on 50 characters of anatomy, chromosomes, spores, and gametophytes, with states that they assigned as either primitive or derived and analysed using the methods of ground-plan-divergence cladistics (Wagner and Wagner 1980). \par{}Wagner and Beitel (1993) treated the North American entities as species. They considered the taxa were based on two hybridisation groups, the eastern North American one containing \i{}H. selago\i0{}, \i{}H. appalachiana\i0{}, and their hybrid. They considered \i{}H. selago\i0{} s.s. occurs in Temperate 'middle' North American material north to the south shore of Hudson Bay and perhaps northwestern parts of mainland Northwest Territories (also "Europe, Asia"). Unfortunately, the majority of the American arctic material from the Canadian Arctic Archipelago, central and northern Greenland, was not included in the treatment (or maps) in Wagner and Beitel (1993). \par{}The Russian approach is satisfactory in that it includes all arctic plants in some kind of system. It is unsatisfactory because it is not in accordance with the current evolutionary hypothesis for the genus (Holub 1983; Øllgaard 1987; and Wagner and Beitel 1992) and because it treats \i{}H. miyoshiana \i0{}as different from the other elements known to be of the same 'genomic' group. The Wagner and Beitel (1993) treatment is unsatisfactory because it is not readily applicable outside North America and because it neglects most of the American arctic plants.>

<In striking contrast to \i{}Diphasiastrum\i0{} and \i{}Huperzia\i0{}, interspecific hybridisation is practically unknown in \i{}Lycopodium\i0{} (Wagner and Beitel 1993). \par{}The North American approach (Wagner and Beitel 1993) has been to neglect the variation in \i{}L. annotinum\i0{} but to accept the variation in \i{}L. clavatum\i0{} at the level of two species. In northwestern European and Russian views, these pairs of species/subspecies are considered comparable. The differences are mainly quantitative in both cases. Elven et al. (2003) chose to recognise subspecies in both cases, suggesting that they are pairs of closely related taxa with south to north distribution (Elven et al. 2003). \i{}Lycopodium annotinum\i0{} subsp. \i{}alpestre\i0{} is the only taxon of this genus in the flora region.\par{}Plants intermediate between \i{}Lycopodium annotinum\i0{} subsp. \i{}alpestre \i0{}and \i{}L. annotinum\i0{} subsp. \i{}annotinum\i0{} are considered to belong to a form that has been called var. \i{}pungens\i0{} (Bachelot de la Pylie) Desvaux. This is an invalid name (Wagner and Beitel 1993).\par{}>

<\i{}Cystopteris fragilis\i0{} occurs at higher latitudes and/or elevations than other species of \i{}Cystopteris. \i0{}It is a polymorphic complex, and morphologically distinct hexaploid cytotypes have been reported from disjunct populations in Ontario, Alaska, Arizona, Colorado, Montana, and Wyoming. Isozymic profiles of each of these populations indicate that the hexaploids are polyphyletic and should not be accorded species status (Haufler et al. 1993). Werth and Windham (1991) suggested that this polymorphic polyploid is probably actively speciating at the tetraploid level, perhaps through gene silencing.\par{}The presence of verrucate spores (as opposed to the normal spiny spores) has been used to circumscribe \i{}Cystopteris dickieana\i0{}. It is possible that the verrucate spore is a recessive feature controlled by one gene, or only a few genes. While present at low frequency in much of the range of \i{}C. fragilis\i0{}, verrucate spores are particularly prominent in the Great Plains, and some specimens from the Arctic have been assigned to \i{}C. dickieana\i0{}, although there is no agreement on such assignments. \par{}Elven et al. (2003) discussed the separation of these entities: "The only consistent feature that separates \i{}'dickieana'\i0{} from \i{}'fragilis'\i0{} s.s. is the spore ornamentation. In the North Atlantic area there is no connection between this ornamentation and other morphological features, and it is impossible to separate \i{}'dickieana'\i0{} on macromorphology. It also occurs more or less occasionally within populations [see, e.g., Berg 1992, and Berg, in Jonsell 2000]. \i{}Cystopteris dickieana\i0{} has been finally 'killed' as a taxon by the investigations published by Dyer et al. (2000) [Edinb. J. Bot. 57: 71-81] and Parks et al. (2000) [Edinb. J. Bot. 57: 83-105]. Even if the reticulate spore ornamentation has a certain geographic pattern, this is to be considered as a geographical variation in one character (possibly caused by a single gene), not associated with other characters, and not nearly enough for recognition of a taxon at any level" .>

<Isozyme studies confirm the longstanding hypothesis that \i{}W. alpina\i0{} is an allotetraploid derived from hybridisation between \i{}W. glabella\i0{} and \i{}W. ilvensis\i0{} (Windham 1993). Hybrids have been reported both from Europe and North America. These morphologically intermediate triploids with malformed spores have been called \i{}W. ×gracilis\i0{} (G. Lawson) Butters.>
<\i{}Woodsia glabella\i0{} is a well-marked species in our area. The glabrous, pale yellow-green (straw-coloured) petiole is a good identification characteristic.>

<Shade forms, and possibly high-latitude forms, of \i{}W. ilvensis\i0{},\i{} \i0{}with reduced numbers of scales and hairs, are occasionally misidentified as \i{}W. alpina\i0{}. The morphological distinctions between these species are further blurred, at least in the south, by natural hybridisation, which produces the intermediate triploid known as \i{}W. ×gracilis\i0{}. Some of the best characters for distinguishing these taxa are spore size and morphology. Spores average less than 46 microns in diameter, in \i{}W. ilvensis\i0{}, more than 46 microns in diameter, in \i{}W. alpina\i0{}, and are malformed and abortive in the hybrid (F.S. Wagner 1987).>

<The reasons for placing this species in the family Tofieldiaceae are documented in the notes associated with the family. \par{}Parker (2002) noted that what appear to be hybrids between \i{}Tofieldia pusilla\i0{} and \i{}T. coccinea \i0{}occasionally occur in Greenland and the Northwest Territories. They are characterised by a leafy bract at or near the middle of the stem and enlarged, crimson bracts below the pedicels. In some suspected hybrids, the bracts are absent, and fused bracteoles, truncate or lobed, sheathe the pedicels well below the flowers.\par{}Tanaka (1981) reported that \i{}T. coccinea\i0{} var. \i{}kondoi\i0{} has small-sized chromosomes and 2\i{}n\i0{} = 30. Utech (1978) reported on the floral vascular anatomy and floral morphology of \i{}T. coccinea\i0{}.>
<The reasons why this species is placed in the family Tofieldiaceae is documented in the notes associated with the family.>

<Hultén (1968) indicated that var. \i{}borealis\i0{} has a shorter, more compact spike of greater length than the leaves, low growth, and seems to be merely a growth form and apparently an adaptation to Northern conditions. \par{}Haynes and Hellquist (2000), in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment, divided the species into three subspecies in North America - subsp. \i{}filiformis\i0{}, \i{}alpina\i0{}, and \i{}occidentalis\i0{} - but their application outside North America is problematic. They consider the \i{}'alpina'\i0{} entity (described from Norway) as synonymous with the \i{}'borealis'\i0{} entity (described from North America), with priority for the former. Elven et al. (2005) suggested that this synonymisation may be artificial. The \i{}'alpina'\i0{} entity is considered by Russian and northwestern European botanists to be just a northern and alpine minor race or modification of the narrow-leaved \i{}'filiformis'\i0{}, whereas \i{}'borealis'\i0{} seems to be a more significant broad-leaved North American entity. These authors proposed keeping \i{}'alpina'\i0{} and \i{}'borealis'\i0{} as different taxa and to synonymise the former with subsp. \i{}filiformis\i0{}. The main character separating Eurasian and North American plants is leaf width, 0.2-0.4 versus 0.5-0.8 mm (Tzvelev and Elven, personal communication, 2002). \par{}Haynes and Hellquist (2000) recorded subsp. \i{}alpina\i0{} only for North America and Asia, but that is erroneous, as the name has a Norwegian typification. Blytt, who described subsp. \i{}alpina\i0{}, referred to material from six sites in southern Norway (Blytt's annotated specimens are in O), and the type must be chosen among these (Tzvelev and Elven, May 2002, in discussion). \par{}The \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment stated that no specimens of this taxon had been seen from Nunavut, but that it is to be expected there (Les and Haynes 1996). Vouchers specimens for the three Nunavut records on the map are housed at CAN. \par{}Fassett (1940) considers this species to be a good duck food. \par{}Porsild (1957) stated that plants are usually sterile in the Arctic. They are found in the muddy bottoms of shallow ponds. \par{}The stipules of \i{}Stuckenia\i0{} are adnate to the blade for two-thirds to nearly the entire length of the stipule. The few species of \i{}Potamogeton\i0{} with adnate stipules have the adnation less than half the length of the stipule, or less than 4 mm. Submerged leaves of \i{}Stuckenia\i0{} are opaque, channelled, and turgid, whereas those of \i{}Potamogeton\i0{} are translucent, flat, and without grooves or channels (Les and Haynes 1996).>

<This orchid is a pinkish brown colour, lacking chlorophyll. It is a saprophyte and gets its nutrients from mycorrhiza on the roots. Because of the complex relationship between the orchid and the environment in which it is growing, this species is almost impossible to transplant and should be left growing where it is found. \par{}This species was first reported from Baffin Island in 1997 by Joyce Gould (Can. Field-Naturalist, 111: 471-472). She found this species in Auyuittuq National Park, Baffin Island, at two sites in 1995, and prepared a plant voucher from one of them. The specimen was deposited at DAO. \par{}This species is circumboreal (Hultén 1968) and is known from continental Northwest territories north to treeline (Porsild 1943), Ungava (northern Quebec) (Cayouette 1984), and western Greenland (Hultén 1968). It was not an altogether unexpected find on southeastern Baffin Island (Gould 1997). \par{}Both of the populations found by Gould (1997) were in fluvial deposits. One population was found on the east side of a river, "at the base of an end moraine and of a fluvial terrace just south of a small tributary, in a habitat dominated by Arctic willow (\i{}Salix arctica\i0{}) and moss (\i{}Pohlia drummondii\i0{}), and with \i{}Arctagrostis latifolia\i0{}, \i{}Pyrola grandiflora\i0{}, \i{}Poa arctica\i0{}, \i{}Persicaria vivipara\i0{}, \i{}Pedicularis\i0{} \i{}flammea\i0{}, and \i{}Carex\i0{} species". The second population was found at the base of a colluvial slope, among \i{}Salix arctica\i0{}, the moss \i{}Aulocomnium\i0{} \i{}turgidum\i0{}, and a species of the lichen \i{}Stereocaulon\i0{}. Hultén (1968, p. 329) describes its habitat as "wet places, woods, bogs." Scoggan (1978, p. 528) notes the habitat as "bogs, thickets and woods", while in the Northwest territories, Porsild and Cody (1980, p. 213) describe the habitat as "turfy, open places". \par{}Magrath and Freudenstein (2002) noted that \i{}Corallorhiza trifida\i0{} is largely autogamous, although a syrphid fly (\i{}Syrphus cinctellus\i0{}) was reported as a pollinator (Silen 1906). Various floral morphs exist, some with weak geographic corrections; they do not appear to warrant recognition.>

<Elven et al. (2003) noted that the most recent North American treatment (Brooks and Clemants 2000) of \i{}J. arcticus\i0{} recognised three varieties, two as arctic (var. \i{}alaskanus\i0{} and var. \i{}balticus\i0{}). Brooks and Clemants (2000) stated that \i{}J. arcticus\i0{} is "a wide-ranging and obviously polymorphic complex that has not read the literature." \par{}\i{}Juncus arcticus\i0{} and \i{}J. balticus\i0{} were both originally described from northern Europe. In most of this area they are very different in general morphology and in many detailed features. When comparing a series of 'typical' plants, no one would be in doubt about them being two different species. But even in Europe the separation of them as species is now disputed. \par{}Another problem to be resolved was whether the \i{}'alaskanus'\i0{} entity belonged as a race of \i{}J. arcticus\i0{} or of \i{}J. balticus\i0{}. Brooks and Clemants (2000) included most northern North American (including Greenland) material in their concept of var. a\i{}laskanus\i0{}, but they allowed that "perhaps \i{}J. arcticus\i0{} var. \i{}alaskanus\i0{} is not distinct from the Eurasian \i{}J. arcticus\i0{} var. \i{}arcticus\i0{}". That is certainly the case with much of the Greenland material, which is indistinguishable from the northern European (type area) and Svalbard material. The Alaskan material is more different, but not very much so. The \i{}'alaskanus'\i0{} entity is obviously much closer to the Northern European \i{}'arcticus'\i0{} entity than it is to the northern European \i{}'balticus'\i0{}. \par{}Elven et al. (2003) considered the options were either to "regard the entire complex as one large, polymorphic species with 4-5 subspecies, as two species (\i{}J. arcticus\i0{} with the \i{}'arcticus'\i0{}, \i{}'alaskanus'\i0{}, and \i{}'sitchensis'\i0{} entities; \i{}J. balticus\i0{} with the \i{}'balticus'\i0{} and \i{}'littoralis'\i0{} entities), or as numerous ill-defined, morphologically overlapping, and probably fully interfertile species." The \i{}'littoralis'\i0{} race is more southern, ranging from Alaska to Newfoundland, often inland (Porsild and Cody 1980). \par{}In May, 2005, Elven and Aiken examined CAN specimens from Banks and Victoria Islands and concluded that they belong to subsp. \i{}arcticus.\i0{} This was not expected, as subsp. \i{}arcticus\i0{} is typified from Scandinavia. Subspecies \i{}arcticus\i0{} has relatively delicate plants with small flowers in compact inflorescences; plants of subsp. \i{}alaskanus\i0{} are coarse, with diffuse inflorescences (Elven, personal communication, May 2005). Also, Porsild and Cody (1980) had reported \i{}J. balticus\i0{} subsp. \i{}alaskanus\i0{} Hultén (synonymous with \i{}J. arcticus\i0{} subsp. \i{}alaskanus\i0{} Hultén) on adjacent continental North America, and also on Victoria and Banks Islands. Elven and Aiken could not separate the specimens collected in the eastern Canadian Arctic Islands on the anther, inflorescence, or capsule characters usually used to recognise separate subspecies. Therefore, currently, subsp. \i{}arcticus\i0{} is recognised on the Canadian Arctic Islands.\par{}Fontenla et al. (2001) studied the mycorrhizal status of plant species in northwestern Patagonia communities representative of Patagonian steppe and marshes including \i{}Juncus arcticus\i0{}. \par{}Cooper and MacDonald (2000) used \i{}J. arcticus\i0{} in a revegetation experiment to restore rich fens that had been mined in Colorado. They found that \i{}Juncus arcticus\i0{} and willow cuttings had differing patterns of survival with respect to the annual maximum height of the water table and that dominant species can be successfully reintroduced to mined surfaces with the appropriate hydrologic conditions. Cooper and MacDonald (2000) stated that human intervention would be necessary to rapidly re-establish plant cover and that the slow rate of peat accumulation means that restoration of the mined fens will require hundreds, if not thousands, of years.>

<Polunin (1940) noted that this is "one of the most characteristic of all arctic phanerogams [and varies] little in any features that are of true taxonomic importance. However, in size and robustness it is liable to show great extremes in different habitats almost anywhere within the [eastern Canadian Arctic], varying from 2 to 30 cm in height, with the culms sometimes stout and sometimes very slender. It is also variable in the length and prominence of the "spathe" [leaf associated with the inflorescence] that subtends the flowers, this being generally longer in plants growing under favourable conditions, but often varying considerably on different culms coming from the same tuft." (p. 146). \par{}A specimen from Ward Hunt Island, 83°N, at the northern edge of its range, has leaves longer than the flowering stems CAN (234211). \par{}Danvind and Nilsson (1997) used \i{}J. biglumis\i0{} in a study testing the hypothesis that diaspore buoyancy is an important factor in determining the distribution range of riparian plants. The authors measured the floating capacity of fruits and seeds from 17 alpine vascular plant species during one year along the free-flowing Vindelu River in northern Sweden. Minimum, median, mean, and maximum floating times of fruits and seeds were related to the downstream distribution of plants. The distances from the alpine headwater region to the most downstream occurrence of plants, and to the cessation of a more continuous distribution, were evaluated. The variation in downstream limits of plants could not be statistically explained by variation in seed buoyancy between species, indicating that floating ability of seeds is not important for plant distribution patterns. \par{}Elven et al. (2003) noted that there might be some interesting unexplored variation in this common arctic-alpine species. Both the two main ploidy levels are known from Scandinavia. Most Scandinavian plants seem to differ morphologically from the majority of plants in the Arctic, in size (smaller), and in some other details.>

<Brooks and Clemants (2000) fully synonymised the \i{}'leucochlamys'\i0{} entity (\i{}Juncus castaneus\i0{} Sm. subsp. \i{}leucochlamys\i0{} (Zinger ex V. Krecz.) Hultén) with \i{}J. castaneus\i0{}. Hultén first accepted them as species [Hultén 1943: 428] but later changed his opinion to subspecies after investigation of more material (Hultén 1967). Elven et al. (2003) followed Hultén's later viewpoint, because the taxa had been observed to intergrade in Alaska. They noted that there are plants from eastern Canada (e.g., from southern Baffin Island: Iqaluit) very different from Eurasiatic \i{}J. castaneus\i0{} s.s. (Elven, after visiting the island in 1999). \par{}Hultén (1968) noted that \i{}J. castaneus\i0{} var. \i{}pallidus\i0{} has pale perianth bracts and capsules, and often has few-flowered heads. It occurs in scattered localities. Polunin (1940) considered this a well-marked colour phase, which occurs only in the south.\par{}Since Porsild (1957) new records have been collected on Ellesmere Island. \par{}>

<Polunin (1940) considered this species a "southern" type, apparently eking out a rather precarious existence in arctic and alpine regions and sometimes only 5 or 6 cm high, although more often attaining a height of some 15 cm. \par{}Bayfield (1996), in a study of long-term changes in colonisation of bulldozed ski slopes, found that, generally where grass seeding was done, most local vascular species were more effective colonists of seeded than of untreated ground, but an exception was \i{}J. trifidus\i0{}, which was more successful on unsown ground. \par{}Marchand and Roach (1980), in a study of reproductive strategies of pioneering alpine species seed production, dispersal, and germination, found that \i{}J. trifidus\i0{} showed high production of viable seed, high germination percentages, and relatively high (albeit short-range) seed mobility, combining the advantages of perennial longevity with reproductive vigour more typical of annuals. While \i{}J. trifidus\i0{} appeared capable of sexual reproduction, successful invasion of disturbed sites was considered probably restricted to fairly local areas where there is a high fallout of seed.>

<Polunin (1940a) noted that this taxon is very common in the extreme south of the flora area but only occasional north of the Arctic Circle, where its place is largely taken by the earlier flowering, and otherwise better adapted, \i{}J. biglumis\i0{}. Like that species, with which it is often associated, it grows chiefly in rather open areas of damp mud or clayey soil. Rarely more than 15 cm high, and often only 5-10 cm high, it is easily overlooked except when flowering, and hence rarely to be found in the collections of amateurs even from areas where it is plentiful. The distribution map presented here shows several more records for Ellesmere and Axel Heiberg Islands since Porsild (1957). \par{}Porsild (1957, 1964) and Porsild and Cody (1980) referred all Canadian populations of \i{}J. triglumis\i0{} s.l. (at least east of Mackenzie River), as well as the Greenland populations, to \i{}J. albescens\i0{}. Hultén (1968) considered \i{}J. triglumis\i0{} s.s. to be circumpolar. \par{}The reported ploidy difference is an argument for recognition of \i{}J. triglumis\i0{} (2\i{}n\i0{} = 50) and \i{}J. albescens\i0{} (2\i{}n\i0{} = 130 - 134) as species, but the morphological and geographical data are ambiguous. A correlation between ploidy level and morphology is still not well established. Löve and Löve (1956) reported, e.g., both 2\i{}n\i0{} = 50 and 2\i{}n\i0{} = about 134 from Iceland where only \i{}J. triglumis\i0{} s.s. is known to occur. At least one of the \i{}'triglumis'\i0{}-level counts is North American, disproving a North American (\i{}albescens\i0{}) and Eurasian (\i{}triglumis\i0{}) disjunction. Elven et al. (2003) favoured subspecific status for the two taxa. Brooks and Clemants (2000) accepted both (as varieties) for North America, largely as sympatric, but with \i{}'albescens'\i0{} as the most widespread. If the morphological distinctions are connected to the ploidal levels (this fact is not yet established), the choice is rather between two species or one polymorphic species, and rank as variety or subspecies is then inappropriate (Elven, personal communication, 2005).\par{}\i{}Juncus triglumis\i0{} is often reported as colonising silty disturbed areas, and tends to be locally sparse. It can be found in numerous habitat types, however, and at varying altitudes from coastal swales to upper mountain slopes as high as 1000 feet above sea level (CAN 370914). In tundra meadows, it can be found in \i{}Carex\i0{} communities along with \i{}J. biglumis\i0{}. In coastal wetlands, it occurs in extensive marshes with \i{}Eriophorum\i0{} and \i{}Carex aquatilis\i0{} var. \i{}minor\i0{}. On black, mucky seepage slopes, it grows with \i{}Kobresia simpliciuscula\i0{} and \i{}Eriophorum callitrix. \i0{}On southern Baffin Island at Ogac Lake, it was reported in this habitat type with \i{}Trichophorum cespitosum\i0{} and \i{}Pinguicula vulgaris\i0{} (CAN 302048). \par{}\i{}Juncus triglumis\i0{} was found to be an early coloniser of oil spills in Alaska (Kershaw and Kershaw 1986).>

<The combination \i{}L. arcuata\i0{} subsp. \i{}confusa\i0{} was not formally made by Blytt (1861 p. 298), just cited in synonymy with reference to Hartman, but there with sufficient citation of basionym to be considered validly published (Elven et al. 2003). \par{}Bliss and Svoboda (1984), in a study of soils, plant communities, and net annual plant production in the western Queen Elizabeth Islands, recognised a \i{}Luzula confusa\i0{} graminoid steppe that was more productive than a \i{}Puccinellia\i0{} barren. Bell and Bliss (1978) estimated that the roots of \i{}L. confusa\i0{} live 7-13 years. Addison and Bliss (1984) reported on the adaptations of \i{}Luzula confusa\i0{} to a polar semi-desert environment.\par{}Van der Wal et al. (2000) manipulated the plant phenology of \i{}Luzula\i0{} heathland plots in Spitsbergen (78°N) by adding or removing snow, which altered the time for plots (2 m × 2 m; \i{}n\i0{} = 10) to become snow-free. Nitrogen content of the forage species decreased with time after snowmelt, whereas C:N ratio increased. Manipulation of snowmelt led to a shift in "phenological time", without altering these plant quality parameters as such. Early in the growing season, Svalbard reindeer (\i{}Rangifer tarandus platyrhynchus\i0{}) selected the advanced plots which had been snow-free for longest, presumably because of the greater biomass of both \i{}Luzula confusa\i0{} and \i{}Salix polaris\i0{}, major components of reindeer diet at that time of the year. Phenolic content did not differ among treatments, and is therefore unlikely to play a role in reindeer selection for plots with early snowmelt. Unlike in temperate regions, where selection for plant quality seems to be of major importance, selection for plant quantity might be an outcome of generally low levels of plant biomass and high forage quality during the growing season in the High Arctic. Reindeer selection for high plant biomass is likely to lead to a more favourable nitrogen and energy return than selection for high plant quality. \par{}Nakatsubo et al. (1998), as a part of the study on soil carbon flow in a deglaciated area in Svalbard (79°N), estimated the contribution of the belowground respiration of vascular plants, including \i{}Luzula confusa\i0{}, to total soil respiration in August 1996. The respiratory activity and the Q10 value of the respiration were higher in \i{}S. polaris\i0{} than in the other two species. Total soil respiration rates measured in the field varied widely. The areas with dense vegetation cover tended to show high respiration rates. The contribution of the belowground respiration to total soil respiration was negligible in the early stages of succession. On the other hand, the respiration of the belowground parts contributed to a significant proportion (approx. 29%) of the total soil respiration in the latter stages of succession.>

<Jarolimova and Kirschner (1995) studied plants of \i{}Luzula multiflora\i0{} s.l. in Ireland from 14 populations that were invariably tetraploid with 2\i{}n \i0{}= 24. Chromosomes of the tetraploid are of AL type (true tetraploidy). Meiosis of the tetraploids is of the same type as described for other \i{}Luzula\i0{} taxa in the literature. In meiosis, 12 bivalents are regularly formed. A hypothesis, based on the morphological and allozyme data, that the tetraploids are of alloploid origin was supported by the results. Meiosis in an artificial hybrid between the presumed parental taxa, \i{}L. campestris\i0{} and \i{}L. pallidula\i0{}, was studied, and a tendency towards chromosome doubling was observed. \par{}Extensive work on this and related taxa has been done in Europe by Kirschner (1990, 1991, 1992, and 1997), Kirschner and Krisa (1980); Kirschner and Rich (1996). \par{}This taxon was anticipated as occurring on the Arctic Archipelago by Porsild (1957) and reported for Baffin Island, Ogac Lake, and Beekman Peninsula by McLaren (1964). These records do not appear in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} map (Brooks and Clemants 2000). This taxon was collected in 2004 near Ogac Lake, by Aiken and LeBlanc.>

<Elven et al. (2003) discussed the use of the name \i{}L. arctica\i0{} for this taxon. They noted that "a number of authors (Hultén 1968, Böcher et al. 1968, Porsild and Cody 1980, Novikov 1990) have considered \i{}L. nivalis\i0{} to be conspecific with \i{}L. arctica\i0{}, but some of them (Hultén 1968, Böcher et al. 1968) have used the name \i{}L. arctica\i0{}, while the others (Porsild and Cody 1980...) [have used] the correct name \i{}L. nivalis\i0{}." According to Chrtek and Krisa (1980), \i{}L. arctica\i0{} and \i{}L. nivalis\i0{} are not identical taxa. In 2005, Kirschner and Elven considered the taxa identical (Elven, personal communication) for the following reasons:\par{}Elven et al. (2003) noted that Nordic and other European authors consider Læstadius' \i{}L. campestris\i0{} var. \i{}nivalis\i0{} as corresponding to current \i{}L. arctica\i0{}. Elven et al (2003) stated "The type of Læstadius' var. \i{}nivalis\i0{} ...clearly belongs to the same species as the type of \i{}L. arctica\i0{}... and both belong to what we consider as \i{}L. arctica\i0{}." According to Hylander (1945: 108-109; 1953: 186), and accepted by Swab (2000), Sprengel's application of the name '\i{}nivalis'\i0{} was different from the '\i{}nivalis\i0{}' of Læstadius and did not correspond to the Nordic and arctic plants; Sprengel's concept was of a central European plant and his description does not fit Læstadius' var. \i{}nivalis\i0{}. Beurling (1853) also explicitly referred to the erroneous usage of Sprengel. If this is the case, Chrtek and Krisa (1980) are right in their comment, since the name '\i{}nivalis\i0{}' would have priority at varietal level but '\i{}arctica\i0{}' at species level. However, Sprengel's name is indeed based on \i{}L. campestris\i0{} (L.) DC. var. \i{}nivalis\i0{} Laest. Therefore, by priority, \i{}Luzula nivalis\i0{} is considered the correct name, and a lectotypification is being published on a Laestadius collection in S (Kirschner, personal communication). Thus we use the name \i{}L. nivalis\i0{}, although Brooks and Clemants (2000) use the name \i{}L. arctica\i0{}. \par{}Polunin (1940) noted that this is one of the most abundant, ubiquitous, and ecologically important of all arctic plants and that it varies considerably if sufficient material is examined. However, the extremes of variation of inflorescence form are linked by plentiful intermediate stages, and because of this and because they concern characters that are of little taxonomic importance elsewhere in the group, they seem hardly worth describing. \par{}Polunin (1940) referenced specimens that appeared to him to be \i{}L. arctica\i0{} × \i{}L. confusa\i0{} hybrids. He noted that sheets labelled "\i{}L. hyperborea\i0{} R. Br." frequently consist of a mixture of the two species, which is true of Robert Brown's type sheet in the British Museum, so that it seems best to discard this name altogether. Nobody else appears to have proposed a hybrid between these taxa that appear to be distantly related and without any hybridisation whatsoever. \par{}Bell and Bliss (1978) estimated that the roots of \i{}L. nivalis\i0{} (\i{}L. arctica\i0{}) live 7-13 years.>

<Polunin (1940) observed that although this species is very variable elsewhere, it seems relatively constant in the Canadian Arctic, although it varies considerably in size and luxuriance and there is some variation in the numbers of cilia on the bracts. Elven et al. (2003) consider the taxon very homogeneous throughout the Arctic but very heterogenous in more southern temperate mountains. \par{}Chrtek and Krísa (1962) reported on a taxonomic study of the species \i{}Luzula\i0{} \i{}spicata\i0{} (L.) D.C. sensu lato in Europe.\par{}>
<The only location for this taxon in Greenland (northeast) could be explained by migration from the Eurasian Arctic (Yurtsev, personal communication, 2001).>

<The \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment (Standley et al. 2002) states that the species \i{}C. aquatilis\i0{} is distinguished by "amphistomic... papillose leaves, glabrous sheaths with a concave apex, and perigynia that lack veins and are usually brown-spotted in the proximal half, and have glossy achenes," and recognises four extensively intergrading varieties. The one that occurs in the Arctic Archipelago, although extensively intergrading along the Arctic coast with var. \i{}aquatilis\i0{},\i{} \i0{}appears to be distinct, as it has been reported to maintain its distinctive characteristics in cultivation (Cayouette and Morisset 1986). \par{}The entity that occurs in the Canadian Arctic is called \i{}C. aquatilis\i0{} var. \i{}minor\i0{} Boott in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment (Standley et al. 2002). Elven et al. (2003) recognise this taxon as subsp. \i{}stans\i0{} (Drejer) Hultén, with the comment that "the division into \i{}aquatilis\i0{} and \i{}stans\i0{} seems to be made differently in different areas. In Norway and Greenland, and partly in North America, \i{}'minor'\i0{} is considered fairly narrowly whereas some Russian floras [Fl. Murm. Obl.] consider it much more widely 'stans'. This results in discrepancies at national borders". If subsp. \i{}stans\i0{} is raised to species, the name \i{}C. concolor\i0{} R. Br. has priority (Egorova, personal communication, 2002). \par{}The role of this taxon (as \i{}C. aquatilis\i0{} var. \i{}minor\i0{}) in methane efflux from boreal peat lands was studied by Pullman et al. (1995). \par{}In a study of scale-dependent correlations of Arctic vegetation and snow cover in southeastern Victoria Island, Schaefer and Messier (1995) found that this taxon (as \i{}C. aquatilis\i0{} var. \i{}minor\i0{}) exhibited positive associations with various measures of snow cover. It is thought that snow cover may reduce the rate of desiccation, protect plants from abrasion, and insulate from low temperatures. \par{}\i{}Carex aquatilis\i0{} s.l. is a forage species for lesser snow geese (\i{}Anser caerulescens\i0{}). In their study of the nutrient contents of principal forage plants utilised by the geese at La Perouse Bay, Manitoba, Gadallah and Jefferies (1995) show that nutrient content in \i{}C. aquatilis\i0{} s.l. is lower than that of \i{}C. subspathacea\i0{}, which inhabits salt marshes nearer to the coast. Although the lesser snow goose prefers to forage on \i{}C. subspathacea\i0{}, it will feed on the leaf tips of \i{}C. aquatilis\i0{} during the summer and on the shoot bases and rhizomes in spring and autumn. \par{}\i{}Carex aquatilis\i0{} was found to be an early coloniser of oil spills in Alaska (Kershaw and Kershaw 1986). \par{}Ovenden (1986) found \i{}Carex aquatilis\i0{} s.l. was an early colonising species on the lake bed of Illisarvik, the site of a thermokarst lake that was artificially drained in August 1978. By 1985, the lake bed was dry in most areas and wind erosion was extensive. Substrate type appeared to have had little influence on distributional patterns of the colonising vegetation. More important factors were probably erosion, surface wetness, and proximity of the lake-bed margin. Other widespread species included \i{}Tephroseris palustris\i0{} subsp. \i{}congesta\i0{} (\i{}Senecio congestus\i0{}), \i{}Descurainia sophioides\i0{}, \i{}Tripleurospermum maritimum\i0{}, \i{}Artemisia tilesii\i0{}, \i{}Arctophila fulva\i0{}, and \i{}Stellaria longipes.\i0{}>

<A recent investigation based on Scandinavian material (Reinhammer 1999) strongly supported the status of this species as distinct from \i{}C. capitata\i0{}. There are consistent differences in genetic markers between \i{}C. arctogena\i0{} and \i{}C. capitata\i0{}, consistent differences in morphology and ecology, a different distribution pattern (even if overlapping), and not a single documented intermediate or hybrid. Elven et al. (2003) consider they are unambiguously good species both 'biologically' and morphologically. \par{}Murray (2002) in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment states that although these two species are readily distinguished in Scandinavia and Russia (Reinhammer 1999 and Egorova 1999, respectively) the situation is not as clear in North America. Murray noted that in North America two taxa may be distinguished but there are also numerous specimens of uncertain determination. He included both species under \i{}C. capitata\i0{}, but concluded that separate status at some rank may be appropriate for the taxon "arctogena" in North America and urged that, when making new collections, it is important to pay close attention to habitat and habit. \i{}Carex capitata\i0{} occurs in boreal mires and is mat-forming; the pistillate scales are much shorter and narrower than the perigynia with narrow hyaline margins; the perigynia taper gradually to the glabrous beak. \i{}Carex arctogena\i0{} grows in alpine heaths and is tufted; the pistillate scales are as long as the perigynia and with broad hyaline margins; the perigynia have an abrupt beak and may be sparingly serrulate. All specimens of \i{}C. capitata \i0{}from the Canadian Arctic Archipelago that we have checked to date have been redetermined as \i{}C. arctogena\i0{}.>

<Polunin (1940) noted that this species may be mistaken for a marsh form of \i{}Carex fuliginosa\i0{} [as \i{}C. misandra\i0{}] and that specimens of the two are sometimes mounted together; upon closer examination they are actually quite distinct. \par{}In a study of scale-dependent correlations of Arctic vegetation and snow cover in southeastern Victoria Island, Schaefer and Messier (1995) found that \i{}C. atrofusca\i0{} exhibited positive associations with various measures of snow cover. It is thought that snow cover may reduce the rate of desiccation, protect plants from abrasion, and insulate them from low temperatures. \par{}Rare exceptions to the normal morphology are the specimens CAN 23127 and CAN 483451, with two staminate spikes, and CAN 483450, which has a subterminal spike with both staminate and pistillate flowers. \par{}Ball and Mastrogiuseppe (2002) noted that \i{}C. atrofusca\i0{} is the only species in sect. \i{}Aulocystis \i0{}with papillose perigynia, suggesting that it is perhaps misplaced. Egorova (1999, in Elven et al. 2003) placed \i{}C. atrofusca\i0{} in sect. \i{}Chartoteuchium\i0{}.>

<Polunin (1940) described this species as "a characteristic and attractive little sedge, with more or less pendulous spikes of rounded, pastel-green fruits peeping out from behind dark scales". He noted that it varies considerably in luxuriance and has culms that arch in all directions.\par{}>

<This taxon is widespread and variable in the eastern Arctic, varying from strongly stoloniferous and 10-40 cm high to closely tufted and only 4-5 cm high (Polunin 1940). A form with narrow perigynia and long and stiff peduncles to the lower spikes, is sometimes separated as \i{}C. anguillata\i0{}. Polunin (1940) concluded it was best to include this and all other forms in the eastern Arctic under the same name, and this has generally been done. \par{}McLaren (1964) indicated that \i{}C. anguillata\i0{} was an addition to the flora of the Arctic Archipelago. He collected two specimens on Baffin Island at Ogac Lake (specimens at CAN). They are relatively delicate plants but within the concept of \i{}C. bigelowii\i0{}. Another specimen, CAN 204794, collected from the head of Clyde Inlet, Baffin Island, was annotated by Porsild (1958) as ?\i{}C. anguillata\i0{} (Drejer) Fern; "a peculiar form in which the terminal spikes are female at most with 1-2 male flowers near the summit". These document the considerable variation that is known in \i{}C. bigelowii\i0{}. Polunin (1940) discussed why the names \i{}C. concolor\i0{} R. Br. and \i{}C. rigida\i0{} Good. cannot be used. Porsild and Cody (1980) noted that in moist areas the plants become taller and occasionally have longer and more lax-flowered pistillate spikes. \par{}Chater (1980) noted that this is an extremely variable species whose infraspecific taxonomy is confused by its apparent similarity to small variants of \i{}Carex aquatilis\i0{} in the arctic, by the occurrence of numerous hybrids, and by the fact that published work on it has never taken full account of the variation over the entire range. \par{}\i{}Carex bigelowii\i0{} is self-compatible, but protandry limits pollination within flowering shoots (Jonsson et al. 1996). Their study of genetic diversity using allozyme electrophoresis revealed extensive genetic diversity, and indicated high levels of outbreeding in the past. Today, the species produces many seeds and has a large, long-lived seed bank; yet very little seedling recruitment has been observed. In Iceland, seedling recruitment has been observed only in disturbed sites. Reproduction is mainly by vegetative clonal growth (also observed in Swedish Lapland by Wikberg et al. 1994). The long internodes of the rhizomes break down over time, resulting in a large number of independent fragments with the same genetic composition (Jonsson et al. 1996). \par{}The impact of the anticipated climate changes on the population growth and vegetative spread of \i{}Carex bigelowii\i0{} was investigated by Carlsson and Callaghan (1994). They showed that increases in nutrients, carbon dioxide, and temperature (expected consequences of climate change in the Arctic) will lead to increased growth of the species, and that young "guerrilla" type tillers will contribute significantly to vegetative spread.\par{}Demographic aspects in populations of the species were studied in Swedish Lapland by Wikberg et al. (1994) at three altitudes. Tiller densities from the highest altitudes increased significantly during the study period (10-20 years), while those from intermediate and lower altitudes stayed constant. \par{}Experimental control of flowering was investigated by Heide (1992).>

<Standley et al. (2002) recognised this taxon at the subspecies level in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment and keyed out the two subspecies as follows: \par{}"Perigynia green, spotted purple-black on apical half, minutely papillose; stipe 0.15-0.45 mm long, proximal pistillate spike loosely flowered, base often attenuate, less often cuneate... \i{}C. bigelowii \i0{}subsp\i{}. bigelowii. \par{}\i0{}Perigynia green, often white at maturity, uniformly purple-brown on apical half, stongly or minutely papillose; stipe 0-0.15 mm long, proximal pistillate spike densely flowered, base cuneate, less often attenuate...\i{}C. bigelowii\i0{} subsp. \i{}lugens\i0{}." (p. 400) \par{}Standley et al. (2002) note that several floras recognise two species, \i{}C. lugens\i0{} and \i{}C. consimilis, \i0{}in the western Arctic and that these species have more affinities to eastern Asian taxa than to eastern \i{}C. bigelowii\i0{}. "These treatments usually separate \i{}C. lugens\i0{} by the caespitose habit, leaves less than 2 mm wide, and setaceous proximal bract. Careful study of the complex indicates that although there are caespitose and rhizomatous morphs, leaf width, bract width, perigynium size and shape all vary considerably within and between populations and the variation is not correlated with habit. It is not known whether variation in habit is due to genetic differences or merely to plant responses to differences in substrate and soil moisture. Long-rhizomatous plants tend to occur in dry tundra, and short-rhizomatous plants tend to occur in wet, peaty muskeg. For that reason, the group is recognised as a single taxon that needs further study.\rdblquote\par{}Elven (personal communication, 2005) noted that some initial AFLP data (Schönswetter, unpublished) support the fact that \i{}C. lugens\i0{} should be included in \i{}C. bigelowii\i0{} s.l., preferably as a subspecies, but that it also should include several Eurasian entities described as species and subspecies by Russians. \par{}Schaefer and Messier (1995), in a study of scale-dependent correlations of arctic vegetation and snow cover in southeastern Victoria Island, found that \i{}C. bigelowii\i0{} exhibited positive associations with various measures of snow cover. It is thought that snow cover may reduce the rate of desiccation, protect plants from abrasion, and insulate them from low temperatures.>

<Porsild (1957) noted that \i{}C. capillaris\i0{} s.l. is a very variable species and distinguished between var. \i{}capillaris\i0{} s.s. and var. \i{}major\i0{} both in the Arctic Archipelago. He dismissed var. \i{}elongata\i0{} as not occurring in the area. \i{}Carex capillaris\i0{} var. \i{}major\i0{} appears to be just a larger form from more sheltered locations and probably has no genetic basis (P. Ball, personal communication, 1998). The \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment (Ball, 2002, p. 476) indicates that \i{}C. capillaris\i0{} \ldblquote{}is somewhat variable and is often divided into two infraspecific taxa. Plants from the south are larger, have pale brown pistillate scales, and serrulate perigynium beaks. Northern plants are smaller, have medium brown pistillate scales, and smooth perigynium beaks. These characteristics are only weakly correlated making it difficult to assign individuals to these taxa except in a very arbitrary manner."\par{}We recognise the plants in the flora region as \i{}C. capillaris\i0{} subsp. \i{}fuscidula\i0{} as the taxon is currently treated in the Panarctic Flora checklist (Elven et al. 2003). \i{}Carex capillaris\i0{} subsp. \i{}capillaris\i0{} of boreal and temperate European and Russia is characterised by having a long-stalked apical male spike, usually emerging above the female spikes, and pale brown perigynia. The northern arctic plants are all characterised by having a short-stalked apical male spike, situated level with, or below, the female spikes, and chestnut brown perigynia, making the female spikes much darker than in subsp. \i{}capillaris\i0{}. The name subsp. \i{}fuscidula\i0{} belongs to this entity. It is circumpolar and is the one currently documented from the Canadian Arctic Archipelago area. Boreal to southern arctic plants in Southern Greenland, Canada, Alaska, and probably eastern Asia are more difficult to separate from European subsp. \i{}capillaris\i0{} but have been named as subsp. \i{}chlorostachys\i0{}. A renewed analysis on a worldwide base is urgently needed. \par{}Although the \i{}C. capillaris\i0{} aggregate includes \i{}C. krausei\i0{} (Elven et al. 2003), these authors report that specimens from North Greenland and Arctic Canada that they have examined separate fairly cleanly into \i{}C. fuscidula\i0{} and \i{}C. krausei\i0{}, both of which are described in this Flora\i{}.\i0{}>

<Polunin (1940) considered the characteristic habitat of this sedge to be the margins of freshwater pools in sheltered lowland areas where it creeps with conspicuous long stolons on the surface of the wet mud from which the frequent culms arise. Polunin had observed many of the stolons extending out into the water, sometimes for nearly a metre, but in such cases they were barren. Susan Aiken collected this species growing in a wetland area behind the Nunavut Research Institute (Iqaluit) in 1986 and on the beach near the graveyard in 1986 but was not able to find it in 1998, after the wetland area was partially drained and the beach worked with heavy machinery.>

<Polunin (1940) considered this "one of the most familiar and ubiquitous of all arctic sedges....varies [in the eastern North American Arctic] in height from 4 to 40 cm, but the the existence even in the far north of occasional quite large individuals suggests that the reduction elsewhere is merely the result of local exposure and other conditions" (pp. 125-126). \par{}The \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment (Ball and Mastrogiuseppe 2002, p. 479) noted that \ldblquote{}Dietrich (1967) recognised two subspecies in the alpine and arctic regions of Europe, \i{}C. fuliginosa\i0{} subsp. \i{}fuliginosa\i0{} Schkuhr from the mountains of central Europe with leaves about half as long as the fertile stems and spikes 15-20(-25) mm long, and subsp. \i{}misandra\i0{}, from northern Europe, with leaves not more than one third as long as the fertile stems and spikes 10-15 mm long. The North American populations have traditionally been places in subsp. \i{}misandra\i0{}, but in North America many small plants with short spikes have culms scarcely exceeding the leaves; plants with long spikes have the leaves not more than a quarter the length of the culms.\rdblquote\par{}>

<Polunin (1940, p. 120) noted that this is "yet another little sedge that has been in the past, and probably is to this day, repeatedly missed". \par{}In the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment (Ball and Murray 2002), this species and \i{}C. supina \i0{}are placed in sect. \i{}Lamprochlaenae,\i0{} but circumscription of this section has varied. Ball and Murray (2002) noted that Mackenzie (1931-1935, pp. 182) placed \i{}C. glacialis\i0{} and \i{}C. supina\i0{} in sect. \i{}Petraeae\i0{} (sect. \i{}Rupestres\i0{}) although no other author has associated these species with unispicate species. The circumscription in \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} followed that proposed by Egorova (1999).>

<The taxon that occurs in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago is subsp. \i{}glareosa \i0{}(Toivonen 2002). It has leaves 1-2 mm wide and pistillate scales 2-3 mm long. Subspecies \i{}pribylovensis\i0{} that has leaves 1.5-2.5 mm wide and pistillate scales 2.7-3.5 mm long is known only from the Pribilof and Aleutian islands and is relatively rare.\par{}Halliday and Chater (1969a) examined fruit shape in the circumpolar \i{}C. glareosa\i0{} complex and concluded there is continuous variation between the long, fusiform fruits of \i{}C. glareosa\i0{} and the broad fruits of plants which are referred either to \i{}C. marina\i0{} or \i{}C. glareosa\i0{} var. \i{}amphigena\i0{} Fernald. They indicated that the species \i{}C. glareosa\i0{} and \i{}C. lachenalii\i0{} Schkuhr are fairly closely related. \i{}Carex lachenalii\i0{} is a species of freshwater mires and snow patches, but in east Greenland it often occurs by the seashore where poorly developed individuals may very closely resemble \i{}C. glareosa\i0{}. By contrast, \i{}C. glareosa\i0{} is nearly always maritime growing in the Arctic with \i{}C. subspathacea\i0{}, \i{}C. ursina\i0{}, \i{}Puccinellia phryganodes\i0{}, and \i{}Stellaria humifusa\i0{}. \par{}Halliday and Chater (1969a) gave the following characters for separating \i{}C. glareosa\i0{} from \i{}C. lachenalii\i0{}: \i{}Carex glareosa\i0{} plants have leaves with stomata on both surfaces, whereas \i{}C. lachenalii\i0{} plants have stomata on the lower surface only. In \i{}C. glareosa\i0{} the lateral spikes are entirely pistillate, while those of \i{}C. lachenalii\i0{} have staminate flowers at the base. The fruits of \i{}C. glareosa\i0{} are seldom distinctly beaked, concolorus, and they may vary from brown to pale, whitish green. The fruits of \i{}C. lachenalii\i0{} are distinctly beaked, dark brown, and often tinged with green. The leaves are inrolled and filiform in \i{}C. glareosa\i0{}, almost flat in \i{}C. lachenalii.\i0{} The culms are curved and deposit the fruits on the ground in \i{}C. glareosa\i0{}, oblique and straight in \i{}C. lachenalii\i0{}.\par{}Porsild (1957) and Halliday and Chater (1969a) recognised the North American taxon as \i{}C. glareosa\i0{} var. \i{}amphigena\i0{} Fernald. In the Flora of North America treatment (Toivonen 2002), this variety is synonymised under \i{}C. glareosa\i0{} subsp. \i{}glareosa\i0{} but is discussed as a variety dominating in North America. \par{}Porsild (1957) mapped records from Victoria and Ellesmere Islands, but these have not been confirmed.>

<Polunin (1940) noted that this sedge varies greatly in appearance according to the stage of development of the fruits, which seem to be produced in relatively small numbers. \par{}Porsild (1957) mapped one record from Kimmirut. Since then a collection from Isortoq River (69° 56'N, 76° 50'W) is a significant extension of the known range. This suggests the species should be looked for at other locations on Baffin Island. \par{}Cochrane (2002) noted that opinions differ about the taxonomic rank of this taxon, which is from North America and Siberia. He suggests that since it is only weakly distinguished from the the Eurasian \i{}C. dioica\i0{} subsp. \i{}dioica\i0{}, perhaps it is better segregated as \i{}Carex dioica\i0{} subsp. \i{}gynocrates\i0{} as treated by Hultén (1962). The Eurasian taxon has chromosome counts of 2\i{}n\i0{} = 52 and 60, and tends to be less strongly dioecious, with paler pistillate scales and ventrally more convex perigynia. \par{}\i{}Carex\i0{} ×\i{}langeana, \i0{}the hybrid between \i{}C. gynocrates\i0{} and \i{}C maritima\i0{}, might be looked for where the two species co-occur. (Cochrane 2002, p 301) notes that \i{}C. \i0×\i{}langeana\i0{} [=\i{}C. dutillyi\i0{} O'Neill and Duncan] "strongly resembles \i{}C. maritima\i0{}; the leaves are slightly scabrous-roughened toward the apex; the heads are smaller, ellipsoid to ovoid-oblong and only 3-5 mm thick; the perigynia are appressed-ascending and more or less flat; and the achenes are not well developed. \i{}Carex\i0{} \i×langeana \i0{}is reported as forming close turf on dry, peaty limestone barrens in Newfoundland (M.L. Fernald 1933, 1950) and as occasional upon humid rocks and coastal fens along Hudson Bay (J. Deshaye and J. Cayouette 1988). The hybrid should be expected where the parents coexist and has been reported from some of those areas (J. Cayouette and P.M. Catling 1992)" .>

<Polunin (1940) noted that this taxon was frequently classified as a variety of \i{}C. norvegica,\i0{} but in the field it is entirely distinct and he had seen no transitional forms. \par{}Murray (2002) noted that \i{}C. holostoma\i0{} has most likely been overlooked and has a more continuous range than indicated.>

<Polunin (1940) noted that most plants of this species in the eastern arctic varied between 5 and 15 cm in height and recognised those that are much smaller, less than 3 cm in height, as f. \i{}minima\i0{} (Beck) Kükenthal. He found plants on Southampton Island with the branches of the inflorescence more lastingly erect than in the typical form, and the pistillate spikes bearing generally more numerous and more densely clustered flowers, and he named these specimens var. \i{}porsildiana\i0{} Polunin. Neither name has been widely taken up. \par{}Ball (2002, p. 476) stated that \ldblquote{}the status of \i{}C. krausei\i0{} is far from clear, and many authors have treated it as a variant of \i{}C. capillaris\i0{}. None of the morphologic characters by which they are distinguished appear to be reliable, and the relationship between chromosome number and morphology is based on examination of relatively few populations. The relationship is further confounded by \i{}C. boecheriana\i0{} Á. Löve, D. Löve and Raymond, which is morphologically similar to \i{}C. krausei\i0{} but cytologically closer to \i{}C. capillaris\i0{}. There is no evidence of an ecologic difference between \i{}C. capillaris\i0{} and \i{}C. krausei\i0{} across its range; \i{}C. krausei\i0{} appears to be sympatric with \i{}C. capillaris.\i0\rdblquote\par{}Elven et al. (2003) considered that \i{}C. krausei\i0{} is easily recognised by its bisexual apical spike (female at apex, male at base) and by its more numerous and well-separated female spikes, which when fully developed are long-linear (and not elliptic-ovate as in \i{}C. capillaris\i0{}). The dull brown colour of the bracts and perigynia also differs from the colours of races of \i{}C. capillaris\i0{}. Löve et al. (1957) separated several taxa within \i{}C. krausei\i0{} as considered here, mainly based on ploidy differences. The assignment of chromosome numbers to taxa is still very uncertain. \par{}Subspecies \i{}krausei\i0{} is widely amphi-Beringian (Russian Siberia, Russian Far East, Alaska, and Canada). Subspecies \i{}porsildiana\i0{} occurs in the amphi-Atlantic areas (Iceland, Norway, Canada, and Greenland). Subspecies \i{}robustior\i0{} is reported for the Yukon Territory (Porsild and Cody 1980). If the taxon is divided, plants from Alaska-Yukon and Central Canada would be probably classified as \i{}C. krausei\i0{} subsp. \i{}krausei\i0{}; those from the West Hudson Bay area and Baffin-Labrador area probably referred to \i{}C. krausei\i0{} subsp. \i{}porsildiana\i0{}; and those from Greenland to the latter taxon or to \i{}C. boecheriana.\i0\par{}>

<Polunin (1940) discusses the name of this taxon that he called \i{}Carex bipartita\i0{} All. He agreed with Gelting (1934) who considered the familiar salt marsh \i{}C. glareosa\i0{} as a variety of this species and recognised it as \i{}C. bipartita\i0{} var. \i{}glareosa\i0{} (Wahlenb.) Polunin. However, he admitted that seashore plants and individuals occurring away from the shore are referable to a rather variable typical form, and many individuals are intermediate in such characters as the width of the leaves, thickness and rigidity of the culms, and shape of the inflorescence. \par{}Toivonen (2002) reported that \ldblquote\i{}C. lachenalii\i0{} shows a great deal of morphological variation; \u8230\'85 most of the variation has no evident taxonomic relevance\u8230\'85" The name \i{}Carex bipartita\i0{} All. has been widely used for the plant in North America. Toivonen (2002) gave reasons why this name should have priority over \i{}C. lachenalii\i0{}. However, the International Code of Botanical Nomenclature (ICBN) has conserved \i{}Carex lachenalii\i0{} over \i{}C. tripartita\i0{} (Greuter et al. 2000) and rejected \i{}C. bipartita\i0{} (McNeill et al. 2006).>

<\i{}Carex marina\i0{} was described by Dewey (1836) from material collected in the Canadian Arctic by Richardson, probably on the second of Franklin\rquote{}s expeditions. Fernald (1902), like Kükenthal (1909), considered Dewey\rquote{}s plant to be \i{}C. heleonastes\i0{}. Porsild (1957) treated this taxon as \i{}Carex amblyorhyncha\i0{} V. Krecz. Halliday and Chater (1969c) showed that \i{}C. marina\i0{} is the earlier name of this taxon. \par{}The species referred to by Mackenzie (1935) as \i{}C. marina \i0{}is actually \i{}C. glareosa\i0{} Wahlenb. \par{}Halliday and Chater (1969a) suggested that in the past the widespread \i{}C. marina\i0{} hybridised with the more local \i{}C. glareosa\i0{} until the latter no longer occurred in pure populations. Elven (personal communication, 2005) stated that he had seen no specimens indicating this hybridisation.\par{}Toivonen (2002, p. 316-317) in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment noted that "plants from Greenland and Europe often with two spikes and short-beaked perigynia have been called \i{}C. marina\i0{} subsp. \i{}pseudolagopina\i0{} (Sørensen) Böcher; subsp. \i{}marina\i0{} from North America and Siberia [and also a very small area in western Greenland, around Disko Island] differs in having usually (2-)3(-4) spikes equal in size.... narrower leaves, and a more distinct beak." The occurrence of subsp. \i{}pseudolagopina\i0{} from North America (excluding Greenland) remains to be fully documented.>

<Polunin (1940) observed that this species varies so much, especially in vegetative characters, that a number of varieties and forms have been erected, and while he did not feel these were appropriate, as there are all stages of gradation from one to another, he recognised one "phase" as \i{}C. maritima\i0{} f. \i{}inflata\i0{} (Simmons) Polunin. He also felt that there was one variety (which even if it is a mere reduction phase) that was so strikingly different in its extreme depauperation and generally High Arctic habitat from the robust plant of the south that he separated it as \i{}C. maritima\i0{} var. \i{}setina\i0{} (Christ) Fernald. This has not been taken up here. Photographs in the image library illustrate some of the range of variation we have recorded. \par{}Reznicek (2002, p. 310) indicated that \i{}C. maritima\i0{} "is an extremely widespread and variable species. On exposed headlands, plants can be very tiny in contrast to robust individuals on richer river shores or some inland lakeshores. Very small plants with extremely narrow leaves from coastal regions of Newfoundland have been named \i{}C. maritima\i0{} var. \i{}setina\i0{}, and unusually large plants from the shores of Kluane Lake, Yukon Territory, have been named \i{}C. maritima\i0{} subsp. \i{}yukonensis\i0{}. These are both regarded as environmentally derived, representing two extremes in the variation.">

<Ford and Ball (1992, p. 634) noted that this species is "the most restricted of all the short-beaked taxa [in section \i{}Vesicariae\i0{}], being confined primarily to the North American Arctic. It is noticeably absent from Greenland and occurs in Eurasia only in the Chukot Peninsula and Koryakskiy Mountain region of extreme eastern U.S.S.R. [Russia]. It is one of the few truly northern species of sedge, being widespread in the Arctic Archipelago and occurring in the south as far as northern British Columbia, the southern boundary of the Northwest Territories and northern Quebec. Although this species is said to occur in the Churchill, Manitoba region (Johnson 1987, Porsild and Cody 1980)," no specimen has been found to support this suggestion. \par{}Ford and Ball (1992) noted that anatomically \i{}C. saxatilis\i0{} is indistinguishable from \i{}C. membranacea\i0{} and presented evidence to suggest that "this similarity is the result of homoplasy or stasis in anatomical characters rather than an indication of a close evolutionary relationship." (p. 620). \par{}\i{}Carex membranacea\i0{} was found to be an early coloniser of oil spills in Alaska (Kershaw and Kershaw 1986).>

<Since Porsild (1957), one specimen (CAN 485156) was collected on Victoria Island at Holman, which is a considerable range extension. \par{}Reznicek (1990) illustrated the rachilla of \i{}C. microglochin\i0{} and noted that it is very large, but only one-veined. It is terete and smooth. Internally, surrounding the single central vascular strand is a thick layer of spongy parenchyma, making the rachilla a relatively soft, more or less easily bent structure. It is a striking contrast to the rachillas in other species that he studied. \par{}Cochrane (2002, p. 531) noted that "\i{}Carex michroglochin\i0{} subsp. \i{}microglochin\i0{} is usually rare to occasional in subarctic North America and scattered in the Cordilleran region. It can be locally abundant (e.g., Brooks Range, Alaska) or even dominant (e.g., western Newfoundland) despite its very spotty geographic range... \i{}Carex michroglochin\i0{} subsp.\i{} microglochin\i0{} is an inconspicuous but interesting little plant, distinctive in having a well-developed rachilla very similar in appearance to the exserted style of \i{}C. pauciflora\i0{} Lightfoot. The long pointed perigynia, which mature quickly and detach easily, are probably dispersed by animals (Fernald 1926; Savile 1972).">

<In the vegetative state this species may be difficult to distinguished from \i{}Kobresia myosuroides\i0{}. \par{}Polunin (1940) discusses why he considered specimens in the eastern Arctic to be var. \i{}hepburnii\i0{} (Boott) Kükenthal, but recognition of the variety has not been widely taken up in North America. Polunin (1940) had observed the species in Arctic Bay, Baffin Island, where it dominated the slightly damp but by no means sheltered lower slopes around the head of the bay. Plants there were growing sometimes a full 20 cm high, and looked far more luxuriant than any typical \i{}C. nardina\i0{}. \par{}Porsild (1957) indicated that the species was represented in the Canadian Arctic \ldblquote{}by the eastern race, var. \i{}atriceps\i0{} Kükenthal and distinguished from var. \i{}nardina\i0{} by its taller growth and less curved culms and leaves\rdblquote{}. This is no longer considered to be a recognisable entity (P. Ball, University of Toronto, personal communication, 1997). \par{}Murray (2002), in \i{}Flora of North America\i0{}, reported that "much has been written about variation in \i{}Carex nardina\i0{}, but little has been resolved. Russian taxonomists have long maintained that \i{}C. nardina\i0{} is a species restricted to Iceland, Svalbard, Norway, and Sweden and is distinct at the rank of species from \i{}C. hepburnii\i0{} (T.V. Egorova 1999). The differences between perigynia, cited by Egorova and well illustrated in Cronquist (1969), can define two taxa which have been viewed as minor variations (Hultén 1958) or good species. The Scandinavian material does appear to constitute a single taxon \i{}C. nardina\i0{}." \par{}Murray (2002) considers that although the clear geographic limits designated by Porsild (1943) are not found, both forms are found in North America, differing as follows (key derived from Murray 2002):\par{}Perigynia shape: ovate or spindle-shaped; size (3-)3.5-5 × 1.4-1.6 mm; beak formation and size: gradually formed, 0.5 mm, obscure to 0.4 mm; stipe formation and size: distinct, 0.5-1 mm... \b\i{}C. nardina\b0\i0\par{}Perigynia shape: obovate or broadly elliptic, size 3-5 × 1.5-2 mm; beak formation and size: obscure to 0.4 mm; stipe formation and size obscure, less than 0.2 mm...\b\i{}C. hepburnii\b0\i0{}. \par{}Recorded by S. Aiken from herbarium specimens collected in the Arctic islands before the possibility of \i{}C. hepburnii\i0{} was known:\par{}Perigynia shape: broadly ovate: size 3.3-3.7 × 1.4-1.7 mm; beaked with a short beak; contracted at the base into a stipe-like structure. The data suggest the taxon described is closer to \i{}C. nardina\i0{}. \par{}David Murray (personal communication, June 2001), after examining specimens together with Aiken in Stockholm, 2001, noted that both \i{}C. nardina\i0{} and \i{}C. hepburnii\i0{} occur in North America. The problem requires further study, especially among specimens collected from northern Quebec and southern Baffin Island. These overlapped in the characters traditionally used to distinguish the subspecies. \par{}Egorova (1999) and Elven et al. (2003) considered unresolved as to whether \i{}C. nardina\i0{} s.s. (excluding \i{}'hepburnii'\i0{}) is a narrow North Atlantic entity (Iceland, Northern Scandinavia) or whether it also occurs in North America and elsewhere in the Arctic. If the narrow concept is followed, the plants in the CAFF (Conservation of Arctic Flora and Fauna) area become \i{}C. nardina\i0{} subsp. \i{}hepburnii\i0{} (Boott) Á. Löve, D. Löve, and B.M. Kapoor, Arct. Alp. Res. 3, 2: 145. 1971. They represent a major geographical race (the most major one). The \i{}'hepburnii'\i0{} entity is typified from Canada: Rocky Mountains, leg. Drummond, type in K. \par{}Subspecies have not been recognised in this treatment because of the overlapping characters observed in specimens form the eastern Arctic islands.>

<Polunin (1940) noted that except in height this species varies little if at all within the eastern North American Arctic. \par{}Elven et al. (2003) noted that there might be characters other than the margin of the utricles to justify recognising subsp. \i{}inserrulata\i0{}, for example, the width of hyaline margin of bracts, and if so it might represent a distinct taxon (subspecies). The distribution pattern as presented by Hultén and Fries (1986) might support a separation of subspecies: (i) \i{}'norvegica'\i0{} in Europe and southeastern Greenland, (ii) \i{}'inserrulata'\i0{} in eastern and western Greenland and northeastern North America (the few scattered reports from northwestern North America should be very critically checked), and (iii) \i{}'conicorostrata'\i0{} extremely isolated in Chukotka. \par{}Murray (2002) noted that \i{}C. norvegica\i0{} is an amphi-Atlantic species. He treated \i{}C. norvegica\i0{} subsp. \i{}inserrulata\i0{} as synonymous in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment but noted that some differences can be seen between subsp. \i{}inserrulata \i0{}in Greenland and subsp. \i{}norvegica\i0{} in northern Europe, and further study is warranted.\par{}>

<Ball and Zoladz (1994) studied the taxonomy of \i{}C. petricosa\i0{} and related species in North America, \i{}C. franklinii\i0{}, and \i{}C. misandroides\i0{}. In a morphological study of herbarium specimens, the multivariate analyses they used failed to adequately differentiate the taxa and led to the conclusion that all should be treated as a single species. The western and eastern populations differed in the proportion of flowers that were distigmatic. Western plants were mostly tristigmatic or had not more than 50% distigmatic flowers. Eastern plants were mostly distigmatic or had more than 50% distigmatic flowers. Consequently, two varieties were recognised in \i{}C. petricosa\i0{}, var. \i{}petricosa\i0{} from the west and var. \i{}misandroides\i0{} (Fernald) B. Boivin from the east (Newfoundland, Quebec, but not in the Arctic islands). Elven et al. (2003) also recognised two varieties. \par{}Egorova (1999) accepted \i{}Carex franklinii\i0{} as a species (in a list of non-Russian species of the section), as did Hultén (1968), Porsild and Cody (1980), and Cody (1996). \par{}Ball commented that \i{}Carex franklinii\i0{} Boott, often considered as a separate species (e.g., by Hultén 1968a, Porsild and Cody 1980, and Cody 1996), is a synonym of \i{}C. petricosa\i0{} Dewey s.s. \i{}Carex petricosa\i0{} seems to represent small high-altitude plants, whereas \i{}C. franklinii\i0{} seems to represent larger plants from a lower altitude. There is ample material collected from the type area (Alberta), which illustrates the full range of variation.\par{}Ball and Mastrogiuseppe (2002) distinguished varieties in this taxon with the following key (p. 478): \par{}"Stigmas 3; achenes trigonous in at least half of the pistillate flowers and fruits... \i{}C. petricosa\i0{} var. \i{}petricosa\par{}\i0{}Stigmas 2; achenes biconvex in at least half of the pistillate flowers and fruits...\i{}C. petricosa\i0{} var. \i{}misandroides\i0{}". \par{}The record from the Canadian Arctic Archipelago is assigned to \i{}C. petricosa\i0{} var. \i{}petricosa\i0{}. The distribution of \i{}C. petricosa\i0{} var. \i{}misandroides\i0{} is limestone barrens and shores, in Newfoundland Labrador and Quebec.>

<Polunin (1940, p. 127) noted that this species varies considerably in the length of the pedicels, "even the lowest of which may be so short [less than 1 cm long] and rigid as to hold the spike erect instead of pendulous, and so constitute f. \i{}erecta\i0{} Polunin. The species also varies in the colour of the scales, which, except along the midrib, are generally of such a dark brown as to appear jet-black in the field; but they can be of almost any shade to quite a pale brown... This occurrence of forms with light-coloured scales in species that normally have them dark is almost general in this and closely related groups." \par{}Vellend and Waterway (1999), in a study of geographic patterns of genetic diversity for \i{}C. rariflora\i0{}, sampled from the east coast of James Bay, interior Nouveau-Québec, and the northern Yukon Territory. They found that within-population diversity was low overall, and that the degree of population differentiation was high. Particularly low levels of genetic variation at James Bay are attributed to founder events following postglacial colonisation. Higher genetic variation in the northern Yukon is attributed to the presence of glacial refugia during the Pleistocene.>

<Polunin (1940) considered this taxon relatively common and noted that it varies considerably in size according to the local conditions, but not in any character that is of taxonomic importance. \par{}In a study of scale-dependent correlations of Arctic vegetation and snow cover in southeastern Victoria Island, Schaefer and Messier (1995) found that \i{}C. rupestris\i0{} was associated with low snow cover.>
