<In a study of the circumpolar short-beaked taxa of \i{}Carex\i0{} sect. \i{}Vesicariae\i0{}, using numerical analyses of macro-morphological characters, Ford and Ball (1992, p. 620) found that "within the \i{}C. saxatilis\i0{} complex, plants from western North America (\i{}C. physocarpa\i0{}) tend to be robust individuals with long peduncles on the pistillate spikes, wide leaves, and large perigynia. These characters, and others, decrease in size eastward across the North American continent, with intermediate plants usually referred to as \i{}C. saxatilis\i0{} and small plants referred to as \i{}C. miliaris\i0{}." Ford and Ball (1992) concluded that a single distigmatic species, \i{}C. saxatilis\i0{}, should be recognised and present alternative theories for this clinal variation. They noted that anatomically \i{}C. saxatilis\i0{} is indistinguishable from \i{}C. membranacea\i0{} and presented evidence to suggest that "this similarity is the result of homoplasy or stasis in anatomical characters rather than an indication of a close evolutionary relationship." (p. 620).\par{}Elven et al. (2003) considered this an intricate species where perhaps there are three major races or subspecies: "subsp. \i{}saxatilis\i0{} as a mainly boreal-alpine entity in Iceland and mainland Northern Europe, subsp. \i{}laxa\i0{} as an arctic circumpolar entity, and perhaps subsp. \i{}miliaris/rhomalea\i0{} as one or two boreal to Low Arctic entities in northeastern North America and southern Greenland. The southern and northern Greenland plants are very different and must represent different taxa, subspecies or perhaps species. The southern Greenland entity (\i{}'miliaris'\i0{}) also extends into the southern arctic parts of northeastern North America, but perhaps not westwards. The northern Greenland plants are identical with the northern North American, Svalbard, and northern Russian plants (e.g., Novaya Zemlya), i.e., subsp. \i{}laxa\i0{}, and different from the mainland European plants, subsp. \i{}saxatilis\i0{}." If this is the case the problem is how to treat the northeastern America and southern Greenland plants. These authors suggest the solution is to keep \i{}C. miliaris\i0{} as a species. \par{}The chromosome counts listed by Löve and Löve (1975) and Löve (1981d) under the name \i{}C. miliaris\i0{}, if reliable, are an additional argument for status as species. (Elven et al. 2003).>

<Polunin (1940) indicated that this species varies greatly in height, from 5 to 30 cm, in the shape of the spike (which may be subglobose to elongate), and in the presence or absence of a cauline leaf (which may be as much as 6 cm long and overtop the spike). He noted that while several forms and varieties had been recognised they were so inconsistent as to be not worth taking up. \par{}There has been a significant range extension north to Ellesmere Island since Porsild (1957). \par{}Ouellet and Boutin (1994), in a study of the response of vegetation to simulated grazing and browsing of plants available to caribou in the arctic, found that nitrogen, magnesium, potassium, and phosphorus levels in re-growth plants were above the maximum obtained from ungrazed control plants at any point during the growing season and suggested that grazing changes possibly enhance the quality of these plants as food for herbivores. \par{}In a study of scale-dependent correlations of Arctic vegetation and snow cover in southeastern Victoria Island, Schaefer and Messier (1995) found that \i{}C. scirpoidea\i0{} exhibited positive associations with various measures of snow cover. It is thought that snow cover may reduce the rate of desiccation, protect plants from abrasion, and insulate them from low temperatures. \par{}\i{}Carex scirpoidea\i0{} was found to be an early coloniser of oil spills in Alaska (Kershaw and Kershaw 1986). \par{}Dunlop (2002), in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment, recognises four races as subspecies. The one occurring in the Arctic Archipelago is subsp. \i{}scirpoidea\i0{}, which is recognised by "the lack of persistent leaf bases on the flowering shoots, ovate perigynia that are tightly enveloped by the perigynia on all sides, and leaves widely V-shaped in transverse section." (p. 551). It is widespread from the Russian Far East throughout North America and Greenland to northern Norway. He also recognised three others as segregates within the range of subsp. \i{}scirpoidea\i0{}. One of these, the Cordilleran subsp. \i{}stenochlaena\i0{}, reaches the Arctic in northwestern North America and is perhaps the most common race there.>

<\i{}Carex subspathacea\i0{} is a preferred forage species for lesser snow geese (\i{}Anser caerulescens\i0{}) along with \i{}Puccinellia phryganodes\i0{}. Gadallah and Jefferies (1995) analysed the nutrient content of these two species at La Perouse Bay, Manitoba, and found them to be higher than those of other salt marsh graminoids. \par{}Seed set in this taxon is variable. This is a species that requires open ground to flower and set seeds. In areas with such conditions, that is, areas of very low covering and with low companion species, \i{}C. subspathacea\i0{} will flower heavily and the seed set is good to very good, the achenes are well formed, but not fertile. In other areas where individual plants are crowded, most of the population seems sterile and vegetative (J. Cayouette, personal communication, March 2002). \par{}In more boreal areas \i{}C. subspathacea\i0{} is mainly an opportunist occupying gaps and other disturbed sites. \par{}On Arctic islands, \i{}C. subspathacea\i0{} has its own established position on the arctic seashores where it occupies a zone between \i{}Puccinellia phryganodes\i0{}, closer to the sea, and a grass zone on higher ground. \par{}Standley et al. (2002), in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment, noted that \i{}C. subspathacea\i0{} "is evidently, with \i{}C. rufina\i0{}, the smallest species of sect. \i{}Phacocystis\i0{}. Larger plants with one to two staminate spikes and some bisexual spikes frequently occur in Ungava Bay, Hudson Bay, Northwest Territories, and Alaska, but their perigynium and achene characteristics are typical of those in \i{}C. subspathacea.\i0{}" (p. 382). \par{}Among the several hybrids recognised, the ones that should be looked for in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago are \i{}Carex \i0×\i{}flavicans \i0{}F. Nylander (= \i{}C. subspathacea\i0{} × \i{}C. aquatilis\i0{}), \i{}C. \i0×\i{}arctophila\i0{} F. Nylander (= \i{}C. subspathacea\i0{} × \i{}C. bigelowii\i0{}), and \i{}C.\i0{} ×\i{}sorensenii\i0{} E. Lepage (\i{}= C. subspathacea\i0{} × \i{}C. rariflora\i0{}).>

<Polunin (1940) suggested that this little sedge is widespread but rarely collected. \par{}Ball and Murray (2002) place this species in sect. \i{}Lamprochlaenae. \i0{}They noted that Mackenzie (1931-1935, pp. 221) placed \i{}C. supina\i0{} in sect. \i{}Obtusatae\i0{}, but other authors have not associated this species with unispicate species. Recently, sect. \i{}Lamprochlaenae\i0{} has been recognised, although circumscription of this section has varied. The circumscription followed in \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} is that proposed by Egorova (1999).>

<Polunin (1940, p. 113) noted that "except in the Far North, where it is rather rare, the species is probably common along the seashores wherever these are muddy or of damp sand, its dense tussocks being locally very abundant, or coalescing to form extensive mats around the high-water mark in sheltered lagoons...After \i{}Puccinellia phryganodes\i0{} it is about the most important salt marsh plant within our area [in the eastern Arctic], forming a characteristic association with this species and \i{}Stellaria humifusa\i0{}." Such an association is found at Sylvia Grinnell Park, Iqaluit, and illustrated in the image library.>

<Rothrock and Reznicek (2002, p. 428), in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment, noted that "Fernald (1950) pointed out that North American plants sometimes segregated as \i{}Carex saltuensis \i0{}do not appear to be sufficiently distinct to warrant recognition as a separate species. T.V. Egorova (1999) recognised both \i{}C. saltuensis\i0{} and \i{}C. vaginata\i0{}, the latter with two subspecies, in North America. More research is clearly needed on this complex circumpolar entity. The inclusion of \i{}C. vaginata\i0{} in sect. \i{}Paniceae \i0{}is uncertain. Unlike other members of the group, \i{}C. vaginata\i0{} lacks papillae on abaxial leaf epidermis, peduncle, and perigynium." \par{}Elven et al. (2003) recognise all the arctic plants, including those from the Canadian Arctic Archipelago, as subsp. \i{}quasivaginata\i0{} and as clearly different from \i{}C. vaginata\i0{} Tausch. s.s. as typified. There are, however, doubts about the name. The name \i{}'sparsiflora'\i0{} might be the correct one, but this name has not yet been recombined as a subspecies. \par{}In a study correlating Arctic vegetation and snow cover in southeastern Victoria Island, Schaefer and Messier (1995) found that \i{}C. vaginata\i0{} exhibited positive associations with various measures of snow cover. It is thought that snow cover may reduce the rate of desiccation, protect plants from abrasion, and insulate from low temperatures.>

<This species was mentioned in Porsild (1957) as similar to \i{}C. capillaris\i0{} and occurring from Alaska to Labrador. Porsild and Cody (1980) mapped records from southern Baffin Island. Four collections from Baffin Island, Iqaluit, have been made since Porsild (1957). It occurs in the tundra of Hudson Bay coast and in the field may be mistaken for \i{}C. krausei.\par{}\i0{}Peter Ball (personal communication, Nov. 2004) noted that in the material he had seen this species is often staminate and only sometimes androgynous. He questioned whether these are really androgynous spikes or whether they are a staminate terminal spike with the distal lateral spike reduced to a single perigynium. Occasionally, there is more than one perigynium. He noted also that \i{}C. williamsii \i0{}is unlike \i{}C. capillaris\i0{} s.l. in which plants with gynecandrous spikes show up erratically in the Rockies in Alberta, and in Greenland sometimes you get staminate and gynecandrous spikes on the same collection and less often on the same plant. Gynecandrous spikes are very uncommon in Canada, but they seem quite common in Greenland.>

<Polunin (1940) noted that this plant was first found in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago at Kimmirut in 1936, submersed in small freshwater ponds in marshy lowland areas a few miles inland. It has since been found in Iqaluit. In the Arctic Archipelago, as is usually the case in Greenland, the plants are submersed and entirely sterile. \par{}\i{}Eleocharis acicularis\i0{} is abundant and ecologically important throughout much of its southern range. Submerged, usually non-flowering plants have been distinguished as formas, e.g., forma \i{}inundata\i0{} Svenson, forma \i{}submersa\i0{} (Nilsson) Norman. "The culms of the submerged plants are terete, smooth, soft to flaccid, translucent and the partitions of the air cavities within are clearly visible... Much of the variation is apparently due to phenotypic plasticity in response to environmental factors, especially water depth...The named varieties intergrade extensively, and achenes, which are important in defining varieties, are often absent...Most plants from the Arctic to cool-temperate North America...have culms cylindrical or three- to four-angled; leaf sheaths mostly obscure and closely sheathing; and achenes about two times longer than wide." (Smith 2002, pp. 109). Polunin (1940) suggested that these submerged plants might be recognised as \i{}E. acicularis\i0{} f. \i{}submersa\i0{} (H. Nilss.) Norman, but taxonomic recognition is not appropriate, as the plants are merely the underwater form.They are similar to the type that was described from Europe.>

<The earliest name for this taxon is \i{}E. polystachion.\i0{} Polunin (1940) gave three reasons for rejecting this name. This rejection was proposed by Turland (1997) and formally accepted by McNeill et al. (2006). \par{}The status of '\i{}triste'\i0{} as a species or subspecies was discussed by Novoselova in Elven et al. (2003). Elven et al. (2003) also note that a somewhat "quixotic argument" for treating \i{}E. triste\i0{} as a species is its 'hybridisation pattern'. The hybrid entity \i{}E. ×sorenseni\i0{} (\i{}E. scheuchzeri\i0{} × \i{}E. triste\i0{}) seems to occur in most areas where \i{}E. triste\i0{} occurs. No hybrid has been documented between \i{}E. angustifolium\i0{} s.s. and \i{}E. scheuchzeri\i0{} in spite of their very frequent co-occurrence. \par{}Novoselova reports that \i{}E. angustifolium\i0{} subsp. \i{}triste\i0{} differs from \i{}E. angustifolium\i0{} subsp. \i{}angustifolium\i0{} in the following: "uppermost leaf sheath funnel-shaped (not cylindrical); peduncle scabrous, up to 2 cm long (not drooping, smooth, up to 5-10 cm long); flowering spikes ovoid to almost spherical (not oblong-ovoid or oblong-elliptical); fruiting heads obovoid (not bell-shaped or narrowly bell-shaped); scales blackish and without whitish margins (not brownish grey, greyish, reddish or ferrugineous with white margins); anthers (1.8-)2.5-2.8(-3) mm long (not (2.5-)3-4(-5) mm long); achenes widely obovoid, 2-2.5 mm long (not oblong-obovoid or oblong-elliptical (2.5-)2.8-3(-3.5) mm long); and chromosome number 2\i{}n\i0{} = 60 (not 58)." \par{}These characters should be enough for specific recognition, but the characters are not always clear-cut on herbarium specimens. In Svalbard (from where '\i{}triste\i0{}' was described) it is very distinct, as it is in Northern Greenland and Ellesmere Island, but there are problems with recognising it elsewhere in Arctic Canada and Alaska. Peter Ball (personal communication, 2005) has stated it is not possible to distinguish the subspecies on the basis of a single character. In the arctic most plants are small, with dense scabridity on all sides of the peduncles, but even there, there are a few populations with essentially glabrous peduncles and others with much reduced scabridity. Southwards the scabridity is reduced and the plants are larger. \ldblquote{}I cannot recall seeing any collections from the mainland which match the High Arctic \i{}triste\i0{} in all characters. Usually the scabridity is restricted to one side of the peduncle and is less dense. Plants like this show up erratically as far south as the north shore of the St. Lawrence, but these plants in all other characters are indistinguishable from subsp. \i{}angustifolium\i0{}. I took a very conservative view of subsp. \i{}trist\i0{}e in FNA (\i{}Flora of North America\i0{}; Ball and Wujek 2002)) excluding most of the intermediate types\rdblquote{} (Peter Ball, personal communication, 2005).\par{}Given the uncertainty about reliable characters in the Canadian Arctic and the number of intermediate specimens that have been found to date, further study of this species is required. Therefore, here we include all specimens under \i{}E. angustifolium \i0{}s.l.\par{}A study of the effects of variable soil oxygen and nutrient availability on \i{}E. angustifolium\i0{} and \i{}E. vaginatum\i0{} was done by Gebauer et al. (1995) near Toolik Lake, Alaska. It was shown that growth in \i{}E. angustifolium\i0{} was improved by soil anoxia, and that biomass allocation among plant parts was not significantly affected, indicating that the species is well adapted to flooded, wet habitat. \par{}In a study of scale-dependent correlations of arctic vegetation and snow cover in southeastern Victoria Island, Schaefer and Messier (1995) found that \i{}E. angustifolium\i0{} exhibited positive associations with various measures of snow cover. It is thought that snow cover may reduce the rate of desiccation, protect plants from abrasion, and insulate from low temperatures during the winter season. \par{}Lutz (1996) showed that photo-inhibition occurs in plants when cold temperatures and high light levels cause free-radical formation and subsequent destruction of the photosynthetic membranes. In his study of this phenomenon in high alpine populations of \i{}E. angustifolium\i0{} in Tirol, Austria, he showed that the species avoids this hazard by delaying the development of the photosynthetic apparatus until temperature conditions are favourable. Only etiolated leaves are formed early in the season. When photosynthetic membranes do appear they are protected by a set of carotenoids and antioxidants. \par{}Ferland and Rochefort (1997) reported that \i{}E. angustifolium\i0{} has a positive effect on the survival of peat mosses during the restoration of ombrotrophic peat-lands at Maisonnette, New Brunswick. It is easily transplanted and propagated, and is the companion species that leads to the best recolonisation of \i{}Sphagnum\i0{} diaspores. \par{}\i{}Eriophorum angustifolium\i0{} was found to be an early coloniser of oil spills in Alaska (Kershaw and Kershaw 1986).>
<There is a new distribution record for this taxon occurring on Victoria Island since Porsild (1957).>

<Cayouette (2004) noted that "this nothosubspecies is currently known only in northeastern Canada, from continental Nunavut... Baffin and Southampton islands...to northern Quebec...Since the sympatric range of the two parental taxa covers large parts of the Nunavut and Northwest Territories, the western Canadian provinces, Alaska, and eastern to western parts of Russia, \i{}E. ×medium\i0{} subsp. \i{}album\i0{} is likely to be discovered in some of these major areas." However, Cayouette (2004) indicated that no specimen outside of northeastern Canada was known to Novoselova in 2004. Cayouette also stated that there was "the slight possibility that the taxon described from Alaska as \i{}E. russeolum\i0{} var. \i{}albidum\i0{} by Nylander (1846:10) and bearing \ldblquote{}narrowly lanceolate scales\rdblquote{} could refer to the new nothosubspecies, but the type should be searched for and examined." Cayoutte (2004) noted that "some paratypes of \i{}E. ×medium\i0{} subsp. \i{}album\i0{} have been seen with good mature achenes, indicating that subsp. \i{}album\i0{} has perhaps become a stabilised orthospecies of hybrid origin in some areas." (pp 808-809).>

<Ball and Wujek (2002) referred to this taxon under the name \i{}E. chamissonis\i0{} C.A. Meyer and place \i{}E. russeolum\i0{} var. \i{}leucothrix\i0{} (Blomgren) Hultén in synonymy with it. Novoselova (1993) discussed the question of the identity of \i{}E. chamissonis\i0{} C.A. Meyer, drawing attention to the several points of view in the literature concerning the possible use of the name \i{}E. chamissonis\i0{} and its restrictions. \par{}Novoselova (in Elven et al. 2003) considers \i{}E. russeolum\i0{} to be a species separate from \i{}E. chamissonis\i0{}. The taxon that we have in North America is \i{}E. russeolum\i0{} subsp. \i{}leiocarpum.\i0\par{}Novoselova (in Elven et al. 2003) stated that subspecies \i{}leiocarpum\i0{} differs from subsp. \i{}russeolum\i0{} in "(i) shorter culms (height (14-)20-30(-35) cm versus 15-80 cm); (ii) fruiting heads white or cream coloured (not different shades of ferrugineous or red); (iii) scales dark grey to black (not grey to dark grey); (iv) anthers shorter (length (0.7-)1-2(-3) mm versus (1.5-)2-3 mm); and (v) achenes glabrate or with very few spicules at apex (not with numerous spicules at apex, rarely glabrate)."\par{}Cayouette (2004, p. 805) noted that "\i{}Eriophorum russeolum\i0{} subsp. \i{}leiocarpum\i0{} is quite variable, and some specimens can be considered merely as white-coloured counterparts to orange-brown \i{}E. russeolum. \i0{}Nevertheless, the spikelets of this subspecies tend to be more often ellipsoid than obovoid, the achenes more often obovoid than ellipsoid, and the achene beaks narrower on average than in subsp. This variation is encountered in all parts of subsp. \i{}leiocarpum\i0{}'s North American range\i{}.\i0{} Specimens from higher latitudes (e.g., Nunavut) tend to have more blackish medial scales, but all other characters are within the variation of the subspecies.">

<Polunin (1940, pp. 98-99) commented that in the eastern Canadian Arctic "this species varies so much in the length of the anthers and the width of the white margin to the involucral scales that it is sometimes difficult to distinguish from specimens of the generally more slender \i{}E. chamissonis\i0{} f. \i{}albidum\i0{} [in this treatment = \i{}E. russeolum\i0{}]... the shape of the head is apt to be misleading, for it, and indeed the whole appearance of the pappus, may become changed after some days of exposure to wind, rain, and snow... thus Fernald (1905, p.82) gives the length of the anther as 1 mm in \i{}E. scheuchzeri\i0{} and 1.5-3 mm in [\i{}E. russeolum\i0{}], and this allows us to separate the vast majority of specimens [at CAN]." In other Arctic regions anthers of \i{}E. scheuchzeri\i0{} apparently never overlap in length with those of \i{}E. russeolum\i0{}, but that the anthers of the quite frequent hybrids do. Polunin's difficulty in distinguishing the two species may have been due to the presence of hybrids. \par{}Ball and Wujek (2002) in their Flora North America treatment of \i{}Eriophorum\i0{} did not recognize any subspecifc taxa within \i{}E. scheuchzeri\i0{}. However, other authors have recognized infraspecific taxa; pertinent to the present discussion is \i{}E. scheuchzeri\i0{} subsp. \i{}arcticum\i0{}, which is considered to be a circumpolar or at least partly circumpolar taxon (Novoselova 2004; Cayouette 2004). \par{}Novoselova in Elven et al. (2003) noted that in Russia subspecies \i{}arcticum\i0{} differs from subspecies \i{}scheuchzeri\i0{} in: (i) slightly smaller size [(5-)7-20 cm vs 8-30 cm]; (ii) thinner culms [(0.7-)1.1-1.2(-2) mm versus (1-)1.2-1.5(-2) mm]; (iii) spherical, versus half-spherical, flowering spike; (iv) outermost scales lanceolate or rarely widely lanceolate, 0.6-0.9 cm long, with white margins, often yellowish near the apex (not widely lanceolate, rarely ovoid, 0.9-1 cm long, very rarely with narrow white margins); (v) outer scales lanceolate, long-pointed, black or dark grey with pale margins, usually with at least some red stripes of pigmented cells (not narrowly lanceolate, very long-pointed, brownish grey, with narrow pale margins, and with numerous red stripes). \par{}Cayouette (2004) revised the \i{}Eriophoum russeolum \i0{}- \i{}E. scheuchzeri\i0{} complex in North America. He noted that \i{}E. scheuchzeri\i0{} subsp. \i{}scheuchzeri\i0{} differs from other rhizomatous taxa with solitary whitish spikelets, including their hybrids with the two subspecies of \i{}E. russeolum\i0{}, by having the shortest anthers (0.35-0.8 mm) and the narrowest (0.4-1.0 mm) and most narrowly acuminate medial fertile scales. These scales are dark gray to blackish with narrow hyaline margins or with hyaline margins absent. Cayouette (2004) recognised \i{}E. scheuchzeri\i0{} subsp. \i{}arcticum\i0{},\i{} \i0{}following Novoselova (1994), and provided a table listing the main differences between the subspecies. The range of subsp. arcticum was established for northeast North America, and collections from Axel Heiberg, east central Baffin, Devon, Ellesmere, Prince Charles, Southampton Islands in Nunavut and from northern-most Quebec were confirmed as belonging to this subspecies. \par{}In the present treatment we are provisionally treating \i{}E. scheuchzeri \i0{}in the broad sense, including\i{} \i0{}subsp. \i{}arcticum\i0{}. Subspecies \i{}arcticum\i0{} appears to be the widespread and common entity in the Arctic Archipelago, while subsp. \i{}scheuchzeri\i0{} may be restricted to the southern-most arctic islands. However, the presence of specimens having characters intermediate between the two subspecies in the High Arctic, together with the mostly overlapping or non-discrete character states differentiating the subspecies make identification at the subspecies level difficult. A more thorough study of Canadian Arctic material, particularly from the western Arctic, is needed.>

<Two races have been recognised, a widely distributed subsp. \i{}vaginatum\i0{} in Eurasia and northwestern North America and a more restricted subsp. \i{}spissum\i0{} in northeastern North America and Greenland. Porsild (1957) suggested that the western subsp. \i{}vaginatum\i0{} gradually passes into subsp. \i{}spissum\i0{} east of the 100th meridian. Elven et al. (2003) accepted this concept, which was also mapped by Porsild and Cody (1980). Hultén (1968) had a different concept where the two races were largely sympatric, both occurring in Alaska and Yukon. Specimens he annotated as subsp. \i{}spissum\i0{} from Alaska (in S) are inseparable from European and type \i{}E. vaginatum\i0{} s.s. Only one taxon is recognised by Ball and Wujek (2002) in \i{}Flora of North America\i0{}. If two subspecies are accepted, the plants from Banks Melville and Victoria Islands belong to subsp. \i{}vaginatum\i0{}, those from Baffin and Southampton to subsp. \i{}spissum\i0{}.\par{}A study of the effects of variable soil oxygen and nutrient availability of \i{}E. angustifolium\i0{} and \i{}E. vaginatum\i0{} was done by Gebauer et al. (1995) near Toolik Lake, Alaska. It was shown that whole-plant growth in \i{}E. vaginatum\i0{} improved in flooded soils, but only when nitrogen availability was high. In areas of low nitrogen availability, growth was reduced by 20% compared to growth in drier more aerobic soil. \par{}The roots of \i{}E. vaginatum\i0{} have been shown to have the ability to absorb free amino acids as well as inorganic nitrogen (Chapin et al. 1993). This was the first documented example of a non-mycorrhizal plant with this capability. Such an adaptation is highly advantageous in the Arctic where inorganic nitrogen is often limiting. Factors regulating the uptake of ammonium and glycine in the field were investigated by Leadley et al. (1997). Nitrogen supply rate was found to be more important than soil factors (buffer capacity and diffusion coefficient), root density, or root uptake kinetics. \par{}Leadly et al. (1997) presented a model of nitrogen uptake by \i{}Eriophorum vaginatum\i0{} roots in the field and discuss some of the ecological implications. \par{}Moorhead et al. (1993) modelled the relative contributions of phosphatases associated with the living roots of \i{}E. vaginatum\i0{} and phosphatases associated with soil microbes to the phosphorus released from the substrate within the tussocks of the plant. They found that the former contributed 4% of the total phosphorus released, but that this amount was almost twice the annual demand for the plant. Thus, \i{}E. vaginatum\i0{} may obtain a significant amount of phosphorus from the activity of root surface phosphatase. They also found that 28% of the phosphatase activity occurred during a brief period of time in autumn when substrate availability was high. Since maximum growth occurs early in the year, \i{}E. vaginatum\i0{} must draw on reserves from the previous year to sustain growth.\par{}McGraw (1993) studied ecological genetic variation in seed banks and reported on the differentiation of extant and seed-bank-derived populations of \i{}Eriophorum vaginatum.\i0\par{}The role of \i{}E. vaginatum\i0{} in methane flux from boreal peat-lands was studied by Pullman et al. (1995).\par{}Stoner et al. (1982) studied seasonal dynamics and standing crops of biomass and nutrients in a subarctic tundra vegetation in Alaska and found the total aboveground and belowground standing crop or organic matter and biomass was greater in an \i{}E. vaginatum\i0{} tussock tundra than on an adjacent north-facing slope.>

<In the vegetative state, this species can be a challenge to distinguishe from \i{}Carex nardina\i0{}. Polunin (1940) noted that except for local variations in luxuriance, this plant appears to be much the same in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago. He predicted that in time it may be found on most ice-free land, although it had not been recorded from several considerable areas. He also observed that it is "remarkably overlooked" and for this reason possibly under-collected. \par{}\i{}Kobresia myosuroides\i0{} is reported to proliferate in "single passage" vehicle tracks through High Arctic tundra (Kevan et al. 1995). Near Lake Hazen, Ellesmere Island, vehicle tracks tend to be depleted of nutrients and generally low in vegetative cover . \par{}The roots of \i{}K. myosuroides\i0{} have been shown to have the ability to absorb free amino acids as well as inorganic nitrogen (Raab et al. 1996). Such an adaptation is highly advantageous in the Arctic where inorganic nitrogen is often limiting.>

<A local and variable species, not yet fully understood. Some authors consider \i{}K. hyperborea\i0{} and \i{}K. macrocarpa\i0{} to be distinct endemic North American species, while others include these and \i{}K. sibirica\i0{} in the southwest Asian species \i{}K. schoenoides\i0{} (C.A. Meyer) Steudel. In the Asian plants, the bisexual spikelets are reported to have three staminate flowers and no sterile scales (P. Ball, personal communication, 1998).>

<Polunin (1940) observed that \i{}K. simpliciuscula\i0{} prefers less dry and exposed places than does \i{}K. myosuroides\i0{}, often growing in quite damp meadows among grasses. It grows most frequently to about 12 cm high but sometimes exceeds 25 cm or, in unfavourable situations, may be as short as 4 cm. It is markedly calciphilous, but probably not always so (Polunin 1940). It is often badly smutted with fungus. \par{}"\i{}Kobresia simpliciuscula\i0{} s.s. does not reach the Arctic in mainland Europe and is also absent from Iceland. All Svalbard and all studied Greenland and Canada material belong to the \i{}'holarctica'\i0{} entity, which seems to be the only one in the Arctic" (Elven et al. 2003).>

<Polunin (1940, p. 104) noted that all material in the Canadian Eastern Arctic "has the orifice of the upper sheath "short" and with a firm border, and the spikelets short and few-flowered, and so belongs not to the European lowland heath form (subsp. \i{}germanicum\i0{}) but to the wide-ranging "arctic-alpine" [\i{}Scirpus caespitosus\i0{} var. \i{}callosus\i0{}] "(here \i{}Trichophorum\i0{} \i{}cespitosum\i0{}).>

<The name \i{}A. borealis\i0{} was published in 1838, and used by many authors, including Hitchcock (1905) and Porsild (1964). However, the name \i{}A. mertensii\i0{} had been applied to the same taxon since 1836. In the protologue of \i{}A. mertensii\i0{} by Trinius in 1836, the name is given as "\i{}Agrostis Mertensii\i0{} Herb. Acad. Petrop." and the localities of the species cited as "In And. Chil. austr. (Eandem legit b. Mertens in Unalaschka)". The epithet and the method of citation suggest that Trinius was basing the description primarily on Mertens's Alaskan specimen, which was designated as "the type specimen" by A.S. Hitchcock (1905). This is to be regarded as a lectotype [following Art. 9.8 of the \i{}Tokyo Code\i0{} Greuter, McNeill, et al. 1994]. \i{}Agrostis mertensii\i0{} was also published by Trinius in Agrostol. 2: 85 (1841), a preprint from Mém. Acad. St. Petersb. ser. 6 Sci. Nat. 4(1): 331 (1845). This was thought, by Hitchcock (1905) and some later authors, to be the first publication and to have post-dated the name \i{}A. borealis\i0{} Hartman. The interpretation was followed by many authors, including Porsild (1957) (personal communication, Dr. J. McNeill, Director Emeritus, Royal Ontario Museum, 1995). \par{}Tzvelev (1976, 1983) suggested that within \i{}A. mertensii\i0{} there is subsp. \i{}mertensis\i0{} and subsp.\i{} borealis\i0{} (Hartman) Tzvelev, and he provided the following key to distinguish them. \par{}Spikelets 3-4 mm long; lemma entirely scabrous due to very short spinules or pointed tubercles; tufts of hair on the callus about 0.5 mm long, 1/4 the length of the lemma...subsp. \i{}mertensii\i0{} \par{}Spikelets 2-3.5 mm long; lemma slightly scabrous only in the upper part; tufts of hair on the callus about 0.3 mm long, 1/5-1/6 the length of the lemma....subsp. \i{}borealis\i0{} \par{}In discussions with Dr. Tzvelev (Feb. 1999), he suggested that subsp. \i{}mertensii\i0{} is Beringian and subsp. \i{}borealis\i0{} has an Atlantic distribution in North America. This lead to the questions, (a) Can both species be recognised in North American material? and (b) If so, what is the distribution of the subspecies and what happens towards the middle of North America? \par{}To address these questions, Aiken examined 22 specimens, ranging in distribution from Alaska to Greenland, including Alaska 4, Yukon 2, central continental North America 7, Labrador 2, Arctic islands 3, and Greenland 4. In this limited sample, spikelet lengths ranged from 2.4 to 3.4 mm long. One northeastern Alaskan sample (CAN 327780) and one Yukon sample (CAN 31693) from within the area of Beringian distribution had spikelet lengths 2.8 and 2.5 mm long, respectively. These spikelets are shorter than the 3 mm, at least, expected for subsp. \i{}mertensii\i0{}. No spikelets 3.5-4 mm long were found in the sample. \par{}To evaluate the lemma scabrosity character, each lemma was examined at 40×, with the lemma oriented towards the light source. This allowed the tiny scabrous trichomes to be seen. Five samples had glabrous lemmas, and 17 were seen as "entirely scabrous due to very short spinules or tubercules". This character was judged to be inconspicuous, difficult to apply, and probably not reliable. \par{}Lemma and callus lengths for the 22 samples were measured. The callus lengths were measured at 40× and calculated in millimetres. Lemma lengths ranged from 1.7 to 2.8 mm; callus lengths from 0.25 to 0.5 mm. Six specimens had lemmas 2.1-2.8 long, with a callus 0.4 mm long; 8 specimens had lemmas 1.8-2.5 mm long, with a callus 0.3 mm long, and 6 specimens had lemmas 1.8-2.5 mm long, with a callus 0.3 mm long. One lemma 2.5 mm long had a callus 0.25 mm, and another lemma 2 mm long had a callus 0.35 mm. These initial observations suggested a continuum in the length ranges. While the sample size is small, no way to reliably recognise more than one taxon in \i{}A. mertensii\i0{} samples from North America was found using the characters suggested by Tzvelev (1983). In May 2002, Tzvelev agreed to drop the recognition of these subspecies in the Panarctic Flora Checklist (Elven et al. 2003).\par{}>

<The name \i{}A. magellanicus\i0{} follows Soreng et al. (2003). Before that \i{}Alopecurus borealis\i0{} Trin. was accepted as the valid name, this name replacing \i{}A. alpinus\i0{} Sm. which is predated by \i{}A. alpinus\i0{} D. Villars. (Stace 1997). \par{}The species is a high polyploid, with very variable numbers reported (2\i{}n\i0{} = 70 - about 150) and morphologically variable, with several entities described as species or subspecies. The name \i{}A. borealis\i0{} may relate to a Beringian entity (slightly) different from the main plant in the Arctic (Elven, personal communication, 2005).\par{}Porsild (1964), probably writing from his experiences in Greenland, suggested that this species is strongly nitrophilous, and with fertiliser and minimum cultivation, provides good grazing, yielding short but nourishing hay. \par{}Bell and Bliss (1978) estimated that the roots of \i{}A. borealis\i0{} live 3.4-7 years.>

<Porsild (1964) ignored var. \i{}longiglumis\i0{} Polunin, which was described from a thermal oasis on Baffin Island. Polunin (1940) described the species as "an atrocious \i{}typus polymorphus\i0{}". Aiken and Lefkovitch (1990) studied the genus, documented considerable phenotypic plasticity within the species, and found only subsp. \i{}latifolia\i0{} on the Arctic Archipelago, although subsp. \i{}arundinacea\i0{} (Trin.) Tzvelev occurs nearby on the North American continent. No reason for recognising var. \i{}longiglumis\i0{} was found. \par{}Ovenden (1986) found that \i{}Arctagrostis latifolia\i0{} and \i{}Puccinellia borealis\i0{} were common on the lake bed of Illisarvik, the site of a thermokarst lake that was artificially drained in August 1978. \par{}The nematode \i{}Anguina agrostis\i0{} Steinbuck infects spikelets and causes the ovaries to enlarge and become dark purple (Mulvey 1963). Other parts of the infected spikelet become atypical. Specimens with this infection are conspicuous and have been annotated as \i{}forma prolifera\i0{} or \i{}forma vivipara\i0{}, but these names have no taxonomic validity.>

<Tzvelev (1976) reported that \i{}A. fulva\i0{} is one of the best fodder plants and recommended it for introduction into cultivation in the northernmost regions of the USSR, "as it maintains a high nutritive value even at the fruiting stage and can be used as a pasture plant for deer even during the winter. The species is also good fodder for water birds." \par{}Tzvelev (1976) noted that in the USSR the High Arctic populations of this species, with smaller general dimensions (10-30 cm tall), narrower laminas, and fewer spikelets, are separated as subspecies \i{}similis\i0{} (Rupr.) Tzvelev but are rather only a variety, var. \i{}similis\i0{} (Rupr.) Tzvelev, to which not only the type of \i{}Poa similis\i0{} but also the type of \i{}Poa remotiflora\i0{} belong. No attempt to distinguish taxa within plants of the genus occurring in North America has been made, although considerable phenotypic plasticity, apparently often related to microclimate, has been observed. \par{}Tzvelev (1976) noted that "the affinity of the genera \i{}Arctophila\i0{} and \i{}Dupontia\i0{} is confirmed by the existence of the sterile hybrid × \i{}Arctodupontia scleroclada\i0{} (Rupr.) Tzvelev, 1973, Novosti Sist. Vyssh. Rast. 10: 91 (= \i{}Poa scleroclada\i0{} Rupr...) described from the Malaya Zemlya tundra...but recently also found on the Chukotsk Peninsula". On the basis of spikelet structure, it occupies an intermediate position between the parental genera. The intergeneric hybrid has not been reported from North America, but there are places where the two genera occur together and where the possibility of hybrid plants should be investigated, for example, on the Tuktoyaktuk Peninsula and Richards Island at the mouth of the Mackenzie River. However, in Feb. 1999, in a survey of candidate specimens at LE, the only record of the hybrid was the type collection (LE) and it is a questionable specimen. All other specimens of \i{}Arctodupontia\i0{} from the Chukotsk Peninsula were re-determined as \i{}Arctophila fulva\i0{} (R. Elven, personal communication, 1999). However, hybrid populations between \i{}Arctophila\i0{} and \i{}Dupontia\i0{} have recently been confirmed (also by molecular means) from Svalbard, Brysting and Elven (2005).\par{}Ovenden (1986) found \i{}Arctophila fulva\i0{} was an early colonising species on the lake bed of Illisarvik, the site of a thermokarst lake that was artificially drained in August 1978. \par{}Elven et al. (2003) indicated that the impressive infraspecific variation is probably too insufficiently known to allow for the recognition of any subspecific taxa. \par{}Aiken and Buck (2002) described aquatic leaves and vegetative proliferation in this taxon (additional images in the image library). They observed re-growth from apparently dead, previous season's straw that had overwintered in the Arctic. Observations on transplanted material and field observations documented that new shoots grew from the apex, and nodes of the previous season's stems. Strong underground rhizomes, and roots developed, resulting in propagules able to develop into new plants. The previous season's straw that regenerates is probably detached by animals mid-season, before food reserved in the stems are withdrawn to the rhizomes and roots. Such regeneration of detached straw that has overwintered had not been reported previous for any other grass species.>

<This taxon is characterised by having a long stem with 4-5 exposed nodes, leaves that are often flat and very scabrous on the abaxial surface. A single specimen was collected on Baffin Island beside the Soper River in 2002. The species occurs in southern Greenland and is not unexpected on Baffin Island\par{}Greene (1980) considered that this taxon, which he recognised as a variety, differs from var. \i{}canadensis\i0{} in having firm glumes that are 4-6 mm long, rarely hyaline, strongly scabrous on the back, often short-ciliate on the keel. \par{}The name is based on \i{}Arundo langsdorfii\i0{} Link 1821. When he transferred the name to Calamagrostis in 1824, Trinius corrected Link's orthographic error; Link named the species after a Langsdorff, not Langsdorf: thus the name is \i{}Calamagrostis langsdorffii\i0{} (Link) Trin. (Greene, personal communication, 1999). Hultén, who had broad experience on both sides of the Bering Straits, treated \i{}langsdorffii\i0{} as \i{}C. canadensis\i0{} subsp. \i{}langsdorffii\i0{} (Link) Hultén (1942).\par{}Greene indicated that in \i{}Calamagrostis\i0{} he used subspecies only when there seemed to be clear cytological and/or morphological distinctions between entities, such as the primarily 2\i{}n \i0{}= 28 sexual \i{}C. stricta\i0{} subsp. \i{}stricta\i0{} and the 2\i{}n \i0{}= 42-114+ polyploid apomictic complex he named \i{}C. stricta\i0{} subsp. \i{}inexpansa\i0{}. In the case of \i{}C. canadensis\i0{} Greene chose to recognise varieties because the taxa (such as var. \i{}langsdorffii\i0{}) seems to intergrade with var. \i{}canadensis\i0{} in morphology, chromosome number, and reproductive mode. He noted that with more experimental work, these entities may show enough distinctions to be treated as distinct subspecies as opposed to varieties (personal communication, Greene, 1999). \par{}It was the opinion of Greene (when writing the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment of this genus, Marr et al. 2007) that if one accepts that \i{}C. purpurea\i0{} and \i{}C. canadensis\i0{} are synonymous, then \i{}C. canadensis\i0{} (Michx.) Beauv. 1812 (based on \i{}Arundo canadensis\i0{} Michx. 1803) has priority over \i{}C. purpurea \i0{}(Trin.) Trin. 1824 (based on \i{}Arundo purpurea\i0{} Trin. 1821). Greene considered \i{}C. canadensis\i0{} in North America and \i{}C. purpurea\i0{} in northern Eurasia to be manifestations of the same circumpolar species/agamic complex, but that tradition has kept the names separate in regional floras. \par{}Elven et al. (2003) agreed that \i{}C. purpurea\i0{} is probably a basal sexual species of the aggregate. \i{}Calamagrostis canescens\i0{} (Weber) Roth 1789 (based on \i{}Arundo canescens\i0{} Weber 1780) is another sexual tetraploid. If the entire aggregate is merged, then it also has to include \i{}C. canescens\i0{}, and then this name would have priority before \i{}C. canadensis\i0{}. It is therefore best to keep the high-polyploid agamosperms separate, in which case the name \i{}C. canadensis\i0{} can be used for the Canadian plants. It is also justified to keep basal sexuals and derived and assumed allopolyploid agamics as separate species.\par{}Elven et al. (2003) noted that Löve and Löve (1975) separated 'species' in this aggregate purely on basis of ploidy levels. They considered \i{}C. canescens\i0{} and \i{}C. angustifolia\i0{} (subsp. \i{}tenuis\i0{}) as tetraploids, \i{}C. canadensis\i0{} as hexaploid, and \i{}C. phragmitoides\i0{} and \i{}C. langsdorffii\i0{} as octoploids. They did not include in their Atlas the multitude of deviating numbers reported for these taxa, and they sorted numbers among taxa without much consideration of the names given by the original reporters (Tateoka 1973, Mitchell 1968, and Greene 1984). \par{}Elven et al. (2003) discussed the \i{}Calamagrostis canadensis\i0{} aggregate (\i{}C. canadensis\i0{} s.l., \i{}C. phragmitoides\i0{}, \i{}C. tenuis\i0{}) and noted that this aggregate expresses many of the same traits as the \i{}C. purpurascens\i0{} aggregate and \i{}C. neglecta\i0{} s.l., i.e., the presence of morphologically more or less distinguishable sexual tetraploids and less well-defined apomictic high-ploids. There are strong indications that the apomicts are alloploids.\par{}>

<Porsild (1957) mapped a single record from Nunavut, Baffin Island, Iqaluit. It is presumably based on the specimens \i{}J.A. Calder, 2155\i0{}, 25 July 1948, gravel along Sylvia Grinnell River. Only 1 small colony. DAO 19019 and DAO 106575. Sheet DAO 19019 was annotated as \i{}C. lapponica\i0{} (Wahlenb.) Hartm. in 1951, by P. Ls-M l'Institute Agricole d'Oka, with the note, the culm and leaves a little stiff, but the awn and callus-hairs are quite typical; trichomes not well developed. In early July, 2004, Aiken found previous season's \i{}Calamagrostis\i0{} straw in a small patch near the Sylvia Grinnell River opposite the end of the runway. It is known from their diaries that Senn and Calder, who botanised around Iqaluit in 1948, used to travel to the end of the runway with the water truck that drove down regularly to obtain water for the Military base at Crystal 2. \par{}Elven examined the \i{}Calder 2155\i0{} specimen in May, 2005, and annotated it as \i{}C. lapponicum\i0{} because the specimen has relatively short leaves, few nodes culm nodes exposed, leaves that tend to be inrolled and glabrous or almost glabrouse on the abaxial surface. Elven noted that the species is a polyplid and never found with functional anthers. The sterial anther "ghosts" may remain in the inflorescences long after flowering.>

<The name of the species is disputed, as \i{}Calamagrostis neglecta\i0{} or \i{}C. stricta\i0{}. These two names refer to the same species or subspecies. The priority name \i{}C. neglecta\i0{} was rejected because it had been assumed to apply a to previously described \i{}A. halleri\i0{} Willd., and therefore \i{}A. neglecta\i0{} becomes a nomen illegitimum. However, this was argued by Tzvelev (1973) , who reinstated \i{}C. neglecta\i0{}. Soreng et al. (2003) treated \i{}C. neglecta\i0{} as a nom. illeg. superfl. but do not appear to have considered Tzvelev's arguements. As long as it has not finally been refuted, we use here the priority name, \i{}C. neglecta\i0{}.\par{}The \i{}'neglecta groenlandica'\i0{} entity is mainly or entirely tetraploid and sexual. It is also heterogeneous, and both Russians (Tzvelev) and North Americans (Soreng et al. 2003) accept two races, a mainly boreal subsp. \i{}neglecta\i0{} (subsp. \i{}stricta\i0{}) that does not reach the islands, and a subsp. \i{}groenlandica\i0{} that does. \par{}Elven (personal communication, 2005) drew attention to a specimen he collected that belongs to \i{}C. neglecta\i0{} subsp. \i{}groenlandica\i0{}: Melville Island SE: Valley W of Beverley Inlet, inland from Skene Bay, S of and near lake. 75° 03.595'N 107° 50.017'W. 13.08.1999. Leg. R. Elven (O). This supplements the earlier record from Mould Bay, Prince Patrick Island, indicating this taxon is present in the western arctic islands and not merely an accidental introduction by planes landing at Mould Bay.\par{}Greene annotated three specimens from the Canadian Arctic Archipelago as \i{}C. stricta\i0{} var.\i{} borealis\i0{} var. (Laest.) Hartm. in 1997, presumably planning to recognise this taxon in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment. Data from specimens that Greene annotated have been used to gather the data used to describe this taxon.\par{}Another entity that is part of the \i{}C. neglecta\i0{} aggregate (Elven et al. 2003) is the \i{}'inexpansa'\i0{} entity, which is probably entirely high-polyploid and agamospermic. Greene suggested it as a case of autopolyploidy, and therefore considered it a subspecies of \i{}C. neglecta\i0{} (\i{}C. stricta\i0{} in his treatment). It is found in continental arctic regions of North America (Greene 1980) but has not yet been confirmed in the Flora region.\par{}\par{}>

<Elven et al. (2003) noted that Tzvelev considered that the \i{}C. purpurascens\i0{} aggregate "includes species \i{}C. arctica\i0{}, \i{}C. maltei\i0{}, \i{}C. poluninii\i0{}, \i{}C. purpurascens\i0{}, and \i{}C. sesquiflora\i0{}. The aggregate contains sexual tetraploids both in Asia and North America, in \i{}C. purpurascens\i0{} s.s. and in \i{}C. sesquiflora\i0{}, and probably apomictic hexaploids, octoploids, and possibly decaploids." The plants with higher chromosome numbers are probably agamospermic but whether these are auto-polyploids, allo-polyploids, or the product of a combination of these is unknown. \par{}If the entities could be documented as morphologically and geographically definable parts of an agamic complex, recognition at some taxonomic level would be relevant. Soreng et al. (2003) follow this up by recognition of the tetraploid Beringian \i{}C. sesquiflora\i0{} (also including \i{}C. arctica\i0{}).\par{}Greene (1980) analysed the variation in both morphology and cytology of North American taxa. He found reasons to divide\i{} C. purpurescens \i0{}into two varieties only, var. \i{}purpurascens\i0{} (including \i{}C. maltei\i0{} and \i{}C. yukonensis\i0{} Nash) and var. \i{}laricina\i0{} (including \i{}C. poluninii\i0{}). Greene did not, however, consider the Beringian (American) plants.\par{}The two taxa are distinguished by a few characters, but they are largely allopatric. Both reach the Arctic area; var. \i{}purpurascens\i0{} in Alaska, north mainland NWT, the Canadian Arctic Archipelago, and central and northern Greenland, and var. \i{}laricina\i0{} in north mainland NWT, the Ungava area, and southwestern Greenland (as \i{}C. poluninii\i0{}).>

<Löve and Löve (1975) 'adjusted' the counts so as to fit a uniformly tetraploid (2\i{}n\i0{} = 52) concept of \i{}D. alpina\i0{}, while they indicated that plants counted under this name, but with 2\i{}n\i0{} = 26 and 39, could be hybrids. As seen from the above, the 2\i{}n\i0{} = 52 counts are in the minority. In northern Norway and Svalbard, plants that fit the diagnostic characters of \i{}D. alpina\i0{} are counted with 2\i{}n\i0{} = about 39, 41, 49, and 50, and in several of these areas there is no possibility of (recent) hybridisation, as this is the only \i{}Deschampsia\i0{} present. The uniformly tetraploid chromosome number of the Löves that should characterise this species is therefore unknown from what is the type area of \i{}D. alpina\i0{} (northern Fennoscandia, "Lapponia"). This does not exclude that the entire 'species' is an old hybrid complex, probably involving \i{}D. cespitosa\i0{}, that has turned to vivipary. The few diploid counts of 2\i{}n\i0{} = 26 may originate from occasionally vegetatively proliferating \i{}D. cespitosa\i0{} s.s. and not from \i{}D. alpina\i0{}. \par{}This amphi-Atlantic bulbil-reproducing entity differs from \i{}D. cespitosa\i0{} (\i{}D. cespitosa\i0{} subsp. \i{}cespitosa\i0{}) in other characters besides the production of bulbils and is morphologically separable from the occasional vegetatively proliferating forms of subsp. \i{}cespitosa\i0{}. If the taxon is shown to be an autopolyploid derivative of subsp. \i{}cespitosa\i0{} it might be better treated as a subspecies of \i{}D. cespitosa\i0{}, as done by Tzvelev (1976) and Clarke (1980). However, if the taxon is shown to be an alloploid, \i{}D. brevifolia\i0{} might be the other parent (Elven et al. 2003).>

<This taxon was considered part of a \i{}D. cespitosa\i0{} \ldblquote{}complex\rdblquote{} by Kawano (1963, 1966) who investigated the cytogeography and evolution of members of the complex from many parts of the world, including the Canadian Arctic. He reported on the hypothetical relationships of members of the \i{}D. cespitosa\i0{} complex, with chromosome numbers ranging from 2\i{}n\i0{} = 26, 28, 35, 38, 39, 41, 49, 52, to 56 and noted that Tateoka (1955) and Bowden (1960b) had reported the existence of \ldblquote{}B\rdblquote{} or supernumerary chromosomes in \i{}D. cespitosa\i0{}. \par{}Porsild (1964) recognised \i{}D. cespitosa\i0{} (now considered an excluded taxon) and three other taxa within the genus \i{}Deschampsia\i0{}, i.e., \i{}D. alpina\i0{}, \i{}D. brevifolia\i0{}, and \i{}D. pumila\i0{} (see \i{}D. sukatschewii \i0{}(Popl.) Roshev. subsp. \i{}borealis\i0{} (Trautv.) Tzvelev). \par{}Aiken et al. (1995) attempted to follow Porsild (1957) and recognise both \i{}D. cespitosa\i0{} subsp. \i{}cespitosa\i0{} and \i{}D. cespitosa\i0{} subsp. \i{}brevifolia\i0{}. Further field work has established that there is a single, phenotypically plastic taxon in the Canadian Arctic, similar to the type recognised by Robert Brown from Melville Island as \i{}D. brevifolia\i0{}. The taxa \i{}D. cespitosa\i0{} s.s. and \i{}D. glauca\i0{}, as understood in northern Europe, probably do not occur in the Canadian Arctic unless they have been introduced (Elven, personal communication, 2005). \par{}The phenotypic plasticity in this taxon was observed in plants transplanted from Eureka Sound, Ellesmere Island (80°09'N, 86°00'W), in 1990, to Iqaluit, Baffin Island (64°44'N, 68°28'W), and Ottawa, Ontario (45°18'N, 75°50'W). Over a 3-year period the plants grown in Iqaluit became smaller and more stunted. Many of the 10 plants grown in Ottawa died, but the one illustrated in the image library became larger and with more diffuse inflorescences as photographed in 1994. In the photograph, the previous season\rquote{}s inflorescence as seen in the straw has tightly appressed branches, the 1994 inflorescences have spreading branches. The voucher for the original collection is of a plant approximately 16 cm high, whereas the voucher for the photograph in the image library is a plant 32-33 cm high and documents the phenotypic plasticity expressed. \par{}The very short awn is sometimes absent or broken and often overlooked, resulting in small specimens being misidentified as \i{}Poa\i0{} species.\par{}>

<This taxon was known in Canada as \i{}D. pumila\i0{} (Griseb.) Ostenf. (Porsild 1957, Bowden 1960b, Hultén 1968). Tzvelev (1976) recognised that \i{}D. pumila\i0{} is a later homonym of \i{}D. pumila\i0{} Steven. ex Fomin and Waronow, referable to \i{}Catabrosa\i0{}. He recognised the taxon at the subspecific level of \i{}D. cespitosa\i0{} subsp. \i{}paramushirensis\i0{}, distinguishing it from \i{}D. cespitosa\i0{} subsp. \i{}borealis\i0{} Hultén (1968), and he placed the name \i{}D. borealis\i0{} (Trautv.) Roshev. into synonymy under \i{}D. pumila\i0{}. A comparison of characters from Canadian and Eurasian specimens, considered to be this taxon, is given in McLachlan et al. (1989), Table 2. \par{}The combination \i{}D. sukatschewii\i0{} (Popl.) Roshev subsp. \i{}borealis\i0{} (Trautv.) Tzvelev was published by Tzvelev (2000). The Panarctic Flora project Elven et al. (2003) suggests that North American plants assigned to this species may belong to two subspecies, a seashore or coastal plant that is different from a more northern arctic 'moss cushion'. It is possible that in Canada there is an eastern Arctic taxon, subspecies \i{}borealis\i0{}, and a western Arctic taxon \i{}D. sukatschewii\i0{} (Popl.) Roshev. subsp. \i{}orientalis \i0{}(Hultén) Tzvelev.\par{}Elven examined specimens from the Canadian Arctic Archipelgo (May 2005) and concluded that those from the eastern and western islands are all subsp. \i{}borealis.\i0{}>

<The genus \i{}Dupontia\i0{} R. Br. was named "in honour of Monsieur Dupont, of Paris, author of a valuable essay on the sheaths of the leaves of grasses, and observations on the genus \i{}Atriplex\i0{}". The species name \i{}fisheri \i0{}"was that of Mr. Fisher, whose herbarium contained the most complete series of specimens of this grass" (Brown 1823). The type was collected on Melville Island, Canadian Arctic Archipelago. In 1841, \i{}Dupontia fisheri\i0{} var. \i{}flavescens\i0{} Hooker and Arnott was recognised. It had yellow anthers and was based on a specimen from Kotzebue Sound, Alaska (Hooker and Arnott 1841). This taxon name does not appear to have been used since then. \i{}Poa \i0{}(\i{}Dupontia\i0{})\i{} psilosantha\i0{} Rupr.\i{} \i0{}and \i{}P.\i0{} (\i{}Dupontia\i0{})\i{} pelligera\i0{} Rupr. were recognised by Ruprecht (1846). The former has been recognised as a species, \i{}D. psilosantha\i0{} (Rupr.) Griseb.; a subspecies, \i{}D. fisheri\i0{} subsp. \i{}psilosantha\i0{} (Rupr.) Hultén; a variety, \i{}D. fisheri\i0{} var. \i{}psilosantha\i0{} (Rupr.) Trautv.; and a forma, \i{}D. fisheri\i0{} f. \i{}psilosantha\i0{} (Rupr.) Polunin. The latter has been recognised as a species, \i{}D. pelligera \i0{}(Rupr.) Á. Löve and Ritchie; a subspecies, \i{}D. fisheri\i0{} subsp. \i{}pelligera \i0{}(Rupr.) Tzvel.; and a variety \i{}D. fisheri\i0{} var. \i{}pelligera \i0{}(Rupr.) Trautv.\b{} \b0{}When Ruprecht (1846) described \i{}D. pelligera\i0{} he commented that "whether this is \i{}D. fisheri\i0{} R.Br. without comparative original specimens I scarcely dare to decide". He had not seen the Robert Brown type that was collected from the Canadian Arctic Archipelago. \par{}Holm (1907) recognised \i{}D. micrantha \i0{}Holm, claiming that it was readily distinguished from \i{}D. fisheri\i0{} and \i{}D.\i0{} \i{}psilosantha \i0{}by the small size of the spikelets and very narrow leaves. He based his description on material from Halton, Labrador (collected by Waghorne, CAN 36774), and Cape Henrietta, Hudson Bay, northern Quebec (Cape Henrietta, collected by Spreadborough, CAN 513741). \par{}Polunin (1940) commented that many authors had pointed out the impossibility of keeping \i{}D. psilosantha\i0{} as a distinct species and reduced the taxon to a forma. He admitted that the type material of \i{}D. fisheri\i0{} has the glumes more or less obtuse and the lemmas hairy at the base, and that plants assigned to \i{}psilosantha\i0{} are strikingly different 'at least in their extreme development'. Polunin (1940) also noted that in 1936, during numerous field observations in the Eastern Arctic, he had found such a great range of variation, even in closely contiguous plants in the same stand, that he concluded 'Holm's plant is a mere \i{}forma depauperata\i0{}'\i{} \i0{}and generally the result of 'a competition effect'. He reduced the taxon to \i{}D. fisheri \i0{}f.\i{} micrantha \i0{}(Holm) Polunin. He observed what he considered to be a striking aristate form geographically delimited in the Eastern Arctic. It had been named provisionally, on herbarium material, by Malte before he died, and was formally recognised by Polunin (1940) as \i{}D. fisheri\i0{} var. \i{}aristata\i0{} Malte ex Polunin. \par{}Porsild (1964) recognised this taxon and also \i{}D. fisheri\i0{} subsp. \i{}psilosantha\i0{} (Rupr.) Hultén, which we have placed in synonymy with \i{}D. fisheri\i0{}. While extreme morphological expressions occur, there appears to be a continuum of variation among Canadian specimens. \par{}The characters used to separate subspecies in northern Europe and Russia, e.g., shape of glumes, number of florets per spikelet, lemma hairiness, and anther length, do not align consistently among North American samples (Brysting et al. 2003). \par{}Brysting et al. (2003) studied the genus \i{}Dupontia\i0{} from herbarium specimens, including types and chromosome vouchers, by numerical taxonomy, mapping the distribution of morphological characteristics, consideration of chromosome numbers, and field work in the Canadian Arctic. They concluded that morphological characters, used in the literature to divide the genus \i{}Dupontia \i0{}into more than one taxon, cannot be reliably applied to distinguish most North American plants. In North America, we might see two endpoints, which correspond, more or less, to \i{}D. psilosantha \i0{}and \i{}D. fisheri\i0{}, respectively, as these two are recognised in the floras of, for instance, Greenland and Svalbard. However, as suggested by Polunin (1940), there appears to be a continuum of variation among North American specimens and too many intermediate forms that exist, which are impossible to place in two or three categories. Even though only a limited sample of Eurasian specimens were included in the analyses, there is no reason to believe that the inclusion of more specimens from this part of the Arctic will change this conclusion. On the contrary, the continuity in measurements will probably be even more evident. Until further evidence is available, Brysting et al. (2003, 2004) suggest that the genus is treated as monotypic. \par{}Molecular evidence supports the use of a wide species concept (Brysting et al. 2004). DNA sequence data (trnL-trnF, ITS; including plants from Russia, Svalbard, Canada, and Alaska) revealed almost no variation within \i{}Dupontia\i0{}. Only a couple of base pair changes, which were related neither to ploidy levels nor to geography, were found. DNA fingerprinting analysis (AFLP, Amplified Fragment Length Polymorphism) sorted the \i{}Dupontia\i0{} material first of all according to geography (Russia, North America, and Svalbard). Within each geographical region, there was a tendency for plants that were sorted according to ploidy level, suggesting that the ploidy levels have most likely arisen several times within the arctic area. \par{}Two main ploidy levels have been reported in the literature and associated with different taxa: 2\i{}n\i0{} = 42, 44 (4\i{}x\i0{}) and 2\i{}n\i0{} = 84, 88 (8\i{}x\i0{}). The variation in chromosome numbers within each ploidy level is probably the result of B-chromosomes, which are obviously present in these plants (Flovik 1938). \par{}Two counts of 2\i{}n\i0{} = 132 have previously been reported from Arctic Canada, Southampton Island, and Devon Island (Bowden 1960b, Löve and Löve, in Löve 1975a). Results from recent chromosome counts and flow cytometry (Brysting et al. 2004) have revealed that this high ploidy level (2\i{}n\i0{} = 126-132) is widely distributed in Arctic Canada and Alaska and mainly associated with tall, coarse plants with more or less spreading branches. Löve and Ritchie (1966) assigned the three ploidy levels to three different species: \i{}D. psilosantha\i0{} was considered a tetraploid with 2\i{}n\i0{} = 44, \i{}D. pelligera\i0{} an octoploid with 2\i{}n\i0{} = 88, and \i{}D. fisheri\i0{} a decaploid with 2\i{}n\i0{} =132. However, Lipkin (1983) identified \i{}D. fisheri\i0{} subsp. \i{}fisheri\i0{} with the octoploid cytotype (2\i{}n\i0{} = 88), the type material of which is from Melville Island, Canadian Arctic Archipelago. This is in agreement with recent chromosome counts of 2\i{}n\i0{} = 88 for plants from Prince Patrick Island, which are morphologically inseparable from the type material (Brysting et al. 2004). \par{}Tzvelev (1976) reported that "The affinity of the genera \i{}Arctophila\i0{} and \i{}Dupontia\i0{}, is confirmed by the existence of the sterile hybrid ?\i{}Arctodupontia scleroclada\i0{} (Rupr.) [Tzvelev (1973), Novosti Sist. Vyssh. Rast. 10: 91]. = \i{}Poa scleroclada\i0{} Rupr. described from the Malaya Zemlya tundra, but recently also found on the Chukotsk Peninsula]." On the basis of spikelet structure, it occupies an intermediate position between the parental genera. However, in Feb. 1999, in a survey of candidate specimens at LE, all specimens of \i{}Arctodupontia\i0{} from the Chukotsk Peninsula were redetermined as \i{}Arctophila fulva\i0{}.>

<A circumpolar, polymorphic species. Within this taxon several species and subspecies have been distinguished on the basis of the following characters: leaf width, blade surfaces glabrous or pubescent, inflorescence length, glume length and width, and the presence or absence of glume and lemma hairs, the bloom on leaves, the presence or absence of small sharp papillae on culms, the width of the hyaline margins on the glumes and lemma and where trichomes occur on these structures. It is here treated as an aggregate, and the description includes the extremes of variation found in Arctic Island material. More synonymy for this complex, including specimens from outside our area, is suggested by Löve (1984), and many other names have been applied to morphological extremes of the complex by Russian authors as indicated by Tzvelev (1976). \i{}Elymus alaskanus\i0{} is the name used by A. Melderis (1980) in \i{}Flora Europaea\i0{}, Kartesz (1994), and Barkworth et al. (2007).>

<While McNeill and Dore (1976) suggested that \i{}F. baffinensis\i0{} may be a subspecies of \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{}, species status was supported in isozyme studies (Aiken et al. 1993, 1995b, 1997) and by studies of material from Svalbard (Fjellheim et al. 2001, Guldahl et al. 2001). \par{}The plants from east Chukotka (LE) deviate towards \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{} in general habit but confirm with \i{}F. baffinensis\i0{} in formal characters (e.g., hairs on the ovary). This seems to be the only place within its range where there might be a problem identifying this species (Elven et al. 2003). It has often been considered a part of the \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{} aggregate but may not be very closely related to it (Aiken and Elven, in Elven et al. 2005).\par{}Fjellheim et al. (2001) evaluated morphological and RAPD DNA variation in four members of the \i{}Festuca brachyphylla \i0{}complex occurring on Svalbard and found \i{}Festuca baffinensis\i0{} was the most distinct taxon.\par{}Guldahl et al. (2001) studied the variation in the \i{}Festuca brachyphylla\i0{} (Poaceae) complex in Svalbard, elucidated by chromosome numbers and isozymes.>

<A phenotypically plastic, hexaploid species, this is the most widespread \i{}Festuca\i0{} in the Arctic islands (Aiken et al. 1993, 1995b). \par{}Aiken et al. (1993) used variation in isozyme patterns to assess species boundaries in North American arctic and alpine representatives of the \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{} - (\i{}F. ovina\i0{}) complex. They found that isozyme profiles, in combination with chromosome numbers, delimited four discrete entities with the complex: \i{}F. brevissima\i0{} Jurtzev (diploid); F. aggr.\i{} auriculata\i0{} Drobov (diploid, neither occur on the Arctic islands); \i{}F. baffinensis\i0{} Polunin (tetraploid); and \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{} (hexaploid). Some alleles observed in the polyploid taxa were not detected among the diploids, and some observed in \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{}, the hexaploid taxon, were not detected among the diploids. They suggested that one possible explanation for these occurrences is that the North America polyploids originated in Eurasia where there are many other potential diploid and tetraploid progenitors. \par{}Guldahl et al. (2001) studied the \i{}Festuca brachyphylla\i0{} complex in Svalbard, considering chromosome counts, enzymatic, and ecological variation. In a revision of herbarium material she found that \i{}F. edlundiae \i0{}was the most widely distributed species, followed by \i{}F. baffinensis. Festuca brachyphylla \i0{}seemed to be restricted to the favourable fjord areas on central Spitsbergen, whereas \i{}F. hyperborea\i0{} was rare. Chromosome counts were made on several populations of each of the Svalbard species. Three were tetraploid, \i{}F. baffinensis, F. edlundiae,\i0{} and \i{}F. hyperborea\i0{}, and one was hexaploid, \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{}. \i{}Festuca ovina\i0{} from northern Norway was electrophoretically close to the \i{}F. brachyphylla \i0{}complex in Svalbard. \i{}Festuca brachyphylla\i0{}, \i{}F. edlundiae\i0{}, and \i{}F. hyperborea\i0{} all had an electrophoretically stronger affinity to \i{}F. ovina\i0{} than to \i{}F. baffinensis,\i0{} strengthening the impression that the complex may be an artificial taxonomic group. The close affinities between \i{}F. ovina\i0{}, and at least three of the species of the \i{}F. brachyphlla\i0{} complex suggested that they have at least one genome in common. Possible parental species may be found in the Beringina area, where the \i{}F. brachyphylla \i0{}and\i{} F. ovina\i0{} complexes probably have a long history of contact, and where diploids (i.e., \i{}F. brevissima\i0{} and \i{}F. lenensis\i0{}) from both complexes are reported. \par{}Fjellheim et al. (2001) evaluated morphological and RAPD DNA variation in members of the \i{}Festuca brachyphylla\i0{} complex occurring on Svalbard. The overall level of genetical variation within the complex was low. In each of \i{}F. baffinensis\i0{} and \i{}F. hyperborea\i0{} a single phenotype was observed in all except one, and in \i{}F. edlundiae,\i0{} 12 RAPD phenotypes were observed. These three taxa appeared to be related.\i{} Festuca baffinensis\i0{} was the most distinct taxon. \par{}The tetraploid chromosome counts from Russia (Sokolovskaya and Probatova, in Tzvelev 1976) refer to \i{}F. edlundiae\i0{} (vouchers in LE investigated). Only hexaploid counts are known from verified vouchers of this species (Aiken and Elven, working in LE, 1998, unpublished).>

<First discovered by B. May in isozyme studies reported by Aiken et al. (1994, 1995b). The\i{} Festuca\i0{} plants had been collected on Bathurst Island and were a mixture of this taxon and \i{}F. hyperborea\i0{}. The two species differ in having distinct isozyme profiles for at least five isozymes, and in the size and shape of the flag leaves, the size of spikelets, and the shape of the upper glumes. Plants with the isozyme profiles of \i{}F. edlundiae\i0{} were collected from eight sites on five of the Queen Elizabeth Islands in 1992, and from Ellesmere Island in 1993. All sites are highly calcareous with fine-grained mineral soils. A herbarium study found specimens from 30 other locations including sites in northern Greenland and the former U.S.S.R. Morphological and isozyme characteristics were used to distinguish \i{}F. edlundiae\i0{} from \i{}F. baffinensis, F. brachyphylla\i0{}, and \i{}F. hyperborea\i0{}. The specific epithet honours Dr. S.A. Edlund for her extensive and intensive contributions to Arctic field work and her studies of the vegetation in the Arctic Archipelago over many years (Aiken et al. 1995b). \par{}Fjellheim et al. (2001) evaluated morphological and RAPD DNA variation in members of the \i{}Festuca brachyphylla \i0{}complex occurring on Svalbard and observed 12 RAPD phenotypes in \i{}F. edlundiae. \par{}\i0{}Guldahl et al. (2001) studied the \i{}Festuca brachyphylla\i0{} complex in Svalbard, considering chromosome counts, enzymatic, and ecological variation. In a revision of herbarium material she found that \i{}F. edlundiae \i0{}was the most widely distributed species.>

<This species was mentioned in Porsild (1964) but not mapped, although he believed it to occur on the northern islands of the Canadian Arctic Archipelago. \i{}Festuca hyperborea\i0{} was distinguished by Holmen (1952), but the name was not validly published until a study by Frederiksen (1977). Discussed in Aiken et al. (1994, 1995b). \par{}Elven et al. (2003) noted that only tetraploids (2\i{}n\i0{} = 28) are known from verified \i{}F. hyperborea\i0{}. The Russian counts of Sokolovskaya and Probatova, in Tzvelev (1976), were made on material identified from the insufficient first description of Holmen (1952). The investigated chromosome vouchers in LE represent \i{}F. edlundiae\i0{} (2\i{}n\i0{} = 28) and small-grown \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{} (2\i{}n\i0{} = 42) (Aiken and Elven, unpublished, 1999). Most of the counts referred to this species by Löve and Löve (1975) must be critically checked against vouchers, as some of them may refer to the later described \i{}F. edlundiae\i0{}. \par{}A revision of large parts of the materials in LE proved \i{}F. hyperborea\i0{} to be very rare in Russia. Alexeev had applied Holmen's very insufficient criteria and determined nearly all small-grown \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{} as \i{}F. hyperborea\i0{}. We (Aiken and Elven 1998) found evidence for \i{}F. hyperborea\i0{} in the restricted sense of Frederiksen (1977), Aiken et al. (1995b), Guldahl (1999), Fjellheim et al. (2001), and Guldahl et al. (2001), only from a very few areas: northernmost Taimyr, Severnaya Zemlya, and perhaps Novosiberian Islands. All plants named as such from Chukotka and Wrangel Island were reidentified. The regions in Russian Far East are therefore omitted from the distributional parts of the Panarctic Flora Checklist (Elven et al. 2003). \par{}The same may be the case in North America. During a 1999 expedition, \i{}F. hyperborea\i0{} was only found in the northernmost, coldest parts of the Canadian Arctic. The tetraploid counts of Aiken et al. (1995b) also came from these areas. It is very easy to mistake small-grown \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{} for \i{}F. hyperborea\i0{}. Elven claimed to have seen no specimens from Alaska of this species (Elven, personal communication, 2001).>
<An important, commercially available turf grass and probably deliberately introduced to the Arctic islands in several Arctic communities as a potential lawn grass, and to stabilise steep roadsides.>

<Taxonomically, Elven et al. (2003) noted that this is a very complicated complex, "as indicated for Europe by Markgraf-Dannenberg (1980, Fl. Eur. 5) who recognised about 14 species and split \i{}F. rubra\i0{} s.s. into seven subspecies. All ploidy levels from di- to decaploid are reported. There seems, however, to be one main hexaploid entity everywhere in the Arctic, even if it goes by different names (\i{}arctica\i0{}, \i{}cryophila\i0{}, \i{}mutica\i0{}, \i{}richardsonii\i0{}). The characters given by Markgraf-Dannenberg also mostly hold true, even if hairiness of the lemmas may vary. The main problem is the other, more southern 'races' that reach the Arctic both as natives in some areas (at least in northern Fennoscandia, Svalbard, southern Greenland, and Alaska) and sometimes as deliberate introductions."\par{}The name \i{}'arenaria'\i0{} has been widely used for the major arctic race until fairly recently. All checked records of \i{}F. arenaria\i0{} or \i{}F. rubra\i0{} subsp. \i{}arenaria\i0{} in the Arctic are referrable to \i{}F. rubra.\i0{} subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{}. Subspecies \i{}arctica\i0{} and subsp. \i{}arenaria\i0{} have the hairy lemmas in common, but little else. As currently understood, subsp. \i{}arenaria\i0{} is confined to western European sand dunes north to southwestern Norway and the southern Baltic, but very far from the Arctic.\par{}Elven et al. (2003) noted that no exact reference to a type of Hackel's \i{}'arctica'\i0{} had been found whereas there is a clearly identifiable type of Hooker's \i{}'richardsonii'\i0{} ("Arctic Coast, 1826, new", leg. Dr. Richardson). This was an argument for using the name subsp. \i{}richardsonii\i0{} instead of subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{} even if the latter has priority as subspecies. The identity of the Russian \i{}F. cryophila\i0{} Krecz. and Bobrov and the North American \i{}F. richardsonii\i0{} Hooker with subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{} is assumed but not finally proved as long as we have not compared types. \par{}This entity differs from \i{}F.rubra\i0{} s. s. in several characters, partly assumed independent (awn length, lemma hairiness, leaf width and structure), but there is an even transition between subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{} and subsp. \i{}rubra\i0{} at least in the Fennoscandian area, Greenland and northern Yukon. For this reason the taxon is treated as a subspecies rather than species. The well-documented counts are hexaploid (and possibly octoploid).>

<Porsild (1964) mentions \i{}F. vivipara\i0{} (L.) Sm., noting that the Canadian specimens are similar to \i{}F. baffinensis\i0{} and \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{}, but the panicle is always proliferous. Frederiksen (1981) stated that "according to a handwritten note by Holmen, the chromosome number given for Plantae Vasculares Groenlandicae Exsiccatae nr. 22 belongs to the above-mentioned holotype. The number 2\i{}n\i0{} = 56 was published (Holmen and Laegaard 1960), but re-examination shows 2\i{}n\i0{} = 49 to be correct, and as far as I know, no other numbers have been known from Greenland... 2\i{}n\i0{} = 56 was found in material from Alaska and Wrangel Island." This species has very often been connected with \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{}, and morphologically it looks very much like this species. In the few cases where anthers were observed, they were about 2 mm. As \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{} is very distinct because of its very short anthers, rarely if ever exceeding 1.2 mm (Frederiksen 1977), and as \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{} has the leaf sheaths partly split while they are always open in \i{}F. vivipara\i0{}, no close connection seems to exist between these two taxa. On the other hand \i{}F. vivipara\i0{} subsp. \i{}glabra\i0{} seems isolated from the two other subspecies in nearly all examined characters; thus it possibly has another origin.\par{}A specimen at CAN, which was annotated by Signe Frederiksen in 1987, was collected on Ellesmere Island [Lower Dumbell Lake, the water supply lake for Alert, growing in moist herbmat \i{}C.R. Harrington 201\i0{}, August 18, 1959]. An extensive search, in 1992, to find the voucher for the mapped record from Ellesmere Island, Judge Daily Promitory (Frederiksen 1981), was unsuccessful. The specimen from the Canadian Arctic may be an \i{}F. baffinensis\i0{} ? \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{} hybrid. The plants have very young inflorescences, with few definitive characteristics. Several attempts to obtain fresh material with which to do isozyme experiments have failed. \par{}\i{}Festuca vivipara\i0{} s.s. was interpreted by Alexeev as an offspring from \i{}F. ovina,\i0{} alone, or in combination with other species. The triploid chromosome number was interpreted by Frederiksen (1981) as a result of hybridisation between \i{}F. ovina\i0{} and \i{}F. vivipara\i0{} subsp. \i{}vivipara\i0{}. She stated, however, that the triploid plants are morphologically indistinguishable from the tetraploids. They occur independently outside the range of \i{}F. ovina\i0{} and form large populations (Salvesen 1986). Triploids may have evolved several times as the hybrid \i{}F. vivipara\i0{} ×\i{}ovina\i0{}, but most of the southern Norwegian triploids seem to constitute a distinct alpine taxon. Tetraploid \i{}F. vivipara\i0{} cannot easily be derived from any ancestral form occurring in Scandinavia today. From morphological and geographical evidence, it therefore seems reasonable to include both triploids and tetraploids (and probably also higher polyploids) in \i{}F. vivipara\i0{} subsp. \i{}vivipara\i0{} (Elven, in Elven et al. 2003). \par{}Alexeev (1995) interpreted \i{}F. viviparoidea\i0{} as a viviparous offspring of \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{}. \i{}Festuca viviparoidea\i0{} is based on subsp. \i{}glabra\i0{} and the same type. Frederiksen (1981) explicitly stated that she found \i{}F. vivipara\i0{} subsp. \i{}glabra\i0{} to belong to the \i{}'ovina'\i0{} group, not the \i{}'brachyphylla'\i0{} group. Pavlick (1984) reported the anthers, when present, to be of \i{}'ovina'\i0{}-group length. It is therefore very improbable that Frederiksen's subsp. \i{}glabra\i0{} (and by implication \i{}F. viviparoidea\i0{}) are anything else than a viviparous offspring from the \i{}F. ovina\i0{} group rather than the \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{} group. Morphologically, the material from northern Siberia (for example, Taimyr), northern Alaska and northwestern Canada differs from the Atlantic \i{}F. vivipara\i0{} and might have an origin in the \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{} group. It is unlikely that the name \i{}F. viviparoidea\i0{} is correctly applied for them. \par{}Elven et al.
