(2003) noted that the vegetatively proliferating plants found in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago have affinities with the \i{}F. brachyphylla\i0{} complex. \par{}Viviparous plants occur fairly regularly in 'continental' northwestern North America, in British Mountains, and northern Alaska where they form populations, have their own ecology, and behave like a taxon. There may be a gap in the distribution between this area and Greenland, making the identification of the northwestern American plants with \i{}F. vivipara\i0{} subsp. \i{}glabra\i0{} (and thereby with \i{}F. viviparoidea\i0{}) problematic. \par{}Several attempts to obtain living material of suitable plants from Northern Ellesmere Island have failed. Isozyme analyses of such plants would have been conclusive if they were merely vegetatively proliferating specimens of either \i{}F. baffinensis\i0{} or \i{}F. brachyphylla.\i0{} The above information is included to draw attention to collections from the Arctic Islands where further study is required to determine the correct taxonomic status.>

<Weimark (1971) distinguished two subspecies: (a) subsp. \i{}alpina\i0{}, recognised by these characters: the awn of the upper staminate floret inserted (0.9-)1.3-2.1(-2.5) mm above the lemma base, usually twisted at base (and geniculate), from (b) subsp. \i{}orthantha\i0{}, where the awn of the upper male floret is inserted (2.2-)2.6-4.0(-4.5) mm above the lemma base, and is straight. Subspecies \i{}orthantha\i0{} has been recorded from Alaska, Greenland, Northern Labrador, and Quebec, but not from the Canadian Arctic Archipelago. \par{}Veldkamp (in Schouten and Veldcamp 1985) aligned many \i{}Hierochloë\i0{} taxa with the genus \i{}Anthoxanthum\i0{}, and this subspecies became \i{}A. monticolum\i0{} subsp. \i{}alpinum\i0{}.\i{} \i0{}As this CD was going to press, this combination was taken up by Allred and Barkworth (2007) in \i{}Flora of North America\i0{}.>

<This tiny grass often occurs as single plants and is easily overlooked.\par{}As this CD was going to press, this species was accepted as \i{}Anthoxanthum arcticum\i0{} Veldkamp by Allred and Barkworth (2007) in \i{}Flora of North America\i0{}.\par{}>

<This species was first collected in the Arctic islands in 1986, as an apparently accidental introduction at Apex, Frobisher Bay, Baffin Island (63°43'N, 68°27'W), in front of the former Hudson Bay Manager's house. The first introduction is suspected to have occurred in the late 1960's when straw was fed to a goat (or was it a pig?) tethered in front of the house. Plants were flourishing when observed in 1986, 1989, and again in 1998. By 2002, they were beginning to spread into a wider area towards the beach at Apex. In 2006, the population of these plants at Apex had been overgrown by a thicket of arctic willow and dense and taller plants of \i{}Poa pratensis\i0{} subsp. \i{}alpigena\i0{}. It was not found at the site. The species was observed elsewhere in Iqaluit in 2005, by Carolyn Mallory, but it was not at that location in 2006. As in Inuvik, this species may have potential as a lawn grass in Iqaluit. \par{}The taxon in the Arctic is subsp. \i{}jubatum\i0{}. It occurs in the Arctic regions of Alaska, the Yukon, and continental N.W.T.>

<Elven (personal communication, 2005) noted that the two subspecies [subsp. \i{}mollis\i0{} and subsp. \i{}villosissimus\i0{}] are separable (and not always) mainly on one character, that is, the hairs on glumes and lemmas. Their ranges are overlapping (parapatric). They are probably acceptable as geographical races (as done by Soreng et al. 2003) but hardly as species. Specimens from the Canadian Arctic Archipelago, examined by Elven, in Oslo, May 2005, all had soft villous hairs on the glumes and lemmas and were unambiguously subsp. \i{}villosissimus.\i0\par{}This species is a member of the grass tribe Triticeae, where there has been much discussion about generic alignments; see, for example, the synonymy for \i{}Elymus alaskanus\i0{}. \par{}Elven et al. (2003) noted that "the separation of \i{}L. mollis\i0{} and \i{}L. arenarius\i0{} at species level is probably justified on a combination of morphological and ploidal differences, even if the morphological differences are few and all the hairiness characters may be genetically interconnected." The taxon in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago is \i{}L.\i0{} \i{}mollis\i0{}. On continental North America, \i{}L. mollis\i0{} subsp. \i{}villosissimus\i0{} A. Löve and D. Löve has been recognised [Bot. Not. 128: 503. 1976], but subspecies within \i{}L. mollis\i0{} are difficult to recognise clearly on morphological evidence, as the differences mostly are quantitative. In northern Alaska and Canada, subsp. \i{}mollis\i0{} and subsp. \i{}villosissimus\i0{} are sympatric and not easy to distinguish. \par{}Heagy and Cooke (1979) studied the vegetation at a Lesser Snow Goose [\i{}Anser caerulescens caerulescens\i0{}] breeding colony to determine if particular plant species or species associations were characteristic of the nest sites of the geese. A stepwise discriminant analysis revealed that nest sites could be satisfactorily distinguished from the ambient vegetation using 2 of the 29 plant species growing in the quadrats. These two species, lyme grass (\i{}Leymus mollis\i0{}) and arctic daisy (\i{}Arctanthemum arcticum\i0{} (L.) Tzvelev subsp. \i{}polare\i0{}), were strongly associated with Snow Goose nest sites. Possible explanations for the association are examined. Rather than a cause and effect relationship between plants and nest sites, it was suggested that \i{}L. mollis\i0{} and \i{}A. arcticum\i0{} apparently have similar ecological requirements to those of the geese for a nesting site.>

<This species was deliberately introduced to Baffin Island, early this century (before 2005). Along with \i{}Festuca rubra\i0{} it was a major component in a mixture of grass seed that was used to hydro-seed the hillside in front of the hospital in Iqaluit. The mixture was also used in a planting on locally produced compost that was placed on the same hillside in the form of a large "C". The compost remained in position, and the "C" contains a mixture of plants of \i{}Lolium\i0{} and \i{}Festuca\i0{}. Seeds in the hydroseeded mixture did not remain in position at the top of the hill, or on the slope, but washed off and accumulated at the junction between the disturbed gravel and the tundra. Here they formed a lush zone of these introduced species. The occurrence of Lolium in hamlets in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago may become more widespread if hydro-seeding is used more extensively. \par{}Ryegrass is one of the few "throw and grow" seeds that can be sown without the hassle of tilling, scarifying, or digging into the soil and destroying any of the permanent ground covers already in place. Perennial \par{}\i{}Lolium perenne\i0{}, a Eurasian species, is commercially important, being included in lawn seed mixtures as well as being used for forage and erosion prevention. \i{}Lolium perenne\i0{} and \i{}L. multiflorum\i0{} are interfertile and intergrade. \i{}Lolium multiflorum \i0{}differs from \i{}L. perenne\i0{} in being a taller, shorter lived perennial with wider leaves that are rolled, rather than folded, in the bud. Hybrids between the two species are called \i{}Lolium ×hybridum\i0{} Hausskn. \par{} \i{}Lolium multiflorum\i0{}, a European species, now grows in most of North America. It is planted as a cover crop, as a temporary lawn grass, for roadside restoration, and for soil or forage enrichment; it often escapes from cultivation, becoming established in disturbed sites (Mary Barkworth, personal communication, 2006, based on E. Terrell's treatment of the genus for \i{}Flora of North America\i0{}).>

<Canadian specimens of \i{}Phippsia\i0{} that have lemmas with a few conspicuous hairs towards the base, but do not otherwise conform to \i{}P. concinna\i0{}, may be assigned to f. \i{}vestita\i0{} Holmb. \par{}Grulke and Bliss (1988), in a study of comparative life history characteristics of two High Arctic grasses, noted that \i{}Phippsia algida\i0{} is a ruderal species that colonises bare soil in mesic sites, but also occurs across a broad range of habitats. \i{}Phippsia\i0{} was observed to experience more frequent and severe drought stress at less extreme physical conditions than \i{}Puccinellia vaginata\i0{}, the species it was being compared with. Drought stress and low temperatures reduced whole plant biomass of \i{}Phippsia\i0{} of all ages in the study. Grulke and Bliss (1988) found that \i{}Phippsia\i0{} was relatively short-lived (living on average 23 years and a maximum of 34 years). They noted that the mean age of initial reproduction was relatively late when compared to temperate species, that is, 17 ± 6 years. Under all the field conditions monitored \i{}Phippsia\i0{} had high, constant seed set. In short growing seasons, \i{}Phippsia\i0{} continued high carbon allocation to reproduction, but also had high rates of plant mortality. The authors concluded that \i{}Phippsia algida\i0{} has many characteristics of a ruderal and fills this role in a High Arctic ecosystem. \par{}Bell and Bliss (1978) estimated that the roots of \i{}P. algida\i0{} live 1.5 years. On three separate occasions Aiken has found plants of \i{}Phippsia\i0{} to be one of the most difficult grasses to transplant to a greenhouse in the south. Although several plants were brought south, they did not survive more than 2-3 weeks after being removed from an arctic environment. The late Dr. Eilif Dahl and students investigated this plant and found it to be very susceptible to high temperatures. Its lethal temperature limit was lower than for most other arctic-alpine plants. It is therefore not surprising that it did not survive transplantation in the south (Elven, personal communication, 2005).\par{}This species is possibly the first arctic grass to flower and set seed and appears to do so before mid-August in most habitats. On Herschel Island in July 1988, \i{}Phippsia\i0{} had flowered and was setting seed before other grasses in the area were at anthesis. \par{}In the former Soviet Union this species is considered to produce good pasture plants when fertilised (Tzvelev 1976). In Canada, the usually small plants, 5-10 cm high, are larger when they receive additional nutrients; see, for example, plants growing near the sewage lagoon in Iqaluit. \par{}Aares et al. (2000) studied phylogeographic and taxonomic relations among 54 North Atlantic populations of \i{}Phippsia\i0{} using isozyme techniques and genetically based morphological variation and found that their results supported the recognition of two distinct species, \i{}P. algida\i0{} and \i{}P. concinna\i0{}, the latter with at least two subspecies. They stated that both of these self-fertilising arctic pioneer species were genetic allotetraploids almost without intra-populational variation. Also, the two species showed strikingly different phylogeographies in the North Atlantic region in spite of their similarity in morphology, habitat ecology, mating system, and dispersal ecology, and in spite of their present co-occurrence in many geographic areas, sometimes even in the same snowbeds. The same electrophoretic multilocus phenotype was observed in all populations of \i{}P. algida\i0{}, and although this species showed considerable morphological variation, the variation was unstructured geographically. They concluded that \i{}P. algida\i0{} showed a pattern similar to other arctic species investigated in the North Atlantic region and that it has probably dispersed postglacially across the sea barriers between Greenland, Svalbard, Iceland, and Scandinavia. In contrast, \i{}P. concinna\i0{} was virtually fixed for different multilocus phenotypes in the three main geographic areas analysed (southern and northern Norway, Svalbard, Greenland), corresponding to fairly distinct divergence in morphology. The pattern suggested (i) absence of postglacial, between area dispersal in this species, and (ii) that it may have immigrated to the North Atlantic region from different source areas and/or survived the last glaciation \i{}in situ.\par{}\i0{}Steen et al. (2004) reported on evidence from Svalbard plants for the hybrid origin of the arctic × \i{}Pucciphippsia vacillans\i0{} (Poaceae).>

<The Greenland records for \i{}P. concinna\i0{} subsp. \i{}algidiformis\i0{} reported from here by Bay (1993) [Nord. J. Bot. 13: 1-40] were examined in Oslo (by Elven and Aiken, May 2005), and all collections from northern Greenland were assigned to \i{}P. concinna.\i0{} They are usually prostrate or erect plants, with only slightly spreading inflorescences. Similar specimens were found from Ellesmere Island at O. It was at that time concluded that \i{}P. concinna\i0{} is present in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago and it is included in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment (Consaul and Aiken 2007). \par{}The name \ldblquote\i{}algidiformis\i0\rdblquote{} was first used by Harry Smith (1914) for an isolated population of \i{}P. concinna\i0{} plants that grow in the mountains between Sweden and Norway. His type is at UPS, with isotype in O. He later synonymised these plants under \i{}P. concinna\i0{}, indicating he no longer recognised the taxon he described Tzvelev (1976/1983). \par{}An Alaska record from Hultén (1950) is from St. Lawrence Island (a mixed collection of \i{}P. algida\i0{} and \i{}P. concinna\i0{}, leg. Kjellman 1879, S).>

<This species has the most northern distribution for an emergent grass. Data for Canadian samples suggests some specimens are larger plants than those that occur in northern Europe. The taxon was named for the Arctic explorer Edward Sabine. The spelling of \i{}"sabinii"\i0{} appears to have been a deliberate Latinising of the name by Robert Brown, and according to the \i{}International Code of Botanical Nomenclature\i0{}, Articles 60,1 and 60,11, the spelling should be corrected (Greuter et al. 1994).>

<There has been constant agreement that this is a distinct species (Porsild 1964, Edmondson 1980, Tzvelev 1976). All specimens examined from the Canadian Arctic Islands belong to subsp. \i{}abbreviata\i0{} (Soreng, personal communication, 1991). A second subspecies, \i{}P. abbreviata\i0{} subsp. \i{}pattersonii \i0{}(Vasey) A. and D. Löve and Kapoor, is found in northwestern North America, but has not been found on the Canadian Arctic Islands. Tzvelev (1976) also recognised subsp. \i{}jordalii\i0{} (A.E. Porsild) Hultén, but this subspecies is now considered a synonym of \i{}P. abbreviata\i0{} subsp. \i{}pattersonii\i0{} (Vasey) A. and D. Löve and Kapoor, by Soreng (1991).>

<This taxon is readily distinguished from other Arctic \i{}Poa\i0{} species by its broad leaves that are nearly uniformly wide until they are abruptly contracted at the apex, the build-up of a "thick sock" (or its "booties") of old sheaths at the base of the plant, and by the relatively large spikelets that often seem to cause the branches to droop. \par{}Polunin (1940) commented that no viviparous forms were found in the Canadian Arctic. Porsild (1957, 1964) and Porsild and Cody (1980), however, describe \i{}P. alpina\i0{} as viviparous, particularly in the Canadian Eastern Arctic. Viviparous or vegetatively proliferating specimens substantiating this statement have not been found in CAN or DAO, or recently collected. They are, however, common in northern Europe (R. Elven, personal communication). Viviparous \i{}P. alpina\i0{} is treated as a variety, \i{}P. alpina\i0{} var. \i{}vivipara\i0{} L., by Elven et al. (2003), and as a subspecies by Soreng et al. (2003). \par{}\i{}Poa alpina\i0{} was found to be an early coloniser of oil spills in Alaska (Kershaw and Kershaw 1986).>

<A widespread, relatively distinct species, \i{}Poa arctica\i0{} is considered highly polymorphic (Tzvelev 1976; Edmondson 1980). Tzvelev (1976) claimed that it is probably represented in the former Soviet Union by several, still unidentified subspecies with different chromosome numbers. In Svalbard, proliferating and non-proliferating entities are about equally frequent and the non-proliferating ones seem to be highly agamospermic, often with shrivelled anthers and undeveloped pollen (see also Notes for \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}caespitans\i0{}). \par{}Tzvelev (1976) commented that the rarely found viviparous variety \i{}P. arctica\i0{} var. \i{}vivipara\i0{} Hooker is probably the hybrid between \i{}P. arctica\i0{} × \i{}P. pratensis\i0{} s.l., which is not always distinguishable from some forms of \i{}P. pratensis\i0{} subsp. \i{}colpodea\i0{} (Th. Fr.) Tzvelev. Porsild (1955) suggested that most viviparous High Arctic \i{}Poa\i0{} is best placed in \i{}P\i0{}. \i{}arctica\i0{} as var. \i{}vivipara\i0{}, but unfortunately without explanation. Porsild (1957, 1964) and Porsild and Cody (1980) mapped \i{}P. arctica\i0{} var. \i{}vivipara\i0{} in 18 different localities throughout the Eastern Arctic. We have not been able to verify any of these records. Upon examination of herbarium specimens at CAN and DAO, none were located at CAN, while the several specimens found at DAO were redetermined as \i{}P\i0{}. \i{}pratensis\i0{} subsp. \i{}colpodea\i0{}. Gillespie and Boles (2001) concluded that \i{}P. arctica\i0{} var. \i{}vivipara\i0{} is not present on the Canadian Arctic Islands based on their present understanding of arctic \i{}Poa\i0{} taxa.\par{}Gillespie and Boles (2001) noted that \i{}P. arctica\i0{} is a highly polymorphic species in the Canadian Arctic, and as this variation is far from being discrete morphologically or geographically, they questioned the validity and utility of recognising infraspecific taxa. They agreed with Polunin (1940) that there appears to be so much variation, and plants vary "in such a mixed and baffling manner that I have given up on sorting out the more obvious traits". One of these morphotypes (included here under \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{}) is a low cushion or clumped form found in cold wet seepages and meadows at higher elevations in the High Arctic (see image library).>

<This subspecies has been recognised by Elven et al. (2003) for the Panarctic Flora and tentatively by Soreng et al. (2003) for North America. Mentioned by Porsild (1964) under species comments on \i{}P. arctica\i0{}, along with comments on \i{}P. arctica\i0{} var. \i{}vivipara\i0{} Hooker, as a well-marked eastern arctic taxon. Tzvelev (1976), following Roshevitz (1932), suggested that this may be a hybrid between \i{}P. arctica\i0{} × \i{}P. glauca\i0{}. Genetically, \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}caespitans\i0{} seems to be simpler, with fewer molecular markers, e.g., less enzyme multilocus phenotypes, at least in Svalbard (Haugen 2000), and at a lower ploidal level than most of \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{}. It seems to be constantly octoploid, whereas most voucher-supported counts of \i{}P. arctica\i0{} s. str. - at least from the amphi-Atlantic areas - are at 9\i{}x\i0{} or higher (Elven et al. 2003). Gillespie and Boles (2001) and Gillespie et al. (2005, and unpublished data) did not find cpDNA sequence or restriction site variation distinguishing it from subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{}.\par{}While Nannfeldt (1940) claimed that he had not seen fertile anthers in this taxon, Porsild (1964) noted that the anthers never contain good pollen. However, inflorescences on herbarium specimens from the Canadian Arctic Archipelago that are housed at CAN, and that were annotated by R.J. Soreng in 1990, have fully developed, but not necessarily fertile, anthers. \par{}Specimens of the Canadian Arctic complex that have been called subsp. \i{}caespitans\i0{} are densely tufted, only occasionally rhizomatous, with flat, soft leaves. Porsild (1964) provided distribution maps of both \i{}Poa arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}caespitans\i0{} and \i{}Poa arctica\i0{} var. \i{}vivipara\i0{} Hooker, but did not indicate how he distinguished them. Löve and Löve (1975) followed Roshevitz (1932) and listed the taxon as having 2\i{}n\i0{} = 56, on 12 counts, which contrasts with 2\i{}n\i0{} = 60-88 that they give for \i{}P. arctica\i0{} s.s. \par{}The name has been put into synonomy under \i{}P. tolmatchewii\i0{} Roshevitz by Tzvelev (1976), following Roshevitz (1932) who suggested that the taxon may be a hybrid \i{}P. arctica\i0{} × \i{}P. glauca\i0{}. In annotating specimens at CAN in 1990, R.J. Soreng, Smithsonian University, recognised \i{}P. arctica\i0{} and \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}caespitans\i0{}. In 1995, he explained that subsp. \i{}caespitans\i0{} is not a well-defined taxon. It may not be diagnosable using the attributes scabrous branches and more open sheaths, but it appears to be intermediate between \i{}P. arctica\i0{} and other species and may represent hybrids and the products of backcrossing. \par{}Recent field studies (1999) have shown that there appears to be at least two densely tufted \i{}Poa\i0{} taxa in the Canadian Arctic Islands. One, found in mesic stony habitats, and generally considered to be \i{}P\i0{}. \i{}arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}caespitans\i0{}, has mostly robust plants with broad flat leaves and often tall flowering culms. The other found in cold moist to wet areas at higher elevations has low mound-forming plants with short culms. \par{}Haugen (2000) tested two of Tzvelev's hypotheses about the hybrid origins of taxa in \i{}Poa\i0{}, using material collected in Svalbard. The entities investigated and compared in her thesis were \i{}P. abbreviata\i0{}, \i{}P. alpigena\i0{} viviparous type, \i{}P. alpigena\i0{} subsp. \i{}colpodea\i0{}, \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{}, \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}cespitans\i0{}, \i{}P. glauca\i0{}, and \i{}P. hartzii\i0{}. The investigation concerned morphology (about 50 characters), biological reproductive characteristics, and isoenzymes as genetic markers. The samples of \i{}P. alpigena\i0{} and \i{}P. arctica\i0{} investigated were insufficiently separated in most morphological characters (except the lemma hairiness) and also less distinct in isoenzymes than would be expected of two 'species' from different aggregates. \i{}Poa arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}cespitans\i0{} was slightly more distinct from \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{} in morphology than the latter was from \i{}P. alpigena\i0{}. \i{}Poa arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}cespitans\i0{} was also distinct enzymatically although most closely related to \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{}. \i{}Poa alpigena\i0{} subsp. \i{}colpodea\i0{} was fairly distinct, both morphologically and enzymatically. In morphology, it was a little more distant from 'normal' \i{}P. alpigena\i0{} than the latter was from \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{}. In enzymes, however, \i{}P. alpigena\i0{} subsp. \i{}colpodea\i0{} was closer to \i{}P. alpigena\i0{} s.s. than to \i{}P. arctica\i0{}. The Svalbard plants of \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{} corresponded very well both with the type material (Melville Island) and with material collected in Melville Island in 1999. They obviously belong to the 'type' subspecies. Plants of \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}cespitans\i0{} from Svalbard are generally morphologically quite similar to Simmons' type collections from Ellesmere Island and also to plants from Greenland named as \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}cespitans\i0{}. \i{}Poa alpigena\i0{} subsp. \i{}colpodea\i0{} was described from Svalbard, and the plants Hagen (2000) investigated corresponded to the type and to plants named as such from arctic North America. What these results imply is that it is difficult to separate between the aggregates around \i{}Poa arctica\i0{} and \i{}P. pratensis.\i0\par{}Gillespie and Boles (2001) found no evidence for \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}caespitans\i0{} as a taxon distinct from \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}arctica \i0{}on chloroplast DNA evidence, as individuals examined all had the same cpDNA haplotype. Nor was there evidence that it might be a hybrid between \i{}P. arctica \i0{}and\i{} P. glauca\i0{} either on the cpDNA evidence or from observations made during field work, but they state that further DNA studies are needed to investigate possible independent lineages suggested by morphological differences. \par{}In northern Norway and Svalbard, \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{} regularly has some pollen, whereas no pollen development has been found in specimens of \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}caespitans\i0{} in which agamospermy and proliferation seems to be nearly obligate (R. Elven, personal communication, 1999).>

<This is a very widespread species that looks rather different in cold sectors of the Arctic, as stunted plants only reach 10-15 cm high and have a spike-like inflorescence. Caryopses are rarely formed in High Arctic plants because of the short growing season. \par{}Elven et al. (2003) considered that \i{}P. glauca\i0{} is fairly homogeneous in most northern arctic areas. It becomes much more variable further south in the transition from tundra to forest, boreal mountain ranges, and possibly in the amphi-Beringian area. They suggested that much of the variation is probably caused by hybridisation and will be difficult or impossible to classify satisfactorily.>

<Field observations, morphological evidence, and germination trials reported in Gillespie et al. (1997) support \i{}P. hartzii\i0{} as a morphologically distinct apomictic species that reproduces by seed. DNA evidence in the same paper provides evidence for two possible origins of \i{}P. hartzii\i0{}. The first is a hybrid origin between two ancestral species. The second, and more likely, is that \i{}P. hartzii\i0{} was an existing species that "captured" DNA from a second species, \i{}P. glauca \i0{}(Gillespie et al. 1997). Recent molecular evidence supports the second hypothesis, since \i{}P. hartzii\i0{} has a unique cpDNA haplotype within the \i{}P.\i0{} sect. \i{}Secundae \i0{}group (Gillespie and Boles 2001, Gillespie and Soreng 2005). Individuals of \i{}P. hartzii\i0{},\i{} \i0{}having a haplotype identical to that of \i{}P. glauca \i0{}(widespread in Arctic Canada), were found only in High Arctic sites and are postulated to result from hybridisation and introgression.\par{}\i{}Poa hartzii\i0{} was previously thought to be possibly \i{}P. abbreviata\i0{} or \i{}P. arctica\i0{} × \i{}P. glauca\i0{}. Cayouette (1984) recorded a collection of \i{}P. hartzii\i0{} from northern Quebec and summarised the debate concerning this taxon, pointing out that Sørensen (1953), Holmen (1957), and Porsild (1964) considered it a species. According to Sørensen (1933), "Even if \i{}Poa Hartzii\i0{} is thus intermediate in many respects between \i{}P. abbreviata\i0{} and \i{}P. glauca\i0{}, it hardly represents the hybrid between these two species". Jørgensen et al. (1958) noted that individuals of \i{}P. hartzii\i0{} in Greenland showed meiotic irregularities and formed abnormal pollen but developed good seeds that lead them to conclude that the taxon was apomictic. Scholander (1934) observed \i{}P. hartzii\i0{} to be intermediate between \i{}P. abbreviata\i0{} and \i{}P. glauca\i0{}, whereas Nannfeldt (1935) suggested that it may be the hybrid \i{}P. arctica\i0{} × \i{}P. abbreviata\i0{}. Edmondson (1980) treated it as a stabilised, but apparently sterile, hybrid of \i{}P. abbreviata\i0{} × \i{}P. glauca\i0{}. Soreng (1991) discussed \i{}P. hartzii\i0{} as a species that possibly had a hybrid origin. \par{}In Svalbard, this taxon sometimes forms stands over large areas (tens of kilometres) with well-defined individuals (1000-10000, at least), where it is obviously seed-propagated, even though it flowers late. It appears to be agamospermic, as no evidence of fertile pollen has been found, agreeing with the North American findings given above (R. Elven, personal communication, 1999). \par{}Haugen (2000) investigated possible hybrid origins of \i{}Poa hartzii\i0{} and \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}caespitans\i0{} in Svalbard, using morphological and isozyme techniques. In the populations studied she found \i{}P. hartzii\i0{} was enzymatically non-varying and had a unique multilocus phenotype and most similar to \i{}P. glauca\i0{}.>

<This taxon is distinct and relatively common in the eastern Canadian High Arctic. It has a chloroplast DNA haplotype that is distinct from that of the southern subsp. \i{}pratensis\i0{} (Gillespie and Boles 2001). It was treated as a full species \i{}Poa alpigena \i0{}by Porsild (1955) and Edmondson (1980) and as a subspecies by Tzvelev (1976). Porsild (1955) claimed that Canadian specimens agreed well with specimens from northeastern Greenland and also with the excellent description and illustrations given by Scholander (1934).\par{}Elven et al. (2003) noted that most taxa of the \i{}P. pratensis\i0{} aggregate are more or less apomictic with both agamospermy and bulbil propagation (many studies from Müntzing 1932, 1940 onwards). Some reticulation is at least probable, and the limits between entities (agamospecies) are often unclear. There are several bulbil-reproducing plants in the \i{}'alpigena'\i0{} affinity. In Svalbard and Greenland, several biotypes of subsp. \i{}alpigena\i0{} (described as var. \i{}vivipara\i0{}) are much more common than is subsp. \i{}colpodea\i0{}. In the Canadian Arctic viviparous plants of subsp. \i{}alpigena\i0{} have been observed on Melville Island, but are generally less common and widespread than subsp. \i{}colpodea\i0{}.>

<Haugen (2000) tested two of Tzvelev's hypotheses about the hybrid origins of taxa in \i{}Poa\i0{} using material collected in Svalbard. The entities investigated and compared in her thesis were \i{}P. abbreviata\i0{}, \i{}P. alpigena\i0{} viviparous type, \i{}P. alpigena\i0{} subsp. \i{}colpodea\i0{}, \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{}, \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}cespitans\i0{}, \i{}P. glauca\i0{}, and \i{}P. hartzii\i0{}. The investigation concerned morphology (about 50 characters), biological reproductive characteristics, and isoenzymes as genetical markers. The samples of \i{}Poa alpigena\i0{} and \i{}P. arctica\i0{} investigated were insufficiently separated in most morphological characters (except the lemma hairiness) and also less distinct in isoenzymes than would be expected of two 'species' from different aggregates. \i{}Poa alpigena\i0{} subsp. \i{}colpodea\i0{} was fairly distinct, both morphologically and enzymatically. In morphology, it was a little more distant from 'normal' \i{}P. alpigena\i0{} than the latter was from \i{}P. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{}. In enzymes, however, \i{}P. alpigena\i0{} subsp. \i{}colpodea\i0{} was closer to \i{}P. alpigena\i0{} s.s. than to \i{}P. arctica\i0{}. \i{}Poa alpigena\i0{} subsp. \i{}colpodea\i0{} was described from Svalbard, and the plants Hagen (2000) investigated corresponded to the type and to plants named as such from arctic North America. What these results imply is that it is difficult to separate between the aggregates around \i{}Poa arctica\i0{} and \i{}P. pratensis\i0{}, the latter exemplified by Svalbard \i{}P. alpigena\i0{} var. \i{}vivipara\i0{} and subsp. \i{}colpodea.\par{}\i0{}Elven (personal communication, 2005) noted that Soreng et al. (2003) accepted subsp. \i{}colpodea\i0{} but circumscribed it widely and included, e.g., \i{}"P. alpigena\i0{} var. \i{}vivipara"\i0{}. Here we consider viviparous \i{}P. pratensis\i0{} supbsp. \i{}alpigena\i0{} as distinct from \i{}P. pratensis\i0{} subsp. \i{}colpodea\i0{}.>

<Swallen (1944) said that this is a rather distinct species in which the long decumbent base, short, stiffly spreading panicle branches, and acute, more or less toothed lemmas, are characteristic. He considered that close relationships with other arctic species were not evident. \par{}Consaul and Gillespie (2001) found some confusion with the Canadian isotype specimen of \i{}P. andersonii\i0{}. Swallen (1944) reported in his protologue discussion of \i{}P. andersonii\i0{} that the original collection by Anderson was composed of two species: \i{}P. andersonii\i0{}, which became sheet 4399a and the type, and \i{}P. paupercula\i0{} (= \i{}P. langeana\i0{}), which became sheet 4399b. During the separation of the two species some specimens of \i{}P. langeana\i0{} were apparently transferred to the Canada isotype, 4399a. Consaul and Gillespie annotated the \i{}P. andersonii\i0{} isotype specimens as 4399a-1, and the \i{}P. langeana\i0{} specimens as 4399a-2. The same problem does not occur with the holotype (US ex NA). Consaul and Gillespie (2001) found that the isotype (i.e., 4399a-1, \i{}P. andersonii\i0{}) and two other \i{}P. andersonii\i0{} specimens were smaller and less hairy than all the other collections of \i{}P. andersonii\i0{} examined in the PCoA, and clustered with \i{}P. langeana\i0{} in cluster analyses the former three specimens fell between the rest of the \i{}P. andersonii\i0{} specimens and \i{}P. langeana\i0{}. This has led to the question of whether there are two taxa represented by the \i{}P. andersonii\i0{} specimens analysed, and this is part of a study being undertaken by Consaul (2002-2006).\par{}Sørensen (1953) described the lemma as entire, but in several Canadian specimens annotated by him, we observed the lemmas are erose. When described, \i{}Puccinellia andersonii\i0{} was known only from the type locality, Pt. Lay, Arctic central Alaska. Sørensen (1953) indicated that it occurs over northern Greenland [southward to about 70°N on the west coast and to about 73°N on the east coast] and suggested that it had previously been mistaken for \i{}Puccinellia angustata\i0{}, or in some cases for \i{}Puccinellia (Colpodium\i0{})\i{} vahlianum\i0{}. He noted that while the species grow in similar habitats, no direct connection between \i{}P. andersonii\i0{} and \i{}P. angustata\i0{} seemed to exist. Consaul and Gillespie (2001) had made observations in 1997-1999 in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago and confirmed that there \i{}P. andersonii\i0{} and \i{}P. angustata\i0{} do grow in similar habitats and do appear different. When plants of each species were growing near each other they were at similar stages of phenology. These authors confirmed the observation of Grulke and Bliss (1988) that like \i{}P. vaginata\i0{} the inflorescences remain prostrate when sexually mature. They even suspected that occasionally \i{}P. angustata\i0{} was collected preferentially to \i{}P. andersonii\i0{} because in the latter the whole plant was often prostrate, looking like a "less healthy" plant. Although this is a relatively distinct taxon, specimens are found that have characteristics of \i{}P. langeana\i0{}, if very glabrous, and \i{}P. vaginata\i0{} if more hairy (Consaul and Gillespie 2001). \par{}Although never previously considered to be closely related, when plants\i{} \i0{}of \i{}P. andersonii\i0{} and \i{}P. vaginata\i0{} were growing together they were not always easy to distinguish on the character lemmas "erose-ciliolate" (Sørensen 1953). Consaul and Gillespie (2001) found that these two taxa, as currently recognised, overlap morphologically. Some specimens considered to be \i{}P. andersonii, \i0{}since the apices of the lemmas and glumes are erose and acute, had unusually long trichomes on the lemma and glume margins, and in this they approach \i{}P. vaginata\i0{}. Other specimens were considered intermediate between \i{}P. andersonii\i0{} and \i{}P. vaginata\i0{} in the anther lengths, suggested as distinct in Porsild (1964) [\i{}P. vaginata\i0{}, 0.6-0.8 mm long: \i{}P. andersonii\i0{},\i{} \i0{}0.8-1.0 mm long].>

<In the Canadian records this is the most commonly collected species on the Arctic islands. Cayouette and Blondeau, 1996, recorded the occurrence of \i{}P. angustata\i0{} s.s. in Nunavik (northern Quebec).\par{}Sørensen (1953) suggested that although variation in this taxon is considerable, he did not consider it justified to recognise more than one entity. Elven et al. (2003) drew attention to \i{}Puccinellia angustata\i0{} (R.Br.) E.L. Rand and Redfield var. \i{}decumbens\i0{} Jørg. ex T.J. Sørensen, Meddel. Grønl. 136, 3: 30. 1953, based on the type from Svalbard: Spitsbergen, Advent Bay, East side, 21.07.1896, leg. E. Jørgensen (O, C). They noted that this variety is fairly distinct even where it co-occurs with the type variety in Svalbard. Jørgensen did not publish the name (only noted it on herbarium labels), so the correct citation is probably 'Jørg. ex T.J. Sørensen'. \par{}This species usually grows in clay or silt environments. The centre of the plant often has somewhat erect stems, while the outer culms of a clump are generally prostrate. In loose, windblown, riverbank sand, such as found along the MacDonald River Delta near Tanquary Fiord on Ellesmere Island, plants were found that were almost completely erect, possibly as a response to being slowly buried by sand. \par{}The character states that have been used to key out this species have differed, depending on the author. Sørensen (1953) used the character lemmas erose-ciliolate; Porsild and Cody (1980) describe the lemmas as tapering, commonly with hyaline tips. Consaul and Gillespie (2001) described and illustrated small, acuminate trichomes, which render the margins of the glumes and lemmas scabrous or scaberulous. \par{}Sørensen (1955) considered \i{}P. bruggemannii\i0{} easily mistaken for stunted \i{}P. angustata\i0{}, but indicated that they differ in leaf epidermal characters, indicating that \i{}P. angustata\i0{} usually has stomates and \i{}P. bruggemannii\i0{} does not. In Consaul's (2002-2006) systematic study of arctic \i{}Puccinellia\i0{}, stomates were not examined because Tzvelev (1964) noted a lot of within-species variation in this character. Variation in this character should be examined after the species limits have been clarified. Consaul and Gillespie (2001) found that specimens of \i{}P. bruggemannii\i0{} can usually be distinguished from \i{}P. angustata\i0{} on size characters.>

<\i{}Puccinellia arctica\i0{} and \i{}P. borealis\i0{} were added to the flora of the Canadian Arctic Archipelago (Porsild 1957), in the supplement Porsild (1964), \par{}The characters given as separating these species were as follows:\par{}Plants littoral, panicle 6-9 cm long, anthers 1.5 mm long\u8230\'85. \i{}P. arctica\i0{}, \par{}Plants non-littoral, common to weedy on disturbed subarctic riverbanks and lakeshores; panicle 10-25 cm long, anthers 0.6-0.7 mm long \u8230\'85\i{}P. borealis\i0{}. \par{}Kartesz (1999) placed \i{}P. borealis\i0{} into synonymy under \i{}P. arctica\i0{}, but gave no reason for doing so. It is conceivable that he was influenced by Porsild's (1951) statement that \i{}P. borealis\i0{} of the sea-coast probably should be referred to \i{}P. arctica\i0{}, or, alternatively, by Welsh's (1974) description of the distribution of \i{}P. arctica\i0{} as Alaska "eastward to the Labrador (\i{}P. borealis\i0{} Swallen)" (Consaul and Gillespie 2001). No support for the synonymy in Kartesz (1999) was found by Consaul and Gillespie (2001). These authors found that the characters given above plus the structure of the lemma apex margin differ between the two taxa. \par{}Lemma margin with trichomes greater than 25 micrometres long and evenly spaced\u8230\'85. \i{}P. borealis\i0{} \par{}Lemma margin with trichomes less than 25 micrometres long, unevenly spaced \u8230\'85 \i{}P. arctica\i0{}. \par{}Consaul and Gillespie (2001) found that \i{}P. arctica\i0{} was difficult to distinguish from \i{}P. agrostidea\i0{} in the western Arctic. Analyzing specimens from throughout the range of these species, they found no morphological evidence that \i{}P. agrostidea\i0{}, \i{}P. arctica\i0{}, and \i{}P. poacea\i0{} are different species. These three species have been synonymized in Davis and Consaul (2007) under \i{}P. arctica\i0{}. \par{}Elven et al. (2003) included this name as representing a distinct taxon in the Panarctic Flora Checklist.>

<When Sørensen (1955, p. 81) described this species, he commented, "\i{}Puccinellia bruggemannii\i0{} superficially resembles \i{}Poa abbreviata\i0{} and, unlike most other members of the genus, is probably not halophilous - a peculiarity it shares with \i{}P. angustata\i0{}. For that reason, and because of its hairy lemmas and paleas, it may easily be mistaken for a stunted \i{}P. angustata\i0{} but may always be distinguished by the somewhat incurved lemmas.\rdblquote{} Sørensen (1955) considered the resemblance between these two species to be only superficial. He considered that these taxa were not even closely related because \i{}P. bruggemannii \i0{}lacks stomates on the abaxial surfaces of the leaves, which is a rare feature in \i{}Puccinellia\i0{}. He speculated that \i{}P. bruggemannii\i0{} is related to the Siberian \i{}P. tenuiflora\i0{} (Turcz.) Krecz. Consaul, after examining specimens of \i{}P. tenuiflora\i0{} identified by Sørensen, in 2002, found it was difficult to perceive a close relationship between these two species.\par{}Tzvelev (1983) distinguished these taxa as follows: \par{}Plants 7-9 cm tall, lemmas 3-3.4 mm, and anthers 0.6-0.8 mm\u8230\'85\i{} P. bruggemannii\i0\par{}Plants 20-80 cm tall, lemmas 1.5-2.3 mm, and anthers 0.8-1.4 mm\u8230\'85\i{} P. tenuiflora\i0{} \par{}In Consaul's (2002-2006) systematic study of arctic \i{}Puccinellia\i0{}, stomates were not examined because Tzvelev (1964) indicated there was a lot of within-species variation in this character. Variation in this character should be examined after the species limits have been clarified. This taxon is treated as a species in Davis and Consaul (2007).>

<\i{}Puccinellia borealis\i0{} has been synonymised under \i{}P. nuttalliana\i0{} in the treatment for \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} (Davis and Consaul 2007). Elven et al. (2003) included this name (\i{}P. borealis\i0{}) as representing a distinct taxon in the Panarctic Flora Checklist. Davis and Soreng (2003) also treated \i{}P. borealis\i0{} as a separate species, and commented "this might be better treated within \i{}P. nuttalliana.\i0{}"\par{}\i{}Puccinellia nuttalliana\i0{} (as \i{}P. borealis\i0{}) was reported in the archipelago from Beechey Island by McJannet et al. (1993), but the voucher specimen at CAN was annotated to \i{}P. angustata\i0{} by S.G. Aiken, April 1994. In 1997, Consaul and Gillespie (personal observations) reported this taxon under the name \i{}P. borealis\i0{} as abundant and weedy on Victoria Island. It is a species that would be expected to spread to other locations in the southern islands of the Arctic Archipelago, helped by anthropogenic influences.\par{}\i{}Puccinellia arctica\i0{} and \i{}P. borealis\i0{} were added to the flora of the Canadian Arctic Archipelago (Porsild 1957), in the supplement Porsild (1964), \par{}The characters given as separating these species were as follows:\par{}Plants littoral, panicle 6-9 cm long, anthers 1.5 mm long\u8230\'85. \i{}P. arctica\i0{}, \par{}Plants non-littoral, common to weedy on disturbed subarctic riverbanks and lakeshores; panicle 10-25 cm long, anthers 0.6-0.7 mm long \u8230\'85\i{}P. borealis\i0{}. \par{}Kartesz (1999) placed \i{}P. borealis\i0{} into synonymy under \i{}P. arctica\i0{}, but gave no reason for doing so. It is conceivable that he was influenced by Porsild's (1951) statement that \i{}P. borealis\i0{} of the sea-coast probably should be referred to \i{}P. arctica\i0{}, or, alternatively, by Welsh's (1974) description of the distribution of \i{}P. arctica\i0{} as Alaska "eastward to the Labrador (\i{}P. borealis\i0{} Swallen)" (Consaul and Gillespie 2001). No support for the synonymy in Kartesz (1999) was found by Consaul and Gillespie (2001). These authors found that, as well as the anther lengths being different, the structure of the lemma apex margin differs between the two taxa. \par{}Lemma margin with trichomes greater than 25 micrometres long and evenly spaced\u8230\'85. \i{}P. borealis\i0{} \par{}Lemma margin with trichomes less than 25 micrometres long, unevenly spaced \u8230\'85 \i{}P. arctica\i0{}. \par{}Specimens of \i{}P. borealis\i0{} are close morphologically to western plants of \i{}P. vaginata\i0{} with intermediate-sized lemmas and anthers. They may be investigated as potential hybrids. \par{}Ovenden (1986) found \i{}P. nuttalliana\i0{} (\i{}P. borealis\i0{}) and \i{}Arctagrostis latifolia\i0{} were common on the lake bed of Illisarvik, the site of a thermokarst lake that was artificially drained in August 1978. By 1985, the lake bed was dry in most areas and wind erosion was extensive.>

<Bowden (1961) considered this taxon to be a sterile, triploid hybrid of unknown parentage. Sørensen (1953) recognised four variants of \i{}P. phryganodes\i0{}, based on pedicels thickened or not thickened, floret numbers per spikelet, lemma lengths, and epidermal cell features. He concluded that Canadian material is mainly the "Greenland type" (= \i{}P. phryganodes\i0{} subsp. \i{}neoarctica\i0{}), but generally with better developed pistils. Tzvelev (1976) recognised various subspecies, but remarked that none of them is morphologically clearly separated, and they may not deserve recognition. The description by Hughes and Halliday (1980) differs from the one given here, in the following characters: "spikelets not more than 4 florets; lower glume 1.2-1.7 mm, upper glume 1.5-2.3 mm; lemma 1.5-2.5 mm". The Hughes and Halliday (1980) description is based on northern Norwegian plants, i.e., triploids with even more reduced florets and anthers (or the pale shadows of very clearly aborted anthers) (R. Elven, personal communication, 1999). \par{}In the Panarctic Flora checklist, Elven et al. (2003) followed the concept of Tzvelev (1976) on the variation in the \i{}'phryganodes'\i0{} aggregate, noting that the morphological differences seem constant (albeit small) and are partly associated with ploidy differences. The entities they suggest represented major geographical allopatric or parapatric races, and qualified as subspecies in their concepts. This treatment suggested the following subspecies:\par{}\i{}Puccinellia phryganodes\i0{} (Trin.) Scribn. and Merr. subsp. \i{}phryganodes\i0{} as most probably a tetraploid, 2\i{}n\i0{} = 28, that occurs in the Russian Far East and Alaska. The plants investigated of this entity in W and NW Alaska are also fully pollen-fertile, in opposition to most or all plants elsewhere. We have investigated plants also from the type region ("Kotzebue Sund"). The W-NW Alaskan entity (\i{}phryganodes\i0{} s. str.) is tetraploid (2\i{}n\i0{} = 28) (Elven, personal communication, 2005).\par{}\i{}Puccinellia phryganodes\i0{} (Trin.) Scribn. and Merr. subsp. \i{}neoarctica\i0{} (Á. Löve and D. Löve) comb. nov. needed, a triploid, 2\i{}n\i0{} = 21, that occurs in Svalbard, Greenland, and Canada.\par{}\i{}Puccinellia phryganodes\i0{} (Trin.) Scribn. and Merr. subsp. \i{}sibirica\i0{} (Hada\u269\'3f and Á. Löve) comb. nov. needed, Type, European Russia: Waigatsch, Sinus Warnek, 14.07.1907, leg. O. Ekstam (S) holotype, a taxon with triploids and tetraploids that occurs from Norway to the Russian Far East.\par{}\i{}Puccinellia phryganodes\i0{} (Trin.) Scribn. and Merr. subsp. \i{}vilfoidea\i0{} (Andersson) Tzvelev, in Tolm. Fl. Arct. URSS 2: 186. 1964. Described from Svalbard. \par{}\i{}Puccinellia phryganodes\i0{} (Trin.) Scribn. and Merr. subsp. \i{}geniculata\i0{} (Turcz. ex V.I.Krecz.) Tzvelev, Novosti Sist. Vyssh. Rast. 8: 77. 1971. This is a diploid taxon that occurs in Alaska and may be species-level distinct. In 2005, Elven et al. (2005) treated this taxon as a separate species. \par{}Following Elven et al. (2003) we draw attention to this discussion, but as some of the combinations have not been published, we do not follow it yet (March 2005). \par{}Jefferies and Gottlieb (1983) studied genetic variation within and between populations of \i{}Puccinellia phryganodes\i0{}. Because they assumed that the taxon is a sterile triploid, they expected that the level of genetic variation would be low, both within and between populations. They examined the electrophoretic mobilities of isozymes of 12 systems in plants from three widely separated populations in Arctic Canada (La Prouse Bay, Manitoba, 58°4'N, 94°4'W; Tuktoyaktuk, N.W.T. 69°27'N, 133°00'W; and Alexandra Fiord, Ellesmere Island, Nunavut 78°53'N, 75°55'W) and found a high level of variability both within and between populations. They suggested that the unexpected discovery of significant amounts of genetic variability indicated that sexual processes occur in this species. \par{}Siira and Merila (1985), working in Finland, found that around the coast of Bothnian Bay, in the Baltic Sea area, the populations of \i{}P. phryganodes\i0{} had decreased greatly during the previous 20 years. They noted that the species has "a narrow ecological amplitude and poor colonization ability", and suggested that in some areas, continuous land uplift causes fairly rapid changes in the ecological conditions, and primary succession is not always the same. They also noted that human activity had influenced the nature of the shorelines studied.>

<The description given here is based on a limited number of specimens available and supplemented by description in J.I. Davis (1983). He considered that \i{}P. pumila\i0{} is exclusively coastal and can be distinguished from other species in the \i{}P. nuttalliana\i0{} complex by the entire, erose, or sparsely scabrous margin of the lemma, as opposed to the predominantly scabrous margin typical of the other three species (\i{}P. grandis\i0{} Swallen, \i{}P. nutkaensis\i0{} (J. Presl) Fernald and Weath., and \i{}P. nuttalliana\i0{} (Schult.) Hitchc.). \ldblquote{}It is more glabrous overall than any other species in the complex" (Davis 1983). \par{}McJannet et al. (1993) followed Kartesz (1994) and used \i{}P. kurilensis\i0{} (Takeda) Honda for members of this taxon. J.I. Davis was not prepared to consider North American \i{}P. pumila\i0{} synonymous with \i{}P. kurilensis\i0{} (personal communication, 1994); Davis and Soreng (2003) have excluded the name \i{}P. kurilensis \i0{}from the New World Grass flora. \i{}Puccinellia pumila\i0{} is recognised in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment (Davis and Consaul 2007).>

<The description given here is based on specimens that were annotated by T.J. Sørensen as subsp. \i{}typica\i0{}. Sørensen (1953) stated that the taxonomy and nomenclature of this taxon were disputed from the time it was first recognised as \i{}Glyceria langeana\i0{} Berlin. He recognised the specimens from North America as subsp. \i{}typica\i0{}, distinct from those in Asia (subsp. \i{}asiatica\i0{} T.J. Sørensen) and Alaska (subsp. \i{}alaskana\i0{} (Scribn. and Merr.) T.J. Sørensen). He commented that the epidermis of the leaves of the \i{}P. langeana\i0{} group is unusual when compared with other arctic \i{}Puccinellia\i0{} species because there are relatively few stomata on the underside of the leaf and the leaf margins are finely crenulate from short, rounded, marginal cells.\par{}This taxon was distinguished by the absence of hairs on the callus, lemma base, and palea. However, some specimens annotated by Sørensen as this taxon were found to have a ring of small callus hairs, to 0.05 mm long (Consaul and Gillespie 2001). These specimens are still readily separated from the other \i{}Puccinellia\i0{} species in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago by the size and lack of hairs on the almost completely glabrous plants and in usually having no trichomes on the margins of the lemmas or glumes (see image library). \par{}In multivariate analyses, small very slightly hairy \i{}P. andersonii\i0{} plants grouped very closely with \i{}P. langeana\i0{} specimens (Consaul and Gillespie 2001). An isotype specimen of \i{}P. andersonii\i0{} was a mixed collection of \i{}P. langeana\i0{} and \i{}P. andersonii\i0{}. The close similarity of small \i{}P. andersonii\i0{} plants to \i{}P. langeana\i0{} is being further studied (Consaul 2002-2006). Consaul (personal communication, March 2005) had compared the ITS sequences from \i{}P. langeana\i0{} and \i{}P. tenella\i0{}, based on limited herbarium material for the latter, and found these two have the same ITS sequences (different from other diploid species), which lends support to subspecies status. However, she noted that if \i{}P. langeana\i0{} and \i{}P. tenella\i0{} are subspecies then the question is, What is the name? The appropriateness of placing them under \i{}P. langeana\i0{} is addressed in extensive discussion in Sorensen (1953). Tzvelev (1964) provides a counterdiscussion, supporting placing them under \i{}P. tenella\i0{} in \i{}Flora of the Russian Arctic\i0{} (Vol. 2). After an examination of the protologues and drawings, Consaul et al. (in press) use \i{}P. tenella\i0{} subsp. \i{}langeana\i0{}, following Tzvelev (1964).>

<Sørensen (1953) observed that plants of \i{}P. vaginata\i0{} are remarkable for their soft texture, large drooping panicles, which are just exserted above the slightly inflated, uppermost culm leaf sheaths, and by the relatively large, loose, and conspicuously glossy spikelets. \par{}Grulke and Bliss (1988), in a study of comparative life history characteristics of two High Arctic grasses, noted that \i{}Puccinellia vaginata\i0{} occurs in xeric micro-sites with little soil disturbance. Drought stress that reduced whole plant biomass of \i{}Phippsia\i0{}, the species that \i{}P. vaginata\i0{} was being compared with, affected only seedlings of the latter species. Root biomass remained constant. \par{}Grulke and Bliss (1988) found that \i{}P. vaginata\i0{} was relatively long-lived (living on average 35 years and a maximum of 74 years). They noted that the mean age of initial reproduction was relatively late when compared to temperate species, that is, 26 ± 9 years. Production of viable seeds in \i{}P. vaginata\i0{} was restricted by short growing seasons, low solar radiation, and low temperatures. During stressful years, \i{}P. vaginata\i0{} usually had low carbon allocation to reproduction, and low rates of mortality. Grulke and Bliss (1988) concluded that \i{}P. vaginata\i0{} has most characteristics of a stress-tolerant species. Bell and Bliss (1978) estimated that the roots of \i{}P. vaginata\i0{} live 3.4-7 years. \par{}Consaul and Gillespie (2001) found the species has been more frequently collected in Greenland (from where it was originally described), and in the western continental Northwest Territories and Nunavut, but very few specimens of \i{}P. vaginata\i0{} had been collected in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago. Some of the specimens from the islands have intermediate characteristics, for example, specimens from Baffin Island (CAN 312013 and CAN 295761) are very hairy, and approach \i{}P. angustata\i0{} in morphology. A specimen from Melville Island (CAN 502596) and one from Victoria Island (CAN 522664) have smaller trichomes on the glume and lemma margins than are typical for \i{}P. vaginata\i0{}, and more approach \i{}P. bruggemannii\i0{}. These specimens, as well as a collection from Tanquary Fiord, are indicated on the map. They are included in a current molecular study on species limits of Canadian Arctic \i{}Puccinellia\i0{} at the Canadian Museum of Nature.>

<This taxon was treated as \i{}Colpodium vahlianum\i0{} (Liebm.) Nevski, in Porsild (1964). It was placed in the genus \i{}Puccinellia\i0{}, subgenus \i{}Pseudocolpodium\i0{} (Tzvelev) W.E. Hughes, by Hughes and Halliday (1980). This subgenus differs from subgenus \i{}Puccinellia\i0{} in which all our other puccinellias are placed, in that the leaf epidermis is not differentiated into long and short cells, the rachilla is slender and abruptly thickened at the insertion of the florets, and the glumes, with divergent veins, are sub-equal, and almost as long as the lemma. It also differs from the other puccinellias observed in having leaves folded in bud, and bulliform cells on either side of the blade midvein. \par{}Consaul and Gillespie (2001) found this species to be close morphologically to the rest of the genus, and agreed with including it in the genus \i{}Puccinellia\i0{}. The characters that separate plants of this species most clearly from other \i{}Puccinellia\i0{} taxa are the very long first glume and the ratio of first glume to spikelet length. This species generally does not have trichomes on the lemma margins, but usually has small (less than 20 microns) and blunt trichomes on the margins of the glumes. The roots of this species are strikingly yellowish, thick and curly. This is a character also found to a certain extent in the arctic polyploid species of the genus, giving more evidence for treating it under the genus \i{}Puccinellia\i0{}.>

<Boivin (1967) published ?\i{}Maltea\i0{} for what he considered to be the intergeneric hybrid \i{}Phippsia\i0{} × \i{}Puccinellia\i0{}. As this is not a condensed formula, the name cannot be used for that intergeneric hybrid for which the correct name is ×\i{}Pucciphippsia\i0{} Tzvelev (1971). Boivin did, however, provide a Latin description and designate a type; consequently, \i{}Maltea\i0{} is a validly published generic name and is correct if its type is treated as belonging to a separate genus, not a nothogenus (Greuter et al. 1994). \par{}Hedberg (1962) found this hybrid growing at an archeological site, on Cornwallis Island, near the former site of the village at Resolute close to the seashore. His detailed description includes photographs comparing spikelets, leaf cross sections, and chromosome studies. Canadian ×\i{}Pucciphippsia\i0{} involves \i{}Phippsia algida\i0{} as the \i{}Phippsia\i0{} parent, but in Europe, hybrids with \i{}P. concinna\i0{} may occur (Hedberg 1962). This may explain slight differences between this description and that given by Halliday and Hughes (1980). A study of ×\i{}Pucciphippsia\i0{} in Svalbard indicated that specimens there were triploid and sterile. Additive banding in one enzyme supported its origin as a \i{}Puccinellia\i0{} ×\i{}Phippsia\i0{} hybrid, and morphological evidence suggested that \i{}P. algida\i0{} is the most probable \i{}Phippsia\i0{} parent (Steen et al. 2004).>

<Hultén (1959b) reported on the \i{}T. spicatum\i0{} complex and recognised several varieties, stating that plants in the High Arctic conform closely to subsp. \i{}spicatum\i0{} in having dense spike-like inflorescences and a violet colour zone on the glumes and lemmas, while their margins are brown. The culm is strongly pubescent with long, soft, and (except at the top) downward pointing hairs. The panicle branches are pubescent as well as the sheaths, and the awn is affixed at the upper third or fourth of the lemma and bent and twisted. The flowers considerably overtop the glumes. Randall and Hilu (1986) studied \i{}T. spicatum\i0{} throughout its North American distribution and concluded that the data for 33 morphological characters revealed extreme variation within the species and did not support the recognition of infraspecific taxa or the elevation of the hexaploids to specific rank. \par{}Elven et al. (2003) considered this a difficult case where "the status of the different entities described has varied among authors from species through subspecies, variety, and forma to nothing." In addition to the recent work by Randall and Hilu (1986), Syst. Bot. 11: 567-578, we should also consult some previous treatments, e.g., that of Jonsell (1975), Sv. Bot. Tidskr. 69. "There is a contrast between the homogeneity in the material from [mainland Europe] and the High Arctic and the heterogeneity in that from the Beringian area, western (Cordilleran) North America, northeastern North America, southern Greenland, and Iceland. From a European viewpoint it is difficult to neglect this difference entirely; some taxonomy should be involved" (Elven et al. 2003). \par{}Hultén (1959b) reported on the \i{}T. spicatum\i0{} complex and recognised [two subspecies and] several varieties [for the Arctic], stating that plants in the High Arctic conform closely to subsp. \i{}spicatum\i0{} in having dense spike-like inflorescences and a violet colour zone on the glumes and lemmas, while their margins are brown. The culm is strongly pubescent with long, soft, and (except at the top) downward pointing hairs. The panicle branches are pubescent as well as the sheaths, and the awn is affixed at the upper third or fourth of the lemma and bent and twisted. The flowers considerably overtop the glumes. Randall and Hilu (1986) studied \i{}T. spicatum\i0{} throughout its North American distribution and concluded that the data for 33 morphological characters revealed extreme variation within the species and did not support the recognition of infraspecific taxa or the elevation of the hexaploids to specific rank [\i{}molle/triflorum\i0{}] (Aiken).\par{}\i{}Trisetum spicatum\i0{} was found to be an early coloniser of oil spills in Alaska (Kershaw and Kershaw 1986).>

<Morphologically \i{}P. macounii\i0{} s.s. differs from \i{}P. keelei \i0{}in many features, e.g., basal sheaths much more persistent and firm, leaves nearly concolourous and paler green, scapes often numerous and ascending, and flowers much larger and with more numerous stamens. We can see little reason for lumping them within one species, except for the single feature of a narrow capsule with a pyramidal stigmatic disc. However, this feature is also shared with several Asian species. The plants we have seen of \i{}P. keelei\i0{} from arctic Canada (incl. Banks Island) closely correspond morphologically to those throughout Alaska and eastern Chukotka.\par{}Porsild (1945) described \i{}P. keelei\i0{} from Yukon, and Hultén (1945) described \i{}P. macounii\i0{} subsp. \i{}discolor\i0{} from Alaska. Subsequent authors have proposed that the names represent different entities. This assumption was based on publication of two decaploid chromosome counts for \i{}P. keelei\i0{} from Yukon (Mulligan and Porsild 1969, Porsild 1975) as different from the numerous tetraploid counts for \i{}P. macounii\i0{} subsp. \i{}discolor \i0{}[see above]. During field work in Alaska and Yukon in 1998-2003, we saw some variation. We tried to sort this into the two entities that were described, but we were not comfortable with the result. We collected plants conforming morphologically with \i{}P. keelei\i0{} as described in northern Yukon (British Mountains 1999, Richardson Mountains 2003) and in north-central Yukon (Ogilvie Mountains 2003), but they were all found to be tetraploid in flow cytometry (Solstad et al., unpublished). According to D.F. Murray (pers. comm.) the Mulligan voucher was originally identified as \i{}P. radicatum \i0{}Rottb. This fits well with reported decaploids from several populations of Alaskan and Yukon plants assigned to \i{}P. \i0\lquote\i{}radicatum\i0\rquote{} in the previous North American concept. Murray recollects that the Mulligan voucher was not representative of \i{}P. keelei\i0{} stating: \ldblquote{}So, the 2n=70 reports may be a red herring\u8213\'3feventually to be ignored.\rdblquote{} We consider the names\i{} P. keelei\i0{} and \i{}P. macounii\i0{} subsp. \i{}discolor\i0{} as contemporaneous namings of the same taxon of which \i{}P. keelei\i0{} is the valid name if accepted as a species.\par{}The morphologically closest relatives are found in the north Siberian and northeast Asian \i{}P. paucistaminum \i0{}Tolm. & V.V.Petrovsky group (\i{}P. paucistaminum\i0{}, \i{}P. minutiflorum\i0{} Tolm. and \i{}P. atrovirens \i0{}V.V.Petrovsky). Common features include the narrowly clavate capsules with a high conical stigmatic disc, the comparatively few stigmatic rays, and partly also the diffuse growth and preference for damp and densely vegetated grassy or mossy habitats. Main differences between \i{}P. keelei\i0{} and the \i{}P. paucistaminum\i0{} group are the lower ploidal level and the more numerous stamens of \i{}P. keelei\i0{}. Analyses of AFLP fragments also confirm a genetic connection between \i{}P. atrovirens\i0{} and \i{}P. paucistamineum\i0{} although the results are not that clear-cut probably due to polyploidisation and reticulation events (Solstad et al., unpublished results).>

<The taxonomy of \i{}Papaver\i0{} section \i{}Meconella\i0{} Spach is controversial both in the Arctic and in temperate and boreal regions. In the last 60-70 years several approaches have been taken for arctic Canadian species. Polunin (1940, p.223) accepted a broad \i{}P. radicatum\i0{} Rottb. in the eastern Canadian Arctic with the following justification: \ldblquote{}Whether or not the recent wholesale \lquote{}splitting\rquote{} of the Old World members of this group (cf. Nordhagen 1931) is justified I am quite unqualified to say, but certainly the material from within our area, variable as it is, seems to belong to one series that should be kept together under a single specific name\rdblquote{}. Fifteen years later Porsild (1955) followed the same policy for the poppies of the western Canadian Arctic, except that he accepted the Banks Island \i{}P. keelei\i0{} A.E.Porsild as a separate species. He commented, however, that: \ldblquote{}On the basis of such combination of characters, it may be possible to recognize within the Canadian Arctic Archipelago four \lquote{}races\rquote{} of \i{}P. radicatum\i0{}, each with a rather distinct geographical range\rdblquote{} (p. 118) without further elaboration.\par{}\tab{}Morphological, cytological and hybridization studies by Knaben (1959a, 1959b) resulted in her recognizing four non-intergrading species in the amphi-Atlantic region: a decaploid \i{}P. radicatum\i0{} s. str. which she considered as strictly European (Iceland, the Faeroes, and Scandinavia), a decaploid \i{}P. dahlianum\i0{} Nordh. as mainly high arctic in Greenland and arctic Europe, an octoploid \i{}P. laestadianum \i0{}(Nordh.) Nordh. as a local endemic in N Scandinavia, and an octoploid \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{} (Tolm.) Nordh. to which she assigned plants from N Russia, N Scandinavia, and all plants in Greenland and arctic Canada except for \i{}P. dahlianum\i0{}. She also recognized three New World subspecies of \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{}: subsp. \i{}occidentale\i0{} (A.E.Lundstr.) G.Knaben, subsp. \i{}porsildii\i0{} G.Knaben, and subsp. \i{}labradoricum\i0{} (Fedde) G.Knaben - all present in both Greenland and arctic Canada, and a Scandinavian subsp. \i{}scandinavicum\i0{} G.Knaben. Her treatment was supported by morphological features and partly by much lower fertility in crosses between races and species than within.\par{}\tab{}Confusion was caused by an ambiguous typification of the name \i{}P. radicatum.\i0{} Knaben (1958) proposed a typification based on Icelandic plants, further argued for by Knaben & Hylander (1970). Löve (1955) proposed a typification based on Greenlandic plants (i.e., Knaben\rquote{}s \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{}), based on a suggestion by Hultén (1945) and further argued by Löve (1962a, 1962b). In Löve\rquote{}s proposal, the Icelandic and Scandinavian plants are not \i{}P. radicatum\i0{}. The issue is now solved by (hopefully) final typifications of \i{}P. radicatum\i0{} on Icelandic material (Nilsson & Elven in Jonsell 2001) and also of \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{} on NW Russian material (Egorova 1998). Whereas Knaben\rquote{}s conclusions were accepted and applied in Europe, this was not the case in North America or Greenland. Böcher et al. (1978, p. 102) applied a broadly circumscribed \i{}P. \lquote{}radicatum\rquote{} \i0{}in Greenland but suggested three \lquote{}smaller\rquote{} species (\lquote{}småarter\rquote{} in Danish): one \i{}P.\i0{} sp. perhaps related to \i{}P. dahlianum\i0{}, another \i{}P.\i0{} sp. perhaps conspecific with \i{}P. cornwallisense\i0{} D.Löve (described from Cornwallis Island), and a \i{}P. \lquote{}radicatum\rquote\i0{} s. str. which they considered synonymous with \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{} sensu Knaben and with three subspecies: subsp. \i\lquote{}radicatum\rquote\i0{} (same as Knaben\rquote{}s \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{} subsp. \i{}occidentale\i0{}), subsp. \i{}labradoricum\i0{} and subsp. \i{}porsildii\i0{}. Böcher then closely followed Knaben except with the opposite meaning for the name \i{}P. radicatum\i0{}. The same was done by Porsild & Cody (1980) in that they accepted three species in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago: \i{}P. keelei\i0{} on Banks Island; \i{}P. cornwallisense\i0{} on most of the islands (and in N Greenland) but rare or absent on most of Baffin Island; and \i{}P. radicatum\i0{} (meaning \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{} as now typified) throughout. Major parts of the treatments of Böcher et al. (1978) and Porsild & Cody (1980) are reflected in the molecular data we now have available.\par{}\tab{}A major effort to clarify the taxonomy was made by Kiger & Murray (1997, for arctic poppies mainly by Murray) in Flora of North America. Besides \i{}P. keelei\i0{} (by them as \i{}P. macounii\i0{} subsp. \i{}discolor\i0{} (Hultén) Rändel ex D.F.Murray), they accepted three taxa in the islands: \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{}, \i{}P. radicatum\i0{} subsp. \i{}radicatum\i0{}, and \i{}P. radicatum\i0{} subsp. \i{}polare\i0{}. In their synonymy, Knaben\rquote{}s three Greenlandic and Canadian races of \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{} were included in \i{}P. radicatum\i0{} subsp. \i{}radicatum\i0{}, \i{}P. cornwallisense\i0{} was included in \i{}P. radicatum\i0{} subsp. \i{}polare\i0{} (which they, on the authority of Rändel 1974, considered as specifically different from \i{}P. dahlianum\i0{}), whereas their \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{} was based on the Russian description and included \i{}P. hultenii\i0{} Knaben as a synonym. Their treatment must have been based on an assumption that Knaben\rquote{}s Greenlandic-Canadian races of \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{} (their \i{}P. \lquote{}radicatum\rquote\i0{}) are specifically different from the N European \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{} (their \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{}). Many of the problems connected with the North American treatments are due to the persistent attempt in American tradition to apply European names to their poppies. \par{}\tab{}Our morphological and molecular (mainly AFLPs \u8213\'3f Amplified fragment length polymorphisms, a fingerprinting method) data are not in accordance with the Flora of North America treatment; they instead extend the taxonomy suggested by Böcher et al. (1978) and Porsild & Cody (1980), but with other names. There appear to be five separate entities (in addition \i{}P. keelei\i0{}), likely best recognized at the specific level, in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago. The main features of our provisional revised taxonomy are:\par{}\tab\par{}(1) \i{}Papaver dahlianum\i0{} (typified from mainland N Norway) and \i{}P. polare\i0{} (Tolm.) Perfil., (\i{}P. radicatum\i0{} subsp. \i{}polare\i0{}, \i{}P. dahlianum\i0{} subsp. \i{}polare \i0{}(Tolm.) Elven & Ö.Nilsson, typified from the Svalbard islands) are conspecific and not separable by molecular markers. They are also similar in morphology. \i{}Papaver dahlianum\i0{} (subsp. \i{}polare\i0{}) is widespread in northern and western parts of the islands but rare in central, southern and eastern parts. Our range conforms closely with that made by Petrovsky (1999) from morphological evidence alone. \i{}Papaver dahlianum\i0{} is morphologically close to \i{}P. cornwallisense\i0{} but separable on, leaf and leaf lobe shape (ovate in \i{}P. dahlianum\i0{} versus narrow, strap-shaped in \i{}P. cornwallisense\i0{}), leaf color (greyish green versus dark to bluish green), and in capsule shape (more or less elongated pear-shaped versus subglobular). Molecular markers place \i{}Papaver dahlianum\i0{} much closer to \i{}P. uschakovii\i0{} Tolm. & V.V.Petrovsky from Wrangel Island and to a yet unnamed N Alaskan entity than to \i{}P. cornwallisense\i0{}. Both \i{}Papaver dahlianum\i0{} and \i{}P. cornwallisense\i0{} are widespread in the Canadian Arctic, with overlapping ranges, but no clear intergradation has been observed in molecular markers. They are probably allopolyploids based on different parental combinations.\par{}\par{}(2) \i{}Papaver cornwallisense\i0{} is widespread (see above) but especially concentrated in the central, southern and eastern parts of the islands. This supports the proposal of Böcher et al. (1978). The \i{}P. cornwallisense\i0{} of Porsild & Cody (1980), however, includes both \i{}P. cornwallisense \i0{}and\i{} P. dahlianum\i0{}. The affinity of \i{}P. cornwallisense\i0{} judged by molecular markers is clearly to \i{}P. gorodkovii\i0{} in Beringia (also morphologically in leaf color, in leaf lobe and capsule shape, and in often smaller flowers). Our molecular results also conform very well with the map of \i{}P. cornwallisense \i0{}by Petrovsky (1999).\par{}\par{}(3) \i{}Papaver lapponicum\i0{} is polymorphic both in molecular markers and in morphology, but belongs to the same major group as \i{}P\i0{}. \i{}radicatum\i0{} (see next paragraph). Material from the Canadian Arctic Archipelago (except for most of Baffin Island) and from northern parts of Greenland constitute one subunit, corresponding with Knaben\rquote{}s subsp. \i{}occidentale\i0{} and also subsp. \i{}porsildii\i0{}. Material from NE Greenland, N Scandinavia and N Ural mountains belong in another subunit, corresponding with subsp. \i{}lapponicum\i0{} and including subsp. \i{}jugoricum \i0{}(Tolm.) Tolm. of the Ural Mountains. Material from Taimyr in N Siberia forms the third subunit and corresponds with subsp. \i{}orientale \i0{}Tolm. Much of the material we now assign to \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{} subsp. \i{}occidentale\i0{} was field identified as \i{}P. dahlianum\i0{} subsp. \i{}polare\i0{} because subsp. \i{}occidentale\i0{} superficially resembles \i{}P. dahlianum\i0{} morphologically (and even the original illustration of Lundström and his type specimen does). Molecular markers do not show close connections between \i{}P. dahlianum \i0{}and \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{} subsp. \i{}occidentale\i0{}.\par{}\i{}Papaver radicatum\i0{} (as typified) is, in our material, restricted to Iceland and Scandinavia. Its closest relatives are found to the east, in N Russia and NW Siberia. None of our numerous samples from all major parts of Greenland and the Canadian Arctic Archipelago confirm the occurrence of \i{}P. radicatum \i0{}in these areas. This supports the conclusions of Knaben (1959a, 1959b) and also those of Böcher et al. (1978) and Porsild & Cody (1980), but under different names.\par{}\par{}(4) Material from the easternmost parts of the Canadian Arctic Archipelago and W Greenland differ from all the other groups in molecular markers and are also distinct in morphological features. These plants were recognized early as a race \i\lquote{}labradoricum\rquote\i0{} and treated by Knaben as \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{} subsp. \i{}labradoricum\i0{}. The molecular data indicate that \i{}Papaver \lquote{}labradoricum\rquote\i0{} is a distinct entity and does not belong to the \i{}P. radicatum\i0{}-\i{}lapponicum\i0{} complex (nor to the \i{}P. dahlianum\i0{}-\i{}cornwallisense\i0{} complex). It should therefore be separated from \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{} at the specific level and recognized as \i{}P. \lquote{}labradoricum\rquote{}.\i0{} At present \i{}P. \lquote{}labradoricum\rquote\i0{} is known from SW and W Greenland, Baffin Island, N Labrador and N Quebec, and in most of these regions it seems to be the only species of \i{}Papaver\i0{}. \i{}Papaver \lquote{}labradoricum\rquote\i0{} resembles European \i{}P. radicatum\i0{} in some features (numerous and erect stems, comparatively small and not fully open flowers, capsule shape) but differs in leaf shape (lobes always narrowly ovate-lanceolate, simple and mostly diverging at a small angle from the mid axis). Molecular markes indicate that the Asian Beringian \i{}P. detritophilum \i0{}is the closest relative.\par{}\par{}(5) Plants from several sites on Banks Island were assigned to a separate and quite distinct molecular group that connects to several still taxonomically unresolved taxa in western and Beringian North America (including the Cordilleran \i{}P. kluanense\i0{}) and also in Beringian Asia, especially in Wrangel Island, but is distinctly different also from these. The Banks Island plants most probably represent an undescribed species.\par{}\b\par{}Provisional key to \i{}Papaver\i0{} spp. (not including \i{}P. keelei\i0{})\par{}\b0\par{}1. Gynoecium (ovary plus stigmas) and fruit obconical, obovate, or hemispherical, broadest apically. Flowering stems ascending. Anthers 20-30. Hairs on flowering stems much longer than diameter of stem, dark brown to nearly black in upper part of flowering stem, mostly spreading - 2\par{}\par{}1. Gynoecium and fruit broadly oblong, broadest at the middle or from the middle and upwards. Flowering stems more or less erect. Anthers 30-60. Hairs of flowering stems mostly as long as diameter of stem or shorter, brown in upper part of flowering stem, subappressed to spreading - 3\par{}\par{}2. Gynoecium and fruit broadly obconical or hemispherical, about as broad as long. Gynoecium bristles shiny black (becoming deep brown in fruit). Leaf lobes on well developed plants more or less distant and more or less strap-shaped - \i{}P. cornwallisense\i0\par{}\par{}2. Gynoecium and fruit obconical or obovate, longer than broad. Gynoecium bristles dark golden brown (becoming paler in fruit). Leaf lobes on well developed plants close to each other and partly overlapping, ovate-oblong - \i{}P. dahlianum\i0{} subsp. \i{}polare\par{}\par{}\i0{}3. Gynoecium and fruit obconical, as broad at top as at middle. Leaves with simple lobes (very rarely secondarily lobed); lobe pairs nearly equidistant; lobes mostly with an angle of 25-45° with blade mid axis, often distinctly pointing forwards - \i{}P.\i0{} \lquote\i{}labradoricum\i0\rquote\par{}\par{}3. Gynoecium and fruit obovate, broader at the middle than at the top (narrowing towards the stigmatic disc). Leaves of well developed plants mostly with secondary division of some lobes; lower lobe pair(s) more distant from upper pairs; lobes mostly with an angle of 30-60° with blade mid axis, not pointing forward - 4\par{}\par{}4. Stigmatic disc flat or slightly convex, not peaked. Hairs on flowering stems not appressed. Leaf lobes oblanceolate in outline, subacute, indistinctly narrowing at base of lobe - \i{}P. lapponicum\i0{} subsp. \i{}occidentale\i0\par{}\par{}4. Stigmatic disc peaked. Hairs on flowering stems appressed. Leaf lobes oblong-obovate in outline, distinctly narrowing at base of lobe - \i{}P.\i0{} \i{}sp. \i0\lquote{}Banks\rquote{}>

<Burt (2000) said that in northcentral continental North America, this species can be confused with the flower of the \i{}akpik\i0{}, or cloudberry (\i{}Rubus chamaemorus\i0{}), but the \i{}akpik\i0{} has both petals and sepals, and its stem leaves are alternate rather than whorled and much larger than the anemone. On continental North America when this anemone is in full bloom, it is much taller and more flexible than the cloudberry.>

<Dutton et al. (1997), in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{}, treated this taxon as \i{}Anemone patens \i0{}var.\i{} multifida\i0{}. They were aware that this taxon is often placed in the genus \i{}Pulsatilla\i0{} Miller on the basis of the long plumose achene beaks but claimed that recent phylogentic analyses of \i{}Anemone\i0{} in the broad sense indicated that it should be subsumed within \i{}Anemone\i0{} (Hoot et al. 1994). They commented that \i{}Anemone patens\i0{} var.\i{} multifida\i0{} has frequently been recognised as a subspecies of \i{}A. patens\i0{}.
