A rare form that Polunin (1940) considered to have been collected in the Arctic Archipelago. \par{}Porsild (1957) and Hultén (1968), Porsild and Cody (1980) did not recognise any of the intraspecific taxa in the above list. \i{}Saxifraga cernua\i0{} is one of the chief plants in the High Arctic. It has a very wide range of tolerance to most environmental conditions, occurring in almost all habitats from wet to very dry and sheltered to exposed, and doing especially well in manured areas and snow patches. It is highly resistant to frost. This taxon appears to be a phenotypically plastic one in which various expressions have been named. \par{}\i{}Saxifraga cernua\i0{} was one of seven arctic species studied at Truelove Inlet, Devon Island (Atkin et al. 1993), for their ability to utilise nitrate nitrogen under field conditions. \i{}Saxifraga cernua\i0{}, \i{}S. oppositifolia\i0{}, \i{}Cerastium alpinum, Oxyria digyna\i0{}, and \i{}Papaver radicatum\i0{} s.l. were able to use nitrate nitrogen, while \i{}Dryas integrifolia\i0{} and \i{}Salix arctica\i0{} showed little utilisation. Porsild (1957, 1964) and Porsild and Cody (1980) recognised a single taxon for this species and did not accept any of the four intraspecific taxa recognised by Polunin (1940). No reason to do so has been found. \par{}Molau (1992) discussed the occurrence of sexual reproduction in this species. \par{}Kjølner et al. (2004) studied the clonal diversity in \i{}S. cernua\i0{} using amplified fragment length polymorphisn and random amplified polymorphic DNA markers.>

<This is a circumpolar arctic-alpine species that is complicated and poorly studied. "Some forms have been described as species. The majority of botanists now regard \i{}S. cespitosa\i0{} as a polymorphic species with several morphologically poorly differentiated races" (Zhmylev, in Elven et al. (2003)). \par{}This polymorphous species varies greatly in form and size with local conditions. It forms loose stands with branched inflorescences growing 20 cm or more high in sheltered rocky or manured places and dense cushions bearing a few unifloral axes, sometimes only 2 or 3 cm high in unfavourable situations. Distinct taxa have been recognised based on this variation. We have not maintained the three that Porsild (1957) and Porsild and Cody (1980) recognised as occurring in northern Canada. They are as follows: \par{}1. subsp. \b\i{}cespitosa\b0\i0{} (= subsp. \i{}eucespitosa\i0{} Engl. and Irmsch. an invalid name). Flowers relatively large, 8-10 mm wide, usually 3, rarely 1 or 2, Amphi-Atlantic subarctic. \par{}2. subsp. \b\i{}uniflora\b0\i0{} (R. Br.)Porsild. Flowers smaller, 4-7 mm wide, mostly solitary, calyx purplish black, circumpolar with large gaps. \par{}3. subsp. \b\i{}exaratoides\b0\i0{} (Simm) Engl. and Irmsch. emend. Porsild. Flowers mostly 3, calyx greenish purple, endemic to Paleozoic parts of Hudson Bay region, north to Ellesmere Island (Porsild 1955). \par{}Polunin (1940, p. 257) observed that this is "one of the commonest and hardiest of arctic plants, having such a wide range of tolerance to most environmental conditions that it can grow in almost any habitat. However, it prefers open clayey plains and sandy or gravelly seashores or exposed ridges, being unable to withstand much competition .... and hence found only occasionally in closed communities". \par{}Whittaker (1993), studying plant population patterns in the Storbreen glacier foreland succession, 61°35'N, 8°E, found that \i{}S. cespitosa\i0{} and \i{}Arabis alpina\i0{} L. are visually the most characteristic forbes of the youngest ground. Both species peaked in local frequency within 30 years of deglaciation in sites close to the glacier snout and subject to severe physical disturbance by periglacial activity. They had virtually disappeared from the vegetation within approximately 50 years.\par{}Crawford et al. (1994) found a uniquely high level of anoxic tolerance in Spitsbergen populations of this species and \i{}S. cernua, S. foliolosa\i0{},\i{} S. hieracifolia\i0{}, and \i{}S. oppositifolia\i0{}. Plants have the ability to maintain turgid green leaves throughout a period of anoxia and into the recovery phase. This is unusual, as leaves normally loose turgor and wither rapidly when deprived of oxygen. Tests on more southern populations from Norway, Iceland, and Scotland failed to find equivalent ability to survive oxygen deprivation. This suggests a different evolutionary history and the idea that some arctic populations may have survived the Pleistocene epoch at high latitudes in ice-free polar deserts. \par{}\i{}Saxifraga cespitosa\i0{} is considered a \lquote{}short-distance disperser\rquote{} and a selfing polypoid (Tollefsrud et al. 1998). \par{}North American authors as late as Porsild and Cody (1980) have recognised several races as subspecies (see above), and these races may possibly represent some reality, but the problem is that the variation has not been treated in a similar way in northwestern Europe or Russia. In Russia, subsp. \i{}monticola\i0{} (Small) A.E. Porsild is recognised for Russian Far East (as \i{}S. monticola\i0{} (Small) Fedde), whereas all other material is combined in \i{}S. cespitosa\i0{}. Note that \i{}'monticola'\i0{} is an American name and that Porsild and Cody considered it as a Cordilleran endemic (not as a Russian or amphi-Beringian plant). The type of Small's \i{}Muscaria monticola\i0{} is as follows: Canada: Alberta, Banff Natl. Park, Tunnel Mt., 23.06.1899, leg. W.C.McCalla 2288 (NY) holotype (Elven, personal communication, 2005).\par{}This approach was followed by Zhmylev, in Elven et al. (2003). In Svalbard, Rönning (1996) recognised some characteristic yellow-flowered plants with half-closed flowers and narrow petals as a separate \i{}S. aurea\i0{} (Hada\u269\'3f) Rönning, a name that is a homonym several times. Such plants may differ in some genetic markers (Brochmann unpublished) and have their own ecology, mainly in snowbeds. However, similar plants occur as populations elsewhere, such as, occasionally in southern and northern Norway (Elven et al. 2003).>

<Elven et al. (2003) noted that this species is superficially similar to \i{}S. oppositifolia\i0{}, but differs in its grey-green foliage and alternate leaves. It was first collected on the Arctic Archipelago in 1968. It is possibly under-collected, as it resembles lichens when not flowering. "It is an Amphi-Beringian mainly arctic species, closely related to \i{}S. hemisphaerica\i0{} Hooker f. and Thoms., distributed in the Himalayas high mountains" (Zhmylev, in Elven et al. (2003).>

<Polunin (1940) recognised both var. \i{}hirculus\i0{} and var. \i{}propinqua\i0{} as occurring in the Canadian Arctic. Porsild (1957) indicated that var. \i{}hirculus\i0{} is a circumpolar arctic-alpine species and considered that only var. \i{}propinqua\i0{} occurs in the eastern Canadian Arctic Archipelago. Polunin (1940) noted that this taxon exhibits considerable variation in our area. Hedberg (1967), in a study of taxonomic differentiation in \i{}S. hirculus\i0{}, found that field fixations of specimens from Arctic Canada yielded two chromosome numbers, 2\i{}n\i0{} = 16, for plants from northern Canada, Victoria and Southampton Island, and northern Alaska (10 counts). He also reported one triploid count (2\i{}n\i0{} = 24) as \i{}'propinqua'\i0{}) from Cornwallis Island. All the plants he assigned to subsp. \i{}propinqua\i0{}. \par{}Hedberg (1992) argued that \i{}S. hirculus\i0{} s.l. is an arctic-boreal aggregate developed from the very diverse 'Himalayan' centre of sect. \i{}Ciliatae\i0{} (he stated that 54 species were known from Nepal alone). He accepted one northern species with four subspecies, three of which are present in the Arctic: a tetraploid subsp. \i{}hirculus\i0{} in European Russia, Siberia, Alaska, and Canada; a diploid subsp. \i{}propinqua\i0{} in eastern Chukotka, Alaska, Canada, and northeastern Greenland; and a tetraploid subsp. \i{}compacta\i0{} in eastern Greenland, Iceland, Svalbard, northeastern Russia, Siberia, Russian Far East, Alaska, and northwesternmost Canada. A diploid subsp. \i{}coloradensis\i0{} Hedberg is recognised in southwestern USA: Colorado. Hedberg (1992) presented morphological and cytological support for his proposal. His detailed cytotaxonomic study of the species as a whole concluded that most of the material of \i{}S. hirculus\i0{} studied could be easily distributed between these above-named four morphologically and geographically distinguishable populations and that they deserved taxonomic recognition although intermediates were found wherever the populations met. He indicated that only subsp. \i{}propinqua\i0{} occurs in the eastern Canada Arctic. \par{}Zhmylev (in Elven et al. 2003) considerd \i{}S. hirculus\i0{} as a circumpolar arctic-boreal species of considerable morphological variability. Shortly, rhizomatous, diploid and tetraploid plants (2\i{}n\i0{} = 16, 32), often treated as subsp. \i{}propinqua\i0{}, are found in high-arctic regions and mountain ridge tundra. In southern tundra, in wet mires and damp meadows are found tetraploid plants with long rhizomes, subsp. \i{}hirculus\i0{}. However, the other characters (e.g., shape of petals and sepals, flowers number) are only slightly correlated with growth form. Zhmylev (in Elven et al. 2005) proposed that "ecological-morphological races of \i{}S. hirculus\i0{} should not be accepted at subspecific or specific rank." Elven and Murray (in Elven et al. 2005) "tentatively accept his conclusion and propose informal entry of Hedberg's entities. Molecular studies could be rewarding in this intriguing complex. Note that Hedberg (1992) only mapped and reported material he had inspected."\par{}Warncke et al. (1993) listed 76 species of insects visiting \i{}S. hirculus\i0{} at the only site where it occurs in Switzerland. Based on the number of flower visits, they found four species were dominant, and only two of the 76 species were among the visitors to flowers of \i{}S. hirculus\i0{} in Denmark. \par{}>

<This circumpolar arctic-alpine species differs from \i{}S. rivularis\i0{} s.s. in its tiny size, absence of underground stolons and more developed hypanthium. These distinctions, however, are not always well expressed (Zhmylev, in Elven et al. 2003). Jørgensen & Elven (in Elven et al. 2005) said that "these distinctions (except for the stolons) are not always obvious, but Jørgensen (2004) and Jørgensen et al. (2006) summarised some additional differences."\par{}Polunin (1940) noted that this plant may penetrate farther into very late-melting snow patches than any other angiosperm. It is frequent almost everywhere, and in places rather abundant, although so small as to be often overlooked. \par{}Löve and Löve (1975) sorted the diploid counts into two subspecies of \i{}S. hyperborea\i0{}: subsp. \i{}hyperborea\i0{} in the northern Arctic; and subsp. \i{}debilis\i0{} in the broadly Pacific area, including counts around the Bering Strait, in western North America, and also a southern Siberian count (Krogulevich 1971, see above). \par{}There are two basic diploids (2\i{}n\i0{} = 26) represented by the amphi-Pacific and amphi-Beringian \i{}S. bracteata\i0{} D. Don and the circumpolar and arctic-alpine \i{}S. hyperborea\i0{} R. Br. The Cordilleran \i{}S. flexuosa\i0{} Sternb. is inseparable from \i{}S. hyperborea\i0{} in molecular markers and also nearly inseparable in all studied morphological characters which overlap in every character considered. It probably represents some kind of segregate south of the Cordilleran glaciation but has either survived in or reinvaded the Beringian areas. Transitions between the \i{}'flexuosa'\i0{} and \i{}'hyperborea'\i0{} morphologies are very abundant in northern Alaska and Yukon. The amphi-Atlantic \i{}Saxifraga rivularis\i0{} L. and the now amphi-Beringian \i{}S. arctolitoralis\i0{} Jurtz. and V.V.Petrovsky are allotetraploids.\par{}>

<This circumpolar arctic-alpine species shows considerable variability of habit, cilia length and hydathode number on the leaves, shape and pubescence of sepals, size and colour of petals. However, the geographical pattern of this morphological polymorphism is not clear. In this connection the majority of botanists accept a broad interpretation of \i{}S. oppositifolia\i0{} (Zhmylev, in Elven et al. 2003). \par{}The variation in \i{}S. oppositifolia\i0{} was the basis of a study by Teeri (1972) at Truelove Inlet, Devon Island. He concluded that distinct forms had been named as taxa, which were merely expressions of a single species that shows remarkable vegetatively phenotypic plasticity with little reliable genotypic basis on which to separate infraspecific taxa. \par{}Brysting et al. (1996) studied the purple saxifrage on Svalbard to determine whether there were two taxa or one. They concluded the conspicuous variation probably results from local, in situ ecoclinal differentiation, which is without taxonomic significance but is important in the context of arctic conservation biology and the potential impact of global warming on Arctic vegetation. \par{}Boris Yurtsev has suggested that there are two taxa within \i{}S. oppositifolia\i0{} in Canada, one with glabrous sepals, the other with glandular hairs on the sepals (personal communication, 1997). In a survey of specimens at CAN plants with glandular sepals there were plants with specimens with densely matted hairs on the sepals, and others with sparse or few hairs. The type specimen of the name "\i{}smalliana\i0{}" has almost no hairs on the sepals. \par{}Polunin (1940) considered this to be one of the common species in the Arctic Archipelago and possibly one of the most numerous of all arctic species. It dominates large tracts of country in the Far North, if the ecological term "dominates" can be used when the total vegetation is extremely sparse and largely limited to occasional tufts of this one species. He considered it possibly the hardiest of all phanerogams, at least in cold-rigour, occurring on the most exposed ridges and hill tops, often where no other vascular plants can grow. This may be because of the unique structure of the leaves. Elven (personal communication, 2005) noted that this is the northernmost flowering plant in the world, occurring as it does on the off-shore islands north of Greenland. Polunin (1940, p. 268) remarked that "\i{}S. oppositifolia\i0{} ... before and after flowering is among the most squalid-looking of plants, forming untidy brownish mats or tussocks in barren and often dusty situations. When it blooms it must be reckoned among the world's greatest beauties, especially as it stands out in its usually bleak and desolate surroundings. Unfortunately, few ever see it at its best, which is surely in the Far North, for it is so quickly over that the vast majority of the ever-increasing band of summer visitors to arctic parts come too late." \par{}The internal structure of the leaves led Galloe (1910) to consider this species a xerophyte. The upper epidermal cells have fairly straight lateral walls with numerous pits. Only the part of the leaf that is covered with neighbouring leaves bears stomata, while the light-exposed surface is almost without them. This was regarded as protection against excessive transpiration by Lazniewski (1896). Galloe (1910) considered the distribution of the stomata represented a primitive form of bud-protection in developing leaves in a species where bud scales are absent. \par{}Gabrielsen et al. (1997) analysed 18 populations of this species from Norway, Svalbard, and Novaya Zemlya, using RAPDs DNA technology, and found more variation in the populations from the High Arctic than further south. Their results suggested that there is more inbreeding towards the north, probably because of lower pollinator activity. \par{}Gugerli et al. (1999) investigated the genetic variation of \i{}S. oppositifolia\i0{} from 10 populations of the Alps in southern Switzerland using RAPDs. They found the genetic variation was mainly within populations (95%), whereas less than 5% was found among populations. They assumed the high outcrossing rate, rare clonal reproductions, and some long-distance dispersal even among topographically separated populations are the crucial determinants for the pattern of genetic variation found in the investigated areas. \par{}Abbot et al. (2000) examined the chloroplast DNA (cpDNA) restriction site variation among 548 plants sampled from 90 different populations from around the circumpolar and circumboreal area and found 14 cpDNA haplotypes. From their phylogenetic analysis of the cpDNA variation, they suggested that this species first occurred in the Arctic in western Beringia before it migrated east and west to achieve a circumpolar distribution. They suggested that the geographical distribution of cpDNA variation in the species supports the hypothesis that during Pleistocene glaciations, some plant refugia were located in the Arctic as well as at more southern latitudes.\par{}Aiken et al. (2005) examined growth forms and the presence or absence of hairs on the surfaces of the sepals of plants of \i{}Saxifraga oppositifolia \i0{}L., on type specimens and for more than 400 herbarium specimens collected from all over North America and Europe. No morphological differences are associated with three different chromosome numbers known for \i{}S oppositifolia\i0{} plants from the area of the North American type specimens, and DNA analyses done mainly on European specimens but also including a potential candidate for the name \ldblquote{}smalliana\rdblquote{} gave inconclusive results. Thus, chromosome and DNA data join these morphological data on growth forms and the occurrence of sepal hairs, to discourage recognising subspecies among plants occurring in North America. Aiken et al. (2005) reported that the type specimen of \i{}S. oppositifolia\i0{} subsp. \i{}smalliana \i0{}(\i{}S. pulvinata\i0{}) from the Yukon has compact plants and flowers that have sepal surfaces with a few sparse hairs.>

<Warming (1909) noted that the leaves after dying persist for a long time in a black, decaying condition. In northern Europe, this species belongs to a complex in which polymorphic entities have been recorded (Engler and Irmscher 1919). Polunin (1940) suggested that in the Arctic Archipelago it appears to vary very little. \par{}Galloe (1910) noted that each tooth of the leaves has a vein that terminates in a hydathode with a large cavity. The epidermis of the hydathode has 1-2 water pores, and some of the cells are elongated as papillae. In many of the cells of the mesophyll there are quantities of tanin. \par{}Zhmylev in Elven et al. (2003) noted this "Amphi-Atlantic, arctic-alpine, polymorphic species is widely distributed in the mountains of western and central Europe. Arctic plants differ from the typical race (2\i{}n\i0{} = 28) in having longer different testa papillae and thicker raphe, marking the place of capsule dehiscence. American botanists have regarded arctic plants as \i{}S. paniculata\i0{} subsp. \i{}neogaea\i0{} (2\i{}n\i0{} = 28). The variability of \i{}S. paniculata\i0{}, however, is fairly large, so that the differences may not have any taxonomic value." \par{}There is a discrepancy between Löve and Löve (1975), which included Iceland and Greenland plants in subsp. \i{}neogaea\i0{}, and Hultén and Fries (1986), which restricted subsp. \i{}neogaea\i0{} to Canada and U.S.A. (Elven in Elven et al. 2003).>

<This species is sometimes recognised as \i{}Saxifraga flagellaris\i0{} subsp. \i{}platysepala\i0{} (Porsild 1964, Porsild and Cody 1980). \par{}Porsild and Cody (1980) recognised: \par{}1. \b\i{}Saxifraga flagellaris\b0{} \i0{}subsp. \b\i{}flagellaris\b0\i0{}: in which the hypanthium is broadly campanulate (bell-shaped) and green. It is of Amphi-Beringian range, and known only from calcareous rocks along the east slopes of the Mackenzie and Richardson Mountains. \par{}2. \b\i{}S. flagellaris\b0{} \i0{}subsp. \b\i{}platysepala\b0\i0{} (Trautv.) Porsild: is a High Arctic and nearly circumpolar taxon. It is mostly 1-flowered, with a turbinate (top-like), rather than campanulate hypanthium with dark purple sepals that are obovate-oblong, united in the lower third, and covered by stalked, purple-headed glands. They indicated that this taxon has not been reported from the continent. Polunin (1940) commented that although the species as a whole is very variable he had not been able to find marked taxa within the Canadian Arctic.\par{}The geographic separation of the subspecies recognised in Porsild and Cody (1980) and the strength of distinct characters are regarded as sufficient to justify recognising the taxon as a distinct species. However, Porsild and Cody's (1980) subsp. \i{}flagellaris\i0{} is \i{}Saxifraga setigera\i0{} Pursh (or \i{}S. flagellaris\i0{} subsp. \i{}setigera\i0{} (Pursh) Tolm.). Willdenow's \i{}S. flagellaris\i0{} s. str. is probably restricted to the Caucasus (Elven, 2005, personal communication).\par{}Galloe (1910), discussing the fleshy leaves of \i{}S. flagellaris\i0{}, suggested there are three features that appear to be useless rudiments inherited from parent plants with foliage leaves similar in structure to those of the present-day \i{}S. flagellaris\i0{}. These are (a) functionless (permanently closed) stomata, (b) functionless hydathodes (in which the water pores are closed), and (c) light-orientated (obliquely placed) palisade cells. \par{}Polunin (1940, p. 264) noted that "this extremely attractive high-arctic and alpine species, was known to the old sailors and whalers as 'spider plant' on account of its round 'body' and long, leg-like 'flagellae' subtending daughter individuals". He reported curious contradictions with regard to substrate pH relationships. Scholander (1934) says that it is "fairly common in North-East Land, (Greenland) except in the pure dolomite areas, where it is almost lacking". Gelting (1934) wrote, "as I have not found the species outside soil rich in lime, I consider it calciphilous". Polunin (1940) stated that he had never found it on soils that were at all highly calcareous either in Spitsbergen or in Arctic America, but always in rather exposed barren situations where the soil was nevertheless lastingly damp, owing to poor drainage or occasionally to feeding from a long-lasting snowdrift. Polunin's observations are true for plants found growing beside the road to "Satellite hill" near Resolute Bay, Cornwallis Island.>

<Polunin (1940) indicated that this is one of the most ubiquitous and generally common of arctic plants. At that time he included \i{}S. hyperborea\i0{} in \i{}S. rivularis\i0{}, and almost all his statements refer to the former rather than the latter.\par{}This is an Amphi-Atlantic arctic species that previously included \i{}S. hyperborea\i0{}. "At present, only plants with stolons and 2\i{}n\i0{} = 52 are attributed to \i{}S. rivularis\i0{}. However, the [distinctiveness of the growth forms] and other morphological distinctions between \i{}S. rivularis\i0{} and \i{}S. hyperborea\i0{} are not always obvious" (Zhmylev in Elven et al. 2003), and the problem was studied by Jørgensen (2004).\par{}Jørgensen (2004), in a thesis done at Oslo (with Elven, R., Stedje, B., Gabrielsen, T.M., and Brochmann, C.), studied reticulate evolution and species delimitation in the arctic \i{}Saxifraga rivularis\i0{} complex and found there is a very good correspondence between molecular genetic evidence, chromosome ploidy evidence, and morphological evidence for the structure they proposed in the \i{}Saxifraga rivularis\i0{} group.\par{}The amphi-Atlantic \i{}Saxifraga rivularis\i0{} L. subsp. \i{}rivularis\i0{} and the now amphi-Beringian \i{}S. rivularis \i0{}subsp.\i{} arctolitoralis\i0{} (Jurtzev & Petrovsky) M.H.Jørg. & Elven are allotetraploids, and they have a common parentage from one or more crossed between \i{}S. bracteata\i0{} and \i{}S. hyperborea\i0{}. The origin is therefore suspected to be Beringian. However, there is a vast gap between the ranges of these two subspecies, also associated with some small morphological differences and some slight molecular differences. It is therefore appropriate to recognise them as two subspecies, but not as two species. \par{}A survey of the Alaska and Yukon material (in ALA) proved \i{}S. rivularis\i0{} subsp. \i{}arctolitoralis\i0{} to be fairly common in NW and N Alaska. It reaches close to the Canadian border but has not yet been found in Canada.>

<The northernmost record, and first collection from the Arctic Archipelago, is from Melville Island, Sabine Peninsula, Barrow Dome, 76°38'N, 109°05'W, 21 July 1971, \i{}M. Kuc 157\i0{} (Canada). There have been three other collections from different places on Melville Island. This tiny plant is easily overlooked and is probably under-collected. Plants found in Canada belong to subsp. \i{}serpyllifolia\i0{}. It is an Amphi-Beringian mainly arctic subspecies with glabrous leaves on the vegetative shoots and yellow flowers. Transitional forms to subsp. \i{}glandulosa\i0{}, with slightly pubescent leaves on the vegetative shoots, can be found rarely in the lower reaches of the Lena river and in the southern regions of the Siberian part of the area (Zhmylev, in Elven et al. 2003).>

<Galloe (1910) considered this species a xerophyte based on the habitats where it grows and the internal anatomy of leaves. \par{}This species is not known outside of North America and Greenland. Polunin (1940) stated that "the vast majority of the specimens from the Canadian Arctic Archipelago have the leaves tricuspidate, and so belong to the typical form. Some however, especially when growing in exposed habitats, have most of their leaves lacking these conspicuous lateral teeth, and a few from widely separate places have all the leaves sub-entire". Polunin (1938) recognised a forma \i{}subintegrifolia\i0{} (Abrom.) Polunin, but this was not taken up by Porsild (1957). \par{}Polunin (1940, p. 263) stated that "\i{}S. tricuspidata\i0{} varies little in our area, except in luxuriance. Thus the axes may sometimes be only 5 cm high, although generally they rise to double this height and sometimes exceed 15 cm. Such luxuriant specimens growing in the most favourable situations may form extensive mats, especially in the south. The plant generally looks reddish, but in damp and shaded crevices there occur lengthened green forms, which are usually sterile". No reason for maintaining the forma recognised by Polunin (1940) has been found.>

<Mosquin (1971) made a very good case for recognition of two subspecies, one widespread (subsp. \i{}lewisii\i0{}) and one restricted to the Hudson and James Bay shores (subsp. \i{}lepagei\i0{}). The plants collected in the Arctic Archipelago are subsp. \i{}lewisii\i0{}. One collection is from the site of a Rough-legged Hawk (\i{}Buteo lagopus\i0{}) nest, suggesting that it was accidentally introduced to the area by birds.\par{}Kikuchi (1929) reported on the difference of chromosome numbers in \i{}Linum\i0{} species.>

<\i{}Salix alaxensis \i0{}is one of the tallest growing willows in the Arctic Archipelago. In the Masik River valley, southwestern Banks Island, it forms a dominating shrub tundra in association with \i{}S. pulchra\i0{} and \i{}S. richardsonii\i0{} (Kuc 1970, 1974). It occurs in northern Ungava (Maycock 1963), but evidently it has not been able to cross the Hudson Straits to Baffin Island.>

<This circumpolar species is morphologically polymorphic and nomenclaturally confused. Many botanists studying the flora of the Arctic Archipelago have collected what they thought were two or three species of \i{}Salix\i0{} only to find on their return that they were all \i{}S. arctica\i0{}. Some taxonomists (Hultén 1967, 1971) have recognised three subspecies in \i{}S. arctica\i0{}: (1) subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{} (circumpolar from Iceland and the Faeroe Islands across northern Russia, Alaska, and Canada to Greenland, south to the Hudson Bay shores of Ontario and the Gasp\u8218\'82 Peninsula), (2) subsp. \i{}crassijulis\i0{} (a North Pacific race ranging from Kamchatka and the Russian Far East to the Aleutian Islands, south central and southeastern Alaska along the coast to northern Washington), and (3) subsp. \i{}torulosa\i0{} (ranging from the mountains of Central Asia to Kamchatka and the Bering Straits, the Brooks Range and the Rocky Mountains in Alaska, south in the cordillera to southern British Columbia and Alberta). While the phytogeographic pattern of these three races is appealing, they are actually very difficult or impossible to separate morphologically. Argus (1973) presented evidence that the latter two subspecies were environmental modifications of one species. He reported that robust plants in the Glacier Bay area of southeastern Alaska (\i{}S. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}crassijulis\i0{}) were associated with nitrogen-rich \i{}Alnus\i0{} thickets, whereas small plants (\i{}S. arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}torulosa\i0{}) from the same area were growing on open moraine. Others have also reported environmental modification of \i{}S. arctica\i0{}. Savile (1964) noted that depauperate specimens occurred in depressions behind beach ridges where they may be immersed in years of high water. Soper and Powell (1985) observed that this species varied considerably according to ecological and edaphic conditions. Dawson (1987) showed that the female-biased sex ratios in \i{}S. arctica\i0{} are environmentally controlled. He found that female plants are significantly over-represented in mesic-wet, more fertile, low soil temperature sites, whereas male plants are predominant in drier, less fertile sites. In light of this evidence, the possibility that the complex morphological variability within \i{}S. arctica\i0{} may be ecophenic or ecotypic deserves study. Other characters cited to separate subsp. \i{}torulosa\i0{} (Hultén 1971), including leaf shape and floral bract colour, do not withstand scrutiny (Argus 1973, Raup 1959). The morphological variability within \i{}S. arctica\i0{}, although striking, does not seem to reflect taxonomic differences. \par{}Specimens of \i{}Salix arctica\i0{} of various ages have been reported in the arctic. Gelting (1934) found a specimen of about 130 years in Franz Joseph Fjord, East Greenland. In the Mesters Vig area of East Greenland (King Oscars Fjord), Raup (1965) reported that most specimens were about 60 years old, with one reaching 180 years and another 236 years. Savile (1979) reported the oldest Canadian material, 85 years, from Lake Hazen, Ellesmere Island (Savile 1979). \par{}In northern Greenland, \i{}Salix arctica\i0{} is one of the primary foods for muskox, arctic hare, and collared lemming (Klein and Bay 1991). \par{}\b{}Hybrids\b0{} \par{}\i{}Salix arctica\i0{} × \i{}S. arctophila\i0{} (\i{}S\i0{}. ×\i{}hudsonensis \i0{}C. K. Schneider) (Argus, in press, Polunin 1940). There are a number of putative hybrids in the Canadian Museum of Nature collection from Baffin and Ellesmere islands. These plants have leaves and branchlets that are almost glabrous as in \i{}S. arctophila\i0{}, but bearing only a few long hairs. In addition, the ovaries have flattened, refractive hairs as in \i{}S. arctica\i0{}, not ribbon-like hairs as in \i{}S. arctophila\i0{}. A specimen from Bylot Island reported to be intermediate between \i{}S. arctica\i0{} and \i{}S. arctophila \i0{}(Drury 1962: 88-89) is \i{}S. arctica\i0{}. Representative specimens: \i{}Soper, J.D. 122106\i0{}, Baffin Island, Panguirtung Fjord. 26 July 1924. CAN 46583; \i{}Wynne-Edwards, V.C\i0{}. Baffin Island, Head of Clyde Inlet. 11 July 1950. CAN 283881; \i{}Polunin, N. 2376\i0{}. Baffin Island, Cape Dorset. 15 June 1924. CAN 46516; \i{}Soper, J.D. 132178\i0{}. Baffin Island, Head of Kinga Fjord. 31 July 1924. CAN 46520; \i{}Malte, M.O. s.n\i0{}. Ellesmere Island, Craig Harbour. 2 Aug. 1927. CAN 46377; \i{}Malte, M.O. 118599\i0{}. Ellesmere Island, Dundas Harbour. 27 July 1927. CAN 46381. \par{}\i{}Salix arctica\i0{} × \i{}S. glauca\i0{} (\i{}S.\i0{} ×\i{}waghornei \i0{}Rydb.) (Argus 1965, 1973, 2003, Skvortsov 1971). In 1965 Argus wrote, \ldblquote{}This hybrid is characterised by various combinations of the characteristics of \i{}S\i0{}. \i{}arctica\i0{} and \i{}S\i0{}. \i{}glauca\i0{}. The \i{}S\i0{}. \i{}glauca\i0{} characteristics include erect habit, leaves less oblanceolate and without the attenuate base of \i{}S. arctica\i0{}, shorter petioles, bracts light-colored with shorter wavy trichomes [hairs], and a divided style. The \i{}S. arctica\i0{} characteristics include prostrate habit, pruinose [glaucous] stems and buds, sparse branchlet-pubescence, dark-colored bracts with long, straight trichomes, leaves with long straight trichomes on the lower [abaxial] surface projecting in a \lquote{}beard\rquote{} at the apex, capsules reddish with long stigmas, and dark colored anthers.\rdblquote{} Specimens identified as hybrids combine these characters in various ways. On Baffin Island, the hybrid is difficult to recognise because \i{}S. glauca\i0{} and \i{}S. arctica\i0{} are so convergent in their morphology that the recognition of intermediates is difficult.>

<\b{}Hybrids\b0{} \par{}\i{}Salix arctica\i0{} × \i{}S. arctophila\i0{} (\i{}S\i0{}. ×\i{}hudsonensis \i0{}C. K. Schneider) (Argus 2007, Polunin 1940). There are a number of putative hybrids in the Canadian Museum of Nature collection from Baffin and Ellesmere islands. These plants have leaves and branchlets that are almost glabrous as in \i{}S. arctophila\i0{}, but bearing only a few long hairs. In addition, the ovaries have flattened, refractive hairs as in \i{}S. arctica\i0{}, not ribbon-like hairs as in \i{}S. arctophila\i0{}. A specimen from Bylot Island reported to be intermediate between \i{}S. arctica\i0{} and \i{}S. arctophila \i0{}(Drury 1962: 88-89) is \i{}S. arctica\i0{}. Representative specimens: \i{}Soper, J.D. 122106\i0{}, Baffin Island, Panguirtung Fjord. 26 July 1924. CAN 46583; \i{}Wynne-Edwards, V.C\i0{}. Baffin Island, Head of Clyde Inlet. 11 July 1950. CAN 283881; \i{}Polunin, N. 2376\i0{}. Baffin Island, Cape Dorset. 15 June 1924. CAN 46516; \i{}Soper, J.D. 132178\i0{}. Baffin Island, Head of Kinga Fjord. 31 July 1924. CAN 46520; \i{}Malte, M.O. s.n\i0{}. Ellesmere Island, Craig Harbour. 2 Aug. 1927. CAN 46377; \i{}Malte, M.O. 118599\i0{}. Ellesmere Island, Dundas Harbour. 27 July 1927. CAN 46381. \par{}\i{}Salix arctophila\i0{} × \i{}S. uva-ursi\i0{} (Polunin 1940). There are four specimens in the Canadian Museum of Nature collection that appear to be this hybrid. Specimens: \i{}M. O. Malte 118635\i0{}, Baffin Island, Kimmirut (Lake Harbour), 25-26 Aug 1927, CAN 46276 (undeveloped ovaries with patchy hairiness); \i{}Soper, J.D. 132144\i0{}, Hekerton Islands, Cumberland Gulf. 29 July 1924, CAN 46176; \i{}A. P. Low 23039\i0{}, Ungava, Erick Cove, 1 Aug. 1898, CAN; \i{}M. P. Porsild s.n\i0{}. West Greenland, Fiskefjord, 29 July 1941. CAN. Some of these plants have the leaves of \i{}S. uva-ursi\i0{} and the capsules of \i{}S. arctophila\i0{}, but others simply look like depauperate specimens of \i{}S. arctophila\i0{}. Skvortsov (1971) discounts this hybrid but notes that a few specimens are somewhat doubtful. \par{}\i{}Salix arctophila\i0{} × \i{}S. glauca\i0{}. This hybrid is reported to be common in East Greenland but absent from West Greenland (Böcher 1952). It is not known to occur in Canada.>

<\i{}Salix calcicola\i0{} is a low, erect shrub. The leaves are usually broad to sub-circular, the margins are usually minutely toothed, the stipules are small and usually ovate, the catkins are sessile, the ovaries are glabrous, and the stipes and styles long. \par{}This species has been treated as \i{}S. lanata\i0{} subsp. \i{}calcicola\i0{} (Hultén 1968). Subspecies rank was proposed because the two taxa were thought to intergrade where their ranges overlap in the eastern Arctic. The intergradation, however, is not clear, and hybridisation between \i{}S. calcicola\i0{} and \i{}S. richardsonii\i0{} is not proved. This situation is very similar to that found in \i{}S. lanata\i0{} - \i{}S\i0{}. \i{}richardsonii, S. lanata \i0{}-\i{} S. calcicola\i0{}, and \i{}S. brachycarpa\i0{} - \i{}S. niphoclada\i0{}. Trinomial nomenclature, in all of these cases, was used to show the close evolutionary relationship between these taxa. But inasmuch as such nomenclature is cumbersome to use and is therefore often ignored by the non-taxonomist, its information value is minimal. In addition, the evidence of intergradation is often indistinct or non-existent, suggesting that the use of binomial nomenclature may be more appropriate. \par{}\b{}Hybrids\b0{} \par{}\i{}Salix calcicola\i0{} × \i{}S. richardsonii\i0{}. Polunin described \i{}S. richardsonii\i0{} var. \i{}mckeandii\i0{} (1940) and \i{}S. calcicola\i0{} var. \i{}nicholsiana\i0{} (1938), which he thought were hybridising and intergrading on Baffin and Southampton islands. He claimed to have seen some suggestion of hybridisation between \i{}S. calcicola\i0{} and \i{}S. richardsonii\i0{} on Southampton Island, but no clear evidence of hybridisation elsewhere. This problem requires field study.>
<\i{}Salix fuscescens\i0{} is known in the Arctic islands only on Victoria Island, where it was collected at Long Lake by J.D.H. Lambert on 14 July 1964 (CAN 52349).>

<\i{}Salix glauca\i0{} subsp. \i{}callicarpaea\i0{} is an erect shrub; its leaves are glaucous and sparsely to moderately densely hairy abaxially and sparsely hairy to glabrate adaxially; stipules often present but not prominent, usually 0-4 mm long; catkins densely flowered and borne on leafy flowering branchlets; floral bracts pale or dark brown and ovaries densely hairy. \par{}The taxonomy of \i{}S. glauca\i0{} in the Arctic islands and on Greenland has been confusing. Böcher (1952) noted two ecologically and morphologically different types of \i{}Salix glauca\i0{} occurring in West Greenland. A smooth one corresponding to \i{}S. cordifolia\i0{} var. \i{}callicarpaea\i0{} and an hirsute one corresponding to \i{}S. cordifolia\i0{} var. \i{}intonsa\i0{}. Argus (1965) proposed that all Greenland material belonged to \i{}S. glauca\i0{} subsp. \i{}callicarpaea\i0{} (as the Eastern Phase of \i{}S. glauca\i0{}). Böcher later recognised them as two subspecies, \i{}S. glauca\i0{} subsp. \i{}callicarpaea\i0{} (including var. \i{}intonsa\i0{}) and \i{}S. glauca\i0{} subsp. \i{}glauca\i0{}, which he thought resembled the European \i{}S. glauca\i0{} (Böcher et al. 1968). Skvortsov (1971) agreed with Argus that European \i{}S. glauca\i0{} subsp. \i{}glauca\i0{} did not occur on Greenland. He pointed out that it differed in the following characters: generally shorter, broader, more obtuse leaves; adaxial leaf surface bare and even somewhat shiny; flowering branchlets as long as the catkins themselves (European plants are usually shorter); bracts often brownish; stamens with glabrous filaments (more common than in European plants); and a more spreading growth form. \par{}Subspecies \i{}callicarpaea\i0{} extends across Canada, south to northern Saskatchewan and Manitoba, and east to Newfoundland and Greenland. All specimens of subsp. \i{}callicarpaea\i0{} reported from Iceland, the Faeroes, and Svalbard are \i{}S. arctica\i0{} (Pálsson, in Jonsell 2000). \par{}\b{}Hybrids\b0{} \par{}\i{}Salix arctica\i0{} × \i{}S. glauca\i0{} subsp. \i{}callicarpaea\i0{} (\i{}S\i0{}. ×\i{}waghornei \i0{}Rydb.) (Argus 1965, 1973, 2003, Bay 1992, Skvortsov 1971). In 1965 Argus wrote, \ldblquote{}This hybrid is characterised by various combinations of the characteristics of \i{}S\i0{}. \i{}arctica\i0{} and \i{}S\i0{}. \i{}glauca\i0{}. The \i{}S\i0{}. \i{}glauca\i0{} characteristics include erect habit, leaves less oblanceolate and without the attenuate base of \i{}S. arctica\i0{}, shorter petioles, bracts light-colored with shorter wavy trichomes [hairs], and a divided style. The \i{}S. arctica\i0{} characteristics include prostrate habit, pruinose [glaucous] stems and buds, sparse branchlet-pubescence, dark-colored bracts with long, straight trichomes, leaves with long straight trichomes on the lower [abaxial] surface projecting in a \lquote{}beard\rquote{} at the apex, capsules reddish with long stigmas, and dark colored anthers.\rdblquote{} Specimens identified as hybrids combine these characters in various ways. On Baffin Island, the hybrid is difficult to recognise because \i{}S. glauca\i0{} and \i{}S. arctica\i0{} are so convergent in their morphology that the recognition of intermediates is difficult. \par{}\i{}Salix arctophila\i0{} × \i{}S. glauca\i0{} subsp. \i{}callicarpaea\i0{}. This hybrid is reported to be common in East Greenland but absent from West Greenland (Böcher 1952). It is not known to occur in Canada.>

<This taxon was treated as \i{}S. glauca\i0{} var. \i{}glauca\i0{} (Argus 1973). The voucher specimen (Thannheiser, personal herbarium) on which the report of \i{}S. glauca\i0{} subsp. \i{}callicarpaea\i0{} from Victoria Island was based was identified by Argus as \i{}S. glauca\i0{} subsp. \i{}stipulifera\i0{}.>

<\i{}Salix herbacea\i0{} is a dwarf species, with most of its branching underground (rhizomatous), often only the tips of the branchlets appear above the surface; leaves broad, crenulate, and lack stipules; catkins short, few-flowered and borne at the tips of normal vegetative shoots.\par{}The distribution of \i{}S. herbacea\i0{} is amphi-Atlantic (Hultén 1958). Populations at the eastern end of Great Bear Lake and western end of Great Slave Lake appear to be small, disjunct populations. During the late-glacial period it was known to occur as far south in North America as Cambridge, Massachusetts, where leaves were found in a kettle moraine (Argus and Davis 1962). \par{}An excellent report by Beerling (1998) dealing with all aspects of the biology, ecology, distribution, anatomy, morphology, taxonomy, etc. of \i{}Salix herbacea \i0{}was written for the \i{}Biological Flora of the British Isles\i0{}. \par{}\b{}Hybrids\b0{} \par{}\i{}S. herbacea\i0{} × \i{}S\i0{}. \i{}uva-ursi \i0{}(\i{}Salix\i0{} ×\i{}peasei\i0{} Fernald). This hybrid was described as a species of hybrid origin from Mount Washington, New Hampshire (Fernald 1917), but most authors regard it as a hybrid. It combines characters of the parental species: it is coarser than \i{}S. herbacea\i0{} and has thick, trailing stems; its leaves are crenate as in \i{}S. herbacea\i0{}; but its longer catkins resemble \i{}S. uva-ursi\i0{}. Polunin (1940) reports it from Chesterfield Inlet. He also includes it in the key and illustrates it in his Circumpolar Arctic Flora (Polunin 1959).>

<\i{}Salix niphoclada\i0{} is a low to sometimes prostrate shrub with small, elliptic leaves with very short petioles (barely longer than the bud), slender catkins, dark floral bracts, and almost sessile ovaries. This species has been treated as \i{}S. brachycarpa\i0{} subsp. \i{}niphoclada\i0{} (Argus 1965, 1973). Subspecies rank was proposed because the two taxa were thought to intergrade where their ranges overlap in northern British Columbia. The intergradation, however, is not strong and seems not to extend beyond the area of overlapping ranges. This situation is very similar to that described for \i{}S. lanata\i0{} - \i{}S\i0{}. \i{}richardsonii \i0{}-\i{} S. calcicola\i0{}, and \i{}S. planifolia\i0{} - \i{}S\i0{}. \i{}pulchra\i0{}. Trinomial nomenclature, in all of these cases, was used to show the close evolutionary relationship between these taxa. But inasmuch as such nomenclature is cumbersome to use and is therefore often ignored by the non-taxonomist, its information value is minimal. In addition, since the evidence for intergradation is often indistinct, it appears most appropriate to use binomial nomenclature. \i{}Salix fullertonensis\i0{} C.K. Schneider, used in Porsild (1957, 1964), is a synonym of \i{}Salix niphoclada\i0{} Rydberg. \par{}\b{}Hybrids\b0{} \par{}\i{}Salix glauca\i0{} × \i{}S. niphoclada\i0{}. This putative hybrid recombines the characteristics of the parental species. In 1965 Argus wrote, \ldblquote{}Characteristics indicative of [\i{}S. niphoclada\i0{}] are the short petioles, small narrowly elliptic-oblanceolate leaves with acute-attenuate apices, small stipules, and narrow, loosely flowered aments [catkins]. Characteristics suggesting \i{}S. glauca\i0{} are the long petioles, large oblanceolate leaves, large stipules, and densely flowered, broadly cylindrical aments.\rdblquote{}>

<\i{}Salix planifolia\i0{} is a low shrubby species that has small, usually ovate, non-persistent stipules. The catkins are sessile, the ovaries are glabrous, and the nectaries 0-3 times as long as the stipes. It is closely related to \i{}Salix pulchra\i0{} which differs from it in having prominent, linear, persistent stipules. This species has been treated as \i{}S. planifolia\i0{} subsp. \i{}planifolia\i0{} (Argus 1973). Subspecies rank was proposed because this taxon and \i{}S. pulchra\i0{} appeared to intergrade where their ranges overlap in the Mackenzie Mountains and in northwestern British Columbia. The intergradation, however, does not seem to extend beyond the overlapping populations. This situation is very similar to that described for \i{}S. lanata\i0{} - \i{}S\i0{}. \i{}richardsonii \i0{}-\i{} S. calcicola\i0{}, and \i{}S. brachycarpa\i0{} - \i{}S\i0{}. \i{}niphoclada\i0{}. Trinomial nomenclature, in all of these cases, was used to show the close evolutionary relationship between these taxa. But inasmuch as such nomenclature is cumbersome to use and is therefore often ignored by the non-taxonomist, its information value is minimal. In addition, since the evidence of intergradation is indistinct, it appears more appropriate to use binomial nomenclature. \par{}In Alaska, \i{}Salix planifolia\i0{} was found to be an early coloniser of oil spills (Kershaw and Kershaw 1986). \par{}\i{}Salix planifolia\i0{} can be separated from the European \i{}S. phylicifolia\i0{} by the following characters: branches and branchlets (twigs) often densely villous; juvenile and mature leaf blades and petioles often hairy with white and rust-coloured hairs; stipules usually present; and stipes (pedicels) usually shorter (0.3-0.8 versus 0.8-2 mm long). \i{}Salix pulchra\i0{} differs from \i{}S. planifolia\i0{} in its prominent, linear to lanceolate stipules (often persistent for 2 or more years), which generally equal or exceed the petioles, and in its juvenile leaves that are usually glabrous or sparsely pubescent. \i{}Salix phylicifolia\i0{} differs from the other two species by having catkins that are usually borne on longer peduncles (3-6(-20) mm long versus 0-2.5(-5) mm). There also seems to be a difference in chromosome number. \i{}Salix phylicifolia\i0{} usually has 2\i{}n\i0{} = 114, although 2\i{}n\i0{} = 38 has been reported, whereas \i{}S. pulchra\i0{} and \i{}S. planifolia\i0{} have 2\i{}n\i0{} = 76. Where \i{}S. planifolia\i0{} and \i{}S. pulchra\i0{} overlap in the Mackenzie River basin (NWT and Yukon Territory), there is some evidence of hybridisation but species distinctions are not compromised. \par{}In summary, our reasons for treating them as species are that they seem to be separated by a number of characters such that the area of overlap between them is small and that intergradation between them is limited even where they overlap (Argus and Elven 2000, in Elven et al. 2003).>

<\i{}Salix polaris\i0{} is a dwarf species with underground stems (rhizomes). Its leaves are essentially entire and non-glaucous abaxially. Pistils are hairy and have a prominent style. Sometimes diminutive material of \i{}S. arctica\i0{} resembles \i{}S. polaris\i0{}, but they can be separated by the abaxial leaf surface being glaucous or non-glaucous, respectively.>

<\i{}Salix pulchra\i0{} is a shrubby species with prominent, persistent, linear stipules. The catkins are essentially sessile, the ovaries are glabrous, and the nectaries 2-3 times as long as the stipes. \par{}It is closely related to \i{}S. planifolia\i0{}, which differs from it in having smaller, usually ovate or short-linear, non-persistent stipules. It is sometimes difficult to separate from \i{}S. richardsonii\i0{} based on vegetative material. The two overlap on Banks Island, but they are easily separated by the silky ovaries of \i{}Salix pulchra\i0{} and the glabrous ovaries of \i{}S. richardsonii\i0{}. \par{}This species has been treated as \i{}S. planifolia\i0{} subsp. \i{}pulchra\i0{} (Argus 1973). Subspecies rank was proposed because the two taxa appeared to intergrade where their ranges overlap in the Mackenzie Mountains and in northwestern British Columbia. The intergradation, however, does not seem to extend beyond the overlapping populations. This situation is very similar to that found in \i{}S. lanata\i0{} - \i{}S\i0{}. \i{}richardsonii \i0{}-\i{} S. calcicola\i0{}, and \i{}S. brachycarpa\i0{} - \i{}S\i0{}. \i{}niphoclada\i0{}. Trinomial nomenclature, in all of these cases, was used to show the close evolutionary relationship between these taxa. But inasmuch as such nomenclature is cumbersome to use and is therefore often ignored by the non-taxonomist, its information value is minimal. In addition, since the evidence for intergradation is often indistinct, it appears more appropriate to use binomial nomenclature. \par{}This species, along with \i{}S. alaxensis\i0{} and \i{}S. richardsonii\i0{}, are the tallest growing willows in the Arctic Archipelago. In the Masik River valley, southwestern Banks Island, it forms a dominant shrub tundra in association with \i{}S. alaxensis\i0{} and \i{}S. richardsonii\i0{} (Kuc 1970, 1974).>

<\i{}Salix reticulata\i0{} is a dwarf species with stems that trail on the surface of the ground or in moss. Leaves are usually broad to circular-elliptic, with an adaxial surface that is prominently reticulate with impressed venation. Catkins are borne on flowering branchlets that are indistinguishable from normal vegetative branchlets; some plants have almost all branchlets ending in a catkin. When the leaves of this species emerge in the spring, they are covered with fine white hairs. These interrupt the flow of cold air across the surface of the leaf yet permit sunlight to enter, creating a miniature greenhouse in which the sun can raise the temperature of the surface of the plant several degrees above the surrounding temperature (Savile 1972). This allows the leaf to begin photosynthesising under colder conditions.>

<\i{}Salix richardsonii\i0{} is a shrubby species with persistent, prominent, slender stipules with a long attenuate tip and a broader, inequilateral base. Catkins are sessile or with a few green bracts at the base. The ovaries are glabrous, and the nectaries 2-3 times as long as the stipes. It is similar to \i{}S. pulchra\i0{}, but because the latter species is known in our area only on Banks Island, their separation will not often pose a problem. On Banks Island, the two species are easily separated by the hairiness of their ovaries.\par{}This species is often treated as \i{}S. lanata\i0{} subsp. \i{}richardsonii\i0{} (Argus 1973, Skvortsov 1968). Subspecies rank was proposed by Skvortsov because the two taxa apparently intergrade where their ranges overlap in the Ural Mountains, Russia (Skvortsov 1968, 1999). The intergradation, however, does not seem to extend beyond the overlapping populations. This situation is very similar to that found in \i{}S. planifolia\i0{} - \i{}S\i0{}. \i{}pulchra\i0{}, and \i{}S. brachycarpa\i0{} - \i{}S\i0{}. \i{}niphoclada\i0{}. Trinomial nomenclature, in all of these cases, was used to show the close evolutionary relationship between these taxa. But inasmuch as such nomenclature is cumbersome to use and is therefore often ignored by the non-taxonomist, its information value is minimal. In addition, since the evidence of intergradation is often indistinct, it appears appropriate to use binomial nomenclature. I have decided to treat these taxa as distinct species because the area of overlap between them is relatively small, and because the use of trinomial nomenclature in taxa with widely separated ranges is unnecessarily cumbersome. \par{}Polunin (1940) described \i{}S. richardsonii\i0{} var. \i{}mckeandii\i0{} as differing from the species in having smaller leaves [1-3 (4) cm long and 0.4-1.3 (1.5) cm wide] and capsules borne on short, hairy stipes. The type, which is in the British Museum, and the specimens he cites (1940: 169) require study. It is treated here as a synonym of \i{}S. richardsonii\i0{}. \par{}This species, along with \i{}S. alaxensis\i0{} and\i{} S. pulchra\i0{}, are the tallest willows in the Arctic Archipelago. Plants up to 8 ft tall have been reported from the south coast of Victoria Island (Holm 1922). In the Masik River valley, southwestern Banks Island, it forms a dominant shrub tundra in association with \i{}S. alaxensis\i0{} and \i{}S. pulchra\i0{} (Kuc 1970, 1974). \par{}\b{}Hybrids\b0{} \par{}\i{}Salix calcicola\i0{} × \i{}S. richardsonii\i0{}. Polunin (1940) described \i{}S. richardsonii\i0{} var. \i{}mckeandii\i0{} and \i{}S. calcicola\i0{} var. \i{}nicholsiana\i0{}, which he thought were hybridising and intergrading on Baffin and Southampton islands. I have not seen the types of either of these varieties. There is some suggestion of hybridisation between \i{}S. calcicola\i0{} and \i{}S. richardsonii\i0{} on Southampton Island, but it is not clear, and there is no evidence of hybridisation between these two species elsewhere. This problem requires field study.>

<\i{}Salix uva-ursi\i0{} is a dwarf shrub that forms large mats with prostrate branches. Its leaves are entire and elliptic, and ovaries are glabrous.\par{}\b{}Hybrids\par{}\b0\i{}S. herbacea\i0{} × \i{}S. uva-ursi \i0{}(\i{}Salix\i0{} ×\i{}peasei\i0{} Fernald). This hybrid combines characters of the parental species. It is coarser than \i{}S. herbacea\i0{} and has thick, trailing stems. Its leaves are crenate as in \i{}S. herbacea\i0{}, but its longer catkins resemble \i{}S. uva-ursi\i0{}. Polunin (1940) reports it from Chesterfield Inlet; he includes it in the key and illustrates it in his Circumpolar Arctic Flora (Polunin 1959). This hybrid was described based on material from Mt. Washington, New Hampshire.>

<\i{}Salix vestita\i0{} is an erect, shrubby relative of \i{}S. reticulata\i0{}. Its leaves and branchlets, however, have distinct and permanent long silky hairs. In the Arctic Archipelago, this species occurs only on Akpatok Island in Ungava Bay. The only known collections (in the British Museum) were made by Nicholas Polunin in about 1933 (Polunin 1934).>

<Barneby (1964) recognised this species as being in the section \i{}Astragalus\i0{}. He stated that \ldblquote{}the alpine milk-vetch is the most widely dispersed of all astagali, yet when due allowance has been made for the diversity of soils, climates, and environments to which it has become adapted, it is a comparatively little variable species.\rdblquote{} He recognised two varieties as occurring in North America. The arctic plants are \i{}A. alpinus\i0{} var. \i{}alpinus\i0{}. A second variety, \i{}A. alpinus\i0{} var. \i{}brunetianus\i0{}, occurs on river and lake shores in New England, Newfoundland, and southeastern Quebec. \par{}Barneby (1964) discussed another variant of \i{}A. alpinus\i0{}, "... confined to the highest latitudes around the pole, that has been described as \i{}A. arcticus\i0{} Bunge." It was maintained by Gontscharov (1946), as a distinct species under the epithet \i{}subpolaris\i0{}, and recognised by Hultén (1944) as a subspecies coordinate with subsp. \i{}alaskanus\i0{}. Barneby (1964) whom we follow found no reason to recognise variants such \i{}A. arcticus\i0{} Bunge or \i{}A. subpolaris\i0{} Gontascharov at species level. \par{}Polunin (1940, p. 288) noted that the little \ldblquote{}alpine milk-vetch varies considerably in robustness and general appearance; also varies in the colour of the flowers and the size, shape and hairiness of the leaflets\rdblquote{}. \par{}Elven et al. (2003) proposed three subspecies: subsp. \i{}alpinus\i0{} in northeastern Siberia, Russian Far East, and North America; subsp. \i{}arcticus\i0{} in northern Europe, northern Asia, North America, and northeastern Greenland; and subsp. \i{}alaskanus\i0{} in eastern and southern Chukotka and in Alaska. Only subsp. \i{}alpinus\i0{} is in the Flora region.>

<Barneby (1964) recognised this species as being in section \i{}Hemiphragmium\i0{}. Porsild (1964) identified the Arctic taxon as \i{}A. richardsonii\i0{} Sheldon and indicated the species is closely related to the prairie species \i{}A. aboriginum\i0{} Richardson from which it differs in having large flowers, glabrous legumes, and more densely tomentose leaves. \par{}Barneby (1964) stated that \ldblquote{}because of the variations in stature, vestiture, and amplitude of the foliage, the Indian milk-vetch, \i{}A. aboriginum\i0{}, cannot be characterised in a few succinct words\rdblquote{}. He placed \i{}A. richardsonii\i0{} in synonymy under \i{}A. aboriginum\i0{} because of the large, prominently veined, obtuse stipules at base of the stems and the toothed wing petals.\par{}Barneby (1964) also noted that "the Arctic and sub-arctic races of \i{}A. aboriginum\i0{} introduce three new features, petioled stem leaves, larger flowers, and broader pods than found in the Rocky Mountains." Barneby (1964) was not willing to equate \i{}A. aboriginum\i0{} with the circumpolar \i{}A. australis\i0{} (also the earlier name), however. This step was left to Welsh (1991). \par{}Murray and Elven (personal communication, 2005) noted that this section, or alternatively as the \i{}A. australis\i0{} aggregate, is perhaps the most controversial group of arctic \i{}Astragalus\i0{}. The opinions differ strongly, both in general and among the collaborators on the Panarctic Flora Checklist (Elven et al. 2003). No consensus has been arrived at. It is one case, among many, of very widespread Eurasiatic and North American taxa with several allopatric to parapatric, morphologically distinguishable entities in different mountains and tundras. Such cases have been treated very differently in different families and by various authors. We are here treating \i{}A. aboriginum\i0{} and \i{}A. richardsonii\i0{} under \i{}A. australis\i0{} (following Welsh 1991), pending further study in this group. \par{}\i{}Astragalus australis\i0{} was one of the taxa considered by Liston (1992) in a study of the variation in the chloroplast genes RPOC1 and RCOP2 of the genus.>

<Barneby (1964) recognised this taxon as being in section \i{}Oroboidei\i0{}. A similar species, \i{}A. robbinsii\i0{} (Oakes) Gray, grows in central and southern Yukon and southern Alaska. Barneby (1964) considered the elegant milk-vetch \i{}A. eucosmus\i0{} to be closely related to \i{}A. robbinsii\i0{}, differing chiefly in the sessile pod. The leaflets tend to be narrower and the flowers are often smaller, but neither of these features is diagnostic of \i{}A. eucosmus\i0{}, and fruits, at least half-formed, are often necessary for identification. Despite its great range, \i{}A. eucosmus\i0{} is only moderately variable, much less so than a glance at the synonymy might suggest. Normally an erect plant of moderate stature, it is susceptible to dwarfing in open montane and far northern environments, where the stems become diffuse or weakly ascending as well as shorter, and the raceme tends to become shorter and more compact in fruit. The raceme of \i{}A. eucosmus\i0{} ordinarily elongates rapidly during anthesis, the axis becoming about 3.5-19 cm long in fruit, with pods well spaced along its length. Instances of shorter fruit are correlated with short diffuse stems and an unfavourable habitat, mostly on exposed seashores at high latitudes in eastern Canada and Baffin. \par{}Elven et al (2005) noted that "Scoggan (1978) synonymised \i{}A. sealei\i0{} with \i{}A. eucosmus\i0{} f. \i{}eucosmus\i0{} (one of four formae). Gillett et al. (1999) also fully included \i{}A. sealei\i0{} in \i{}A. eucosmus\i0{}. Hultén (1968b and elsewhere) treated the entities \i{}'eucosmus'\i0{} and \i{}'sealei'\i0{} as subspecies but commented on the similarity between \i{}'sealei'\i0{} and the Eurasian \i{}A. norvegicus\i0{}. Yurtsev (in Elven et al. 2003) treated all three entities as species. Murray and Elven [personal communication, 2005] compared material of all three taxa and share[d] Yurtsev's opinion. [They found] the diploid amphi-Beringian \i{}A. sealei\i0{} morphologically more similar to the diploid Eurasian \i{}A. norvegicus\i0{} than to the tetraploid North American \i{}A. eucosmus\i0{} to which it usually has been assigned as a subspecies. An alternative might be to assign \i{}'sealei'\i0{} as a subspecies to \i{}A. norvegicus\i0{}, but we are not aware of such a combination.">

<A relatively well-defined single entity in the Arctic Archipelago. Yurtsev (Sept 2001) considered that \i{}Hedysarum alpinum\i0{} and \i{}H. americanum\i0{} are species-level distinct. "They cannot be considered as vicarious taxa due to an enormous gap between their ranges (several thousand km!) (this gap is just within the Russian Far-East). There are constant distinctions between \i{}H. alpinum\i0{} and \i{}H. americanum\i0{}, e.g., in shape of leaflets and their termination, length of mucrone - brevissime versus elongate, form of bracts and their length in relation to that of pedicels (shorter versus somewhat longer in \i{}H. americanum\i0{}), the characters of pubescence of inflorescence, form of calyx teeth (triangular versus triangular-lanceolate). Despite similarity of morphotype, they are different in characters for nearly all organs and thus should not be considered as conspecific" (Yurtsev, Sept. 2001).\par{}The current North American opinion (Gillett et al. 1999 onwards) has been to accept a widely defined \i{}H. alpinum\i0{} and even to include the more arctic parts of the North American range in a var. \i{}alpinum\i0{} described from Siberia (Linnaeus 1753), with an unnamed variety (beta) in the Alps. \par{}Elven et al. (2003) suggested that the solution may be "to accept a widely defined \i{}H. alpinum\i0{} with 2-3 subspecies: subsp. \i{}alpinum\i0{} (perhaps not arctic, perhaps including \i{}'vicioides'\i0{} and then arctic), subsp. \i{}vicioides\i0{}, and subsp. \i{}americanum\i0{} (including all the North American plants)." Hultén (1968) was of the opinion that the Asiatic plants were subsp. \i{}alpinum\i0{}, the North American ones subsp. \i{}americanum\i0{}. His opinion was that all the Siberian plants belonged in subsp. \i{}alpinum \i0{}s.s., that is, also the \i{}'vicioides'\i0{} entity. (Yurtsev (personal communication Sept. 2001) considered that \i{}H. vicioides\i0{} is a very good species slightly reaching the Arctic in the lower reaches of the Lena River, with very small yellowish white flowers, bracts and calyx glabrous, ciliate, pubescent in lower half. Rhizomes are lacking, roots tuberose. It can hardly be included into any aggregate). \par{}Porsild and Cody (1980) commented that in North America, \ldblquote{}the transitional differences between the arctic and more temperate plants appear to be quite gradual and to be merely an expression of climatic differences\rdblquote{}, therefore also agreeing on a single North American taxon. \par{}We treat the taxon \i{}H. americanum\i0{} at species level, following the current treatment in the Panarctic Flora Project, recognising that the authors of the PAF project agree that it is still unresolved whether the taxa are sufficiently different to warrant species status.\par{}We have found no Arctic Island specimens with the fruiting stages collected. The data on fruits are based on material collected in continental North America.>

<Porsild (1964) indicated that plants grow 10-25 cm tall. Plants 40 cm tall have been collected from southern Banks Island, Nelson Head, 2 mi. northeast, 2 July 1952, \i{}T. H. Manning and A. Macpherson 77\i0{}. CAN 220125.>

<There have been no nomenclatural disputes about the name of this species. Subsp. \i{}arcticus\i0{} is the only one extending into the Arctic islands. There are two other subspecies occurring in southern British Columbia and south into Washington. In the Arctic islands, the Arctic lupin is usually found on well-drained hummocks in the tundra, but it has occasionally been collected in sedge meadows. Further south, near the Arctic Circle, it is found in forest clearings. \i{}Lupinus arcticus\i0{} is closely related to \i{}L. perennis\i0{} L. \par{}Majak et al. (1994), studying alkaloid distribution in two species of \i{}Lupinus\i0{}, did not have data for the arctic subspecies, but found that \i{}L. arcticus\i0{} subsp. \i{}subalpinus\i0{} had sparteine, beta-isiosparteine, and multiflorine as the major alkaloids.>

<In this treatment we have used the species name \i{}Oxytropis arctica\i0{} because the subspecific circumscription is disputed on a circumarctic basis (Elven and Murray personal communication, 2005). However, all of the plants in the Flora region appear to fall under the typical subspecies \i{}O. arctica \i0{}subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{}. According to investigations of Jorgensen (2001) and Jorgensen et al. (2003), this typical subspecies is purple-flowered and appears to be distributed in Canada and northern Alaska. Their studies suggested that the white-flowered "barnebyana" entity of western and northern Alaska is best considered a variety of \i{}O. arctica\i0{}. \par{}The northern Canadian plants have been counted as decaploid and dodecaploid, Siberian plants (different subspecies) are counted as octoploid, and western Alaskan plants as hexaploid (incl. \i{}O. koyukukensis\i0{}).\par{}>

<Elven et al. (2003) reported a major discussion on the \i{}Oxytropis nigrescens\i0{} aggregate (\i{}O. nigrescens\i0{}, \i{}O. pumilio\i0{}, ?\i{}O.sublongipes\i0{}). They noted that this aggregate was proposed as 8-9 separate species in Yurtsev's draft for Elven et al. (2003). The North American view is to consider the entire American part of the aggregate as one variable species with 'varieties' (Barneby 1952, later taken up by Gillett et al. 1999 onwards). As the varieties mostly occupy different regions, they would more naturally be subspecies in the Panarctic Checklist concept (Elven et al. 2003). This is also supported by the ranges of the major entities: \i{}nigrescens\i0{} s.s. from Jenisei to Kolyma, '\i{}czukotica' \i0{}from Kolyma to the Bering Strait, '\i{}pygmaea\i0\rquote{} ('\i{}gorodkovii\i0\rquote{}) around the Bering Strait, '\i{}bryophila\i0\rquote{} in Alaska-Yukon, and '\i{}arctobia\i0\rquote{} in northern Canada. They are all diploid or tetraploid, parapatric, and closely related. Because the nomenclatural conclusions are still not completely resolved, we are using the specific rank for the Canadian entity 'arctobia', following Yurtsev's draft for Elven et al. (2003). \par{}Polunin (1940) noted that there is a specimen of this species in the Gray Herbarium among a collection that has often been referred to as coming from Melville Island, but actually was made far to the southeast during Parry\rquote{}s second voyage. He indicated that the Arctic Bay material differs from all other specimens that he had examined in having seeds that are light brown instead of almost black when ripe, and having the insides of the pods essentially glabrous instead of flocculent-pubescent. The pubescence on the outside also tends to be less dense and spreading. On these characters he recognised \i{}O. arctobia\i0{} var. \i{}hyperarctica \i0{}Polunin. This name and the recognition of this taxon has not been widely taken up. \par{}>

<Elven et al. (2003) treat \i{}Oxytropis borealis\i0{} as \i{}O. glutinosa\i0{} A.E. Porsild and noted the pattern in North America might justify four regional races: \i{}'borealis'\i0{} as amphi-Beringian and Alaskan, \i{}'glutinosa'\i0{} as northwestern Canadian, \i{}'viscida'\i0{} as Cordilleran, and \i{}'hudsonica'\i0{} as central-northeastern Canadian ('Hudsonian'). An alternative would be to merge \i{}'borealis'\i0{} and \i{}'glutinosa'\i0{} within one subspecies. Because the combinations for subspecies of these taxa are not yet available, here we use the species names \i{}O. borealis\i0{} for the western taxon (as this will be the name published in \i{}Flora of North America\i0{}) and \i{}O. hudsonica \i0{}for this taxon of the Hudsonian region, until a classification is clarified which satisfies the circumpolar morphological discontinuities, available chromosome evidence, and any future molecular evidence.\par{}Welsh (1990) considered that \i{}O. borealis\i0{} in North America consists of an intergrading series of varieties. This whole species complex has fragrant viscid herbage, and was treated as \i{}O. viscida\i0{} by Barneby (1952), but \i{}O. borealis\i0{} is the earliest name in North America (Welsh 1990). In the Canadian Arctic Islands, plants are generally recognisable as belonging to two varieties. \par{}Specimens from Banks Island most closely resemble \i{}O.\i0{} \i{}borealis\i0{}. These plants have calyx teeth that are 2 mm or longer, and possess copious glandular verrucae; the calyces are copiously black hairy. In dried specimens the glands can become less noticeable, but the glandular verrucae on the calyx lobes remain prominent (Barneby 1952, p 239). However, some of the Banks Island specimens approach the more southern \i{}var. viscida\i0{} in that although the leaves generally have 25 leaflets or fewer, some specimens have more leaflets. The distinction between var. \i{}borealis\i0{} and var. \i{}viscida\i0{} is sometimes not possible (Barneby 1952), especially when the plant is in flower, but Barneby gives arguments for recognising the more northern ones as var. \i{}borealis\i0{}. Banks Island specimens have been identified by S.L. Welsh (in 1998), but the distinction between these two varieties requires further study (S.L. Welsh, personal communication, 1999). \par{}The taxon recognised by Porsild's (1957) as \i{}O. glutinosa\i0{} was synonymised under \i{}O. borealis\i0{} var. \i{}viscida\i0{}, but as Welsh (1990) stated," var. \i{}borealis\i0{} consists, at least in part, of what has passed under the name of \i{}O. glutinosa\i0{} Porsild".>

<Porsild (1964) recognised this taxon as \i{}O. foliolosa\i0{} Hooker. Barneby (1952), followed by Welsh (1991), treated it as \i{}O. deflexa\i0{} var. \i{}foliolosa\i0{}, which Cody (1994) changed to subspecies status. Cronquist et al. (1989) and Isely (1998) have since synonymised var. \i{}foliolosa\i0{} under var. \i{}deflexa\i0{}.\par{}The Iqaluit distribution records are new since Porsild (1957). One site is near the airport, another near Arctic College. Is it possible that the Iqaluit records were accidentally introduced from Kimmirut (Lake Harbour)? Porsild (1957) mapped a collection from the coast of midwestern Baffin Island, but the specimen has not been found.>

<Elven et al. (2003) treat \i{}Oxytropis borealis\i0{} as \i{}Oxytropis glutinosa\i0{} A.E. Porsild and noted the pattern in North America might justify four regional races: \i{}'borealis'\i0{} as amphi-Beringian and Alaskan, \i{}'glutinosa'\i0{} as northwestern Canadian, \i{}'viscida'\i0{} as Cordilleran, and \i{}'hudsonica'\i0{} as central-northeastern Canadian ('Hudsonian'). An alternative would be to merge \i{}'borealis'\i0{} and \i{}'glutinosa'\i0{} within one subspecies. Because the combinations for subspecies of these taxa are not yet available, here we use the species names \i{}O. borealis\i0{} for the western taxon (as this will be the name published in \i{}Flora of North America\i0{}) and \i{}O. hudsonica \i0{}for this taxon of the Hudsonian region, until a classification is clarified which satisfies the circumpolar morphological discontinuities, available chromosome evidence, and any future molecular evidence.\par{}Welsh (1990) considered that \i{}O. borealis\i0{} in North America consists of an intergrading series of varieties. This whole species complex has fragrant viscid herbage, and was treated as \i{}O. viscida\i0{} by Barneby (1952), but \i{}O. borealis\i0{} is the earliest name (Welsh 1990). In the Canadian Arctic Islands, plants are generally recognisable as belonging to two varieties, which Porsild (1957, 1964) treated under \i{}O. hudsonica\i0{} (Greene) Fernald and \i{}O. glutinosa\i0{} Porsild. Porsild separated these as follows: \par{}Calyx lobes deltoid, one-quarter to one-third as long as the tube...\i{}O. hudsonica\i0\par{}Calyx lobes subulate, one-half to two-thirds as long as the tube....\i{}O. glutinosa \i0{}[= \i{}O. borealis\i0{}]\par{}In the east, and on Southampton Island, \i{}O. hudsonica\i0{} is recognised by having calyx teeth less than 2 mm long and lacking glandular verrucae. It also has some black hairs on the calyx, as opposed to the copiously black hairy calyces of \i{}O.\i0{} \i{}borealis\i0{}.>

<The taxon in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago is treated as subsp. \i{}melanocephala\i0{} following Elven et al. (2005). These authors considered that subsp. \i{}maydelliana\i0{} is the amphi-Beringian subspecies that occurs east to Mackenzie River, while subsp. \i{}melanocephala\i0{} is North American and occurs from Mackenzie eastwards. Intermediates occur in the Mackenzie River area, but that is to be expected among subspecies. The main diagnostic character used to distinguish the subspecies, inflorescence indumentum, seems to hold.>
<Porsild (1964) mapped records for Kimmirut and Cape Dorset, but we have found no vouchers to confirm the distributions.>

<This entity was treated as \i{}O. campestris\i0{} var. \i{}terrae-novae\i0{} by Barneby (1952) and for priority reasons as \i{}O. campestris\i0{} var. \i{}minor\i0{} by Gillett et al. (1999 onwards). It is a major entity in northeastern North America and is in the framework or the Panarctic Flora checklist either as a subspecies or a species. The North American plants treated as varieties of \i{}O. campestris\i0{} (last century) differ much more morphologically from each other and from \i{}O. campestris\i0{} s.s. than do the European subspecies and some of the Russian species. For this reason the North American plants are treated as a species distinct from European \i{}O. campestris.\i0{}>

<Elisens and Packer (1980) considered the \i{}O. campestris\i0{} complex in northwestern North America a polyploid series comprising at least seven morphologically and geographically distinct taxa. They recognised \i{}O. varians\i0{} as having hexaploid and decaploid representatives but did not attempt to divide the taxa, as no differences were observed between them with the exception of guard cell size. Elven (personal communication, 2005) noted that the following ploidy levels are reported within \i{}O. varians\i0{}: 2\i{}x\i0{}, 4\i{}x\i0{}, 6\i{}x\i0{}, 8\i{}x\i0{}, 12\i{}x\i0{}, all of them on quite reliably identified material. This is obviously a complex 'species'.\par{}\i{}Oxytropis hyperborea\i0{} is now synonymised with \i{}O. varians\i0{} or, if it is considered to be a subspecies or variety, with \i{}O. campestris\i0{} subsp./var. \i{}varians\i0{} by almost all current North American authors, e.g., Cody (1996), Gillett et al. (1999 onwards).>

<Furlow (1997) stated that \i{}B. glandulosa\i0{} is the characteristic dwarf birch of upland habitats throughout the west, occurring as well in dry open areas across the north. In parts of Alaska and near Churchill, Manitoba, where the ranges of these species overlap, \i{}B. glandulosa\i0{} integrates with \i{}B. nana\i0{}, forming a confusing complex of intermediate forms with plants intermediate between \i{}B. glandulosa\i0{} and \i{}B. nana\i0{} subsp. \i{}exilis\i0{}. Whenever they remain in isolation, the species remain reasonably distinct and easy to identify. In southern Greenland, \i{}B. glandulosa\i0{} hybridises with \i{}B. nana\i0{} and with \i{}B. pubescens\i0{}.\par{}Jacobs et al. (1985) described pollen deposition and the distribution of \i{}Betula glandulosa\i0{} at the limit of Low Arctic tundra in southern Baffin Island.>

<Furlow (1997) distinguishes subsp. \i{}nana\i0{} as having young pubescent twigs, not covered with a conspicuous resinous layer. This is the taxon that occurs in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago. Plant with twigs glabrous or only puberulent, and covered with a thick resinous coating, are \i{}B. nana\i0{} subsp. \i{}exilis\i0{} (Sukaczev) Hultén. This subspecies occurs in the Yukon, Alaska, and Northern Asia. \par{}\i{}Betula nana\i0{} subsp. \i{}nana\i0{} occurs in both eastern and western Greenland at latitudes north of 63°N. In northern Europe, the range of this subspecies extends across the subarctic zone and southward in the Alps and other ranges. \par{}There seems to be some agreement that there are three major geographic races, the very widely amphi-Atlantic subsp. \i{}nana\i0{}, the Russian-Siberian subsp. \i{}tundrarum\i0{}, and the widely amphi-Beringian subsp. \i{}exilis\i0{} (Elven et al. 2003).>

<Hebda and Chinnappa (1990) reported that the pollen of this taxon is produced in monads that are isopolar, radially symmetrical, and tetracolporate, and they described the pollen in detail. \par{}Chambers et al. (1990) observed the effects of disturbance type on seedling environment and establishment of alpine species with different physiological and life history traits during a 2-year study on the Beartooth Plateau in southwestern Montana, USA. They compared soil temperatures, water potentials, and nutrients on mineral soils of a gravel borrow area with those on highly organic soils of a \i{}Acomastylis (Geum)\i0{} turf area. They concluded that successful seedling establishment on different alpine disturbance types may depend more on obtaining the necessary conditions for seedling emergence and on species interactions than on the ability of seedlings to survive different environmental conditions. \par{}Chambers (1991) studied the relationships of clone area and neighbourhood to ramet size, reproductive effort, and spatial distribution within \i{}A. rossii\i0{} clones in an alpine ecosystem on the Beartooth Plateau, Montana, USA. Conservative patterns of growth and reproduction make \i{}A. rossii\i0{} well suited to dominate in dense, heterogeneous neighbourhoods of late seral sites and to colonise mineral soils of early seral sites. Similar to other clonal species, site characteristics and the type of neighbourhood determine the trade-off between the physical occupation of space and the allocation to ramet growth and reproduction in \i{}A. rossii\i0{}.>

<Elven et al. (2003) suggested that if \i{}Dasiphora\i0{}, \i{}Comarum\i0{} and \i{}Sibbaldiopsis\i0{} are recognised as separate genera, we also have to recognise \i{}Argentina,\i0{} as it is equally well differentiated (Eriksson et al. 1998) [Pl. Syst. Evol. 211: 155-179]. \par{}\i{}Argentina anserina/egedii\i0{} constitutes a widespread complex where \i{}A. anserina\i0{} s.s. is the temperate part and \i{}A. egedii\i0{} is the arctic-subarctic part (see Rousi 1965, Hultén 1971). Fertile intermediates are frequent in northwestern and northern Europe in seashore sites where \i{}A. anserina\i0{} s.s. and \i{}A. egedii\i0{} meet, even if they are partly ecologically separated. \i{}Argentina egedii\i0{} is restricted to silty and clayey salt marshes, whereas \i{}A. anserina\i0{} s.s. is more frequent on sandy and gravelly shores and especially in driftwalls.
