The entity described as \i{}A. egedii\i0{} var. \i{}groenlandica\i0{} (or \i{}Potentilla anserina\i0{} var. \i{}groenlandica\i0{}) is intermediate between \i{}A. egedii\i0{} and \i{}A. anserina\i0{} s.s. in some aspects but belongs mainly within the former. Its main distinguishing character seems to be the more or less hairy lower surface of leaves. It is concentrated in the southern parts of the range of \i{}A. egedii\i0{} where it meets \i{}A. anserina\i0{} s.s. At subspecies level, subsp. \i{}groenlandica\i0{} has priority, at species level \i{}A\i0{}. \i{}egedii\i0{}. \par{}The hybridisation and the 'intermediacy' of var. \i{}groenlandica\i0{} are two reasons for treating \i{}A. anserina\i0{} and \i{}A. egedii\i0{} as major eco-geographic races, i.e., as two subspecies, instead of as species. In the material from the Arctic islands, all specimens from Victoria and about half of those from Baffin show some '\i{}groenlandica\i0{}' features (i.e., more or less hairy lower leaf surfaces). In these areas, there seems to be intra-population variation not worth taxonomic recognition. However, the indumentum variation is within the '\i{}egedii\i0{}' entity rather than a sign of intermediacy. \par{}The taxon is a complicated case. In Alaska-Yukon, Hultén (1968b) divided the variation on two species and within \i{}A. (Potentilla) egedii\i0{} on three subspecies - one with two varieties - all of which reach the arctic parts. One of the subspecies (\i{}'yukonensis'\i0{}) was later transferred by Hultén to \i{}A. (Potentilla) anserina\i0{}. In northwestern Europe three entities have been recognised through time, \i{}A. (Potentilla) anserina\i0{} and two races of \i{}A. (Potentilla) egedii\i0{}. One of these - \i{}'groenlandica'\i0{} - is transitional in one feature (lower leaf surface indumentum) between the two species and exemplifies the problem in consistent separation of \i{}A. anserina\i0{} and \i{}A. egedii\i0{}. \par{}As 'typical', the two are very different in several presumed independent characters and also differ ecologically. Intermediate habitats are rare, but where they occur, intermediate plants are very often found and there seems to be no barrier except the eco-geographical one. It would be very tempting to treat them as subspecies except that a more deviant race within the \i{}A. egedii\i0{} affinity occurs in the Beringian area, namely \i{}'pacifica'\i0{} or \i{}'grandis'\i0{}. To be able reflect these two levels of differentiation we should perhaps accept two species. In any case, the \i{}'groenlandica'\i0{} plants should be included in \i{}A. egedii\i0{} subsp. \i{}egedii\i0{} as a synonym. The name is accepted in several standard sources, e.g., Hultén (1968b), Löve and Löve (1975, as \i{}A. anserina\i0{} subsp. \i{}groenlandica\i0{}), and Böcher et al. (1978). If the \i{}'egedii'\i0{} entity is considered a subspecies of \i{}A. argentina\i0{}, the correct name is also subsp. \i{}groenlandica\i0{} (see Soják 1969, Löve 1970).>

<The choice between recognising this as a species of \i{}Potentilla\i0{} or placing it in its own genus \i{}Comarum\i0{} is largely a matter of how widely or narrowly \i{}Potentilla\i0{} should be circumscribed. If \i{}Comarum\i0{} is split off, it also necessitates recognition of \i{}Anserina\i0{} and \i{}Dasiphora\i0{} as separate genera, whereas an inclusion of these in \i{}Potentilla\i0{} should be followed by an inclusion of, for example, \i{}Fragaria\i0{} and \i{}Sibbaldia\i0{}. Elven et al. (2003) preferred to accept \i{}Comarum\i0{} as a separate genus.>

<Porsild (1947) indicated that \i{}D. integrifolia\i0{} in North America is by far the most common and widespread member of the genus, and in postglacial time has reoccupied nearly all land surface in the Arctic once occupied by ice. It is an arctic-alpine species, which within its main area is an ubiquitous pioneer species in rocky and gravelly places such as river flats and screes, but less common in dwarf shrub heath where it is rapidly out-competed for space. \i{}Dryas integrifolia\i0{} fruits abundantly, and its immature achenes form an important food item for numerous species of small rodents and for several species of birds. \par{}Porsild (1947) stated that \i{}D. integrifolia\i0{} seems to be entirely lacking in ecotypes, an opinion that might be debated based on specimens from the Canadian Arctic Archipelago. He noted that \i{}D. integrifolia\i0{} from Greenland, \i{}D. octopetala\i0{} s.s. from Europe, and\i{} D. drummondii\i0{} from the Canadian Rockies have long been grown commercially and in botanical gardens. They have all preserved their characteristics, and there is little reason to expect that fundamental characters such as the presence or absence of glands would be controlled by ecological variables. He also noted that it would be of considerable interest to grow in cultivation many of the other taxa that have been recognised in the genus. However, many of them occur in inaccessible areas, and fresh seed material cannot be easily procured. \par{}Juzepchuk (1919, 1929) provided a comprehensive treatment of the genus \i{}Dryas\i0{} chiefly dealing with Asiatic plants. Porsild (1947) wrote on the genus in North America, extending the treatment by Juzepczuk to areas in North America where that author had few specimens to work with. A summary of the structure in the genus, as seen by current Russians, is presented by Yurtsev (1997). These authors recognised the subgeneric entities following within the genus: \par{}\b{}Section or subgenus\b0{} \b\i{}Nothodryas\i0{} \b0{}Juz. has leaves pointed at the base; petals and sepals erect-spreading or quite erect during flowering and receptacles flattened, species \i{}D. drummondii\i0{} and \i{}D. grandis\i0{}; \par{}\b{}Section or subgenus \i{}Eudryas\b0\i0{} Juz., leaves mostly rounded, truncate or sub-cordate at the base; petals and sepals spreading during flowering, receptacles convex. \par{}Within \i{}Eudryas\b{} \b0\i0{}the Russian authors recognised the following sub-sections: \par{}\b{} Subsection \i{}Dryas\i0{},\b0{} leaves dentate, without punctiform glands, but with feathery hairs ('\i{}octopetala\i0{} scales') along the lower leaf surface midvein, no glandular hairs on the lower surface midvein, e.g., species \i{}D. octopetala\i0{} and \i{}D. ajanensis\i0{}.\par{} \b{}Subsection \i{}Incisae\b0\i0{} Jurtz., leaves crenate or dentate throughout, without punctiform glands, glandular hairs, or feathery hairs, e.g., \i{}D. incisa\i0{}.\par{} \b{}Subsection \i{}Tenellae\i0{} \b0{}Juz., leaves entire or crenate in basal part only, without punctiform glands, glandular hairs, or feathery hairs, e.g., \i{}D. integrifolia\i0{}.\par{} \b{}Subsection \i{}Punctatae\b0\i0{} Juz., leaves dentate, with punctiform glands, glandular hairs along the lower leaf midvein, but generally without feathery hairs, e.g., \i{}D. punctata\i0{} and \i{}D. alaskensis\i0{}.\par{}Porsild (1947) and Hultén (1959a) considered \i{}Dryas\i0{} as an old holarctic genus that is particularly interesting for studies in phytogeography and phylogeny. \i{}Dryas octopetala\i0{} is thought to have once had a complete circumpolar distribution reaching North America from Alaska south to Colorado and east to northeastern Greenland. Hultén (1959a) considered \i{}Dryas\i0{} to be a tertiary genus that early differentiated into three types, two closely related, \i{}D. octopetala\i0{} and \i{}D. integrifolia\i0{}, and the third more differentiated, \i{}D. drummondii\i0{}, which occurs in western continental North America, and possibly a fourth, \i{}D. grandis\i0{}, which occurs in Eastern Russia. He stated that both \i{}D. octopetala\i0{} and \i{}D. integrifolia \i0{}are probably fairly old and must have existed before the glacial period. During the glacial period, southern isolated populations of \i{}D. octopetala\i0{} also occurred in central Europe, in the Caucasus, in Japan, and in the Rocky Mountains, where more or less different races were developed and still remain isolated in most cases. \par{}Considering the Canadian Arctic Archipelago, Hultén (1959a) stated that this is where \i{}D. integrifolia \i0{}is presumed to have survived the glacial period and to have hybridised with \i{}D. octopetala\i0{} so strongly that today only a remnant of the hybrid is left, while in eastern Greenland \i{}D. octopetala\i0{} still survives, although a large part of its population apparently shows the hybrid influence of \i{}D. integrifolia\i0{} in lacking \i{}octopetala\i0{} scales. \par{}Hultén (1959a) considered hairs, glands, and scales on the leaves are very good characters for identifying the different races within the \i{}D. octopetala\i0{} complex, while the form of the leaves and other characteristics used for that purpose he considered less reliable. He described \i{}octopetala\i0{} scales as long, narrow, more or less flat brownish coloured tuft-like scales, built up of several rows of cells with white hairs on their margins. The scales occur on the underside of the leaves on the leaf mid-nerve and to a lesser extent on the lateral nerves. Hultén (1959a) commented that it is remarkable that \i{}octopetala\i0{} scales, which are so significant for some taxa, can be missing where they would be expected and occur where they are not expected. For example, \i{}D. octopetala-\i0{}like taxa lacking \i{}octopetala\i0{} scales occur in Alaska and in East Greenland. \par{}Hultén (1959a) offered the opinion that \i{}D. integrifolia\i0{} is supposed to have occurred in the Rocky Mountains, south of its present range and also in eastern Asia westwards to Lake Bajkal, but was so strongly influenced by \i{}D. octopetala\i0{} there that only hybrids remain today, except in the northeastern corner of Asia where \i{}D. integrifolia\i0{} still occurs. In unglaciated Alaska and Yukon, races of both \i{}D. integrifolia\i0{} (subsp. \i{}sylvatica\i0{} Hultén) and \i{}D. octopetala\i0{} (subsp. \i{}alaskensis\i0{} Porsild) developed during the glacial period. There the areas of at least six different entities (not counting \i{}D. drummondii)\i0{} overlap and cross more or less freely and can only more or less arbitrarily be distinguished from each other. Cody (1996) provides a key to these taxa. Hultén (1959a) provided a key to taxa and hybrids that he recognised. \par{}In the Canadian Arctic Archipelago, Hultén (1959a) recognised \i{}D. integrifolia\i0{} Vahl subsp. \i{}integrifolia\i0{} ×\i{}octopetala\i0{} L., citing specimens collected from Southampton Island and Prince Patrick Island, but subsequent authors have not recognised this hybrid. \par{}Nordal et al. (1999) held a workshop to discuss a proposed treatment of the genus \i{}Dryas\i0{} for the Panarctic Flora Checklist (Elven et al. 2003). Yurtsev (1984, 1997) recognised 15 species in the genus globally and of these nine reach the Arctic. The taxa are mainly defined and delimited by characters from indumentum, glands (presence/absence and types), and leaf shape, incision, and structure. The workshop provided a modified translation of the key given by Yurtsev (1997), with hybrid combinations that he proposed removed. The discussions concerned the interpretation of the morphological variation and its taxonomic significance, especially the use of single characters and of the assumptions of hybridogenous origins of taxa with intermediate features. No consensus was reached. The conclusion was that here is an obvious need for modern analyses of both arctic and non-arctic \i{}Dryas, \i0{}involving both more extensive morphological analyses, investigation of molecular markers, and further application of eco-geographic methods. \par{}The common name 'mountain avens' is also used for the species \i{}Dryas octopetala\i0{} in northern Europe. \par{}The flowers of \i{}Dryas\i0{} are heliotropic and face the sun as it moves across the horizon. The flower sepals in bud often appear black from the many coarse hairs that may be glandular-tipped. Occasionally, these hairs are absent and the sepals appear grey-green (see, for example, Baffin Island, Camp Kungovik, \i{}J.D. Soper 125996\i0{}, 15 July 1929. CAN 74264).>

<The name \i{}P. arenosa\i0{} is accepted over \i{}P. hookeriana \i0{}after a reconsideration of the types (Elven, personal communication, 2005). Jurtsev and Soják (personal communication) have long asserted that Lehmann's type of \i{}P. hookeriana\i0{}, which has a restricted distibution in the southern Cordilleran, is possibly a hybrid, and is inapplicable for the widespread arctic-boreal plant(s). Bente Eriksen (personal communication) has also studied the type and concurs. This means that the priority name must be \i{}P. arenosa\i0{}, if we consider the Russian and the American plants as the same, which we do.\par{}This is a circumpolar taxon that is very common in both the high and Low Arctic parts and often with isolated occurrences in temperate mountains.\par{}At least six names at species level have been considered within this group of races or closely related species: \i{}P. hookeriana\i0{} (1849 described from western North America), \i{}P. nipharga\i0{} (1908), \i{}P. arenosa\i0{} (1941) (described as a variety of \i{}P. nivea\i0{} in 1843 from Russia), \i{}P. kuznetzovii\i0{} (1941 described from Russia), \i{}P. chamissonis\i0{} (1945 described from Sweden), and also \i{}P. nivea\i0{} L. sensu Soják 1989, non Eriksen et al. 1999. North American and Greenland usage has focussed on \i{}P. arenosa\i0{} and \i{}P. chamissonis\i0{}, northwestern European usage on \i{}P. chamissonis\i0{}, and Russian usage on \i{}P. arenosa\i0{}, \i{}P. chamissonis\i0{}, and \i{}P. kuznetzovii\i0{}. The taxa are similar morphologically. There is close affinity across the North Atlantic, as emphasised by, e.g., Hultén (1945), and a similar close affinity occurs among plants on either side of the Bering Strait as emphasised by several authors. The major pattern is here interpreted as one widely Amphi-Atlantic entity and one widely Amphi-Beringian and American entity. \par{}The name '\i{}chamissonis\i0{}' relates to the North Atlantic entity and probably also the name '\i{}kuznetzovii'\i0{}, whereas the names \i{}'arenosa'\i0{} and \i{}'nivea'\i0{} sensu Soják relate to the amphi-Beringian plants. The name \i{}'hookeriana'\i0{}, previously applied to the almost circumpolar species, most probably belongs to a more local entity, perhaps a hybrid, in Rocky Mountains (according to independent evaluations by J. Soják / B. Yurtsev and by B. Eriksen). The name \i{}'nipharga'\i0{} is much more enigmatic. It is currently applied to a plant of arctic northeastern Canada and Greenland, strongly resembling \i{}P. arenosa\i0{} s.s., but differing in the hairs of the petioles. \i{}Potentilla arenosa\i0{} s.s. has a characteristic combination of stiff, long, verrucose hairs and an understory of very short, stiff hairs. The understory on the petioles of \i{}P. nipharga\i0{} consists of short, curved hairs. Another problem is that the name \i{}P. nipharga\i0{} is typified on plants from northwestern Canada (Fort Good Hope on the Mackenzie River, leg. I.S. Onion, type in NY), outside the range where the entity currently is accepted. Soják and Russian authors (e.g., Yurtsev) consider \i{}P. nipharga\i0{} as specifically different from \i{}P. arenosa\i0{}. If they are merged, \i{}P. nipharga\i0{} Rydb., 1908, has priority before \i{}P. arenosa\i0{} (Turcz.) Juz. 1941.\par{}The two main geographical entities are connected by specimens that appear to be morphologically intermediate both in North America, Greenland, and northern Eurasia. They are therefore better treated as subspecies than as species, as was done by Hultén (1968b). However, as the name has not yet been published for subsp. \i{}chamissonis\i0{}, in this Flora we treat them as species.>
<See \i{}Potentilla arenosa\i0{} for notes.>

<The species is very variable in northern Europe, which is the centre of distribution, and both sexual and apomictic reproduction has been reported (Asker and Jerling 1992, Nyléhn 2002). Attempts to subdivide the variation into taxa have not been generally accepted. In the Arctic, there seems to be comparatively little variation from eastern Canada through Greenland to Jan Mayen and Svalbard. The number of leaflets varies from three to five, and variation in number may occur within populations and within plants. Soják (1985, in determinations) restricted \i{}P. crantzii\i0{} to the regularly digitate-leaved plants, whereas the ternate-leaved ones were considered as \i{}P. gelida\i0{} C.A. Meyer subsp. \i{}boreo-asiatica\i0{} Jurtz. and R. Kamel. and plants with mixed leaves were considered as the hybrid species \i{}P.\i0{} ×\i{}scandica\i0{} Soják. This treatment is not in accordance with genetic patterns (Hansen et al. 2000, Hamre 2000, Nyléhn 2002) and also obscures the possible significance of the differences between the Atlantic \i{}P. crantzii\i0{} and the mainly Asian \i{}P. gelida\i0{}. The Canadian plants are predominantly digitate (five leaflets). \par{}Kartesz (1994) suggested that \i{}P. crantzii\i0{} may be synonymous with \i{}Potentilla tabernaemontani\i0{} Aschers. (\i{}P. neumanniana\i0{} Reichenb.), a species recognised as distinctly different from \i{}P. crantzii\i0{} in all recent European sources. Elven (personal communication, 2005) stated this has been investigated, and \i{}P. tabernaemontani\i0{} is an apomictic, hybridogenous complex where \i{}P. crantzii\i0{} partakes, but is not an important part. The Canadian plants are \i{}P. crantzii\i0{} and nothing else.\par{}Elven (personal communication, 2005) noted that "Kamelin, in Tzvelev (2001), claimed that the priority name for \i{}P. crantzii\i0{} should be \i{}P. verna\i0{}. The name \i{}P. verna\i0{} has been applied for several different plants and has scarcely been applied at all the last 100 years. Kamelin did not designate a lectotype, and the original material of Linnaeus' \i{}P. verna\i0{} is heterogeneous. It consists, according to Cafferty and Jarvis (2002) of \i{}P. crantzii\i0{} (LINN 655.23), \i{}P. aurea\i0{} (Haller 1740, t. 6, f. 4), \i{}P. grandiflora\i0{} (UPS Burser XVIII(2): 1), and an uncertain plant (LINN 655.24). To preserve current usage without formally rejecting \i{}P. verna\i0{}, Cafferty and Jarvis (2002, in \i{}Taxon\i0{}) selected the Burser specimen as lectotype, making \i{}P. verna\i0{} into a synonym of \i{}P. grandiflora\i0{} L., which resolved this question.">

<The long accepted name \i{}P. emarginata\i0{} Pursh, 1814, has to be rejected, as it is a later homonym of \i{}P. emarginata\i0{} Desv. 1804. The priority name at species level depends on whether or not the marginal populations in the temperate White Mountains (New Hampshire, \i{}P. robbinsiana\i0{} Oakes) and/or those in the Aleutian and Commodore islands (\i{}P. nana\i0{} Willd. ex Schltdl.) are included. \i{}Potentilla nana\i0{} was described in 1813-1816 and is the oldest name in the group. Russian authors consider it as a distinct and separate species, but the matter is not closed. \i{}Potentilla robbinsiana\i0{} was described in 1840, long before \i{}P. hyparctica\i0{} Malte was described from Ellesmere Island. They were united with the arctic plants at species level (but treated as different subspecies) by Löve and Solbrig (1964) and Löve and Löve (1965). However, Hultén (1946) considered \i{}P. robbinsiana\i0{} more closely related to the mainly Asian \i{}P. elegans\i0{} Cham. and Schltdl. Pending a more thorough comparison between \i{}P. hyparctica, P. nana\i0{}, and \i{}P. robbinsiana\i0{}, the former name is retained for the arctic plants. A parallel alpine taxon in northeastern Asia has been described as \i{}P. pulviniformis\i0{} Khokhr. Similar slightly deviating alpine plants, currently identified as \i{}P. hyparctica\i0{}, are known from southern Alaska and Scandinavia. \par{}The material from the Canadian Arctic falls into two fairly distinct entities, here only named Northern Race and Southern Race. The Northern Race contains the majority of the plants found throughout the Arctic islands except for southern Baffin and also on several of the northern mainland peninsulas. It has been named as \i{}P. groenlandica\i0{} R. Br. The Southern Race contains the majority of plants that occur in southern Baffin Island, the islands in Hudson Bay (except for Southampton), and on the mainland from Alaska to Labrador. It has also been named as var. \i{}elatior\i0{} (Abromeit) Fernald. The types behind these names have not yet been studied. \par{}The two races differ fairly consistently; there seems to be comparatively little overlap in characters and distributions. They are, however, obviously closely related and should be considered as major geographical races, i.e., as subspecies rather than species. The two races differ in several morphological features, as seen from the descriptions. Northern Race plants are more slender, more hairy, with leaflets that are more dissected and with more acute lobes. They have much smaller and more acute calyx and epicalyx segments. All Ellesmere Island specimens from CAN and DAO belong to this 'majority' race, and the type specimen of \i{}P. hyparctica\i0{} also belongs here. The Asian \i{}P. pulviniformis\i0{} is very close to the Northern Race. \par{}Southern Race plants are taller, have rounded leaflet lobes, and large and rounded epicalyx and calyx segments. As plants matching this description predominate on continental North America, it is at least probable that the type of \i{}P. robbinsiana\i0{} could belong to the southern race, but this must be checked against the type. \par{}Formal names for the races are not proposed here, mainly because the variation outside eastern Canada was not analysed. There might be relevant names also available from other regions. \par{}The data for the two races were scored independently. When it was compared the following differences were noted. \par{}Plant heights: southern race (2-)5-15(-20) cm, northern race, (1-)5-12(-15) cm\par{}Stipule widths: southern race (2-)3-5(-6), northern race 1-2(-3) mm \par{}Petiole lengths: southern race (10-)15-40(-60) mm, northern race (5-)10-20(-40) mm \par{}Sessile glands on petioles: southern race sparse, northern race, abundant\par{}Leaf blade lengths: southern race (5-)12-30(-35) mm, northern race (5-)8-15(-20) mm\par{}Leaf blade widths: southern race (10-)12-25(-30) mm, northern race (8-)10-15(-20) mm\par{}Leaflet blade lengths: southern race (5-)8-20(-22) mm, northern race (4-)6-12(-15) mm\par{}Leaflet blade widths: southern race (4-)8-15(-18) mm, northern race (3-)5-8(-12) mm\par{}Leaflet blade margins degree of incision: southern race 5-60%, northern race 25-75%\par{}Apical leaflet: southern race maybe stipitate, northern race, not stipitate\par{}Epicalyx segments lengths: southern race 3-6 mm, northern race 2.5-4 mm\par{}Epicalyx segments widths: southern race 2-3.5(-4) mm, northern race 1-1.5 mm\par{}Sepal lengths: southern race 6.5-8 mm, northern race 4-6(-8) mm\par{}Sepal widths: southern race (2.8-)3-3.5 mm, northern race 2.2-3 mm\par{}Petals widths: southern race (4-)5-8(-9) mm, northern race (3.5-)4-6(-7) mm\par{}Fruit length: southern race 1.2-1.5 mm, northern race 0.9-1.2 mm\par{}Fruit width: southern race 0.9-1.2 mm, northern race 0.7-1 mm\par{}Distribution: southern race, not in N.W.T. islands, southern race not in Labrador and Quebec.>

<As defined here, \i{}P. nivea\i0{} is a circumpolar entity. It reaches the High Arctic in Greenland and Svalbard but is distinctly Low Arctic in the Canadian Arctic Islands. The Baffin island plants are uniformly trifoliate and densely tomentose (floccose), with almost no straight hairs, and they match \i{}P. nivea\i0{} L. s.s. The Victoria island plants have some straight hairs and also some other characters that may be indicative of some influence from the \i{}P. arenosa\i0{} subgroup. They differ, however, appreciably from the Beringian entity (\i{}P. crebridens \i0{}or \i{}P. nivea\i0{} subsp. \i{}hemicryophila\i0{}). \par{}The name \i{}P. nivea\i0{} L. subsp. \i{}nivea\i0{} might be applicable for the eastern Canadian plants if the current, mainly genetically based, entities are separated as subspecies. Relations between the Canadian and European plants, and the variation in Greenland, need to be ascertained by genetic investigations before any firm taxonomic and nomenclatural conclusions can be drawn.>

<Interruptedly circumpolar, almost exclusively in the Arctic but with many gaps, especially in Russia-Siberia. The gaps are probably a result of the species' strong affinity for dry and distinctly basic substrates.\par{}\i{}Potentilla pulchella\i0{} is fairly unambiguous in an arctic context and might be seen as a comparatively homogeneous arctic counterpart of the much more diverse boreal-temperate \i{}P. multifida\i0{} L. complex (including \i{}P. bimundorum\i0{} Soják and \i{}P. virgulata\i0{} Nels.) that does not reach the Arctic islands. \par{}Variety \i{}gracilicaulis\i0{} A.E. Porsild was described to encompass more southern and western plants and was said to differ from the 'main' race (described from Melville Island) in being taller and with less hairy leaves. It was typified from Canada: Atkinson Pt., 01.-03.08.1927, leg. A.E.Porsild and R.T.Porsild 3632 (CAN) holotype. There is a wide range in size and indumentum in this species. Very tall plants are commonly found in manured sites, and populations of sub-glabrous plants are sometimes found in exposed coastal situations like shore terraces. A test of three such 'morphs' from Svalbard found that each of them kept some of the same appearance in cultivation but were inseparable in genetic markers (isozymes and RAPDs) (Hansen et al. 2000, Hamre 2000). Most of the numerous isoenzyme multiloci phenotypes were found in all three 'morphs', and they were interpreted as phenetic responses. Variety \i{}gracilicaulis\i0{} might be one or more of such phenetic 'morphs' and thereby not worth recognition as a variety. \par{}There is a geographical pattern in the variation in North America that might merit further analysis. In addition to the western \i{}'gracilicaulis'\i0{} plants, a conspicuously robust and hairy entity occurs in the Hudson Bay region. Other recognisable patterns are found in other regions outside North America. At present (2005), we proposed to keep this widespread and variable species as one entity throughout the circumpolar area.>

<What here is entered as a \i{}P. rubricaulis\i0{} aggregate is a possibly artificial group of plants that have mainly three features in common: leaves digitate (more than three leaflets attached at about the same point) or semipinnate (more than three leaflets attached along a very short axis); an often silky indumentum of long, often shiny hairs on both leaf surfaces (and on other parts); and multiflowered stems. They are interpreted by J. Soják and B. Yurtsev (personal communication) as probably agamospermic derivatives from hybrids between several species of sect. \i{}Niveae\i0{} (both the \i{}P. nivea\i0{} group and the \i{}P. uniflora\i0{} group) and at least two species of sect. \i{}Multifidae\i0{} (\i{}P. anachoretica\i0{}, \i{}P. pulchella\i0{}, perhaps also \i{}P. bimundorum\i0{} in the case of \i{}P. rubricaulis\i0{} s. str.).\par{}The hypotheses of Soják and Yurtsev may well be true as to the origin of the aggregate. It still leaves the question whether it is feasible (and worthwhile) to try to classify such agamic complexes. In this aggregate, some of the entities are comparatively widespread and may be locally common. They cannot be ignored. However, they often vary morphologically from island to island, and sometimes from site to site. It is evident that their evolutionary background is diverse and includes several parental species. The choice is between a collective treatment and a treatment as several species. The former option is chosen here, as the data needed for a more detailed taxonomic treatment still are absent. Numerous taxa have been described from northeastern Asia and Alaska (and one from the European North Atlantic), but it is uncertain or even improbable whether these are the relevant ones in northern Canada and Greenland. The variation in northern Canada is much too large to fit well into the two taxa described from this area. This is a matter for further studies.\par{}For North America and Greenland, the following seven entities have been proposed. The suggested origins are indicated.\par{}\b\i{}Potentilla rubricaulis\i0{} Lehm\b0{}. Perhaps originating from \i{}P. bimundorum\i0{} Soják (\i{}Multifidae\i0{}) and \i{}P. arenosa\i0{} s.l. (\i{}Niveae\i0{}). This entity, described from Mackenzie District, occurs north to Liverpool Bay and Cape Dalhousie, but is unlikely to occur in the archipelago islands.\par{}\b\i{}Potentilla pedersenii\i0{} Rydberg\b0{} Probably originating from \i{}P. pulchella\i0{} R. Br. (\i{}Multifidae\i0{}) and a species of sect. \i{}Niveae\i0{}. This entity, described from Greenland, is probably a name that is relevant for at least some plants from the northeastern islands.\par{}\b\i{}Potentilla borealis\i0{} Soják\b0{} Probably originating from \i{}P. anachoretica\i0{} Soják (\i{}Multifidae\i0{}) and \i{}P. arenosa\i0{} s. str. (\i{}Niveae\i0{}). This entity, described from West Chukotka, has been reported from Alaska and may occur in the western archipelago islands.\par{}\b\i{}Potentilla petrovskyi\i0{} Soják \b0{}Probably originating from \i{}P. anachoretica\i0{} Soják (\i{}Multifidae\i0{}) and \i{}P. nivea\i0{} s. lat. (\i{}Niveae\i0{}, most probably subsp. \i{}hemicryophila\i0{} or \i{}P. crebridens\i0{}). This entity, described from South Chukotka, has also been reported from Alaska and may occur in the western archipelago islands.\par{}\b\i{}Potentilla tschaunensis\i0{} Juz. ex Jurtz.\b0{} This entity probably has the same general origin. It is described from West Chukotka, reported from Alaska, and may occur in the western archipelago islands.\par{}\b\i{}Potentilla murrayi\i0{} Jurtz. \b0{}Probably originating from \i{}P. anachoretica\i0{} Soják (\i{}Multifidae\i0{}) and a species of the \i{}P. uniflora\i0{} group (\i{}Niveae\i0{}, Yurtsev proposed \i{}P. subvahliana\i0{} Jurtz. as the parent). This entity, described from Brooks Range in northern Alaska, might be relevant in northwestern Canada.\par{}\b\i{}Potentilla insularis\i0{} Soják\b0{} Proposed by Soják as originating from \i{}P. lyngei\i0{} Jurtz. and Soják (\i{}Multifidae\i0{}) and \i{}P. arenosa\i0{} (Trautv.) Juz. subsp. \i{}chamissonis\i0{} (Hultén). This origin has been disputed (Hansen et al. 2000, Hamre 2000), because \i{}P. lyngei\i0{} is absent from the area where it occurs and because the \i{}Multifidae\i0{} species that is present (\i{}P. pulchella\i0{}) does not seem to be involved. It is reported from Svalbard and much more doubtfully from Greenland. As it certainly is closely related to, and probably derived from, \i{}P. arenosa\i0{} subsp. \i{}chamissonis\i0{}, it may well occur in northern Canada.>

<See also notes for \i{}P. vahliana\i0{}. Several specimens from Banks and Victoria Islands, previously included in \i{}P. vahliana\i0{}, differ from that relatively common taxon by having a pure white indumentum, slightly more deeply dissected leaflets, and most conspicuously by lacking an elongated caudex thickly covered by leaf remains. These specimens were redetermined to \i{}P. uniflora\i0{}, being inseparable morphologically from specimens of \i{}P. uniflora\i0{} collected on continental North America. They have previously been overlooked, both in the islands and on the mainland coast east of the Mackenzie River, and the species distribution may be more widespread in the archipelago than indicated here.\par{}The holotype specimen is recorded from the Russian Far East, 'Terra Tschuktschorum ad sin. St. Lawrentii', leg. \i{}Eschscholtz\i0{}, in LE. \i{}Potentilla uniflora\i0{} in the current meaning has not been observed at Lavrentiya (St. Lawrence Bay) (Yurtsev, personal communication, 2003). The earlier collection which might have been available to Ledebour is Adams' collection from the lower reaches of Lena River and Bykov Mts. in northern Yakutia. These plants look like Ledebour's paratypes.>

<Canadian plants that Yurtsev had identified as \i{}P. subvahliana\i0{} were redetermined by Elven to \i{}P. vahliana\i0{} in 2000, following a comparison with Greenland plants identified by Yurtsev as \i{}P. vahliana\i0{} s.s. The single specimen annotated as \i{}P. subvahliana\i0{} by Soják in CAN and DAO is a \i{}P. uniflora\i0{} hybrid with \i{}P. arenosa\i0{} (probably a F1 hybrid). The western limit of the distribution in the arctic islands of \i{}P. vahliana\i0{} seems to be Banks and Victoria. Reports from northern Alaska (Hultén 1968b) are not confirmed, and no specimens of \i{}P. vahliana\i0{} from the northern Yukon or northern Alaska have been found in CAN or DAO. There might be a (slightly) different plant (a low-ploidal entity) on the west side of the Bering Straits, justifying the recognition of \i{}P. subvahliana\i0{} Jurtz., but further study is needed on the differences between \i{}P. vahliana\i0{} and \i{}P. subvahliana\i0{}. Thus, the name \i{}P. vahliana\i0{} is applied for the Canadian plants.\par{}Sometimes the differences between \i{}P. vahliana\i0{} and \i{}P. uniflora \i0{}are slight. Some specimens from continental North America eastwards from the Mackenzie River seem to combine characters and are difficult to assign with certainty. Treating members of this aggregate as subspecies might be more appropriate, but as ploidy level differences are reported (Löve and Löve 1975), they are currently treated as species.>

<Small and Catling (2000b) have written an extensive and informative review of cloudberry. They state the name is "from the Latin \i{}rubus\i0{}, bramble, from \i{}ruber\i0{}, meaning red, an allusion to red dye obtained from fruits of some of the species. \i{}Chamaemorus\i0{}, from the Greek \i{}chamai\i0{} and \i{}moron.\i0{} First applied for this species by Carolus Clusius, 1601. The word \i{}chamae\i0{}, which means on the ground, a reference to the low habit." (p. 43). \par{}"Cloudberry has an extensive creeping and branching system of slender woody rhizomes covered with brownish papery bark. The rhizomes can grow down to a depth of 30 cm," and in southern areas have an average length of about 1 m (Small and Catling 2000b). Cloudberry propagates predominantly by these subterranean rhizomes, which grow about 10 cm below the substrate surface. Such vegetative reproduction has been said to be the best strategy for reproduction in the unpredictable climate of high latitudes. While seeds are necessary to colonise sites, seedlings are rarely observed under natural conditions. That \i{}R. chamaemorus\i0{} is dioecious has been the subject of many evolutionary research studies. Cloudberry stands often have a dominance of male plants, with less than 25% of the flowering shoots female. "This has been attributed partly to greater competitive ability of male plants, and partly to greater flower production by the males. The important fly and bee pollinators show a strong preference for male flowers, which are larger, provide pollen and much more nectar. This seemingly excessive favouring of the male sex may be related to the relatively low dependence of the species on sexual reproduction" (Small and Catling 2000b, p. 44). \par{}\i{}Rubus chamaemorus \i0{}is the only species in the subgenus \i{}Chamaemorus\i0{} which is characterised by annual aerial stems, simple leaves, and yellow fruit. The species has crossed spontaneously (and has been artificially crossed) with the common raspberry, but the offspring of these crosses have been sterile. \par{}Moose and caribou browse the aerial shoots. In Northern areas heavy frost, snowfalls, or rain during flowering may result in very limited or no seed production. "Female flowers appear to be more susceptible to frost than the male flowers. Good snow cover has been observed to delay flowering until the danger of frost damage is reduced". (Small and Catling 2000b, p. 45)\par{}In Canada, it is considered that the best way to harvest is to "pick a combination of the hard red fruit and the soft golden fruit. The hard red fruits seem to have a high pectin content and when cooked produce a delicious apricot-like flavour, but using only the hard red berries produces too thick and dry a preserve. The soft golden fruit is fragile, deteriorates easily, and when cooked without some hard red fruits produces a slightly runny product with an inferior flavour. The fresh berries will keep for several weeks in a refrigerator." (Small and Catling 2000b, p. 45). However, in the Nordic countries (Norway, Sweden, and Finland) it is against the law (and quite often also punished) to pick the red fruits, and jam with some red fruits is considered vastly inferior (Elven, personal communication, 2005). \par{}"The Finnish liqueur Lakka and the Quebec liqueur Chicoutai are both distilled from cloudberry....Cloudberries have a high content (50-150 mg per 100 g of fruit) of ascorbic acid (vitamin C), which is retained well when the berries are frozen or otherwise preserved immediately after picking. The berries are also rich in benzoic acid (ca 50 mg/100 g of fruit), which promotes good storage. Aromatic compounds are prevalent in cloudberry and produce a very pleasing and unique scent. More than 100 volatiles have been identified, the most important of which are ethyl hexanoate, 4-vinylphenol, 2-methoxy-5-vinylphenol, 2-methylbutanoic acid, hexanal benzyl alcohol, and 2-phenyl-ethanol. The volatile compounds may be used to identify cultivars." \par{}"The seeds of cloudberry have tested positive for amygdalin, a poisonous cyanogenetic compound, which may function as a germination inhibitor. There has been no suggestion that the concentrations are sufficient to raise concern, and cloudberries are considered non-toxic." (Small and Catling 2000b, p. 45).>

<Polunin (1940) commented that this seems to be an unusually good monomorph and that he could see no constant difference between the material from the eastern Arctic Archipelago and specimens collected in widely separated parts of Europe and Asia. In the Canadian Arctic, it generally grows in rather close, low tufts, whose very tallest axes scarcely reach 10 cm, but which flower and fruit quite plentifully. \par{}Galen and Stanton (1995) studied responses of snowbed plant species to changes in the length of a growing season. "Over the course of the experiment, growing season length had significant effects on absolute and relative cover of the species studied (\i{}P\i0{} \u8804\'3f 0.025 and \i{}P\i0{} \u8804\'3f 0.005, respectively), and these effects were similar near both the edge and centre of the snowbed. Yet, only for the snowbed specialist, \i{}Sibbaldia procumbens\i0{}, were changes in absolute and relative cover under early and late snowmelt schedules predictable from the species' distribution along the historical snow depth gradient. \i{}Sibbaldia procumben\i0{}s increased in cover under a long growing season and was more common in historically early-melting portions of the snowbed." (p. 1546).>

<The Yukon territorial flower. \par{}Mosquin (1966) studied the taxonomy (of what he called \i{}Epilobium angustifolium\i0{}) because he wished to establish the way in which chromosomal discontinuity correlated with morphological discontinuities after three chromosomal races with \i{}n\i0{} =18, 36, and 54 had been discovered (Mulligan 1957 and Mosquin 1963). Mosquin recognised subspecies \i{}angustifolium\i0{}, \i{}n\i0{} = 18 and 54, and subspecies \i{}circumvagum\i0{} Mosquin, \i{}n\i0{} = 36, the later based on \i{}Chamaenerion angustifolium\i0{} var. \i{}platyphyllum\i0{} Daniels. The best characters for distinguishing the taxa are the pubescence, or lack of it, on the abaxial leaf midribs, the leaf width and length, whether the pollen is triporate, or a mixture of pore sizes, and the diameter of the pollen. Mosquin (1966) mapped the distribution of 95 chromosome records; a map that indicates that plants with 2\i{}n\i0{} = 36 are not found as far north as 60°N. \par{}Mosquin (1966) stated that white-flowered forms are generally most common in 2\i{}n\i0{} = 18 plants, less common in 2\i{}n\i0{} = 36 plants, and apparently unknown among 2\i{}n\i0{} = 54 plants. \par{}Mosquin and Small (1971, p. 680, 681) considered that \i{}C. angustifolium\i0{} and \i{}C. latifolium \i0{}represent an example of parallel evolution and that "although the two species are closely related, evidence indicates that they are isolated by ecological and genetic barriers. [They admitted that] F1 hybrids have been collected from transitional habitats (Böcher 1962) [but noted that hybrids are] extremely infrequent in view of the occurrence of widespread areas of sympatry... Attempts to cross the two species have given variable results (Pugsley 1960, Mosquin, unpubl.) but generally revealed strong barriers to F1 seed production coupled with marked F1 pollen sterility. While these barriers were not considered sufficiently well developed to have prevented introgression between the two species, [Mosquin and Small (1971) stated that] there iss no indication of this in the polyploids, which closely resemble their diploid progenitors, and do not possess characters attributable to introgression from their sister species. \par{}Evidence for parallelism comes from five observations: \par{}(1) Both species occupy comparably widespread ranges in the northern hemisphere... \par{}(2) In each species diploids occupy the more northern and/or alpine areas, while polyploids occur in more southern and/or warmer regions. \par{}(3) In each species autopolyploidy has been the mechanism of polyploidisation. \par{}(4) Each species has retained the capacity to form high levels of quadrivalents at meiosis, unlike many other autopolyploids (Morrison and Rajhathy 1960). \par{}(5) Within each species the diploids very closely resemble the polyploids." \par{}Mosquin and Small (1971) suggested "the evolution of polyploidy has been accompanied by a common morphological change, namely an increase in frequency of extra pores in the pollen grains." (p. 682). \par{}Small and Catling (1999) noted that despite the \ldblquote{}weed\rdblquote{} in fireweed, this species is not usually a significant weed in Canada, although it is a weed in Europe. Potential problems for forest managers may exist, since \i{}C. angustifolium\i0{} seedlings can compete with conifer seedlings in revegetating burned land, and \i{}C. angustifolium\i0{} serves as the alternative host of conifer rusts. Fireweed has also been observed to be a weed of some vegetable crops in northern regions. \par{}Inbreeding depression, which is reduced fitness following self-fertilisation, is extreme in fireweed, making cross-pollination very important. Individual flowers mature their pollen before the stigma is receptive, which prevents selfing. Bees, bumblebees, moths, and butterflies are important pollinators of fireweed. They characteristically move from the bottom towards the top of the flowering stem. The insects visit the lower flowers, which have opened first, have already shed their pollen, and have receptive stigmas. They then move up the inflorescence where they acquire pollen from the upper flowers, which have not yet exposed their stigmas (Small and Catling 1999, Galen and Plowright 1985, Husband and Schemske 1997). \par{}A fruit of fireweed can contain as many as 500 seeds, and a single plant may produce as many as 80,000 seeds per year (Small and Catling 1999). The plumose seeds can be carried by wind for hundreds of kilometres (Solbreack and Andersson 1987). A Swedish study revealed that up to half of the seed produced disperses over the landscape more than 100 m above the ground. Humidity expands the diameter of the seed hairs, decreasing loft, an adaptation that tends to deposit the seeds in humid areas and during wet periods. The seeds are non-dormant and short-lived, rarely remaining viable for more than 3 years and generally germinating as soon as a suitable site is found. \par{}Although seeds account for the remarkable ability of fireweed to colonise new areas, once a seed germinates, vegetative reproduction by rhizomes becomes more important than sexual reproduction. Fragmentation of the rhizomes stimulates production of shoots, contributing to the reputation of fireweed as a hard-to-eradicate weed. Most of the rhizomes occur in the top 5 cm of mineral soils, and this underground portion can survive relatively intense fires. The aboveground shoots of older plants are killed by frost, but the plants overwinter as rhizomes (Small and Catling 1999). Fireweed sprouted quickly from surviving rhizomes, following the volcanic eruption of Mount St. Helens, Washington, in 1980. One year after the explosion, 81% of all seedlings present were from fireweed. \par{}Fireweed is not considered toxic. Compounds, such as an unusual flavonoid myricetin 3-O-ß-D-glucuronide, with strong healing antiseptic and anti-inflammatory effects, have been found in the foliage. This active principle reaches its maximum concentration during and shortly after the plants flower (Ducrey et al. 1995). In Norway we sometimes (not very often) make a very nice and refreshing drink from it, boiling fresh leaves. There has been no rumour of poisonous effects at all in Europe; it is rather seen as a useful (but slightly noxious weedy) plant (Elven, personal communication, 2005).\par{}It has been suggested that mutations from the radiation near uranium deposits results in a relatively high frequency of white-flowered variants of fireweed, and that this phenomenon can be used to find uranium (Shacklette 1964). \par{}This species was found to be an early coloniser of oil spills in Alaska (Kershaw and Kershaw 1986). It is an early and efficient coloniser almost everywhere.\par{}Porsild annotated a specimen (CAN 223779) that was collected from the Gull cliffs opposite Pangnirtung on 15 August 1953 by V.C. Wynne-Edwards as \i{}Epilobium angustifolium\i0{} L. × \i{}E. latifolium\i0{} L. On the label is the note, "both parent species and every gradation of hybrid, in profusion on manured ground beneath the gull cliff opposite Pangnirtung Post. \i{}C. latifolium\i0{} was already finished flowering. \i{}E. angustifolium\i0{} only in bud, and the hybrids make a great show of colour." Peter C. Hoch, Missouri Botanical Garden, annotated the specimen in 1979 as \i{}E. angustifolium\i0{} subsp. \i{}angustifolium\i0{}. The observed difference in flowering time would make hybridisation less likely. \par{}>

<Numerous infraspecific taxa of \i{}C. latifolium\i0{} have been described from local regions (Haussknecht 1884, Böcher 1962, Munz 1965). Small (1968) reported that tetraploids of \i{}C. latifolium\i0{} tend to have high percentages of 4-pored pollen, while the diploids usually have only 3-pored pollen. Small (1968) mapped the distribution of the races in the western hemisphere, indicating that all the collections from the Canadian Arctic Archipelago appear to be diploid. The races appear to form worldwide, allopatric ecogeographic phases. A high level of quadrivalent formation observed during tetraploid meiosis indicated that the tetraploids arose by autopolyploidy. Small (1968) stated that the tetraploids in \i{}C. latifolium\i0{} are undoubtedly autotetraploids, as the polyploids and diploids are almost indistinguishable morphologically. The distinctiveness of \i{}C. latifolium\i0{} within its genus make it highly unlikely that the tetraploids arose by allopolyploidy. Since distinctive phases are not found among the diploid populations, the origin of the tetraploid from hybridisation between different diploid races of \i{}C. latifolium\i0{} is very unlikely. This led Small (1968) to recommend that the races not be given formal taxonomic recognition. \par{}Mosquin and Small (1971, p. 680, 681) considered that \i{}C. angustifolium\i0{} and \i{}C. latifolium \i0{}represent an example of parallel evolution and that "although the two species are closely related, evidence indicates that they are isolated by ecological and genetic barriers. [They admitted that] F1 hybrids have been collected from transitional habitats (Böcher 1962) [but noted that hybrids are] extremely infrequent in view of the occurrence of widespread areas of sympatry... Attempts to cross the two species have given variable results (Pugsley 1960, Mosquin, unpubl.) but generally revealed strong barriers to F1 seed production coupled with marked F1 pollen sterility. While these barriers were not considered sufficiently well developed to have prevented introgression between the two species, [Mosquin and Small (1971) stated that] there iss no indication of this in the polyploids, which closely resemble their diploid progenitors, and do not possess characters attributable to introgression from their sister species. \par{}Evidence for parallelism comes from five observations: \par{}(1) Both species occupy comparably widespread ranges in the northern hemisphere... \par{}(2) In each species diploids occupy the more northern and/or alpine areas, while polyploids occur in more southern and/or warmer regions. \par{}(3) In each species autopolyploidy has been the mechanism of polyploidisation. \par{}(4) Each species has retained the capacity to form high levels of quadrivalents at meiosis, unlike many other autopolyploids (Morrison and Rajhathy 1960). \par{}(5) Within each species the diploids very closely resemble the polyploids." \par{}Mosquin and Small (1971) suggested "the evolution of polyploidy has been accompanied by a common morphological change, namely an increase in frequency of extra pores in the pollen grains." (p. 682). \par{}Doak (1991) conducted a 3-year experimental study of dwarf fireweed's responses to real and simulated attacks by a momphid caterpillar and found that the type and extent of plant responses changed with morphological and temporal scale. Damaged shoots showed effective compensation, producing between 89 and 583% more branch tissue than undamaged shoots, but as clumps of shoots are joined by perennial rhizomes; a single year of herbivore damage to a clump's shoots reduced net growth by more than 75% over a 3-year period. Clump form also changed following attack. In the year after damage, shoot numbers were reduced by 51%, while mean shoot size either increased or was unaffected. Further complicating the caterpillar's impact on its host was its inhibition of mammalian herbivory; simulated caterpillar damage reduced the probability of mammalian attack from 20 to 6%. Doak (1991) concluded that these complicated and very different changes following herbivory illustrate the need to study compensation mechanistically and in the context of plant's biotic environment in order to understand its importance and consequences.>

<Samuelsson (1922) based the original description of this species on collections from Siberia, Novaya Zemlya, and Greenland, and provided a photograph of pressed plants to illustrate the species he was describing. \par{}Hoch (unpublished) considers \i{}E. arcticum\i0{} to be restricted to North America, in northern Alaska, NWT (especially the former Franklin Territory), Canadian Arctic Archipelago, and Greenland north of 70°N. The species was, however, originally described from "Groenlandia, Nova Zemblia, insula Waigatsch et Sibiria arctica", i.e., almost every major arctic region except for North America. Samuelsson cited and illustrated specimens from all the mentioned areas, and no specific type was indicated (Elven et al. 2003).>

<Bednara (1977, 1978) described the development of the monosporic, tetranucleate embryo sac of \i{}E. palustre, \i0{}and the embryology of the macrospore tetrad.\par{}A CAN specimen from Coral Harbour was examined by Elven (May 2005) and confirmed to be this species.>
<See Al-Shehbaz et al. (1999), Novon 9: 296-307, for their concept of \i{}Arabis\i0{} and \i{}Arabidopsis\i0{}.>

<Elven et al. (2003) noted that according to O'Kane and Al-Shehbaz (1997), Novon 7: 323-327, and Al-Shehbaz et al. (1999), Novon 9: 296-307, this genus should be confined in a northern context to \i{}A. thaliana\i0{}, \i{}A. arenosa\i0{}, \i{}A. suecica\i0{} (the alloploid from \i{}A. arenosa\i0{} and \i{}A. thaliana\i0{}, named as \i{}Hylandra\i0{} by Á. Löve), and the \i{}A. kamtschatica\i0{}-\i{}lyrata\i0{}-\i{}petraea\i0{} group. This approach was followed by Elven et al. (2003). It is also strongly supported by the recent works of Koch et al. (1999, 2000, 2001). Their analyses connect \i{}A. thaliana\i0{}, \i{}A. suecica\i0{}, and the \i{}A. kamtschatica\i0{}-\i{}lyrata\i0{}-\i{}petraea\i0{} group inside an \i{}Arabidopsis\i0{} s.s.\par{}>

<Harris (1985) considered \i{}B. glabella\i0{} to be a wide-ranging species composed of many isolated, inbreeding, and somewhat distinct populations. He considered that none of these populations could be consistently grouped into subgroups distinctive enough to warrant taxonomic recognition at the species level, so it seemed wisest, and certainly most practical, to recognise a single polymorphic species.\par{}Recent DNA sequence data provide strong evidence that \i{}Braya glabella\i0{} is an allopolyploid that includes genomic contributions from both the \i{}B. pilosa\i0{}/\i{}B. thorild-wulffii\i0{} and the \i{}B. humilis\i0{}/\i{}B. linearis\i0{}/\i{}B. alpina\i0{} lineages. Perhaps it has arisen several times in several different places, as has been demonstrated in some allopolyploid \i{}Draba\i0{} species.\par{}\i{}Braya glabella\i0{} is extremely variable throughout its range. Multiple origins and non-uniform genomic contributions from parental lineages could account for the morphological variability in \i{}B. glabella\i0{}. Local pockets of variation have at times been recognised at the species, subspecies, and variety levels, but most of these taxonomic designations break down when the complex patterns of variation from the entire range of \i{}B. glabella\i0{} are considered. However, populations of \i{}B. glabella\i0{} from High Arctic regions are usually distinguishable from those from lower arctic and subarctic montane populations, and they are recognised here as subsp. \i{}purpurascens\i0{} and subsp. \i{}glabella\i0{}, respectively. Some populations on southern islands in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago and along the northern coast of continental North America will defy unequivocal placement.\par{}Key to subspecies. \par{}1a.\tab{}Fruits oblong to narrowly oblong-lanceolate, 3.5-8.3 times longer than broad; mature fruiting inflorescences often loosely elongated; plants of lower arctic, subarctic, and montane distribution....subsp. \i{}glabella\i0{} \par{}1b.\tab{}Fruits ovoid-ellipsoid to oblong-ellipsoid (rarely broadly oblong-lanceolate), 2.5-3.7 times longer than broad; mature fruiting inflorescences often densely compact; plants mostly of High Arctic distribution, south to the northern coast of continental North America...subsp. \i{}purpurascens\i0{} \par{}Harris (1985) noted that \i{}Braya glabella\i0{} Richards. is perhaps the most poorly understood \i{}Braya\i0{} species. It is extremely variable from one population to another, and to some extent, even within populations. Previous authors have split the species into several taxa on the basis of differences in silique shape and pubescence, style length, stigma breadth and lobing, leaf shape and dentation, and inflorescence length. While it is true that many populations of \i{}B. glabella\i0{} appear to be strikingly distinct on the basis of these attributes, when a large number of specimens are examined from throughout the entire range of distribution the perceived morphological gaps quickly blur into a bewildering array of overlapping forms. Richardson's original collections of \i{}Braya glabella\i0{} and the original collections of Brown's \i{}Platypetalum purpurascens\i0{} happen to fall near the opposite edges of the spectrum of diversity in the species. It is not at all surprising that Brown (1823, 1824), as well as the overwhelming majority of subsequent authors, recognised the two taxa as separate and distinct species; indeed, the type specimens of \i{}B. glabella\i0{} and \i{}P. purpurascens\i0{} appear to be very different. But, when the entire range of variation is observed, the two morphological forms flow together to the point that it is impossible to draw a sharp boundary line between them. Abbe (1948) commented on the range of variation to be found in this group even within a single population. He and his wife collected 58 individuals from a population at Richmond (E.C. and L.B. Abbe 3819) and found that the plants ranged from specimens that fell very nicely within the range of variation of "typical" \i{}Braya purpurascens\i0{} as described by Brown (1823) and illustrated by Hooker (1830, Tab. XXIII) "...into the robust type of specimen from Southampton Island..." Had Abbe had access to authentic fruiting material of \i{}B. glabella\i0{}, he almost certainly would have realised that the robust specimens from Southampton Island (for example, Malte 120677) are near perfect matches for "typical" \i{}B. glabella\i0{}. This, in fact, appears to be the pattern in the group; specimens from the North American High Arctic are more or less \i{}B. purpurascens\i0{}-like, and plants from lower arctic, subarctic, and montane regions are generally more \i{}B. glabella\i0{}-like, but it is almost always possible to find plants in any population that look somewhat out of place and approach, morphologically, plants of the alternate morphological form. The populations on and near the northern coast of continental North America appear to be in the zone of overlap, and it is here that the greatest difficulty is encountered in attempting to segregate specimens into one or the other of the two forms. This is especially true in disturbed areas, where normally inbreeding, isolated populations come together as they move onto the newly available habitats, gene flow again begins to take place, and plants from the same population may exhibit an extreme range of diversity. On the basis of morphological and molecular evidence, it is difficult to justify the recognition of more than one species in this very plastic group, but it does seem desirable to divide the species into two rather weak subspecies. Many populations will be readily separable into one of these subspecies, but other populations will undoubtedly defy unequivocal placement, particularly those from areas where the ranges of the subspecies meet. Harris (1985) also noted that Abbe (1948), even with very limited material to work with, realised the close relationship between \i{}Braya glabella\i0{} and \i{}B. purpurascens\i0{} and became suspicious that the two might comprise a single species: "There is no evidence against \i{}Braya glabella\i0{} of Richardson being conspecific with \i{}B. purpurascens\i0{} (R. Brown) Bunge. The chief difficulty is the lack of positive evidence concerning the nature of the mature siliques and of their arrangement on the scape. Should these support the possibility that the two are conspecific, then the name \i{}B. glabella\i0{} would have to be substituted for \i{}B. purpurascens\i0{}." It appears that \i{}B. glabella\i0{} and \i{}B. purpurascens\i0{} are indeed conspecific and warrant recognition only at the infraspecific level. Because the epithet "\i{}glabella\i0{}" (Richardson 1823) was validly published before the epithet "\i{}purpurascens\i0{}" (Brown1823), \i{}B. glabella\i0{} has nomenclatural priority over \i{}B. purpurascens\i0{}.>

<See under \i{}B. glabella\i0{} subsp. \i{}glabella\i0{} for a discussion of the species and its infraspecific taxa.\par{}Elven et al. (2003) noted that Rollins (1993) synonymised \i{}B. glabella\i0{}, \i{}B. purpurascens\i0{} (and \i{}B. henryae\i0{}), and \i{}B. bartlettiana\i0{} without any arguments and without reference to other authors. It is difficult both to object to and to accept his point of view without comparison of types of all four entities. \par{}Harris (1985), after examining the types of all four entities, considered \i{}B. henryae\i0{} and \i{}B. bartlettiana\i0{} to be synonyms of \i{}B. glabella\i0{} var. \i{}glabella\i0{}, and recognised \i{}B. purpurascens\i0{} as a variety of \i{}B. glabella\i0{}. \par{}\i{}Braya henryae\i0{} was accepted as a species by Porsild and Cody (1980), who commented that perhaps it should be considered a geographical race of \i{}B. purpurascens.\i0{}>

<Harris (1985) separated the two varieties of \i{}B. humilis\i0{} in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago as follows: \par{}1a. Siliques 1.2-1.8 mm wide, not torulose; stems simple, becoming prostrate in fruit; plants of northern Ellesmere Island... \b{}var. \i{}ellesmerensis\i0{} \par{}\b0{}1b. Siliques 0.6-1.1(-1.3) mm wide, usually more or less torulose; stems simple or branches, ascending to erect; plants of various distributions. Flowers small, average petal length less than 5 mm; most flowers developing normal siliques; leaves often dentate or pinnatifid; plants of wide distribution in North America....\b{}var. \i{}humilis\i0{} \par{}\b0\i{}Braya humilis\i0{} is widely distributed on sedimentary soils in western Canada and Alaska, but completely absent from the granitic rock and soils of the Canadian Shield. In order to explain the present-day distribution of \i{}Braya\i0{} in North America, it is necessary to postulate the survival of segments of the population in unglaciated areas to the north and south of the ice-sheet as well as in localised refugial areas that escaped glaciation even though surrounded by ice. \par{}Harris (1985) superimposed the distribution of \i{}B. humilis\i0{} on the map, showing the approximate limits of the granitic bedrock in the eastern Canadian Shield. He noted the sharply defined distribution limits of \i{}B. humilis\i0{} in Ontario and Manitoba and suggested that this indicated the inability of this species to invade regions of granitic soils. \par{}Acceptance of \i{}Neotorularia\i0{}, as distinct from \i{}Braya\i0{}, was proposed in the work of Hedge and Léonard, in Léonard (1986) and Al-Shehbaz et al. (1999), Novon 9: 296-307. In an arctic context, it consists of entities within what has been named \i{}Braya humilis\i0{} and 1-2 close relatives, entities accepted by Rollins (1993) within his concept of \i{}B. humilis\i0{}. \par{}The genus name \i{}Torularia\i0{} (Coss.) O.E. Schulz was proposed conserved for this genus [Taxon 31: 754, 1982], but this proposal was rejected [see Taxon 34: 661, 1985]. More recent DNA evidence has suggested that \i{}B. humilis\i0{} belongs with other \i{}Braya\i0{} species, and it is to be so treated in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment (Al-Shehbaz, personal communication, Dec. 2003). \par{}The writing of Harris (1985) on this taxon noted that the plants have a tendency to form small populations of fairly uniform individuals, which are each somewhat different from the next population, but may be quite similar to some distant populations. He thought this may be due to several factors, suggesting the following: \par{}1. Hexaploid populations probably often arise through hybridisation of tetraploid and octoploid populations. It appeared to Harris (1985) that hybridisation in different areas may have produced hexaploids which bear some morphological characteristics attributable to ploidy level. Mulligan (1965) noted that hexaploids are more variable than tetraploids and octoploids in style length, pod size, and life span, but most often differences in chromosome number are not accompanied by obvious morphological differences. \par{}2. Some morphological similarities between distant populations may be caused by the establishment of one or a few individuals and subsequent inbreeding of similar alleles in different populations that become fixed. Although this may account for some long-distance interpopulation similarities, paradoxically, it is probably this same process of genetic depletion and fixation, postulated and demonstrated in many groups of flowering plants (Stebbins 1942, 1957, Solbrig 1972, Soltis 1982), that is most responsible for the distinctiveness of many \i{}B. humilis\i0{} populations. \par{}\i{}Braya humilis\i0{} forms a highly variable polyploid complex that has confounded generations of botanists. The long list of synonyms attests to the taxonomic difficulties in the group. In the Canadian Arctic Archipelago, however, most populations fall comfortably within a broad concept of \i{}B. humilis\i0{}. One exception are populations with prostrate to decumbent stems, exceptionally wide siliques, and fenestrate septae from northern Ellesmere Island that may deserve infraspecific recognition (Harris 2004).>

<\i{}Braya thorild-wulffii\i0{} differs from \i{}B. purpurascens\i0{} in several morphological characters and in ploidy level. Plants from Wrangel Island are confirmed as belonging to this species and are geographically connected to the 'type' area in Greenland by later finds through Arctic Canada. It is treated as a distinct species (Petrovsky, Murray, and Elven, in Elven et al. 2003). \par{}Populations of \i{}Braya thorild-wulffii\i0{} on Banks and Victoria Islands have essentially glabrous stems, inflorescences, and fruits, in striking contrast to the densely hairy plants from more northerly populations. This glabrous form may merit infraspecific recognition (Harris, unpublished, 2005).>

<This species is unproblematical, even if the names that have been applied have been widely discussed (see Elven et al. 2003). \par{}Elven et al. (2005) supplied the following information.\par{}\b\i{}Cardamine digitata\b0\i0{} Richardson. "This characteristic plant was described from northwestern Canada: Mackenzie district. The name is unambiguous, as only one entity of the aggregate occurs in that area. Trautvetter (1879) and Schulz (1903) misunderstood this plant (see below). Their var. \i{}oxyphylla\i0{} of either \i{}C. digitata\i0{} or \i{}C. hyperborea\i0{} refers to \i{}C. digitata\i0{} s.s."\par{}\b\i{}Cardamine hyperborea\i0{} \b0{}O.E. Schulz. "This name has been applied differently among authors. Schulz (1903) coined the name as a direct substitute of \i{}C. digitata\i0{} Richardson, which he assumed was a later homonym of \i{}Cardamine digitata\i0{} Lamarck (1786). However, Lamarck described his species as \i{}Dentaria digitata\i0{}, not as a \i{}Cardamine\i0{}. \i{}Cardamine hyperborea\i0{} is therefore based on the same type as \i{}C. digitata\i0{} and is a superfluous synonym, as already pointed out by Shetler (1961) and Rollins (1993) and confirmed by Egorova (in a personal communication to Elven, 2004): "\i{}Cardamine hyperborea\i0{} is a nomen superfluvum illegitimum [for \i{}C. digitata\i0{} Richardson] according to Art. 52, 1-52.2 of the St. Louis Code"." \par{}\b\i{}Cardamine richardsonii\i0{} \b0{}Hultén. "Hultén (1945) coined this name to replace \i{}C. digitata\i0{} Richardson, as he also, on the authority of Schulz, erroneously assumed that Richardson's name was predated by Lamarck's \i{}'digitata'\i0{} and that \i{}C. hyperborea\i0{} belonged to the broad-leaved plants. Löve and Löve (1975) followed the same approach. Hultén's name is also a superfluous, full synonym of \i{}C. digitata\i0{}.">

<The name "cuckoo-flower" comes from the basal leaves that are very variable in shape, sometimes even fern-like. As a result, they are considered either "crazy" or "cuckoo". \par{}Elven in Elven et al. (2003) indicated that \i{}Cardamine pratensis\i0{} s.l. is an "intricate polyploid and apomictic complex for which there may be no ideal taxonomic solution. Some of the complexities were outlined as early as in the 'classical' study of Lövkvist (1956). Several more problems were listed and later sources referred to by Jalas and Suominen (1994). Consideration was given by Elven et al. (2003) as to (a) whether there are one or two 'races' that reach northern Europe; and (b) whether the American plants named as subsp. \i{}angustifolia\i0{} and the Greenlandic-Eurasiatic ones named as subsp. \i{}polemonioides\i0{} or as \i{}C. nymanii\i0{} are the same."\par{}Elven stated that he compared in the field and herbaria plants from arctic Canada (\i{}'angustifolia'\i0{} is described from Southampton Island), Greenland, the arctic Norwegian islands, mainland Scandinavia, and some Russian-Siberian herbarium specimens. I can find no important difference. "Some of the American plants named as subsp. \i{}angustifolia\i0{} differ from the more broad-leaved Eurasiatic ones, but similar narrow-leaved plants occur also on the European side (for example, in northern Scandinavian mountains, see Lövkvist 1956, Nilsson 1986). Broad-leaved plants, indistinguishable from the Svalbard and Scandinavian ones, are found as frequent in arctic Canada. I think we have one and only one widespread arctic race." (Elven in Elven et al. 2003).>

<The generic name \i{}Cochlearia\i0{} comes from the Greek \i{}cochlear\i0{}, a spoon, in reference to the spoon-shaped basal leaves, which also are responsible for the common name of spoonwort. However, in Europe the basal rosette leaves of \i{}C. officinalis\i0{} (as opposed to the leaves on the stem) are typically heart-shaped, not spoon-shaped as in the closely related \i{}C. anglica\i0{} L. (Wyse Jackson, personal communication, 1999). \par{}Huxley et al. (1992) noted that, as might be expected with such a widespread plant, \i{}Cochlearia officinalis\i0{} s.l. is very variable, having races with different chromosome numbers, and requiring taxonomic study (Scoggan 1979, Rich 1991). \par{}Elven et al. (2005) noted that the name \i{}'C. officinalis'\i0{} is connected to the tetraploids. In an arctic context, these are restricted to, and exclusively in, mainland northwestern Europe, whereas all other areas (including ours) have diploids. The arctic diploids differ from the tetraploids in very few characters, the most pronounced being (1) smaller flowers, and (2) lack of the distinct honey smell of \i{}C. officinalis\i0{}. Elven et al. (2003) observed that it is disputed whether all arctic diploids belong within one species. However, plants from Svalbard, Iceland, Greenland, northernmost arctic North America, and northernmost arctic Siberia conform morphologically with \i{}C. groenlandica\i0{}. Elven et al. (2005) suggested that this taxon should be accepted at the level of species; we use this name here. The arguments in favour of a species solution are as follows: (a) consistent ploidy difference (2\i{}n\i0{} = 14 verses 2\i{}n\i0{} = 24); (b) total reproductive barrier; no hybrids or intermediates have ever been documented; (c) indications that the tetraploid \i{}C. officinalis\i0{} is either an auto- or an allopolyploid from diploid parental species (European ones) fully different from \i{}C. groenlandica\i0{}; (d) consistent morphological differences, albeit small ones; and (e) parapatric to nearly allopatric ranges.\par{}Scurvy grass is a biennial, rarely a perennial, although normally cultivated as an annual. In its first year it forms a low rosette (basal cluster) of leaves. In the spring of the second year, it produces a flowering stalk about 30 cm in height with small white flowers. The plant continues to flower into summer. Dwarfed plants may have stems that are only 5 cm long, while the stems of robust plants may be as long as 35 cm (Rollins 1993).\par{}Maessen et al. (1983) studied resource allocation strategies for a range of vascular plant species growing in a High Arctic lowland oasis, located adjacent to Alexandra Fjord, Ellesmere Island, and Nunavut. Species as \i{}Cochlearia\i0{} and \i{}Draba (groenlandica) oblongata\i0{}, which occupied disturbed habitats, had a large proportion of resources allocated to sexual reproductive tissue.>

<Within the genus, this species has been placed in Ser. \b\i{}Alpinae\b0\i0{} Tolm. in Kom., Fl. SSSR, 8: 391.1929. The \i{}Draba alpina\i0{} aggregate is composed of \i{}D. aleutica\i0{}, \i{}D. alpina\i0{}, \i{}D. corymbosa\i0{}, \i{}D. glacialis\i0{}, ?\i{}D. macounii\i0{}, \i{}D. ochroleuca\i0{}, \i{}D. oxycarpa\i0{}, \i{}D. pohlei\i0{},\i{} \i0{}and some others.\par{}Typification of \i{}D. alpina\i0{} is important because this name has been applied indiscriminately for most yellow-flowered drabas throughout the Arctic and sometimes applied contrary to both possible interpretations of Linnaeus' concept. The lectotypification reserves the name for the decaploid (2\i{}n\i0{} = 80) entity, which since the time of Linnaeus has been considered under this name in the European and North Atlantic areas. In other areas, the name has sometimes been applied differently. The most evident case is Löve and Löve (1975), reserving the name '\i{}D. alpina\i0{} L. s.s.' for the octoploid level (2\i{}n\i0{} = 64). Most of the octoploid reports that the Löves (Heilborn 1927, Jørgensen et al. 1958, Löve and Löve 1961d, Knaben and Engelskjøn 1967, Löve 1970a) refer to are \i{}D. oxycarpa\i0{} Sommerf. \par{}The distribution of \i{}D. alpina\i0{} in the restricted (and Linnaean) meaning is unclear. Material from the North Atlantic area (northeastern Canada, Greenland, Svalbard, northern Fennoscandia, northern Russia) corresponds well with it. It is much more uncertain in northwestern America, Russian Far East, and Siberia. These problems cannot be solved without a circumpolar revision of the yellow-flowered drabas. Recently, Elven (personal communication 2007) has suggested that this species may be restricted to the eastern-most parts of the Canadian Arctic Archipelago, reaching Hudson Bay but not further west.\par{}Brochmann et al. (1993) investigated 101 populations of Nordic \i{}Draba\i0{} for chromosome numbers and crossing relationships. The chromosome data suggested that all the populations and species are homoploid. \i{}Draba alpina\i0{} is a decaploid, and the complex is probably polyphyletic. The relationships found from crossing data largely agreed with those inferred from earlier published molecular data, but corresponded poorly to relationships inferred from morphology. \par{}Brochmann (1992b) found that seed size and colour distinguished species in this complex. Brochmann et al. (1993) concluded that \i{}D. alpina\i0{} is probably polyphyletic and that this complex and the morphologically similar polyploid \i{}D. oxycarpa\i0{} do not have any diploid progenitors in common.>

<This species was included in \i{}D. cinerea\i0{} in Flora Europea. During a visit to Canada in May, 2003, Elven separated many sheets of this species from among collections at CAN and DAO, most of which had previously been filed as \i{}Draba cinerea\i0{}. Elven et al. (2003) noted that, morphologically and cytologically, this taxon is distinct from \i{}D. cinerea\i0{} s.s. There are also consistent differences in genetic markers (Brochmann et al. 1992a, 1992c, 1993; Andersen et al. 1999; Andersen 2002). In recent decades this species has been accepted in Greenland, Svalbard, and partly in Russia, Siberia. In North America it was still included by implication in \i{}D. cinerea\i0{} by Porsild and Cody (1980), Rollins (1993), and Cody (1996). The distribution in North America is therefore much less well known than in other areas. The treatment presented here is provisional pending further study.\par{}The Greenland entity \i{}'ostenfeldii'\i0{} described and accepted by Ekman and Böcher was tentatively treated as a subspecies by Elven et al. (2003). Both Böcher (1966) and Andersen et al. (1999) found consistent differences between subsp. \i{}ostenfeldii\i0{} and \i{}D. arctica\i0{} s.s. that may justify treatment as a subspecies even if they are sympatric and both are decaploid. Species rank is out of the question for these 'close' entities, and there is no ecological difference that could justify ecotypical varieties. \par{}Elven (personal communication, 2005) noted that \i{}Draba arctica\i0{} subsp. \i{}ostenfeldii\i0{} is also relevant for the Canadian Arctic Archipelago, as it was described from northeastern Canada in addition to northwestern Greenland. Three syntypes are cited: northwestern Greenland: Thule, Saunders' Island, 1914, leg. P.Freuchen (C); northwestern Greenland: Thule, "det høje Land paa Vejen til Uvdle", 1917, leg. Th.Wulff (C); and northwestern Canada: Ellesmere I., "sinu Goose Fjord", leg. H.G. Simmons 2894 (C, isotype in O).\par{}Andersen (2003) studied morphological and isoenzymatic variation in \i{}Draba arctica\i0{} and its relatives in the North Atlantic region and concluded that the patterns of variation do not indicate any taxonomic heterogeneity. The Svalbard plants belong to subsp. \i{}arctica\i0{} as currently understood, but there is need for a lectotypification of \i{}D. arctica\i0{} to make the application of this name unambiguous. Morphological evidence found species rank appropriate for at least \i{}D. glabella\i0{},\i{} D. cinerea\i0{},\i{} D. arctica\i0{},\i{} \i0{}and \i{}D. arctogena/norvegica\i0{}. For the first three, there is a supporting correspondence between evidence from cytology (ploidy levels), morphology, and genetic markers (isoenzymes) even if \i{}D. arctica\i0{} and \i{}D. cinerea\i0{} are more closely related than these two are to \i{}D. glabella.\i0{}>

<Elven, in May 2003, when he visited Canada, drew attention to the presence of this species among \i{}Draba\i0{} specimens at both CAN and DAO, many of them previously filed under \i{}D. oblongata.\i0\par{}The distribution is unclear. North American and northwestern European authors consider this a species of Greenland, northeastern North America, and perhaps Iceland, and the arctic Norwegian islands (Jan Mayen, Bear Island, Svalbard). Russian authors and Petrovsky (in Elven et al. 2003) indicate it as distributed throughout eastern Siberia and Russian Far East eastwards from Kharaulakh and into Alaska. Elven (personal communication, 2005) stated he had yet to see convincing specimens from outside the amphi-Atlantic regions.\par{}The treatment presented here is provisional pending further study.>

<G.A. Mulligan annotated plants from Ferguson Lake on Victoria Island, 69°25'N and 105°15'W (CAN 561159, CAN 561455), as belonging to this taxon in 1968, and this record is mapped in Porsild and Cody (1980). A second record from Banks Island, Masik River, 71°37'N, 123°06'W (CAN 561469), was annotated by Mulligan the same year but not mapped in Porsild and Cody (1980).>

<The map for this species is based on specimens annotated by Elven when he visited CAN and DAO in May 2003. \par{}Elven et al. (2003) considered that the \i{}Draba cinerea\i0{} aggregate is composed of \i{}D. arctica\i0{}, \i{}D. cinerea\i0{}, \i{}D. oblongata\i0{}, \i{}D. ovibovina\i0{}, and \i{}D. parvisiliquosa\i0{}. \par{}Elven (personal communication, 2005) noted that there are, as indicated, several possible types, and those in herbarium G-DC correspond excellently with our current concept of the species. He had collected the species in 2004 in the type area around the town of Schigansk. These plants are also similar to those in Alaska, Canada, Greenland, and Fennoscandia.\par{}In the North Atlantic areas, \i{}D. cinerea\i0{} is comparatively southern. It occurs in southern Greenland but not in the north. In the Nordic area it is restricted to the northern boreal parts of the mainland and is replaced by \i{}D. arctica\i0{} in Svalbard.\par{}The treatment presented here is provisional pending further study.>
