The conclusion was that the mere presence of another species growing close to a hemi-parasitic plant does not mean that this plant is used as a host. \par{}Freytag and Weber (1987) found that \i{}Pedicularis lapponica\i0{} and \i{}P. hirsuta\i0{} are not host specific. Preferred hosts are \i{}Salix\i0{} species, owing to their frequent occurrence in the habitat of the \i{}Pedicularis\i0{} species or a possible stimulation from the ectomycorrhizal roots of the \i{}Salix\i0{} plants. These \i{}Pedicularis \i0{}species do not show serious injury at the host roots. All parasitic roots are able to attack host roots. Development of the \i{}Pedicularis\i0{} haustoria and the morphological-anatomical structures are typical for the \i{}Rhinanthoideae\i0{}. Just in respect to the xylem system of the haustorium, these species showed differences when compared with middle European \i{}Pedicularis\i0{} species: The xylem system has much more volume, which is a result of procambium-like cells that are derivatives of the pericycle. \par{}Williams and Batzlli (1982), in a study of five species of \i{}Pedicularis\i0{} at Atkasook, Alaska, which rely on bumblebees for pollination, found \i{}P. lapponica\i0{} had the smallest shoots and produced few seeds even though pollination success was high.>

<If subspecies are recognised, the specimens from the Canadian Arctic are subspecies \i{}wormskjoldii\i0{}. \par{}The taxonomic consequences of the variation in this species have a convoluted history that revolves around geographical patterns and ploidy level, as follows:\par{}Hultén (1968b) recognised two entities in North America: the wide-ranging subsp. \i{}wormskjoldii\i0{} from Greenland west to Alaska, and the Cordilleran subsp. \i{}alterniflora\i0{} from California to Alaska where it reaches the Arctic in the Brooks Range. These were not accepted by Cody (1996). Hultén synonymised Bongard's \i{}V. nutans\i0{} with subsp. \i{}wormskjoldii\i0{}. However, after a ploidy variation was documented in the 1960's, Löve and Löve (1975) separated the northwestern American plants as a diploid \i{}V. nutans\i0{} from the northeastern American tetraploid \i{}V. wormskjoldii\i0{} s.s. They did not mention the \i{}'alterniflora'\i0{} entity, and it is not clear whether all the northwestern American plants belong in their \i{}V. nutans\i0{}. \par{}The differences reported between the races or species are small and mainly quantitative. Elven et al. (2003) debated whether to recognise them as distinct taxa or to keep a collective species. The options for separate entities appeared to be as follows:\par{}"(a) As an eastern and western species. \i{}Veronica wormskjoldii\i0{}, restricted to Greenland and eastern Canada, and the western \i{}V. nutans\i0{}, found in western Canada and Alaska. The western species would include both subsp. \i{}alterniflora\i0{} and the western part of subsp. \i{}wormskjoldii\i0{} in Hultén's meaning. \par{}(b) Similar to the above, recognising two subspecies: subsp. \i{}wormskjoldii\i0{}, the eastern entity; subsp. \i{}alterniflora\i0{} (with the \i{}'nutans'\i0{} names as synonyms), the western entity. Elven et al. (2003) felt that both solutions (a) and (b) neglect the morphological variation found among the western plants. \par{}(c) As Hultén (1968b), with a wide subsp. \i{}wormskjoldii\i0{} and a Cordilleran subsp. \i{}alterniflora\i0{}. Such a solution probably neglects the ploidy difference between eastern and western plants. \par{}(d) As three entities, perhaps represented by the names \i{}'wormskjoldii'\i0{} (eastern tetraploid entity, Greenland typification, Canada and Greenland), \i{}'nutans'\i0{} (western coastal, perhaps diploid entity, southeastern Alaskan typification, ALA), and \i{}'alterniflora'\i0{} (western Cordilleran, probably diploid entity, Canadian Rockies typification, ALA).">

<The infraspecific variation is appreciable and treated in different ways in different traditions. In North America, only diploid counts have been reported from the Arctic. In Greenland, Böcher et al. (1978) recognised the plants as \i{}C. gieseckiana\i0{} with two races, the widely distributed diploid (2\i{}n\i0{} = 34) as subsp. \i{}gieseckiana\i0{} and the more restricted southern and eastern tetraploid (2\i{}n\i0{} = 68) as subsp. \i{}groenlandica\i0{}. In Fennoscandia, tetraploids occur everywhere except for the northeastern corner. Both lowland plants with many and comparatively small flowers and alpine plants with often large single flowers are tetraploid, the latter sometimes named as \i{}C. groenlandica\i0{}. There seems to be no discontinuity in the morphological patterns. In the northeastern (arctic) corner diploids are dominant or perhaps exclusive (see Croff 1978), with the morphological pattern of the tetraploid mountain plants. Diploids also occur in the southeastern (Swedish and Finnish) lowlands, with the morphological pattern of the tetraploid lowland plants. The few Svalbard plants that have been counted are diploid and resemble the Greenland and northeastern Fennoscandian diploids. It seems impossible, at least in the Nordic area, to recognise diploids and tetraploids, or mountain/tundra and lowland plants, as separate taxa. Hexaploids do not seem to reach the Arctic (Elven et al. 2003).>

<Holm (1922), in the reporting on the botanical findings of the Canadian Arctic Expedition, 1913-1918, provided a figure that showed the underground structure of this species and noted: "Some remarkably old specimens measuring 22 cm were collected on the south coast of Coronation gulf... The vegetative structure is quite interesting. The primary root is developed as a relatively large, wrinkled tap-root, bearing several shoot at the crown. These shoots are slender, and their subterranean part bears small, scale-like leaves, while toward apex small rosettes of green leaves appear, surrounding the flowering stems. As the main, i.e., the primary, root is wrinkled, indicating that it is contractile, the crown of the root becomes gradually pulled deeper and deeper down in the ground, at the same time as the subterranean parts of the stems increase in length. In young specimens the subterranean stems are thus much shorter, sometimes barely visible, the crown of the root being close to the surface of the ground.">

<The generic name \i{}Achillea\i0{} is usually interpreted as a reference to Achilles, the legendary Greek hero of the Trojan War (about 1200 B.C.). He is said to have used the foliage of yarrow to stanch the flow of blood from wounded fellow soldiers. A less romantic interpretation of the genus name is that it commemorates a Greek doctor named Achilles who recorded the medicinal uses of the plant (Warwick and Black 1982). \par{}Burt (2000) noted that the flowers of the yarrow are white to pinkish and tend to become pinker with age. The ray and disc petals are the same colour. \par{}There are two records from Banks Island, mapped in Porsild and Cody (1980). The specimens were not recorded in Porsild (1957), and have not been found at CAN. \par{}Elven in Elven et al. (2003) noted that "there are different opinions concerning this species or species group. Hultén (1968) and Hultén and Fries (1986) accepted three main northern entities: \par{}\i{}Achillea millefolium\i0{} s.s. in all of Eurasia and as introduced in Greenland and (non-arctic) North America, \par{}\i{}Achillea lanulosa\i0{} Nutt. as the main North American entity but mapped only north to southern Hudson Bay, and \par{}\i{}Achillea borealis\i0{} Bong. in all of northern (arctic and boreal) North America. \par{}Hultén (1968b) described and mapped them as species but indicated that subspecies might be a better rank. This was the solution of Cody (1996) for American representatives in the Yukon. Russian sources (Tzvelev, in Yurtsev 1984) accept three species but with a different interpretation. \i{}Achillea millefolium\i0{} s.s. is treated as a southern and northern Eurasiatic species barely penetrating the Arctic (and possibly not as a native). The northern Eurasiatic material is divided on (1) the northern European \i{}A. apiculata\i0{} Orlova (that is included in Hultén's concept of \i{}A. millefolium\i0{}) and (2) a strongly disjunct \i{}A. nigrescens\i0{} (E. Meyer) Rydberg occurring in northeastern Russia to Chukotka (which according to Hultén is synonymous with his purely American \i{}A. borealis\i0{}). These opinions have not yet been reconciled by an analysis of material." \par{}Small and Catling (1999) reported that yarrow has long been used medicinally in both North America and Europe. Its reputation for healing wounds led to such common names as stanchweed, bloodwort, soldier\rquote{}s bloodwort, nose bleed, and carpenter\rquote{}s grass. Principal traditional uses besides stopping the flow of blood from wounds, included the treatment of fevers, the common cold, diarrhoea, dysentery, and hypertension. Yarrow has also been used in folk medicine as a cure for toothache, earache, and diseases of the lungs, bladder and kidney. Today, it is employed internally (as a tea, tincture, or pill) to treat gastrointestinal complaints (inflammation, diarrhoea, flatulence, cramps), and as a bitter aromatic (to stimulate appetite); and externally in poultices, lotions, and bath preparations. Young yarrow leaves are sometimes consumed (cooked or fresh) in salads (large amounts are said to turn urine brown). The leaves and flowers are used to flavour liqueurs, and were once substituted for hops to flavour beer. Yarrow also has insecticidal constituents (Chandler et al. 1982; Tunon et al. 1994). \par{}Small and Catling (1999) noted that "well over 100 chemicals have been characterised in yarrow. Of greatest interest are the lactones, present in a volatile oil. A metabolic derivative of these, azulene, was once thought to be the constituent primarily responsible for the anti-inflammatory and antipruritic properties of yarrow. However, the medicinal value could be due to chamazulene, the sesquiterpene lactones, or other constituents such as tannins, menthol, camphor, sterols, and triterpenes. The antispasmodic activity of yarrow could be due to its flavonoids. The alkaloid achillenine is an active hemostatic agent, and may explain the traditional uses of checking bleeding of wounds and sores. It has been hypothesised that the salicylic acid derivatives eugenol, menthol, or similar compounds may produce local algesia and reduction of fever. The presence of thujone, a known abortifacient, might explain some of the traditional uses of yarrow associated with the female reproductive system (however, thujone is usually present only in limited amounts)." Small and Catling (1999, p. 9). The important constituent chamazule appears to be present in tetraploid plants only (Bélanger and Dextraze 1992). The volatile constituents in \i{}Achillea\i0{} vary in relation to the infraspecific variation within the species (Kokkalou et al. 1992). \par{}"Yarrow was once used in Ireland for love divination: young girls would cultivate a yarrow plant and subsequently place it beneath their pillow so that they would dream of their sweetheart. It was brought by bridesmaids to weddings to ensure 7 years of love. The closest that research has come to supporting such uses is the finding that the volatile oil of yarrow causes a sexual response in male cockroaches" (Small and Catling 1999, p. 10).>

<\i{}Antennaria canescens\i0{} in a previous, restricted meaning was confined to Greenland and northeastern Canada. Male plants are unknown in Greenland and North America. Several authors (e.g., Löve 1970a, Hämet-Ahti et al. 1986) have reported this entity also from northern Fennoscandia, but in this area some recent investigators have considered \i{}A. canescens\i0{} to be the sexual plants with mixed sexes in the populations, whereas \i{}A. alpina\i0{} s.s. was the purely female agamospermic. Opinions obviously differ. Chmielewski (1998) included both plants, from northern Europe, Greenland, Canada, and Alaska, in his wide concept of subsp. \i{}canescens\i0{}. Europeans feel the need for a more extensive analysis before they fully accept the presence of two 'hairy' subspecies in Scandinavia (and Iceland), \i{}'alpina'\i0{} and \i{}'canescens'\i0{}. \par{}In North America, the species is characterised by its dark green to dark brown involucral bracts (phyllaries) and conspicuous flags on the upper and middle cauline leaves. The basal leaves vary from glabrous to pubescent. \par{}\i{}Antennaria alpina\i0{} belongs to Section \i{}Alpinae\i0{}, which is one of five large polyploid species complexes within the genus. The section has about 20 species names that are currently applied in an arctic context. Bayer (1993) considered that \i{}A. alpina\i0{} s.s. is circumboreal, fully agamospermous, and primarily hexaploid, 2\i{}n\i0{} = 84. Bayer, in Cody (1996), treated this aggregate collectively, probably because it was difficult to analyse on North American representatives alone. Bayer (1993) applied the collective name \i{}A. alpina\i0{} also for some northwestern North American and amphi-Beringian entities (\i{}'compacta'\i0{}, \i{}'cryomophylla'\i0{}, and perhaps \i{}'subcanescens'\i0{}). This is not considered the best solution, and these entities - \i{}'compacta'\i0{}, \i{}'cryomophylla'\i0{}, and perhaps \i{}'subcanescens'\i0{} - are here treated as belonging to the \i{}A. friesiana\i0{} group. Even so, \i{}A. alpina\i0{} is still a very heterogeneous species. \par{}Chmielewski (1998), using canonical discriminant analysis, determined that \i{}A. alpina\i0{} does occur in North America and suggested that the main morphological distinctions between the two aforementioned polyploid complexes are (a) the presence of scarious tips at the ends of middle to distal peduncular leaves in \i{}A. alpina\i0{} (these being absent in \i{}A. media\i0{}) and (b) the shape of the involucral bracts. The analyses of Chmielewski (1998) supported the recognition of \i{}A. alpina\i0{} subsp. \i{}canescens\i0{} and subsp. \i{}porsildii\i0{}. These taxa differed with respect to the degree, distribution, and type of pubescence of the basal leaves. \par{}In this treatment the name \i{}A. subcanescens\i0{} is placed in the synonymy of \i{}Antennaria alpina\i0{} (L.) Gaertn. subsp. \i{}canescens\i0{} (Lange) Chmiel. \i{}Antennaria subcanescens\i0{} has been indicated by other authors as part of the \i{}A. friesiana\i0{} aggregate but is placed in \i{}A. alpina\i0{} subsp. \i{}canescens\i0{} by Chmielewski (1998). Male plants are unknown.\par{}Porsild (1957) indicated that \i{}A. subcanescens\i0{} may be found on the Arctic Archipelago, and is endemic to northwestern North America. The range given by Porsild and Cody (1980) shows a few very scattered sites in eastern and western Greenland, southern Baffin Island, and along the Arctic Coast west to Point Hope on the Bering Strait. Plants mapped in Porsild and Cody (1980) as occurring on southeastern Baffin Island (CAN 284965, 274132) were annotated as \i{}A. friesiana\i0{} subsp. \i{}freisiana\i0{} by J.G. Chmielewski (SLRO) in 1995. Of seven specimens from continental North America, identified as \i{}A. subcanescens\i0{} by A.E. Porsild between 1948 and 1964, two were annotated as \i{}A. media\i0{} Greene J.G. Chmielewski (SLRO) in 1995 (CAN 247480, 247481) and five as \i{}A. friesiana\i0{} (CAN 506840, 506841, 106129, 106130, 106126). Thus no specimens currently considered to be \i{}A. subcanescens\i0{} have been found for the Canadian Arctic.>

<Section \i{}Alpinae\i0{}. \par{}Male plants are unknown and the taxon is most probably an agamospecies. It occurs frequently in western Greenland, is very scattered in northeastern Canada, and has a small area in the Canadian Rockies, which is an unusual distribution pattern. This entity is in many features intermediate between the \i{}A. alpina\i0{} and \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} groups and is here proposed treated with the former. It was accepted as a separate species by Scoggan (1979). \par{}The analyses of Chmielewski (1998) supported the recognition of \i{}A. alpina\i0{} subsp. \i{}canescens \i0{}and subsp. \i{}porsildii\i0{} as differing with respect to the degree, distribution, and type of pubescence of the basal leaves. In 2001, Elven examined a sheet from Nunavut, Baffin Island, Cape Searle (CAN 205051), identified as \i{}A. alpina\i0{} subsp. \i{}porsildii\i0{} by Chmielewski (1998) and considered it closer to the \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} agg. He annotated the specimen as \i{}A. glabrata\i0{}. Bayer (2006), in the treatment for \i{}Flora of North America\i0{}, does not refer to Chmielewski's research and treats these two subspecies and \i{}A. media\i0{} subsp. \i{}compacta\i0{} in a broad concept of \i{}A. alpina.\par{}\i0{}Elven et al. (2003), commenting on \i{}Antennaria alpina\i0{} (L.) Gaertn. subsp. \i{}porsildii\i0{} (E. Ekman) Chmiel., stated, "\i{}A. glabrata\i0{} may be problematic to include in subsp. \i{}porsildii\i0{}. It is typified from western Greenland: Disco, 07-08. without year, leg. Vahl (C) lectotype, selected by Chmielewski (1998). The 'entity' is frequent in western Greenland, very scattered in northeast Canada and in a small area in the Canadian Rockies (omitted by Chmielewski). Male plants are unknown. It is in some features intermediate between the \i{}A. alpina\i0{} and \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} aggregates and fairly distinct from the main body of \i{}'porsildii'\i0{} s.s. in Greenland and Scandinavia. Its most evidently divergent features are as follows: one or very few and congested heads, narrow (non-spatulate) leaves, and lack of runners. The Baffin Island plants mapped....by Chmielewski (one collection in CAN) belong to this 'entity' and are generally more similar, in my [Elven's] opinion, to \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} s.l. than to \i{}A. alpina\i0{} s.l.">

<Hultén (1968b) recognised three subspecies within \i{}A. friesiana \i0{}s.l. (subsp. \i{}friesiana\i0{}, subsp. \i{}alaskana\i0{} (Malte) Hultén, and subsp. \i{}compacta\i0{} (Malte) Hultén). Hultén's (1968b) circumscription of \i{}A. friesiana\i0{} subsp. \i{}compacta\i0{} included \i{}A. densifolia\i0{} A.E. Porsild and \i{}A. neoalaskana\i0{} A.E. Porsild. \par{}Bayer and Stebbins (1993) also recognised three subspecies: \i{}A. friesiana\i0{} subsp. \i{}friesiana\i0{}, subsp. \i{}alaskana\i0{}, and subsp. \i{}neoalaskana\i0{} (A.E. Porsild) Bayer and Stebbins, indicating that the latter two subspecies are the dioecious (sexual) phase of the former gynoecious (asexual) form. Bayer (1991) considered that these sexual populations (subsp. \i{}alaskana\i0{} and subsp. \i{}neoalaskana\i0{}) are restricted to Alaska and cordilleran areas of the northern Yukon and adjacent Northwest territories, whereas the asexual phase (subsp. \i{}friesiana\i0{}) is "almost circumpolar", as this phase occurs from the central and eastern Siberian plateau eastward across the North American arctic to Greenland according to Bayer (1991). However, Elven et al. (2003) record a gap of more than 140°C of latitude between Greenland and the Lena River where the taxon is not recorded. \par{}Bayer's (1993) work (based on field work and morphological studies of herbarium specimens) concluded that Hultén's \i{}A. friesiana\i0{} subsp. \i{}compacta\i0{} contained at least three incongruous entities that are not related to the other two subspecies of \i{}A. friesiana\i0{}. Chmielewski (1997) assigned \i{}A. compacta\i0{} as a subspecies to \i{}A. media\i0{}. \par{}Chmielewski (1994), in a phenetic analysis of the morphological variation in the polyploid complex, independent of a knowledge of chromosome number and reproductive biology, concluded that the rank of subspecies was supported by the analyses for \i{}A. friesiana\i0{} subsp. \i{}friesiana\i0{} and \i{}A. friesiana\i0{} subsp. \i{}alaskana\i0{}. The subspecies were found to differ with respect to the length of the involucre, inner phyllary length, pappus length, corolla length (the latter subspecies typically smaller than the former), chromosome number, reproductive biology, and in part provenance. Chmielewski (1994) stated that \i{}A. frieseana\i0{} subsp. \i{}friesiana\i0{} is an agamospermous polyploid, represented by pentaploid (2\i{}n\i0{} = 70) and hexaploid (2\i{}n\i0{} = 84) cytotypes. \i{}Antennaria friesiana\i0{} subsp. \i{}alaskana\i0{} is a sexual, probably partially agamospermous, tetraploid cytotype, and either diploid (2\i{}n\i0{} = 28) or tetraploid (2\i{}n\i0{} = 56). \par{}Elven et al. (2003) noted that geographically this is the major entity of Section \i{}Alpinae\i0{} and occurs from the Lena area throughout northeastern Asia and North America to western Greenland, i.e., through the entire range of the aggregate. Elven and Petrovsky in Elven et al. (2005) considered that the recognition of three subspecies is now well supported in their circumpolar range as well. The two sexuals (\i{}'alaskana'\i0{} and \i{}'neoalaskana'\i0{}) are consistently different, as both also are from agamospermic \i{}'friesiana'\i0{} s.s. This is now supported by all workers on this group.>

<Section \i{}Alpinae\i0{}. \par{}\i{}Antennaria compacta\i0{} was included in \i{}A. alpina\i0{} s.l. by Bayer in Cody (1996) and in Bayer (2006), who stated that morphological overlap between \i{}A. alpina\i0{} and \i{}A. media\i0{} poses a taxonomic problem. Bayer (2006) suggests that some of the entities he has synonymised under\i{} A. alpina\i0{}, including \i{}A. friesiana\i0{} subsp.\i{} compacta\i0{}, are of apomictic clonal origin. This subspecies was included in \i{}A. media\i0{} s.l. by Chmielewski (1997). Elven et al. (2003) followed Chmielewski (1997) by recognising this taxon as a subspecies of \i{}A. media\i0{} because Chmielewski (1998) presented an analysis that included the\i{} A. alpina \i0{}complex. Elven et al. (2003) will follow this treatment until a consensus is reached about \i{}A. alpina\i0{} in North America and we follow this treatment here.\par{}In \i{}A. media \i0{}subsp.\i{}compacta, \i0{}Section \i{}Alpinae\i0{}, male plants are unknown and the taxon is most probably an agamo-subspecies. It is a widely distributed entity from eastern Greenland to western Alaska, and perhaps to eastern Chukotka. Some authors synonymise \i{}A. cryomophylla\i0{} with \i{}A. compacta\i0{}. The very restricted continental range of \i{}A. cryomophylla\i0{} falls entirely inside that of \i{}A. compacta\i0{} (see Porsild and Cody 1980). \par{}\i{}Antennaria densifolia\i0{} A.E. Porsild [Bull. Natl. Mus. Canada 101, Biol. ser. 30: 26. 1945], from the continental Northwest Territories and Yukon, has been indicated as a synonym of \i{}A. compacta\i0{}. This is probably not correct, as both sexes are present in populations of \i{}A. densifolia\i0{} and it is probably sexual (Bayer in Cody 1996). \i{}Antennaria densifolia\i0{} is treated as a separate species by Bayer (2006). It is not present in the Arctic, as its northern limit seems to be in the Mackenzie Mountains. \par{}>

<Section \i{}Alpinae\i0{}. \par{}Within the concept of \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} s.l., Hultén (1968b) circumscribed the apomictic form of the species as \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} subsp. \i{}angustata\i0{}, extending the range of the species to northern Yukon and Alaska and across the Canadian Arctic into Greenland and down the western Cordillera into Montana and Wyoming. Bayer (1993) chose to follow Hultén's broad concept of \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} and accepted \i{}Antennaria monocephala\i0{} (Torrey and A. Gray) DC. subsp. \i{}philonipha\i0{} (A.E. Porsild) Hultén [Ark. Bot., ser. 2, 7, 1: 135. 1968a], which was described from Canada: "Arctic coast, east of Mackenzie, near Kittigazuit". In this taxon male and female plants are equally frequent and probably sexual. It occurs almost exclusively within the range of \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} in Alaska, Yukon, and westernmost Nunavut, and it hybridises with \i{}A. monocephala \i0{}s.s. (Porsild and Cody 1980). The taxon is synonymised with \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} subsp. \i{}monocephala\i0{} by Bayer, in Cody (1996). It is suggested that there is some polymorphy in sexual \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} that includes \i{}A. philonipha\i0{}. \par{}Chmielewski and Chinnappa (1991) considered gender dependent and independent morphological dimorphism in sexual and apomictic members in \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} s.l. and concluded that it is appropriate to recognise two subspecies, \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} subsp. \i{}monocephala\i0{} and \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} subsp. \i{}angustata\i0{} (Greene) Hultén. These authors indicated that these subspecies differ with respect to tomentum, chromosome number, reproductive biology, and (in part) provenance. They treated \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} subsp. \i{}monocephala \i0{}as a sexual diploid (2\i{}n\i0{} = 28) and \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} subsp. \i{}angustata\i0{} as an apomictic polyploid, with chromosome numbers ranging from tetraploid (2\i{}n\i0{} = 56) to octoploid (2\i{}n\i0{} = 112). In \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} subsp. \i{}monocephala\i0{}, the adaxial surface of the basal and cauline leaves is glabrous-strigose, as is the stem. In \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} subsp. \i{}angustata\i0{}, the adaxial surface of both basal and cauline leaves is floccose-tomentose, as is the surface of the stem. \par{}Chmielewski et al. (1990) examined the pollen morphology of North America species of \i{}Antennaria\i0{} (Asteraceae: Inuleae) and described the grains of \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} as 18.3 ± 0.8 um long in polar diameter and 18.4 ± 0.9 um long in equatorial diameter and striate-perforate-reticulate. These authors also provided an SEM illustration of a grain. \par{}\i{}Antennaria pygmaea\i0{} was described from Labrador. Scoggan (1979) kept \i{}A. pygmaea\i0{} as a separate species based on involucral bract criteria. Bayer, in Cody (1996), synonymised \i{}A. pygmaea\i0{} with \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} subsp. \i{}angustata\i0{}. Male plants are unknown, and it is most probably agamospermic like the other entities synonymised with \i{}A. monocephala\i0{} subsp. \i{}angustata\i0{}.>

<There is some lack of balance in current treatments between North America and Eurasia. American material is now often divided into subspecies or varieties or entities are not recognised at all. Eurasian material is either treated as one entity (in spite of heterogeneity) or divided on species. Korobkov and Elven, in Elven et al. (2003) provisionally proposed treatment as 5-6 major races (subspecies), stating that there is probably agamospermy, but at the same time each of the races are morphologically and geographically characterised. \par{}Downie and Denford (1988b), in an evaluation of systematic relationships in \i{}Arnica\i0{} subgenus \i{}Arctica\i0{}, found that the complex consists of seven species. They proposed no new taxa and recognised several previously proposed taxa as synonyms. They found that \i{}A. angustifolia\i0{}, \i{}A. frigida\i0{}, and \i{}A. lonchophylla\i0{}, each consisting of two subspecies, are extremely polymorphic and variable in chromosome number. Downie and Denford (1988b) provided a taxonomic revision of the subgenus including descriptions, keys, synonymies, distribution maps, and a discussion of phylogenetic relationships. \par{}Downie (1988) reported that the \i{}Arnica angustifolia\i0{} aggregate is a circumpolar taxon made up of a number of geographically distinct infraspecific taxa. Cluster and principal component analyses of 99 populations revealed the aggregate to be best represented by two subspecies: \i{}A. angustifolia\i0{} subsp. \i{}angustifolia\i0{} (a combination of the previously recognised subspecies \i{}angustifolia\i0{}, \i{}attenuata\i0{}, \i{}sornborgeri\i0{}, \i{}intermedia\i0{}, \i{}iljinii\i0{}, \i{}alpina\i0{}, and \i{}plantaginea\i0{}) and \i{}A. angustifolia\i0{} subsp. \i{}tomentosa\i0{}. Downie (1988) stated that \i{}Arnica angustifolia\i0{} subsp. \i{}angustifolia\i0{} is polymorphic and varied in ploidy level and foliar flavonoid chemistry. He found no significant differences among the means of 14 characters in plants collected from six broadly delimited geographic areas. He discerned four cytotypes (2\i{}n\i0{} = 38, 57, 76, and 95) and seven flavonoid glycosides (five flavonols and two flavones). \par{}Downie and Denford (1988a) isolated 12 flavonoids (including seven flavonol and three flavone glycosides, one flavone aglycone, and one unknown) from the leaves of 198 populations of the seven species comprising \i{}Arnica\i0{} subgenus \i{}Arctica\i0{}. They found the flavonoid profiles are relatively simple, with two to six compounds found per population, but considerable flavonoid variation was apparent in populations of \i{}A. angustifolia\i0{}, \i{}A. frigida\i0{}, and \i{}A. lonchophylla\i0{}. These authors suggested that in subgenus \i{}Arctica\i0{}, flavonoid diversity appears to have accompanied high morphological variability and suggested that leaf flavonoid chemistry supports the hypotheses that the absence of any highly derived or methylated flavonoid suggests the subgenus \i{}Arctica\i0{} probably represents the most ancestral subgenus in \i{}Arnica\i0{}. \par{}Small and Catling (1999, p. 29) indicated that "\i{}Arnica\i0{} should not be taken internally, as it is sufficiently toxic that it may cause fatal poisoning. Unidentified substances that it contains can produce stress on the nervous system, the digestive system, and the circulatory system, resulting in muscular weakness, collapse, and even death. Experiments with small animals have confirmed that arnica causes cardiac toxicity and large increases in blood pressure. This herb was listed in a 1995 Health Canada document as unacceptable as a non-prescription drug product for oral use (see 'Herbs used as non-medicinal ingredients in non-prescription drugs for human use,' http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/hpb-dgps/therapeut/drhtmeng/policy.html)... Although not safe for human consumption, \i{}Arnica cordifolia\i0{} has been identified as an important constituent of the diet of elk and mule deer... Applied to the bald scalp, arnica is said to make hair grow, although skin irritation is the more likely result.">

<Sect. \i{}Campestres\i0{} Korobkov, Polyni Severo-Vostoka SSSR, 112. 1981. \par{}There seems to be very few morphological differences, if any, between the diploids named by the Löves as \i{}O. groenlandicus\i0{} and the tetraploids named as \i{}O. borealis\i0{}. They are therefore both retained inside \i{}A. borealis\i0{} s.s. \par{}Elven et al. (2003) noted that a superficial survey of the Alaskan material (ALA) by Murray and Elven showed much, and partly geographically structured, variation. It might be possible to recognise at least three entities, a main entity throughout most of the area, a north to northwestern coastal entity comparable to \i{}'richardsoniana'\i0{}, and also a southwestern coastal entity fairly distinct from the main one. All three reach the Arctic in Alaska. This variation merits further study. \par{}Wang et al. (1990) isolated two polyacetylenes from \i{}Artemisia borealis\i0{}. One exhibited antifungal (\i{}Cladosporium cucumerinum)\i0{} activity and another was highly active in a brine shrimp (\i{}Artemia salina\i0{}) assay and exhibited larvicidal activity against the yellow fever mosquito (\i{}Aedes aegypti\i0{}).>

<Sect. \i{}Campestres\i0{} Korobkov (1981), Polyni Severo-Vostoka SSSR, 112. 1981. \par{}Ling, in Hind and Beentje (1996), considered \i{}A. richardsoniana\i0{} (and \i{}A. subarctica\i0{}) as synonyms of \i{}A. arctica\i0{} and not closely related to \i{}A. borealis\i0{}. American authors (e.g., Cody 1996) considered \i{}A. richardsoniana\i0{} a northwestern American endemic, but that was not supported by Elven et al. (2003). The Panarctic Flora Checklist (Elven et al. 2003) prefers to recognise the taxon as \i{}Artemisia borealis\i0{} Pall. subsp. \i{}richardsoniana\i0{} (Besser) Korobkov, in Jurtz.>

<The type and other Canadian specimens have leaves covered with a "silvery canescence", that is, white, tomentose, and with short silky appressed hairs. The heads are almost always sessile or sub-sessile. In this they differ from the samples of \i{}A. furcata\i0{} from Siberia at CAN, as on those samples the hairs are tawny, villous, long silky, and spreading from the surface of the plant. The Russian specimens usually have heads borne on conspicuous pedicels. \par{}The eastern Canadian specimens also differ from those in Alaskan specimens of \i{}A. furcata\i0{}, which is considered a reason to treat the taxa separately (Elven et al. 2003).>

<Sect. \i{}Artemisia\i0{}. \par{}Porsild and Cody (1980) recognised that this taxon may be divided into subsp. \i{}tilesii\i0{} and subsp. \i{}elatior\i0{} Torrey and Gray. The latter has broader leaf-segments, is a taller plant, and does not occur as far north. \par{}This widespread species seems to be polymorphic, particularly in North America. Hultén (1950, 1968b) recognised four subspecies, but two of these seem to be less distinctive than the others. The Panarctic Flora checklist (Elven et al. 2003) proposed recognising only two taxa and includes subsp. \i{}gormanii\i0{} with subsp. \i{}elatior\i0{} and subsp. \i{}unalaschcensis\i0{} in subsp. \i{}tilesii\i0{}. \par{}Ovenden (1986) found \i{}Artemisia tilesii\i0{} was an early colonising species on the lake bed of Illisarvik, the site of a thermokarst lake that was artificially drained in August 1978. By 1985, the lake bed was dry in most areas and wind erosion was extensive. The surface material was either sandy peat or organic lake mud, except along the eastern margin, where it was sandy. Substrate type appeared to have had little influence on the distributional patterns of the colonising vegetation. More important factors were probably erosion, surface wetness, and proximity of the lake-bed margin. Other widespread species included \i{}Tephroseris palustris\i0{} (L.) Fourr. subsp. \i{}congesta\i0{} (\i{}Senecio congestus\i0{}), \i{}Carex aquatilis\i0{}, \i{}Descurainia sophioides\i0{}, \i{}Tripleurospermum maritimum\i0{} (\i{}Matricaria ambigua\i0{}), \i{}Arctophila fulva\i0{}, and \i{}Stellaria longipes\i0{}. \i{}Senecio\i0{} and \i{}Arctophila\i0{} formed dense stands around the two small residual ponds. \par{}Adams et al. (1984) described the effects of simulated acid rain (pH 2.5-5.6) on the foliar histology of \i{}A. tilesii\i0{}, which is remarkably tolerant to naturally occurring atmospheric acidity at Smoking Hills, Northwest Territories. \par{}Adams and Hutchinson (1984) compared the ability of leaf surfaces of \i{}Artemisia tilesii\i0{}, \i{}Spinacea oleracea\i0{}, and \i{}Phaseolus vulgaris\i0{} to neutralise acidic rain. Acidic droplets of identical size were placed on the leaves. The pH values over time were measured using a micro-pH electrode. The pH of rain droplets initially of pH 3.0, 3.5, and 5.6 increased after contact with leaves of these species. However, for droplets of pH 2.5 the pH of droplets actually decreased with time on leaves as the drops evaporated, despite the very large quantity of H ions neutralised by the leaf surface. Neutralisation of acidic droplets was greatest in \i{}A. tilesii\i0{} plants, which also showed the lowest sensitivity to foliar injury from simulated acid rain. Large increases in Ca, especially, but also in Mg and K in droplets collected from leaves of \i{}A. tilesii\i0{}, suggest that these cations may play an important role in increasing the pH of acidic droplets. \par{}Hutchinson and Adams (1987) used \i{}A. tilesii\i0{} in a study of the relative abilities of four species to neutralise acidic rain droplets placed on their leaf surfaces. They were examined, comparing this species with leaves of sugar beet (\i{}Beta vulgaris\i0{}), radish (\i{}Aphanus sativus\i0{}), and sunflower (\i{}Helianthus annuus\i0{}). Rain droplets (50 mæl) of pH 4.7, 3.8, 3.0, and 2.4 were used. Determinations of droplet pH on the leaf surfaces and on a control parafilm surface were made at intervals until the leaves dried. The plants were grown in sand culture with calcium supplied at a range of five concentrations, from 4.8 to 480 ppm to alter the calcium status of the foliage. While the Ca\super{}++\nosupersub{} treatments strongly influenced the Ca\super{}++ \nosupersub{}content of leaves, they did not influence the neutralising ability of the leaves. \par{}Overfield et al. (1980) reported that a plant used by the southwestern Alaskan Eskimos for treatment of skin infections, chest colds, and arthritis was identified as \i{}A. tilesii\i0{}. The volatile constituents of this plant were identified as an 80:20 mixture of thujone and isothujone. Isothujone has codeine-like properties, which may help arthritic pain.>

<Burt (2000) noted that this plant has a wide range from high passes in Denali National Park, Alaska, to the windswept and spray-lashed beaches of algal limestone islands off the north shore of central North America. It grows on gravel bars in the mouths of arctic rivers that are subject to annual flooding. Its "yellow flowers spread out like a tiny bracelet at the edge of the rosette." (p. 192). \par{}The habit of blooming while the flowering heads still touch the rosette is an adaptation to keep the developing ovaries within the warmest stratum of air close to the ground and the sun-warmed rocks (Savile 1972).\par{}Elven and Murray, in Elven et al. (2005) noted that "the two fairly closely related species previously named as \i{}Crepis elegans\i0{} and \i{}C. nana\i0{} have the base chromosome number of \i{}x\i0{} = 7 (as opposed to 4-6 elsewhere in \i{}Crepis\i0{}), are characteristic morphologically, and have been separated, together with some relatives, as the genus \i{}Askellia\i0{} W.A.Weber, based on \i{}Crepis\i0{} sect. \i{}Ixeredopsis\i0{} Babc." There are good arguments for this solution (see Weber 1984), which has been followed here.>

<Noyes et al. (1995) stated that \i{}E. compositus\i0{} is an agamospermous species complex comprising sexual and agamospermous elements in which five subspecies had been informally proposed for sexual \i{}E. compositus\i0{}: "\i{}articus\i0{}," "\i{}compositus\i0{}," "\i{}pectinipetiolatus\i0{}," "\i{}penicillatus\i0{}," and "\i{}posticus."\i0{} The study by Noyes et al. (1995) reported chromosome counts that showed sexual \i{}E. compositus\i0{} is predominantly diploid, 2\i{}n\i0{} = 18. Sexual tetraploids, 2\i{}n\i0{} = 36, and an aneuploid, 2\i{}n\i0{} = 35, were also observed. Genetic variation was examined in all of the proposed subspecies, with the exception of \i{}E. compositus\i0{} "\i{}anticus\i0{}," and in closely related \i{}E. vagus\i0{}. The four proposed subspecies investigated have very similar allozymes, with a mean genetic identity value (\i{}I\i0{}) of 0.847. Likewise, comparisons between populations of \i{}E. vagus\i0{} and \i{}E. compositus\i0{} yield an \i{}I\i0{} value of 0.889. Fixation indices derived from allozyme data also showed that sexual \i{}E. compositus\i0{} and \i{}E. vagus\i0{} are strongly outcrossing. Allozyme markers, genetic similarity values, and patterns of morphological variation suggest that sexual tetraploid \i{}E. compositus\i0{} is derived from a cross between diploid \i{}E. compositus\i0{} "\i{}compositus\i0{}" and one or more of the sexual "subspecies" of \i{}E. compositus\i0{}. These results represent the first phase in the chromosomal and genetic analysis of the \i{}E. compositus\i0{} agamospermous complex. \par{}Noyes and Soltis (1996, p. 1292) noted "\i{}Erigeron compositus\i0{} occurs in montane western North America and comprises both sexual and agamospermous populations. Sexual \i{}E. compositus\i0{} had previously been characterised as outcrossing and predominantly diploid (2\i{}n\i0{} = 18). Agamic \i{}E. compositus\i0{} is usually hexaploid (2\i{}n\i0{} = 54), though counts herein range from 2\i{}n\i0{} = 36 to 2\i{}n\i0{} = 80. Starch-gel electrophoresis, cytology, and analysis of pollen production were used to evaluate variation within and among agamospermous populations. Fifteen enzyme loci were used to identify 24 unique multilocus genotypes in seven populations, an average of 3.4 genotypes per population. Proportion of distinct genotypes per population sample size (\i{}G\i0{}/\i{}N\i0{}) and measures of genetic diversity (\i{}D\i0{}) and evenness (\i{}E\i0{}) were 0.10, 0.48, and 0.61, respectively, which indicate that \i{}E. compositus\i0{} maintains levels of diversity similar to other agamospermous taxa. Most agamospermous populations are mosaics comprising groups of genetically distinct individuals that are frequently distinguished by cytotype and capacity for pollen production. The geographical and ecological separation of sexual and agamospermous populations make it unlikely that gene flow from sexual populations is a direct source of genetic variation in agamospermous populations. Instead, crossing between genetically distinct facultative agamosperms probably accounts for most variation. Genetic and morphological evidence documented one such putative crossing event. Agamospermous \i{}E. compositus\i0{} is very similar genetically to sexual \i{}E. compositus\i0{}. Allozyme analysis further shows that genetic variation in agamospermous populations is partitioned among a few highly heterozygous genotypes, whereas sexual populations maintain numerous genotypes of relatively low heterozygosity.">

<Porsild (1957), in the key he provided, separated this species from \i{}E. uniflorus\i0{} subsp. \i{}eriocephalus\i0{} on a difference in the diameter of the flowering heads: the latter species being about 2 cm and \i{}E. humilis\i0{} about 1 cm in diameter. However, there are many specimens 1-2 cm in diameter. In general, the flowering heads of \i{}E. humilis\i0{} are smaller and narrower. In the field the difference is pronounced, and it is obvious that the capitula of \i{}E. humilis\i0{} have a cuneate base, while those of \i{}E. uniflorus\i0{} subsp. \i{}eriocephalus\i0{} have a broadly rounded to truncate base (Elven, personal communication, 2005).\par{}The hairs on the involucre of \i{}E. humilis\i0{} are conspicuously different, appearing blackish purple from dark purple pigment at the cross-walls of the multicellular hairs. The ray florets of \i{}E. uniflorus\i0{} subsp. \i{}eriocephalus\i0{} are a pink purple, and the disc florets have the same colour on the tips of the petals. Both may have turned a whitish yellow in herbarium specimens. The ray florets of \i{}E. humilis\i0{} are a bluish purple, and the disc florets may have petal tips that have dried either pale yellow or brown. The two taxa are easily distinguished (see pictures in image library) and probably not very closely related phylogenetically. \par{}Interactions between ploidy level, breeding systems, and morphologic variation have been studied in detail in \i{}E. compositus\i0{}. Five informally designated population systems of diploids are geographically restricted (all to the northwestern United States and closely adjacent Canada) and primarily sexual, compared to the polyploids, which are agamospermous and apparently of hybrid origin, at least in some cases (R.D. Noyes et al. 1995, Noyes and D.E. Soltis 1996). Reduction in ray floret laminae usually is correlated with polyploidy. Plants with once-ternately lobed leaves have been identified as \i{}E. compositus\i0{} var. \i{}glabratus\i0{}, an element of variation that does not have a geographic pattern. \par{}Among its close relatives, \i{}Erigeron compositus\i0{} is the only species that produces strongly thickened caudex branches; occasional collections show a tendency toward the slender, loose branches characteristic of the other species (personal communication, G. Nesom, author of the Flora of North America treatment, Jan. 2005).>

<\i{}Erigeron porsildii\i0{} is an arctic member of a complicated and at least partly agamospermic \i{}E. grandiflorus\i0{} complex. (Stephen Spongberg 1970, on annotation label, CAN 103839.). This complex comprises the Cordilleran \i{}E. grandiflorus\i0{} Hook., the local Alaskan and N Yukon \i{}E. muirii\i0{} A. Gray, the NE Asian \i{}E. koraginensis\i0{} (Kom.) Botsch. (incl. \i{}E. komarovii\i0{} Botsch.), several other E Asian Pacific species, and the arctic \i{}E. porsildii,\i0{} the only entity found in the Flora region. The relationships among these, which are now all considered as species, are discussed by Nesom and Murray (2004). \par{}Porsild and Cody (1980) recognised only one entity in continental NWT as \i{}E. grandiflorus\i0{} subsp. \i{}arcticus \i0{}(=\i{}E. porsildii\i0{}). As seen from their map, this entity excluded \i{}'muirii'\i0{} but included all other northern plants of \i{}E. grandiflorus\i0{} in NWT, Yukon Territory, and Alaska, both the northern Cordilleran ones and the Arctic coastal plants west to Mackenzie River (but not Herschel Island). This view was also reflected by Cody (1996) who recognised \i{}E. muirii\i0{} as a separate species, in Canada only known from Herschel Island, whereas \i{}E. grandiflorus\i0{} subsp. \i{}arcticus\i0{} in Yukon reaches north to the Richardson Mountains. Also Cody, as late as 1996, considered both entities as purely North American. This is also confirmed by Nesom and Murray (2004); \i{}P. porsildii\i0{} and \i{}P. muirii\i0{} are both accepted as species. \par{}Nesom and Murray (2004) were aware of this discussion and noted that it has not been clear whether \i{}E. koraginensis \i0{}occurs on the North America continent or whether it might be conspecific with an earlier-named American species, particularly \i{}E. grandiflorus\i0{}. \i{}Erigeron koraginensis \i0{}and \i{}E. porsildii\i0{} are the most similar among these species, but here, based on material housed at ALA, these authors concluded that \i{}E. koraginensis \i0{}and \i{}E. porsildii\i0{} are distinct and noted that they had seen no collections of \i{}E. koraginensis\i0{} from North America. \par{}They provided the following key to distinguish these taxa. \par{}" 1. Leaves sparsely to moderately villous on both surfaces; villous involucral vestiture of whitish hairs, without coloured cross-walls; ray florets 65-110, corollas 13-17 mm long; disc corollas 3.8-4.5 mm long; outer pappus a prominent series of long setae or scales ... \b\i{}Erigeron porsildii\i0{} \par{}\b0{}1. Leaves glabrous or essentially so on adaxial surfaces, villous abaxially; villous involucral vestiture of hairs with purple cross-walls; ray florets 45-73, corollas 9-13 mm long; disc corollas 3-3.9 mm long, outer pappus of a few minute setae and narrow scales ... \b\i{}Erigeron koraginensis\b0\i0{} " (p. 46)>

<Nesom and Murray (2004) noted that this taxon has been treated at infraspecific rank within \i{}Erigeron uniflorus\i0{} L., but stated that evidence that might clearly define their biological relationship and appropriate taxonomic rank is not at hand. \i{}Erigeron uniflorus\i0{} sensu stricto occurs in the mountains of northern Europe and Caucasus, mostly south of \i{}E.\i0{} \i{}eriocephalus.\i0{}>

<This taxon was placed in the genus \i{}Chrysanthemum\i0{} by Porsild (1957). The name \i{}Hulteniella\i0{} for the genus is used following Yurtsev (1987) in the \i{}Flora of the Russian Arctic\i0{}, and is used in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment (Brouillet 2006). \par{}Chrysanthemums and their relatives (mainly in the genus \i{}Pyrethum\i0{}) are grown (mainly in Africa) to produce pyrethrins, which are used as insecticides. Pyrethrins are chemicals produced within the plant to discourage insect feeding. They can be extracted and used in sprays and other formulations to kill insects. They are considered very "safe" insecticides because they are not long-lived and do not accumulate in the food chain Burt (2000).\par{}Dignard and Gervais (2003) reported on \i{}H. integrifolia \i0{}from the Puvirnituq and Déception rivers in Nunavik (Nouveau-Québec). They mapped the distribution of the species in the southeastern Arctic Archipelago and confirmed previous chromosome counts of 2\i{}n\i0{} = 18.>

<When Löve and Löve (1976) erected the genus \i{}Packera\i0{}, they indicated that this is mainly a North and South American genus with a few representatives in Asia. It comprises the groups \i{}Aurei\i0{}, \i{}Lobati\i0{}, and \i{}Tomentosia\i0{} of the collective genus \i{}Senecio\i0{}. Taxa in \i{}Packera\i0{} stand apart from other divisions of the collective aggregate by having long rhizomes, and if pubescence is present it is a tomentum of more or less arachnoid and never of long jointed hairs that persist as flocculent tufts. Its morphological and geographical distinctions are enhanced by its basic chromosome number, \i{}x\i0{} = 23, which differs from that of \i{}Senecio\i0{} s.s., \i{}x\i0{} = 10, and \i{}Tephroseris \i0{}(Richb.) Richb., \i{}x\i0{} = 8. \par{}Barkley (1999), discussing the segregates of \i{}Senecio\i0{} that are recognised in the \i{}Flora of North America\i0{} treatment (Barkley 2006), including \i{}Packera\i0{} (Trock 2006) stated that the notions leading to these narrower generic concepts are noted in Bremer (1994) and in several papers that were presented at the Compositae Conference at Kew in the summer of 1994 (Hind and Beentje 1996). He provided a synoptic key, stating that nobody doubts the biological significance of the first couplet, but the characters used are impractical for routine plant identification. The first couplet separates the \i{}Tussilagininae\i0{}, which includes \i{}Tephroseris\i0{}, and the \i{}Senecioninae\i0{}, which includes \i{}Packera \i0{}and \i{}Senecio\i0{}. \par{}1. Stigmatic areas confluent on adaxial faces of style branches; anther collars cylindrical and cells not inflated; mostly \i{}n\i0{} = 30, or polyploidy/dysploid derivatives ... \i{}Tussilagininae\i0{} \par{}1. Stigmatic areas marginal and distinct on distal, adaxial faces of style branches; anther collars swollen with basal cells inflated; \i{}n\i0{} = (10) 20, or 22-23, or polyploidy derivatives (rarely genus \i{}Pericallis\i0{}) ... \i{}Senecioninae\i0{}. \par{}Barkley (1999) recognised the genus \i{}Packera\i0{} as having erect free standing plants; stems arising singly or clustered from a taproot, caudex, or rhizome and with abundant, thin branching fibrous roots; principal leaves in a basal cluster with blades not both palmately veined and with expanded-clasping petiole bases; cauline leaves progressively reduced distally; corollas mostly yellow \i{}n\i0{} = 22 or 23, or polyploidy derivatives. \par{}Barkley (1999) indicated that the genus consists of about 60 species centred in the western temperate half of North America but extending into southern Mexico and into the Arctic. Two arctic-alpine species extend into northern Siberia and central Asia. The group has been known as the \ldblquote{}aureoid complex\rdblquote{} of \i{}Senecio \i0{}s.l., and although its members are superficially similar to many species of \i{}Senecio\i0{} it forms a distinct lineage. Intergradation among \i{}Packera\i0{} species is well known (Barkley 1988), but there is no morphological intergradation or putative hybridisation between any \i{}Packera\i0{} and any species of \i{}Senecio\i0{} s.s., or segregate of \i{}Senecio\i0{}. The pollen grains of \i{}Packera\i0{} have a helianthoid ultrastructure, rather than the senecionoid type (Bain and Walker 1995). An ITS-based phylogeny has been estimated for \i{}Packera\i0{} by Bain and Jansen (1995).>

<Elven et al. (2003) noted that "Löve and Löve (1975) splitted \i{}Petasites\i0{} s.l. [into] three genera. \i{}Petasites\i0{} s.s. and \i{}Nardosmia\i0{}, both with \i{}x \i0{}= 10, were separated on morphological criteria from each other. \i{}Endocellion\i0{}, with \i{}x\i0{} = 7, was separated on both morphological and cytological criteria from the others. As for \i{}Petasites\i0{} and \i{}Nardosmia\i0{}, hybridisation with production of 'hybridogenous species' is reported between species assigned to the two genera by the Löves (\i{}P. palmatus\i0{} × \i{}P. sagittatus\i0{} = \i{}P. vitifolius\i0{}); see Bogle (Rhodora 70: 533-551. 1968)." \par{}According to Cody (1996), a local endemic occurs in the Richardson and Mackenzie Mountains in northwestern Canada and reaches the Arctic both on the coast and in the northern Richardson Mountains. Cody recognised this entity as \i{}Petasites frigidus\i0{} (L.) Fr. subsp. \i{}arcticus\i0{} (A.E. Porsild) Cody, in Can. Field-Nat. 108: 94. 1994. Type from Mackenzie River delta, East Branch, CAN (see Porsild 1943: 74). \par{}\i{}Petasites frigidus\i0{} (L.) Fr. subsp. \i{}nivalis\i0{} (Greene) Cody (Can. Field-Nat. 108: 94. 1994) is intermediate in some aspects between subsp. \i{}frigidus\i0{} and subsp. \i{}palmatus\i0{} but occupies a range of its own in northwestern America, west and partly north of subsp. \i{}palmatus\i0{}. \par{}Cherniawsky and Bayer (1998a) considered \i{}Petasites\i0{} a taxonomically difficult genus in North America and presented a table comparing systematic treatments of the genus by Rydberg (1927), Cronquist (1978), Hultén (1950), Bogle (1968), Scoggan (1979), Porsild and Cody (1980), and Packer (1983). Cherniawsky and Bayer (1998b) stated that individuals are polygamodioecious, perennial, and clonal herbs that are widely distributed across Canada, Alaska, and the northern contiguous United States as far south as California. All North American taxa of \i{}Petasites\i0{} have sympatric ranges. These authors concluded that the morphological differentiation between \i{}P. sagittatus\i0{} and other taxa of \i{}Petasites\i0{} is not considered sufficient to warrant recognition of specific status. They recommended that only one polymorphic species of \i{}Petasites\i0{} in North America be recognised (\i{}P. frigidus\i0{} with three varieties) in addition to one hybrid taxon originating from a cross between two of the varieties. \par{}Korobkov (in Elven et al. (2003)) proposed four species in the \i{}P. frigidus\i0{} aggregate: \i{}P. frigidus\i0{} s.s., \i{}P. hyperboreus\i0{} Rydberg, \i{}P. palmatus\i0{} (Ait.) A. Gray, and \i{}P. arcticus\i0{} A.E. Porsild. In North America where most of the variation occurs these intergrade and it is often impossible to keep them as species and perhaps difficult even as subspecies. Bayer et al (2006) treat them as varieties. Pending further information on the subspecific nomenclature, in the present treatment we are using the name of the species \i{}P. frigidus\i0{} s.l.>

<\i{}Solidago multiradiata\i0{} was found to be an early coloniser of oil spills in Alaska (Kershaw and Kershaw 1986). \par{}Gilbert and Cooke (2001) included \i{}S. multiradiata\i0{} in a review study of dyes from plants: past usage, present understanding, and potential, noting that before the synthesis of dyes from byproducts of the petrochemical industry, all colour was derived from natural sources, including plants.>
<This taxon is fairly distinctive and phytogeographically falls into a relictual pattern shared by several other taxa in coastal northwestern Canada and northeastern Alaska (Elven et al. 2003).>

<Hultén's (1968b) map shows \i{}Taraxacum ceratophorum\i0{} (Ledeb.) DC. in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago. He said this species has leaves of various forms; all or at least some involucral bracts with a horn or tubercle below the apex; outer bracts mostly appressed and broader than the inner ones. Hultén (1968b) commented that \i{}T. ceratophorum\i0{} is composed of a large group of small taxa, which maintain themselves as distinct units through seeds that are formed without fertilisation. \par{}The name \i{}T. lacerum\i0{} used in Porsild (1957) for some Baffin Island dandelions is considered inapplicable, as none of the specimens from the Canadian Arctic Archipelago resemble that species when compared with an isotype of that species that is from northern British Columbia. CAN! (see image library). After examining specimens that Porsild labelled \i{}T. lapponicum\i0{}, Aiken and Brouillet (July 2003) found no reason for not merging them into their concept of \i{}T. ceratophorum.\i0{}>

<This High Arctic dwarf species has plants with leaves that are usually patent, and deeply runcinate with staggered lobes on either side of the midvein. The degree of incision of the sinuses reaches almost to the midvein, and there are often additional dentations on the runcinate lobes. Petioles are almost without a wing at the base. The inner phyllaries (involucral bracts) are constricted, calloused, and often horned; the outer petals have a distinct stripe that is more obvious in pressed material. The cypselas are straw-coloured with beaks that have a distinct cone. The cypselas are spinulose throughout, but more strongly so towards the apex.>

<The sub-entire or shallowly dentate leaves are similar to those of \i{}T. phymatocarpum\i0{}. \i{}Taraxacum hyparcticum\i0{} differs from \i{}T. phymatocarpum \i0{}in having wide scarious margins on the inner involucral bracts, much larger and relatively large, pale creamy yellow heads with ligulate petals that often have a tinge of pink. The heads spread fully open and flat at anthesis; those of \i{}T. phymatocarpum \i0{}spread less. The cypselas of \i{}T. hyparcticum\i0{} have beaks that are often tinged rusty orange; the cypsela surfaces are straw-coloured with a reddish tinge or olivacous. They are often only spinulose towards the apex and similar to the illustration in Dahlstedt (1905, p. 21). The cypselas of \i{}T. phymatocarpum \i0{}are grey or black with conspicuous longitudinal grooves and well-developed spicules over most of the surface.\par{}Porsild (1957) reported pollen lacking. A specimen from Axel Heiberg Island (CAN 295570) is annotated as "some pollen present" on the label. \par{}>

<Leaves sub-entire to runcinate on the same plant. There are no horns on the bracts, but the tips are sometimes calloused. The flowering heads are relatively small and do not spread flat at anthesis. The cypselas are mottled grey to dark grey or black, with prominent vertical grooves and spinulose from top to bottom, similar to the illustration in Dahlstedt (1905, p. 25; see image library).>

<Elven (personal communication, 2005) commented that this is another intricate aggregate, in which most of the entities seem at one time or another to have been considered as races of \i{}Senecio atropurpureus\i0{}. It is closely related to \i{}T. atropurpurea\i0{} (Ledeb.) Holub and \i{}T. subfrigida\i0{} (Kom.) Holub, and recognition of these three as three subspecies of one species is defensible. The species name \i{}'atropurpurea'\i0{} (1815) has priority before the name \i{}'frigida'\i0{} (1823).\par{}Burt (2000) stated that this species has a scattered growth habit, and seems to prefer heath tundra that is neither too wet nor too dry, such as protected areas where snow likely collects fairly early in the winter.>

<This is the largest annual plant species in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago. "In the early stages of growth, the leaves, stem, and flowering heads are all covered with translucent hairs -- producing a "greenhouse effect" close to the surface of the plant, essentially extending the growing season by a few vital days by allowing the sun to warm the tissues, and preventing the heat from escaping" (Burt 2000, p. 196; see image library). \par{}Porsild and Cody (1980) claim that \i{}Tephroseris palustris\i0{} subsp. \i{}congesta\i0{} (\i{}Senecio congestus\i0{}) is "hapaxanthic" or flowering only once and then dying afterwards. In high latitudes, specimens in which the flowers of the year are killed by early frost may flower and fruit the following year. \par{}Ovenden (1986) found \i{}Tephroseris palustris\i0{} subsp. \i{}congesta\i0{} to be an early colonising species on the lake bed of Illisarvik, the site of a thermokarst lake that was artificially drained in August 1978. \par{}Gloschenko and Martini (1987) studied the vegetation of four river-influenced coastal marshes located between the Moose River and Harricanaw River in southern James Bay. Six major groupings of species were found. These included (1) a salt marsh dominated by \i{}Puccinellia phryganodes\i0{}, \i{}P. lucida\i0{}, \i{}Hippuris\i0{} \i{}tetraphylla\i0{}, and \i{}Scirpus maritimus\i0{}, (2) saline ponds with \i{}Tephroseris palustris\i0{} subsp. \i{}congesta\i0{}, (3) a saline/brackish meadow marsh with \i{}Carex paleacea\i0{}, (4) an intertidal estuarine marsh with \i{}Eleocharis palustris\i0{}, (5) freshwater ponds with \i{}Potamogeton filiformis\i0{}, and (6) a freshwater marsh/fen. Major environmental factors controlling the distribution of these groups include substrate salinity, river flow patterns, storm surges, and tidal range. The marshes described were considered unique in species composition in James Bay and similar to marshes described in the Gulf of Boothia. \par{}Staniforth et al. (1998) noted that coastal ecosystems at high latitudes are exposed to physical disturbances (abrasion by ice, tides, waves, and wind) and to degradation due to the grazing activities of waterfowl. The frequency of disturbance and the regenerative capacity of plants determine the recovery potential for the plant community. They examined the seed bank in soil samples collected from a beach ridge, a drift zone, a sand bar, and a salt marsh at Bird Cove, near Churchill, Manitoba, on the western shoreline of Hudson Bay. Seedling emergence from soil samples after four successive periods of stratification at 5°C totalled 2968 seedlings of 19 species. Mean emerged seedling densities for each ecosystem were (i) 786 seedlings/m2 (beach ridge), (ii) 699 seedlings/m2 (drift zone), (iii) 2875 seedlings/m2 (sand bar), and (iv) 39,204 seedlings/m2 (salt marsh). These densities are much higher than those for temperate coastal ecosystems and for most terrestrial, subarctic ecosystems. Ninety-seven percent of the 2772 identifiable emergents were of three ruderal species: \i{}Juncus bufonius\i0{}, \i{}Tephroseris palustris\i0{} subsp. \i{}congesta\i0{} (\i{}S. congestus\i0{}), and \i{}Spergularia marina\i0{}. These three common species were found from samples collected from all ecosystems except the beach ridge, which had no species in common with the other ecosystems and was dominated by \i{}Sagina nodosa\i0{} and \i{}Saxifraga tricuspidata\i0{} in its seed bank.>

<When Hämet-Ahti (1967) proposed this name combination, she noted that it was first described at variety level (not as a form as often cited) by Ruprecht (1845) from arctic Russia. Trautvetter (1871, p. 74; not Ruprecht as reported by Porsild 1932, p. 72) considered it a synonym of \i{}Pyrethrum ambigum\i0{} described by Ledebour (1833, p. 118) from the Altai Mountains. Thereafter many later authors have applied the epithet \i{}ambigum\i0{} to this taxon. Hämet-Ahti (1967) had seen the types of both Ruprecht and Trautvetter and noted that although Ruprecht's type specimen is very poor, a comparison of other material from northernmost Russia and the Altai material showed so many differences that she could not regard them as identical. The main differences noted are the narrower bracts that are only slightly triangular, and the shorter leaf segments that are narrower in the Altai specimens than in those from northern Russia. Ecologically, \i{}T. maritimum\i0{} supsp. \i{}phaeocephalum\i0{} is both a seashore and an ruderal plant. \par{}This species was in the genus \i{}Matricaria. \i0{}"According to Schofield (1989) the name "\i{}Matricaria\i0{}" is derived from the Latin roots \i{}matrix\i0{} "mother" and \i{}caria\i0{} "dear". This refers to the long historical use of this genus as medicine for female problems and as a medicine for children. Flower heads of the pineapple weed (\i{}Matricaria matricariodes\i0{}) are widely used as a relaxing tea and medicine by the Dene, Aleuts, and herbalists everywhere. It is said to be an effective insect repellent and to remove fish odours from your hands" (Burt 2000, p. 188). \par{}Ovenden (1986) found \i{}Tripleurospermum maritimum \i0{}(as \i{}Matricaria ambigua\i0{}) to be an early colonising species on the lake bed of Illisarvik, the site of a thermokarst lake that was artificially drained in August 1978. \par{}The entities treated as subspecies in Elven et al. (2003) are sometimes treated as species by Russian botanists. Fertile intermediates are frequent in the Nordic area where the three entities meet Hämet-Ahti (1967). Thus, treatment as subspecies is preferable. However, the circumpolar arctic entity '\i{}phaeocephalum\i0{}' is slightly more different from the other two subspecies than they are among themselves and also geographically better separated. This may justify treatment of \i{}T. phaeocephalum\i0{} as a species (as fairly regularly done both in Russia and North America).>

states: not accepted in this study <or, a synonym>
not yet recorded on arctic islands, but probably in the PAF arctic area
grass species added as occurring in arctic continental North America
